fields.headline: A year of two halves
fields.standfirst: You may feel good about the new year, but watch out: six months of optimism will be followed by six months of gloom and doom, especially for the media industries.
fields.trailText: 2001 is a schizophrenic year, especially for the media and publishing signs of Gemini and Sagittarius, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
2001 is a schizophrenic year, especially for the media and publishing signs of Gemini and Sagittarius.

The first six months under Jupiter's influence bring a mood of expansion when all things seem possible, while the last six are dominated by doubts and brick-wall Saturn.

A turning point for over-optimistic projects is May 5 when Jupiter opposes Pluto, followed by a shake-out when Saturn opposes Pluto on both August 5 and November 2. Clock these dates into your diary now.

This period looks like it will require a serious tightening of the belt for media, publishing and telecoms, more so than for other sectors.

Expect poor sales, low advertising revenue, high paper prices, bad news for mobile phones and the failure of at least one established media institution.

So - happy new year. Sorry about the gloom and doom. Have your fun before the summer and batten down the hatches after mid-July.

Zodiac pythiae for 2001

Aries
March 21 - April 20
With Mars in adventurous Sagittarius from Valentine's Day until September, you're a restless soul, breaking all the rules in your search for a new way of doing things. As far as you're concerned: "The tigers of wrath are wiser than the horses of instruction" - William Blake, The Marriage Of Heaven and Hell (1790).

Taurus
April 21 - May 20
Venus in your house of seclusion leads to much soul-searching from February until June, but the fresh start you're looking for comes from a source you least expect. So remember: "All great deeds and all great thoughts have a ridiculous beginning" - Albert Camus, The Myth of Sisyphus (1942).

Gemini
May 21 - June 20
Jupiter, planet of optimism, is in your sign until July, but doubtful Saturn moves there too on April 24. If you feel suspended between success and failure, remember: "People are always neglecting something they can do in trying to do something they can't" - Edgar Watson Howe, Country Town Sayings (1911).

Cancer
June 21 - July 22
The moon's eclipse on January 9 and the sun's eclipse on June 21 fall in your sign, putting you in the dark. But, don't forget: "Our doubts are traitors
And make us lose the good we oft might win
By fearing to attempt." - Shakespeare, Measure for Measure (1604-05).

Leo
July 23 - August 22
Mars, the warrior planet, makes you bold. Friends seem disloyal when they try to hold you back, but if you believe in something, go all out for it: "I don't meet competition. I crush it" - Charles Revson quoted in Fisk & Barron's Great Business Quotations (1985).

Virgo
August 23 - September 22
Visionary Jupiter triggers inspirational Neptune in your career and work sectors, and it's time to aim high and focus on the bigger picture. Listen up: "Hear ye not the hum of mighty workings?" - Keats, Sonnet XIV.

Libra
September 23 - October 22
Venus has the hots in your house of love from February to June, making you giddy, impatient and naive. So with this in mind: "Do not let any sweet-talking woman beguile your good sense with the fascinations of her shape. It's your barn she's after" - Hesiod, Works And Days (eighth century BC).

Scorpio
October 23 - November 22
Financial wrangles are dominant as you free yourself from situations which bind you in and hold you back. "Money talks, they say. All it ever said to me was good-bye" - Cary Grant quoted in H Haun's The Movie Quote Book.

Sagittarius
November 23 - December 22
Jupiter's opposition to Pluto on May 6 puts you in the hot seat in your love life and with your co-workers. Do things your way: "Never explain - your friends do not need it and your enemies will not believe you anyway" - Elbert Hubbard, The Note Book (1927).

Capricorn
December 23 - January 20
Saturn and Neptune bring out the workaholic in you, especially in June, but put your effort where it does the most and get clear about what you truly value. "I owe much; I have nothing: the rest I leave to the poor" - Rabelais' last words (1553).

Aquarius
January 21 - February 19
Inventive Uranus and idealistic Neptune shine through all your creative projects, but be more realistic if you aspire to be bigger and better.
"Still bent to make some port he knows not where,
Still standing for some false impossible shore" - Matthew Arnold, A Summer Night.

Pisces
February 20 - March 20
Your planets, Jupiter and Neptune, are in perfect harmony on April 5, making for a minor miracle as a secret dream comes true. Property matters are high on your agenda and so is a situation at home: "Fish and guests smell at three days old" - Danish proverb.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Still king of the cups
fields.standfirst: Ron Atkinson remembers the FA Cup glory days, and hopes there's more to come
fields.trailText: After the farce of missing last season's FA Cup Manchester United were always going to be keen to make their presence felt this time. And, with the league more or less won, I sense bad news for the rest of the country.
fields.body:
After the farce of missing last season's FA Cup Manchester United were always going to be keen to make their presence felt this time. And, with the league more or less won, I sense bad news for the rest of the country.

Sir Alex Ferguson loves winning the Cup and his players are the same. Everyone at Old Trafford knows there's a real chance of putting another Double, maybe even another Treble, on the table and that will give them extra impetus.

I know United start with a very hard game at Fulham on Sunday but I think we will see them going flat out. In fact I don't expect to see many rotations in Fergie's FA Cup selections.

In their situation, cruising in the Premiership and comfortable in the Champions League, there's more chance of him rotating his team elsewhere. And don't forget they've got major players such as Jaap Stam and Andrew Cole coming back.

I'm sure a lot of his side will be mad keen to win the Cup. In the 1999 final Stam and Dwight Yorke were put in the pot to be saved for the European Cup final and started on the bench, so they'll want to make an impact.

Yorkie will have seen FA Cup finals on the television as a kid in Tobago and Stam will be very much aware of its importance. Then there are people like Fabien Barthez and Wes Brown who haven't experienced the Cup Final buzz and will desperately want to be there.

What we have to make sure is that great players of the future really want to be part of it. The competition was badly undermined last season and holding this year's final before the last round of Premiership fixtures doesn't do it any favours.

To get a great product back where it deserves I think the Football Association should be trying to create a situation where, if England get a fourth Champions League place, it would go to the FA Cup winners.

I've always loved the Cup and was very proud to win it twice with Manchester United. From the time when I went to the only television in my road to watch the Matthews final as a 14-year-old it's felt special.

My highlight has to be the 1985 final, when United beat Everton 1-0 with that magnificent Norman Whiteside goal. Everton had won the league and just beaten Rapid Vienna in the Cup Winners' Cup final, so we stopped them doing the Treble.

The game-plan had been to squeeze up to keep Graeme Sharp and Andy Gray as far from our goal as we could. That was a big change for us and, when we practised it at Watford four days earlier, we lost 5-1. Kevin Moran and Paul McGrath didn't know if they were coming or going but in the final the boys did it to perfection. Even when Moran was sent off I sensed we would win.

I suppose there had been a sign the force was with us in the semi-final replay against Liverpool. We were leading 2-1 when Liverpool's manager Joe Fagan leant over from the directors' box and told Ronnie Moran and Roy Evans: "Get Kevin off." I couldn't believe it when they held up the No7 and took off Kenny Dalglish. Joe meant Kevin MacDonald but they'd misheard him. Kenny might have pulled something out of nothing for them.

Of course in the 1983 final we were grateful that Gordon Smith made nothing out of something in the last minute for Brighton at 2-2. We had already lost the League Cup to Liverpool with one of the last kicks of extra-time and the First Division runners-up spot with one of the last kicks of the season. I was as amazed as anyone when Gary Bailey coolly sat on the ball.

We won the replay 4-0 and poor Smithy has taken unmerciful stick about all that "And Smith must score" stuff. He came and lived behind me at one stage in Manchester when he joined City. In United's eyes he's the most popular player City have had.

As for other highlights, being part of the Oxford United team who became the first Fourth Division side to reach the sixth round was special. But I've been on the receiving end as well. As manager of Cambridge I was beaten by Leatherhead and at United we lost 2-0 at Bournemouth as holders in 1984.

Harry Redknapp was in charge of Bournemouth then and I think his West Ham team have a good chance this season as long as they come through a tricky tie at Walsall. They'll be one of a few sides tweaking a bit. Tottenham at Leyton Orient could be interesting and it's not beyond the realms that Arsenal will lose at Carlisle. If they do, Arsène Wenger should make his players walk home.

webTitle: Litmanen signing leaves Fowler in limbo

fields.headline: Litmanen signing leaves Fowler in limbo
fields.trailText: Jari Litmanen trained with his Liverpool team-mates yesterday after completing a free transfer move from Barcelona, and within minutes his new manager Gérard Houllier was going to great lengths to stress that the Finn's arrival will not be the catalyst which brings about their wayward vice-captain Robbie Fowler's departure.
fields.body:
Jari Litmanen trained with his Liverpool team-mates yesterday after completing a free transfer move from Barcelona, and within minutes his new manager Gérard Houllier was going to great lengths to stress that the Finn's arrival will not be the catalyst which brings about their wayward vice-captain Robbie Fowler's departure.

Houllier emphasised the modern game's need for four strikers, but it is understood that Fowler, 25, will only have a role to play for as long as Liverpool remain competitive this season. They are still contesting four competitions, all of which Litmanen is eligible to play in, but Chelsea remain interested in the England forward and have already had a £12m bid rejected by the Merseysiders.

Fowler was involved in an early-morning fracas in Liverpool's city centre earlier this week, one which left him with a black eye and a suspected broken nose. It was the second such incident involving the striker in the past two years.

"We needed a fourth striker when both Erik Meijer and Titi Camara left [recently]," Houllier said. "I have a good memory of games when we didn't have enough strikers because of injuries so it is vital for us to have at least four here."

Litmanen, who played 14 games for Barcelona in one-and-a-half seasons, scoring three times, was hindered by injuries there and had his contract terminated 18 months early. He has agreed a £55,000-a-week deal which will keep him at Anfield until 2003.

"He's one of the most exciting signings we have made," said Houllier. "We have signed a world-class player. He comes with a reputation that needs no improvement.

"He can play in a variety of positions in attack and will bring a different style of play to our other strikers. He is a player I am aware this club has wanted for a long time and to get him on a free transfer is a snip."

Newcastle's increasingly desperate search for attacking reinforcements has driven them to haggle with Wimbledon over the services of the 30-year-old Marcus Gayle, with the clubs at considerable odds over the Jamaican forward's valuation.

Gayle, who arrived from Brentford in 1994, scored 34 goals in 204 Premiership appearances but despite his record proving equally unspectacular in the Nationwide League - two goals in 21 league starts this season - Wimbledon rate him at £3.5m.

But with funds at a premium at St James' Park pending the European Commission's decision on the future of the transfer system, the manager Bobby Robson has been granted only £1.5m to conjure up a replacement for the injured Alan Shearer and Carl Cort.

The Newcastle chairman Freddy Shepherd yesterday returned from Paris where he had attempted to entice the £3.25m Didier Domi back to the north-east. The full-back, who is anxious to re-sign for his former club Paris St-Germain, has been absent without leave since before Christmas.

Rangers today expect Lorenzo Amoruso to announce whether he intends to move to West Ham. "He is back in Italy right now and I think he wants a bit of time on his own to think things over," said David Murray, the Ibrox chairman. "We have agreed a transfer fee with West Ham but if Lorenzo says he wants to stay with the club, then we shall accept that."

West Ham are also considering a £6m bid for Aston Villa's Gareth Southgate. "I rate Gareth highly, both as a player and a professional, and it's time we put in an offer," said West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp.

"I wouldn't mind having both Southgate and Amoruso at Upton Park. Lorenzo has a presence about him. He's strong and powerful."

Steve Lomas, moreover, has said he has no desire to leave Upton Park despite interest from his former club Manchester City. "Unless the club tell me any different I am more than happy to be at West Ham and proud to play for them."

Ipswich have turned down Nottingham Forest's £2.5m bid for David Johnson.

webTitle: Bull to pull on boots again for Hereford

fields.headline: Bull to pull on boots again for Hereford
fields.trailText: The former England and Wolverhampton Wanderers striker Steve Bull is to come out of retirement to try to end a shortage of goals at non-league Hereford United.
fields.body:
The former England and Wolverhampton Wanderers striker Steve Bull is to come out of retirement to try to end a shortage of goals at non-league Hereford United.

Bull, 35, scored a club record 250 league goals for Wolves before a knee injury ended his career last season. Since then he has combined a job in the Molineux commercial department with coaching the Conference club Hereford and is now set to play for them within the next week.

"We plan to put him on for the last quarter of an hour or so if we need a goal or two," said the Hereford manager Graham Turner.

Barnsley will choose their next manager from a shortlist of Steve Bruce, Nigel Spackman and Jan Molby. The First Division club will announce a decision after tomorrow's FA Cup third-round tie with Leeds.

The new Wolves manager Dave Jones will not be joined at Molineux by his former No2 at Southampton Dennis Rofe, who has opted to stay on the coaching staff at the Dell.

The former Portsmouth manager Tony Pulis has announced he is to contest chairman Milan Mandaric's decision to cancel his contract this week for alleged misconduct. Pulis was replaced by Steve Claridge in mid-October and put on four months' paid leave to allow him to concentrate on a high court case with his former club Gillingham next month.

Birmingham City have been urged by West Midlands police to switch the date of their Worthington Cup semi-final with Ipswich from January 24 because of fears of violence in the city. Aston Villa are due to play Leeds United in the Premiership on the same evening.

fields.headline: Countdown to the Trustee Act
fields.standfirst: Charity trustees have less than a month to digest the full implications of new rules on investing charity money
fields.trailText: Charity trustees have less than a month to digest the full implications of new rules on investing charity money. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Charity trustees have less than a month to digest the Trustee Act, which comes into force on February 1. The Act relaxes some rules about investments, but imposes conditions of duty on trustees to manage charity money as if it was their own.

Chief executive of the Association of Charitable Foundations, Nigel Siederer, warns: "Investment managers have not caught up with the legislation yet. Charities need to review their invesment arrangements and establish agreements with fund managers in writing."

The new Act repeals the Trustee Investments Act (TIA) of 1961, which prevented charities from investing in companies with less than a five-year dividend record. It also sweeps away the requirement to divide funds into equities and gilts. Siederer says: "This is a good piece of legislation and something we have campaigned for over a number of years. It should mean that some charities that have been in a straightjacket will now make more money."

Ten years ago, Phillips and Drew Fund Managers estimated that the TIA was costing charities £250m per year in lost investment opportunities. This loss was partly removed in 1995 when partial reform of the Act was introduced. Siederer adds: "The rest is now going, together with the TIA's absurd bureaucracy - which has prevented many trusts from buying shares in such obvious companies as newly privatised utilities."

Main elements of the Act

A duty of care: This creates a general duty for trustees to exercise reasonable care in investment, employing an agent, insuring trust property, holding funds, paying debts or acquiring land.

Investment powers: Trustees may make any investment of the kind that they could if the funds were their own, except for land outside the UK, settled land or university land.

Investment duties: Trustees must review investments regularly and obtain proper advice and consider whether there is a need for diversification of funds.

Delegation of trust functions: A trustee can now delegate day to day duties to an agent, for example managing, acquiring or disposing of investment land.

Delegating investment management: Trustees must prepare a written statement giving guidance on how the investment management functions should be managed in the best interest of the charity.

Reimbursement of trustees' expenses: The Act allows for payment of out-of-pocket expenses without the need for an authorising clause in the deed.

Paying fees to trustees: The Act regulates the arrangement for paying a trustee who is appointed in their professional capacity, for example a solicitor or accountant.

Insuring a trust: The Act creates a power for trustees to insure a trust's property.

 The Trustee Act 2000 is available, priced £5.95 plus P&P, from the Stationery Office, PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN, tel: 08457 023474

Chief executive of the Association of Charitable Foundations, Nigel Siederer, warns: "Investment managers have not caught up with the legislation yet. Charities need to review their invesment arrangements and establish agreements with fund managers in writing." The new Act repeals the Trustee Investments Act (TIA) of 1961, which prevented charities from investing in companies with less than a five-year dividend record. It also sweeps away the requirement to divide funds into equities and gilts. Siederer says: "This is a good piece of legislation and something we have campaigned for over a number of years. It should mean that some charities that have been in a straightjacket will now make more money." Ten years ago, Phillips and Drew Fund Managers estimated that the TIA was costing charities £250m per year in lost investment opportunities. This loss was partly removed in 1995 when partial reform of the Act was introduced. Siederer adds: "The rest is now going, together with the TIA's absurd bureaucracy - which has prevented many trusts from buying shares in such obvious companies as newly privatised utilities." Main elements of the Act A duty of care: This creates a general duty for trustees to exercise reasonable care in investment, employing an agent, insuring trust property, holding funds, paying debts or acquiring land. Investment powers: Trustees may make any investment of the kind that they could if the funds were their own, except for land outside the UK, settled land or university land. Investment duties: Trustees must review investments regularly and obtain proper advice and consider whether there is a need for diversification of funds. Delegation of trust functions: A trustee can now delegate day to day duties to an agent, for example managing, acquiring or disposing of investment land. Delegating investment management: Trustees must prepare a written statement giving guidance on how the investment management functions should be managed in the best interest of the charity. Reimbursement of trustees' expenses: The Act allows for payment of out-of-pocket expenses without the need for an authorising clause in the deed. Paying fees to trustees: The Act regulates the arrangement for paying a trustee who is appointed in their professional capacity, for example a solicitor or accountant. Insuring a trust: The Act creates a power for trustees to insure a trust's property.  The Trustee Act 2000 is available, priced £5.95 plus P&P, from the Stationery Office, PO Box 29, Norwich NR3 1GN, tel: 08457 023474

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Andrew
fields.trailText: If you have time, get the train to Katoomba and see the Blue mountains. It's only 60 kilometres from Sydney, but well worth it. There are some good walking trails in Glenbrook nearby.
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

I was in Sydney back in 1989 and was disappointed by how 'British' it was. However, I loved getting the ferry from circular quay to Manly just as it was getting dark.

Also, if you have time, get the train to Katoomba and see the Blue mountains. It's only 60 kilometres from Sydney, but well worth it. There are some good walking trails in Glenbrook nearby.

On a more cautionary note, look after your valuables! Don't be lulled into a false sense of security with other travellers. I was staying in a backpackers' hostel in Coogee where a very determined burglar overnight managed to steal stuff from 11 guys in one dorm without waking any of us! I lost my passport, credit cards and driving licence but it didn't spoil my trip. Be careful!

Have a great trip.

fields.headline: Paradise in the Pacific
fields.standfirst: After an inauspicious arrival in Fiji, Sam braves the local brew, disappearing days and shark-tooth necklaces to find paradise amid the palm trees and cooling breezes
fields.trailText: After an inauspicious arrival in Fiji, Sam braves the local brew, disappearing days and shark-tooth necklaces to find paradise amid the palm trees and cooling breezes
fields.body:
Let me try and describe where I am. I'm sitting on a wooden veranda looking out to sea. There's a cool breeze and the deck is built around a tree whose leaves, just above my head, provide plenty of shade from the sun.

Above the palm trees that mark the edge of the beach I can see across the water to another island about a mile away. Like the one I'm on, its steep, green sides are broken by bare, rocky outcrops and the golden sand at the water's edge. Further away I can see other islands jutting up out of the Pacific. The sea is a variety of blues: light where it's sandy, darker where the coral reefs begin, and pure azure marking the deep water. A whole shoal of small fish have just leaped out of the waves, presumably trying to avoid some predator. They do it again, making a shimmering, silver streak on the water before disappearing.

The sky here is clear but I can see cumulo-nimbus clouds stacking up, far away over mainland Fiji - a distant shadow on the horizon. The local villagers say we will have a storm tonight, but it seems hard to believe that now.

Below me is a long flat grassy area. On one side of this are the thatched buildings (called 'bures') where we are staying. On the other side, some of the local Fijian men are playing touch rugby. The game is played fast and with skill. It's clearly very competitive, but there's lots of laughter. Fiji's people always seem to be laughing. There's a New Year tradition of throwing water over unsuspecting victims, and there are squeals of delight whenever one of the women manages to drench one of the men.

I'm on Waya at the southern tip of the Yasawa group of islands about 40km north west of Fiji's main island, Viti Levu. I've been here four days now and it's beautiful. My arrival in Fiji wasn't quite so idyllic.

My connecting flight from Los Angeles was delayed and I spent a torrid seven hours in the airport twiddling my thumbs. The flight itself took 11 hours as we chased the setting sun across the Pacific Ocean. It was dark by the time we crossed the international date line and I could see the unfamiliar stars of the southern hemisphere. Going from east to west, I lost a day. At midnight on New Year's Eve, I was standing in the passport check queue at Fiji's international airport in Nadi.

When I eventually got to my hotel, I went outside to join a few of the locals by the bar. They gave me some of the traditional drink, kava. This is an infusion from a root plant. and is supposed to be mildly narcotic, although I didn't notice anything. It tastes like muddy water. The locals said I should have been here last New Year's Eve. This year's celebrations (particularly the ones with fireworks) had been cancelled after the coup some months earlier. The leader, George Speight, was due on trial the next day and there had been threats of reprisals. On my travels, I was to see a heavy military presence with armed checkpoints along the main roads.

It was hot and very humid. The change from cool, fresh San Francisco had me gasping and pouring with sweat.

I spent the next morning desperately trying to get out of Nadi. It's a small town and most places were closed for the public holiday. I walked sweating down the main street trying to find somewhere to buy mosquito repellent. I stopped to ask directions in one open shop. They were extremely friendly, and said that they sold repellent (this seemed a bit unlikely as it was a tourist handicraft shop). If I sat down and waited, one of them would go and get it from out back. After 15 minutes in which I was offered various wooden masks, shark-tooth necklaces, a visit to an authentic native village, drugs, and one, two or even three girls, I realised that the repellent wasn't about to materialise and left.

Back at the hostel, Heta, the owner's wife saved me. She found me a driver to take me to the harbour in Lautoka and a boat to take me to one of the offshore islands. The driver was great. Not only did he find me a supermarket which sold repellent, he also offered me his baseball cap when he realised I didn't have a hat for the two-hour boat trip.

At Lautoka, I squeezed into a small single engine boat with five other tourists, and here I am. I like it so much I've put my flight to New Zealand back a week. I can't send you any photos as there's no internet - the island only has electricity between 7 and 10 at night.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From "e-kiloh"
fields.trailText: Another place in Malaysia worthy of your time is Malacca - an old European-style city. As long as you're not sick on the pavement (as I was) the people are really friendly.
fields.body:
Dear Sue,

You sound as if you're having a wonderful time. Just a few words on Malaysia, where I spent a wonderful summer a couple of years ago.

Kuala Lumpur is not really somewhere you want to spend much time (although the big central mosque is definitely worth a visit), but close by are some fantastic places. Pangkor Island is just off the west coast, north of KL, and a good place to unwind. No hassle, beaches, lovely food and bike hire so you can cycle round the island. The Cameron Highlands (tea plantations) are also good, although difficult to reach. To get around on mainland Malaysia you'll have to use buses - there's only one train line. But don't dispair - the buses (well, the ones I used) are efficient and reasonably comfortable. Compared to India, travel and day to day chores in Malaysia are a doddle.

Another place close to KL and much more worthy of your time is Malacca - an old European-style city. And as long as you're not sick on the pavement (as I was) the people are really friendly.

webTitle: Charity warns of increase in disabled births from rubella

fields.headline: Charity warns of increase in disabled births from rubella
fields.standfirst: Public concern over the measles, mumps and rubella jab could lead to a serious health risk, today and in the future
fields.trailText: The number of children born disabled as a result of being infected with rubella during pregnancy could rise if parents continue to shun vaccinations, a leading charity has warned. Clare Horton reports.
fields.body:
The number of children born disabled as a result of being infected with rubella during pregnancy could rise if parents continue to shun vaccinations, a leading charity has warned.

Sense, which works with people damaged by rubella, said confidence in the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) jab had been shaken by reports linking it to autism and the bowel disorder Crohn's disease.

But the charity said the prospect of unborn children being infected with rubella (also known as German measles) was far more serious than the unproven health risks.

Malcolm Matthews, Sense's acting chief executive, said: "The rubella virus seriously affects the development of a foetus if contracted during pregnancy and, after working with people born deafblind and their families for the past 43 years, Sense is only too aware of the devastating consequences it has.

"If children are not immunised now, there could be a rise in the number of babies born deafblind or rubella-damaged - now and in the future."

A falling rate of immunisation increases the risk of rubella both in the future, for today's children when they reach parenthood, and for today's mothers-to-be who could be infected by a non-immunised child.

Mr Matthews's warning followed a report from the Public Health Laboratory Service that children are at risk from a potentially fatal measles epidemic because immunisation levels have dropped to a dangerously low level.

Sense said more than 400 children were born with congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) between 1971 and 1979. Between 1991 and 1996, the figure was around 30.

"This dramatic decline in the number of children born with CRS is due to the introduction of the MMR vaccination programme in the UK," Mr Matthews added.

"Sense urges parents to make an informed choice about MMR. From the evidence available, we firmly believe that the MMR vaccine is clinically the most effective way to protect children from the devastation that rubella can cause."

Jane Mulholland, who caught rubella in the early weeks of pregnancy, said: "From personal experience I know how devastating the damage caused by the rubella infection can be. My son Roger was born with CRS and life is a constant battle, not only for him but for the entire family.

"We all need to be educated on the individual effects of mumps, measles and rubella. Roger was born completely blind and deaf, with brain damage and multiple heart defects - this is what rubella does."

webTitle: Lib-Lab links in 'coma' over voting reform

fields.headline: Lib-Lab links in 'coma' over voting reform
fields.standfirst: Kennedy abandons joint cabinet committee until after election as Lib Dem exasperation grows over Labour delay on electoral changes
fields.trailText: Kennedy abandons joint cabinet committee until after election as Lib Dem exasperation grows over Labour delay on electoral changes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's cherished project to realign the centre left has fallen into a coma, according to the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, who has abandoned a joint cabinet committee until after the general election.

Exasperated by the prime minister's failure to live up to his promises on electoral reform, Mr Kennedy has decided that there is little point in maintaining the Lib-Lab cabinet committee unless Labour shifts its stance on proportional representation. "The project is gently residing in a coma where it is ready for people to revive it if they wish," a Kennedy aide said yesterday. "We haven't held a meeting of the cabinet committee since the summer because we can't see the point of poncing up Downing Street if we aren't going to get something out of it."

Mr Kennedy's reluctance to sit on the historic cabinet committee will come as a severe disappointment to the champions of Lib-Lab cooperation, which was forged in the run-up to the last election by Tony Blair and Sir Paddy Ashdown. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and his Lib Dem counterpart Menzies Campbell, two of the original architects of the project, yesterday underlined their determination to press ahead with strengthening the links.

In an article in the Times to promote a forthcoming book on the centre left, Mr Cook and Mr Campbell said they hoped their "unique exercise in political cooperation" would help to create a new style of politics in Britain.

"Our existing political culture is not conducive to consensus building," they wrote. "The adversarial approach to debate promotes polarisation of opinion. Our cooperation should not be seen as an exercise in short term political management but as a continuing contribution towards a new style of politics."

Although the article was approved by both the prime minister and the Lib Dem leader, its friendly language contrasted with the thinking of the Kennedy circle. The Kennedy aide insisted that there was no division between Mr Campbell and Mr Kennedy, but added: "You can be a bit more statesmanlike in foreign affairs."

Mr Kennedy will decide whether to shut down Lib-Lab cooperation altogether when Labour publishes its manifesto. If Labour commits itself to holding a referendum on electoral reform, he is likely to reopen talks. If there is no mention of a referendum, the project will be consigned to the history books.

Lib Dems have been disappointed with Labour for failing to live up to its 1997 manifesto commitment to hold a referendum on electoral reform. An independent commission was set up under the chairmanship of Lord Jenkins of Hillhead after the election, but its proposal for a new system known as AV plus has been quietly shelved.

It is understood that Mr Kennedy has still not given up hope of a referendum pledge in Labour's next maniesto. But there are reports that Labour may opt for an AV system of voting which falls well short of the Jenkins proposal. "Let us wait to see the colour of their money," the Kennedy aide said.

While the Lib Dems await Labour's manifesto, the party is scaling down its links with the government. There has been no meeting since July of the joint cabinet committee which has been mothballed until after the election. Talks between individual frontbench spokesman are continuing, but these are being wound down.

Likening the state of the project to a coma is the most dramatic illustration of the Lib Dem leader's wariness over co-operation with Labour. Although Mr Kennedy has long been sceptical of the links, he has been careful to use diplomatic language since his election as party leader in 1999 to keep faith with allies of Sir Paddy.

While the parties drift apart at a national level, there is continuing speculation that they may agree informal election pacts at a grassroots level to encourage anti-Tory tactical voting at the general election. This is strenuously denied by both parties.

However, the Lib Dems have failed to select candidates in some key Labour/Tory marginal seats.

webTitle: Ailing princess may have had a second stroke

fields.headline: Ailing princess may have had a second stroke
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Princess Margaret may have suffered a second stroke, Buckingham Palace said last night after days of media speculation about her health. The palace statement followed reports that she had been confined to bed at Sandringham, the royal family's Norfolk estate, throughout Christmas.
fields.body:
Princess Margaret may have suffered a second stroke, Buckingham Palace said last night after days of media speculation about her health. The palace statement followed reports that she had been confined to bed at Sandringham, the royal family's Norfolk estate, throughout Christmas.

The Queen's younger sister, who is 70, underwent medical tests at the weekend and is under constant nursing care, though her two children, Viscount Linley and Lady Sarah Chatto, have not been asked to return to her bedside.

She was said last night to be able to walk, though palace sources were unable to say whether she had suffered any paralysis or whether her speech had been affected. As in previous days her condition was said to be causing concern but not alarm.

A statement issued by the palace said: "Evaluation of a range of test results by Princess Margaret's doctors, conducted against the background of her previous stroke in February 1998 has suggested that [she] may recently have had a second minor stroke or be suffering from the follow on effects of the earlier event.

"It will be some while before the success of the present treatment can be judged and the extent of her recovery can be determined with a view to her deciding on what kind of public engagements she will wish to fulfil in the future.

"Princess Margaret's health obviously remains a matter of concern to the Queen and other members of the royal family, but the situation is stable and her royal highness will be remaining at Sandringham House where nursing care is available."

The princess's next scheduled public appearance - at a ballet gala evening on January 16 - is unlikely to go ahead and a planned trip to the Caribbean for her regular winter holiday may now also be in doubt. It was on the Caribbean island of Mustique, where she formerly had a private home, that the princess suffered her previous, minor stroke and where she badly scalded her feet getting into a bath the following year.

She has also had part of a lung removed following years of heavy smoking.

fields.headline: Alan Garner honoured for services to children's literature
fields.trailText: Alan Garner has been awarded an OBE in the Queen's New Years Honours List for services to children's literature
fields.body:
Author Alan Garner, who has written over 30 books, has been awarded an OBE in the Queen's New Years Honours List.

Though 66-year-old Garner brings similar elements of history and myth to his writing for both adults and children, he said he was "particularly gratified" that the OBE is for services to children's literature. A standard against which most contemporary children's writing is measured, Garner once claimed that he didn't consciously think of children when writing his books but believed that they read him "more intelligently" than adults did.

Thanking those who had supported his work, Garner said: "The author is like the flyer in a high trapeze act. It is the catcher who does much of the hard work, often in obscurity, through telling the flyer when to let go and not letting him fall."

Garner's published his first book, The Weirdstone of Brisingamen, at the age of 22. In 1967 his mythical tragedy The Owl Service, melding Welsh folktale and a modern broken home, won the Carnegie medal and the Guardian Children's Fiction Award. His latest book, The Well of the Wind, was published in 1998.

Born in Congleton, Garner has lived in Cheshire all his life, taking inspiration from his sense of place and history. The first of his family to go to university, he met both JRR Tolkien and CS Lewis while at college in Oxford. Like them his work contains supernatural elements and has strong appeal for adult readers, although as he never reads fiction - not wanting to be subconsciously influenced by other writers' ideas - he has read neither.

Recommended works

Red Shift
A novel for 'young adults', this bleak and allusive tale of love and madness switches between three time frames: Roman Britain (with shades of Vietnam), the Civil War era and a contemporary troubled teenager. Violent and tender by turns, it towers over most 'grown-up' writing.

The Owl Service
A rewriting of the Mabinogion, a classic coming-of-age tale exploring puberty and poltergeists and a chilling ghost story about the power of the past. A children's book, but a very good one indeed.

Strandloper
If you liked him as a child, try this 1996 novel for adults which intertwines Aboriginal dreamtime and Old England.

webTitle: It's a numbers game in teacher 'meltdown'

fields.headline: It's a numbers game in teacher 'meltdown'
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod looks at the figures in the argument over teacher shortages - and finds the government wanting
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod looks at the figures in the argument over teacher shortages - and finds the government wanting.
fields.body:
Headteachers are insisting that meltdown has arrived this term with schools in London and the south east having to go onto a four-day week because they cannot put enough teachers in front of classes.

Yet only last year, education secretary David Blunkett said that while the supply of teachers had come close to meltdown, the government had taken enough action to head it off.

So who is right?

The governments own figures show the position is worsening. The January snapshot of vacancies in England and Wales shows the number of unfilled posts in secondary schools rose from 1028 in January 1998 to 1287 in January 2000. In the same period, primary vacancies grew from 1391 to 1420 despite extra numbers of teachers recruited in order to reduce class sizes.

The problem is worse in London and the southeast. In London, secondary vacancies jumped from 290 to 413 in the past two years, while in the rest of the southeast the rise was from 141 to 250. In contrast, the number of empty posts in the northeast and in Yorkshire fell to 37 and 57 respectively.

In certain subjects the position is also deteriorating. Vacancies for maths teachers rose from 141 to 239, in science from 108 to 163.

These figures sound tiny in relation to the 400,000 workforce, but they are the tip of an iceberg. January is the month when vacancies are at their lowest   few teachers leave at Christmas. Nor do the statistics show what percentage of those teachers are actually unqualified (which is rising, particularly in London) or the number of teachers without specialist knowledge   a biology graduate teaching physics, for instance.

The view from headteachers themselves, expressed in a survey by the Secondary Heads Association, is that an extra 4,000 staff is needed. Schools and further education colleges are about to embark on a huge expansion of activity to cater for four or five A level subjects instead of three under the governments current plans.

To exacerbate the problem, absences are at their highest in January through illness and the departure of supply teachers from the southern hemisphere. (Australia and New Zealand, where the academic year begins in January, are beginning to feel their own shortages and there will be more pressure to keep homegrown teachers.)

So many supply teachers are being used to fill permanent vacancies, there are not enough to cover for illness. That means further disruption for schools and inadequate lessons for children, whatever the governments protests about vacancy rates.

There is an irony in the problem. As John Howson, a consultant who worked for the Teacher Training Agency, points out, the shortage did not manifest itself until Labour started increasing school budgets. Under Conservative spending plans   continued for two years by Blair   schools had to cut back on staff.

Only when schools had the money to start filling posts did the full impact of years of neglect in teacher training become clear. Now there arent enough qualified staff to go round   especially in areas with high housing costs or in schools facing severe social difficulties or special measures imposed by Ofsted.

So why, Mr Blunkett, has the government just cut the target for the number of trainee primary teachers for next September?

fields.headline: Schools face four-day week
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pupils in the most prosperous areas of Britain are facing the prospect of four-day school weeks as a shortage of teachers begins to bite.
fields.body:
Pupils in the most prosperous areas of Britain are facing the prospect of four-day school weeks as a shortage of teachers begins to bite.

Leading educationalists and headteachers have warned that rising property prices and the housing shortage across London and the south are making it harder for schools to recruit and retain staff.

Amid claims of crisis and "meltdown" in the profession, the head of Essex county council's education department has written to David Blunkett, the education secretary, warning of an impending shortfall of teachers across the county.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association (SHA), said the shortages were at crisis levels and government measures were insufficient to combat the problem. An SHA survey last year indicated secondary schools were 4,000 teachers short, while government figures indicated a shortfall of just 1,000.

"The government has been consistently underplaying the extent of the crisis and therefore has not put in place emergency measures soon enough to address what heads are calling the worst situation in their careers," Mr Dunford said.

"It has now reached the stage where it is threatening the government's project to raise standards in secondary schools."

David Hart, the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers (NAHT), said: "We are touching meltdown in terms of the recruitment crisis in parts of the country."

Last year three schools operated a four-day week and yesterday the headmaster of a fourth school in Wiltshire announced that he would be operating a part-time timetable to cope with the shortage.

John Wells, headmaster of Headlands secondary school in Swindon, Wiltshire, is considering a four-day week if he fails to recruit staff before the start of term next week. Mr Wells said that the situation was worse than at any other time in his 17-year career.

"If I don't manage to recruit enough staff over this holiday I will have to send some of the lower school children home for two classes a week - which amounts to one afternoon for them," he added. "Certainly over the last 12 months we have seen a worsening in the problem for us.

"There are key subject areas which are affected in the main. Those are English, maths, science and technology where we are finding great difficulty recruiting despite numerous adverts nationally and on the internet. We're just not getting applicants in and those we do get are very poor quality, unfortunately."

Graham Lane, education representative of the Local Government Association, said the recruitment problem was most marked in London and Surrey where property prices were making it difficult to recruit at a time when some London boroughs needed to employ another 100 teachers a year just to cope with rising rolls. Turnover of young teachers is also running at 20% in some parts of London.

"The government need to look at the financial structure of teacher's pay to keep the talented people in the profession," he said.

In his letter to David Blunkett Paul Lincoln, director of learning services in Essex, warned that the shortage is leading to headteachers becoming demoralised. He also indicated that some staff who would not normally make the grade are being hired.

"Many vacancies are being covered by supply teachers or other teachers on short-term contracts," he wrote. "Increasing reliance is also being placed on the use of agency staff and often including the use of overseas-trained teachers, whose qualifications may not be recognised in the UK. Indeed a significant number of headteachers have told us that they have recently been forced to appoint candidates who they would not even have shortlisted."

In Reading, Berkshire, local MPs and counsellors have expressed concern about the so-called "crisis of prosperity". Some schools are considering subsidising the commuting and accommodation costs of teachers based in the south-west and Wales who would be willing to work in the area. Existing teachers have been approached to see if they will offer rooms to rent.

Estelle Morris, the education minister, conceded that there were recruitment problems but pointed to record numbers of teachers in training.

"I am not underestimating the nature of the problem for some schools but it must be seen against the general background," she said. "There are 7,000 more teachers in service than there were two years ago, and this year we saw the first increase in those people that go into initial teacher training in eight years."

The number of teachers in training rose by 9% last year but it will take between three and four years for them to come into the profession full time. Last month it was revealed that the Department for Education had set up a unit to advise schools who thought they were in danger of having to cancel classes.

A spokesman said staff in London receive regional salary weighting of between £1,524 and £2,316 annually while those on the fringe of the capital receive £581. Grants are also available from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions for education authorities wishing to buy affordable housing for staff, he added.

webTitle: Double first for novel newcomer Zadie Smith

fields.headline: Double first for novel newcomer Zadie Smith
fields.standfirst:
Whitbread win pitches young writer into final five for top book award
A taste of the winners
fields.trailText: Whitbread win pitches young writer into final five for top book award.
fields.body:
One amazing year for Zadie Smith reached another peak yesterday when the 25-year-old holder of the Guardian First Book award also took the Whitbread prize for first novel.

On January 23 she will hear whether she has also won the overall £22,500 Whitbread book of the year award, against competition from three other finalists unveiled yesterday and the as yet unnamed winner of the children's book award.

At the end of the month it will be just under a year since White Teeth, the ex-Cambridge student's 460-page first novel about the multi-racial pot of north London, first brought her celebrity.

The three judges called it "not only the best first novel we've read in ages but one of the best novels we've ever read, and perhaps the best novel about contemporary London". It had been picked for its "superb ear for dialogue and fantastically assured control of a panoramic plot". It was was "a landmark first novel".

Earlier this year, however, White Teeth missed both the Orange and Booker prizes. Zadie Smith called the book "the literary equivalent of a hyperactive, ginger-haired, tap-dancing 10-year-old".

Speaking from New York last night, she said: "I'm delighted, sort of gobsmacked, very chuffed, really psyched. It's the prize every first-time scribbler hopes for."

Each of yesterday's winners gets £3,500. The other woman finalist, English literature don Lorna Sage, is considered one of the strongest contenders for the top prize with her revelatory autobiography Bad Blood, which won the Whitbread biography of the year award. No biography has won the overall Whitbread prize since 1991.

Whitbread judges said it was a brave, compelling and rare book. "This tragi-comic autobiographical story of one young woman's escape from a claustrophobic background in post-war Britain manages to tell the story of not just the author's family but of many others in stark, direct prose."

For Matthew Kneale, 40, it was second time lucky. His colonialist parable The English Passengers was declared novel of the year, after being shortlisted for the Booker last autumn.

The Whitbread judges praised The English Passengers as "one of the most enjoyable books we've ever read for pure, unadulterated, page-turning excitement".

It was "unquestionably" the novel of the year for its historical depth, narrative control and masterly mix of tragedy and comedy, and for Kneale's remarkable ability to deal with complex historical truths "without resorting to bogus hypocritical cant".

Kneale, whose novels have won smaller literary prizes, said from his home in Italy that the Whitbread award was "a marvellous fillip".

The narrative of The English Passengers was prompted by the near-genocide caused by British colonisation of Tasmania in the 19th century, where "all the original population and culture was lost within 40 years. Some colonists were aware of what was happening, but most Englishmen who went down there turned into monsters," he said.

Whitbread's poet of the year is John Burnside for his seventh collection, The Asylum Dance, which the judges felt had stunning unity of tone, style and purpose.

"It constantly strives to evoke what is beyond the sayable. It is a deeply spiritual book while at the same time very physical, filled with a wide humanity. Burnside's poems are a sensory delight with an epiphany on every page."

Burnside, 45, born in Dunfermline and expelled from school in Northamptonshire for smoking pot "and other improprieties", gave up computer programming five years ago to write poetry full time. and is now Dundee University's writer in residence. Yesterday, he said the title poem was inspired partly by Eduard Munk's painting The Dance of Life.

Lorna Sage, 57, professor of English at East Anglia and veteran literary reviewer, was "thrilled, astonished and surprised" but too ill with a chest infection to say more last night.

Bad Blood, one of the highest praised books of 2000, astonished and impressed those outside her immediate circle with its account of growing up in "rural dereliction".

Her publishing editor Nicholas Pearson said, "No-one knew very much about Lorna. It was a departure for her to write about herself. We find the book appeals to a much younger generation than her own".

fields.headline: Costly drugs case collapses
fields.trailText: The taxpayer faces a bill of up to £1.5m over the collapse of a complex and costly high court case brought by the Office of Fair Trading to open up over-the-counter medicines to price competition. Clare Dyer reports
fields.body:
The taxpayer faces a bill of up to £1.5m over the collapse of a complex and costly high court case brought by the Office of Fair Trading to open up over-the-counter medicines to price competition.

The debacle is reminiscent of the Pinochet case, which had to be expensively reheard by the House of Lords after it emerged that one of the original panel of law lords, Lord Hoffmann, had close links with Amnesty International, a party to the case.

The medicines case was halted in November, six weeks into a trial in the restrictive practices court, after one of two lay members hearing the case with a high court judge disclosed that a month after the trial started she had applied for a job with one of two rival economic consultancies whose evidence on behalf of the two opposing sides will be crucial to the outcome.

Penelope Rowlatt, an economist hearing the case with Mr Justice Lightman and an accountant, James Scott, sounded out Frontier Economics about a job. A Frontier director is an important witness for the OFT on the key issue in the case - the effect on small pharmacies of abolishing the exemption for over the counter (OTC) medicines from the ban on resale price maintenance.

The OFT wants to lift a 30-year-old court ruling which allows suppliers of non-prescription medicines to set a minimum price for 2000 branded drugs, including such household names as Nurofen and Lemsip.

The OFT's opponents, the Proprietary Association of Great Britain and the Proprietary Articles Trade Association, representing independent pharmacists and makers of OTC medicines, asked Dr Rowlatt to stand down. She refused, but offered not to take up a job with Frontier for at least two years after the case finished.

The trade associations argued that the whole panel should stand down, because the other members would have discussed the case with Dr Rowlatt. But after she produced a letter from Frontier saying it had no vacancies, Mr Justice Lightman ruledthe case could continue before the existing panel.

The manufacturers and pharmacists went to the court of appeal, which held in November that the whole panel must stand down and the case must start again.

The appeal court gave the reasons for its decision just before the courts adjourned for Christmas. They concluded that the parties would not have had a fair trial, as guaranteed by the Human Rights Act, had the case continued with the existing panel. The Master of the Rolls, Lord Phillips, said: "We reached our decision with great regret. Its consequence is that an immense amount of industry will have gone for nothing."

But a fair-minded observer "would have concluded that there was a real danger that Dr Rowlatt would be unable to make an objective and impartial appraisal of the expert evidence placed before the court by Frontier". She would have discussed the economic issues with the other two panel members. Therefore, all three had to stand down.

Lord Phillips said the documentation was "quite enormous". There were nearly 170 bundles of documents and 70 witnesses.

The OFT, which had four barristers, two solicitors and three paralegals working on the case, said its costs to date totalled £2m, and the extra costs of a rehearing were estimated at £600,000. Its leading QC has other commitments and a new QC will have to be found.

Costs for the pharmacists' and manufacturers' associations, represented by five barristers and a team of solicitors, are certain to be higher. They are applying for their wasted costs to be paid by the Lord Chancellor's department, which sometimes makes ex gratia payments in cases where a judge's error incurs extra costs.

But a fair-minded observer "would have concluded that there was a real danger that Dr Rowlatt would be unable to make an objective and impartial appraisal of the expert evidence placed before the court by Frontier". She would have discussed the economic issues with the other two panel members. Therefore, all three had to stand down. Lord Phillips said the documentation was "quite enormous". There were nearly 170 bundles of documents and 70 witnesses. The OFT, which had four barristers, two solicitors and three paralegals working on the case, said its costs to date totalled £2m, and the extra costs of a rehearing were estimated at £600,000. Its leading QC has other commitments and a new QC will have to be found. Costs for the pharmacists' and manufacturers' associations, represented by five barristers and a team of solicitors, are certain to be higher. They are applying for their wasted costs to be paid by the Lord Chancellor's department, which sometimes makes ex gratia payments in cases where a judge's error incurs extra costs.

fields.headline: Crossing the public-private divide
fields.standfirst: More and more private sector workers are applying for jobs in local government. Do they present any real competition and should you gain private experience if you want to climb the public sector career ladder?
fields.trailText: More and more private sector workers are applying for jobs in local government. Do they present any real competition and should you gain private experience if you want to climb the public sector career ladder? Hamish Davidson investigates.
fields.body:
Public sector employers are forever saying they do not wish to preclude people from the private sector, but those same employers rarely interview any private sector applicants.

Although increasing numbers of private sector applicants are applying for senior public sector jobs, public sector employers accuse them of submitting poor or inadequate applications that fail adequately to address the appointment criteria. Another complaint is that they fail to complete the application form as requested.

The culture in the private sector is not to fill in application forms for senior jobs - one typically submits only a very brief CV. While the private sector feels the public sector makes an allowance for this, the public sector believes strongly in equal opportunities!

Despite this, many parts of the public sector are still keen to bring on board some of the skills and experience of the private sector.

Nevertheless, people joining local government, particularly from those parts of the private sector that operate in a different orbit from the public, invariably have a significant learning curve in terms of getting to grips with the political environment, as well as local government's peculiar and arcane form of bureaucracy. I'm not aware of anything in the private sector that prepares people for these horrors.

So, is it worth public sector workers gaining experience in the private sector?
With best value and partnership working fostering new and different relationships between councils and business, there must surely be greater confidence and credibility to be gained from some first-hand experience, even perhaps through secondments, within the private sector.

Indeed, there are people, especially local government folk, who take a "sabbatical" in the private sector with a view to returning refreshed and brimming with new ideas.

However, the few who do return rarely show any sign of having learned anything, and if they have, they don't seem to be overly anxious to put it into action. Most of the really good ones appear to decide that they have absolutely no desire to return from whence they came - there is a message here!

Although it has to be worth gaining experience in another culture, where the attitudes may be sharper and more "business focused", there are different degrees of experience. Many people who claim to have private sector experience have gained it in one of the "associated industries" - outsourcing companies, privatised services, consultancies, etc. It is debatable whether this is really private sector experience

Private sector experience is useful for the "vision thing". You get to see another way of doing business and learn what is possible. It is, however, not essential for competitive edge at job selection since most of government, both central and local, is pretty conservative in its recruitment, even at the best of times.

Comfort zone
My own thoughts? Enough of this prejudice of each sector against the other. The best people in each sector are very good - and skills are usually much more transferable than commonly imagined. The differing recruitment cultures and processes don't help, and often serve merely to reinforce stereotypical and preconceived impressions.

The truth has to be that just as travel broadens the mind, so too does a period working in a different environment. So I would thoroughly encourage public sector employees to seek secondments and exposure to areas and sectors outside of their own comfort zone - and even, yes, with the private sector, if it is possible.

Such readiness to seek and gain new experiences, to challenge myths and try out different ideas, is well received by most of my more change-focused public sector clients, while closed minds, narrow perspectives and cautious attitudes are not. Take a look over the hedge, and even spend a bit of time there - you won't necessarily like all that you see and experience, but you will end up a wiser person.

As for the private sector executive seeking to spend a bit of time in the public sector - well, sad to say, their experience is likely to prove fairly frightening, as they encounter a quite peculiar political environment filled with protocols, odd relationships and quaint customs.

webTitle: US ad campaign attacks marijuana laws

fields.headline: US ad campaign attacks marijuana laws
fields.trailText: 5pm: An ad campaign suggesting marijuana use should be decriminalised will launch in US tube stations and on buses this week, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
An ad campaign suggesting marijuana use should be decriminalised will launch in US tube stations and on buses this week despite opposition from the transport authorities and anti-drug pressure groups.

The month-long campaign, which will first run in Washington DC, is funded by Change the Climate, a non-profit organisation that believes punishment for marijuana use is too harsh.

There will be three ads including one in which a young woman asks, "Why do kids go to jail for doing what politicians did when they were young?".

Several US politicians, along with their UK counterparts, have recently admitted trying cannabis when at college.

Former president Bill Clinton famously admitted smoking pot but denied inhaling.

Metro officials in Washington initially refused to run the ads, claiming that public service advertising should be "non-partisan".

They reversed their decision when threatened with a lawsuit backed by the American Civil Liberties Union, which argued that the organisation was violating free speech.

All ads carry a disclaimer that the Washington Metro does not "endorse" the message.

webTitle: NewsCorp denies hitch in US TV deal

fields.headline: NewsCorp denies hitch in US TV deal
fields.trailText: 5pm: News Corporation has brushed off fears that its proposed £3.5bn acquisition of 10 US TV stations will fall foul of ownership laws. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
News Corporation has brushed off fears that its proposed £3.5bn acquisition of 10 US TV stations will fall foul of foreign ownership laws.

US watchdogs have challenged Rupert Murdoch's media conglomerate over the deal with Chris-Craft Industries, because takeover rules prohibit a foreign-owned company from controlling more than 25% of a US TV or radio station.

A spokesman for the Australia-based NewsCorp said reports that the deal could be in trouble were "much ado about nothing".

He said that the licences for the stations will be controlled by its Fox Television subsidiary, which answers the main concerns of the Federal Communications Commission watchdog.

However, the FCC is worried that a new NewsCorp subsidiary, Newco, will control the management functions of the stations and violate its laws.

"The FCC is entitled to raised these issues, but Newco is a subsidiary which will hold the physical assets , such as buildings and TV cameras, and it will be Fox TV holding the licences and real control," added the spokesman.

A previous FCC ruling limits News Corporation to acquiring stations through Fox Television.

"We are following the commission's rules entirely, and the structure of the deal is entirely consistent with the way we have structured these acquisitions in the past," he added.

The deal, which is expected to be completed by June, will give NewsCorp 13 TV stations in the top 10 US markets.

webTitle: Yahoo! agrees to ban auctions of Nazi memorabilia

fields.headline: Yahoo! agrees to ban auctions of Nazi memorabilia
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: French human rights activists claimed victory yesterday after the giant US-based internet portal, Yahoo!, suddenly decided to halt its online auctions of Nazi memorabilia and other hate-related artifacts.
fields.body:
French human rights activists claimed victory yesterday after the giant US-based internet portal, Yahoo!, suddenly decided to halt its online auctions of Nazi memorabilia and other hate-related artifacts.

"I believe we have won the battle," Licra spokesman Marc Knoble said. Licra was one of three Jewish and anti-racist groups that sued Yahoo! in April for its internet auctions of items such as SS daggers, swastikas, propaganda films, photos of death camp victims and even replicas of Zyklon B canisters, the deadly gas used in Nazi concentration camps.

Yahoo! said on Tuesday that it would ban sales of Nazi and Ku Klux Klan paraphernalia from all its websites from January 10, saying it did not want to profit from items that glorified or promoted hatred. The outlawed items join a list which includes cigarettes, live animals and used underwear.

The company denied its decision was in response to an earlier Paris court ruling on the case, saying it was responding to users who had requested a more active policy for its site's content, and to groups such as the Simon Wiesenthal Centre and the Anti-Defamation League, which had been in talks with Yahoo! throughout the year.

To enforce its new policy, Yahoo! has launched a monitoring programme that will screen new listings for offensive content, holding back potentially outlawed material for closer review by staff.

Earlier this year a French court found that the material on Yahoo!'s US auction sites, which are easily accessible to French users, broke French laws against the sale or promotion of racist material. The sites, the court found, represented "an apology for Nazism and a contestation of Nazi crimes", and "offended against France's collective memory".

In November the court confirmed that verdict, rejecting Yahoo!'s appeal. It gave the company three months to set up a filtering system that would prevent web-surfers in France from accessing the auctions.

Yahoo! argued that the websites were aimed primarily at the American market and were therefore protected by the US constitution's first amendment, which governs freedom of speech.

Amid alarm in some circles at what was seen as an attempt to impose national views on the quintessentially international, boundary-free internet, Yahoo! promised to fight the French ruling in US courts. It also argued that it would be technically difficult, if not impossible, to "filter" surfers of a particular nationality.

Michael Traynor, a leading American multimedia lawyer who filed an affidavit on behalf of Yahoo!, said the Paris ruling had allowed France to "extra-territorially enforce its notions on the rest of the world".

The French human-rights groups, however, said Yahoo!'s decision vindicated their position. "I am very satisfied. We did not expect this. It goes beyond what we asked for," Mr Knoble said. "Yahoo! recognises that we were right, that they should not be allowing hate auctions on their websites."

Ygal El Harrar, the chairman of the Jewish students' group, UEJF, said it was a great victory. "Basically, economic might puts no one above the law or above morality," he said. "We welcome the American company's return to its senses."
