webTitle: Jari Litmanen's dream move, Ross Kemp's Christmas Carol, and Adam Crozier's encyclopaedic knowledge

fields.headline: Jari Litmanen's dream move, Ross Kemp's Christmas Carol, and Adam Crozier's encyclopaedic knowledge
fields.trailText: YOU CAN'T BEAT A BIT OF LIT
fields.body:
YOU CAN'T BEAT A BIT OF LIT

Gerard Houllier is not a man given to hyperbole. So when he announced that he'd made "one of the most exciting signings" in Liverpool's history today - and that man turned out to be Barcelona's so-out-of-favour-he-hasn't-even-been-on-the-bench forward Jari Litmanen - the Fiver couldn't help feeling a tad confused. And our confusion quickly turned into downright cynicism when a joyous Houllier added: "He comes with a reputation which needs no improvement."

A reputation for being a fancy-boy who won't like it up him come February, we thought. But then we looked at his record. Litmanen averages nearly a goal every other game. He's the all-time leading scorer in Big Cup. He's even been voted the Finnish footballer of the year five times - and that means a lot more than it used to. So it seems it wasn't such a bad idea to sign Rigobert Song, Djimi Triore and Bernard Dio er, hold on to sell Erik Meijer and Titi Camara after all.

New team-mate Sami Hyppia certainly thinks the purchase of Litmanen is good business. "There is not a question you can ask Jari about Liverpool that he will not know the answer to," he beamed. "He knows everything about the club and is always talking about Liverpool." Hyypia's happiness might even spread to Robbie Fowler, after Houllier insisted this afternoon that he has bought Litmanen to complement, and not replace, his current strikers. All of which means Robbie can stay, the Wonder Bar will continue to thrive, and Liverpool will win the Premiership next season. Doesn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ARRY HITS THE SALES

Appy Arry Redknapp didn't get to the top without being organised. In his portakabin round the back of Upton Park, he has a tray marked "wheeling" and a tray marked "dealing". Every potential transfer steal goes into one of these trays (some of them even go into two!) and that way Arry stays ahead of the game. That, and giving Slippy Mickey a monkey every fortnight for the latest gossip, that is.

At the top of Arry's wheeling tray is Aston Villa skipper and feared midfield playmaker Gareth Southgate. Gareth has spent the season playing like a lion and looking like a lemon after his "Villa quit bid" stirred as much interest as Ross Kemp's Christmas Carol. Sniffing a bargain, Arry has now stepped in, and revealed a £6m bid. "Villa's asking price of £10m for a player of 30 is way too high", he said. "But I rate Gareth highly, both as a player and a professional, and it's time we put in an offer."

Arry is wise to keep this bid in the "wheeling" tray, as there is surely six months of rejection, haggling, and bids mysteriously disappearing into tracksuit trousers stylishly tucked into white socks to follow. But Arry's pursuit of Lorenzo "I'll just swing a leg at it" Amoruso is a different matter entirely, and only this morning moved to the top of the "dealing" pile. "Something is on. If the deal goes through and everyone can be happy, I can definitely move [to Upton Park]", Tthe non-racist centre-half admitted today. Arry agreed and, with his poker face on, said: "I wouldn't mind having both Southgate and Amoruso at Upton Park."

We bet you wouldn't. Two new defenders, and Rigobert Song, for the price of one floundering libero - now that's good business. If you spot our Arry in the sales this weekend, our advice would be to follow him.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"He should sign a new, long contract with United, persuade his missus to have a few more bairns and get as much rest as he can" - Brian Clough offers some 21st-century advice to Old Skin 'Ead himself, David Beckham.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OUT OF THE COUNTRY

Thanks to Ken Bates and all the other members on the committee overseeing the New Wembley project - the Football Association Rebuilding and Construction Enterprise (or FARCE for short) - we should soon have the greatest national stadium on the planet in which to stage major sporting events. But for the next 35 years, the show must go on. With this in mind, it was today confirmed that the next three FA Cup Finals will be played at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff.

"This year will be first time an FA Cup final is staged away from Wembley since 1922," explained the FA's advertising executive Adam Crozier, displaying an encyclopaedic knowledge of a tournament won in 1970 by Chelsea at Old Trafford. "But as we saw during the Rugby Union World Cup in 1999, the Millennium Stadium generates a unique atmosphere."

Whether the "unique atmosphere" generated by 76,000 passionate Welsh rugby fans can be replicated by the same number of businessmen yawning and belching while Newcastle are being easily beaten is anyone's guess. But even if all three finals are as tedious as the last three (and the three before them), Cardiff will still be guaranteed some excitement: the Football League are bringing the three divisional play-off finals to the Welsh capital! As well as the LDV Vans Trophy! And the Worthington Cup! Alright, mentioning the Worthington Cup ruined that particular argument.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bayern Munich keeper Oliver Kahn will not be joining Liverpool, despite reports to the contrary. "Liverpool, or anyone else for that matter, can forget about even trying to sign Oliver," Bayern president Franz Beckenbauer said. "He is not for sale at any price."

Newcastle are looking to sign Wimbledon's Marcus Gayle in an attempt to strengthen their threadbare strikeforce.

The Mirror believes Arsenal are to make a renewed attempt to sign Dutch international Edgar Davids who is apparently "disillusioned with life at Juventus".

Birmingham manager Trevor Francis has rekindled his interest in Derby striker Dean Sturridge. "I would still like to bring him here and I know that he remains very keen on us," Francis admitted. "The price we were quoted earlier in the season was £1.5m, but that has come down significantly with Dean closer to becoming a Bosman free transfer in the summer."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Wimbledon's owners are planning to move the club to a new £50m stadium in Milton Keynes. Chairman Bjorn Gjelsten said: "Milton Keynes has a lot to offer and looks like the most realistic option. We have a responsibility to our loyal supporter base but they have to be rational."

Ipswich have rejected Nottingham Forest's £2.5m bid for striker David Johnson.

Steve Lomas has insisted he has no desire to leave West Ham despite interest from Manchester City. "I'm settled here and have never asked for a transfer," he claimed. "Unless the club tell me any different I am more than happy to be at West Ham and proud to play for them."

Leicester's Darren Eadie will be out of action until the end of January after undergoing a knee operation.

Bookmakers Fred Done have decided to pay out on Celtic winning the Scottish Premier League, five months early. "The Scottish League race is over," said a spokesman for the firm. "I reckon it will cost us around £25,000 to pay out for Celtic but the punters might as well get their money now rather than wait until May."

Argentinian World Cup star Claudio Caniggia has committed himself to Dundee for a further two-and-a-half years.

Michael Gray, Sunderland's captain and longest-serving player, has been granted a testimonial match in the summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.55am) "I sometimes see Chris Peacock, who is on London Tonight, in my local kebab shop near the Oval," writes Dave Harrington.

Football Review of the Year (1.30am) "He usually orders a large shish, easy on the chilli sauce."

US Major League Soccer (3.30am) "I've taken an interest in his career since my brother pointed out that if you say his name quickly, it sounds like a nasty burn."

Footy Shorts (5.05am) "He used to work on either South Today or the old TVS news."

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm, 8.30pm SS2, 12midnight) "That's going back a few years when I lived down in Hampshire."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 1am) "My brother swears that one of the other presenters in the region was called Sonia Legg, which suggests that they were making up comedy names."

Australian Soccer League (11pm, 2am) "Although Bruce Parker and Fred Dineage don't seem to support this theory."

Sky Sports 3: Football Gold (10pm) Spotted a television presenter who hasn't quite made it? A commentator who never gets called up to do Football Focus, not even when Sue Thearle's on holiday? Then email the.boss@theguardian.com and tell us about it. God, we love it when you to write to us.

If you spot our Arry in the sales this weekend, our advice would be to follow him. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "He should sign a new, long contract with United, persuade his missus to have a few more bairns and get as much rest as he can" - Brian Clough offers some 21st-century advice to Old Skin 'Ead himself, David Beckham. * * * * * * * * * * * * * OUT OF THE COUNTRY Thanks to Ken Bates and all the other members on the committee overseeing the New Wembley project - the Football Association Rebuilding and Construction Enterprise (or FARCE for short) - we should soon have the greatest national stadium on the planet in which to stage major sporting events. But for the next 35 years, the show must go on. With this in mind, it was today confirmed that the next three FA Cup Finals will be played at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff. "This year will be first time an FA Cup final is staged away from Wembley since 1922," explained the FA's advertising executive Adam Crozier, displaying an encyclopaedic knowledge of a tournament won in 1970 by Chelsea at Old Trafford. "But as we saw during the Rugby Union World Cup in 1999, the Millennium Stadium generates a unique atmosphere." Whether the "unique atmosphere" generated by 76,000 passionate Welsh rugby fans can be replicated by the same number of businessmen yawning and belching while Newcastle are being easily beaten is anyone's guess. But even if all three finals are as tedious as the last three (and the three before them), Cardiff will still be guaranteed some excitement: the Football League are bringing the three divisional play-off finals to the Welsh capital! As well as the LDV Vans Trophy! And the Worthington Cup! Alright, mentioning the Worthington Cup ruined that particular argument. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Bayern Munich keeper Oliver Kahn will not be joining Liverpool, despite reports to the contrary. "Liverpool, or anyone else for that matter, can forget about even trying to sign Oliver," Bayern president Franz Beckenbauer said. "He is not for sale at any price." Newcastle are looking to sign Wimbledon's Marcus Gayle in an attempt to strengthen their threadbare strikeforce. The Mirror believes Arsenal are to make a renewed attempt to sign Dutch international Edgar Davids who is apparently "disillusioned with life at Juventus". Birmingham manager Trevor Francis has rekindled his interest in Derby striker Dean Sturridge. "I would still like to bring him here and I know that he remains very keen on us," Francis admitted. "The price we were quoted earlier in the season was £1.5m, but that has come down significantly with Dean closer to becoming a Bosman free transfer in the summer." * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Wimbledon's owners are planning to move the club to a new £50m stadium in Milton Keynes. Chairman Bjorn Gjelsten said: "Milton Keynes has a lot to offer and looks like the most realistic option. We have a responsibility to our loyal supporter base but they have to be rational." Ipswich have rejected Nottingham Forest's £2.5m bid for striker David Johnson. Steve Lomas has insisted he has no desire to leave West Ham despite interest from Manchester City. "I'm settled here and have never asked for a transfer," he claimed. "Unless the club tell me any different I am more than happy to be at West Ham and proud to play for them." Leicester's Darren Eadie will be out of action until the end of January after undergoing a knee operation. Bookmakers Fred Done have decided to pay out on Celtic winning the Scottish Premier League, five months early. "The Scottish League race is over," said a spokesman for the firm. "I reckon it will cost us around £25,000 to pay out for Celtic but the punters might as well get their money now rather than wait until May." Argentinian World Cup star Claudio Caniggia has committed himself to Dundee for a further two-and-a-half years. Michael Gray, Sunderland's captain and longest-serving player, has been granted a testimonial match in the summer. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.55am) "I sometimes see Chris Peacock, who is on London Tonight, in my local kebab shop near the Oval," writes Dave Harrington. Football Review of the Year (1.30am) "He usually orders a large shish, easy on the chilli sauce." US Major League Soccer (3.30am) "I've taken an interest in his career since my brother pointed out that if you say his name quickly, it sounds like a nasty burn." Footy Shorts (5.05am) "He used to work on either South Today or the old TVS news." Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (6.30pm, 8.30pm SS2, 12midnight) "That's going back a few years when I lived down in Hampshire." You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 1am) "My brother swears that one of the other presenters in the region was called Sonia Legg, which suggests that they were making up comedy names." Australian Soccer League (11pm, 2am) "Although Bruce Parker and Fred Dineage don't seem to support this theory." Sky Sports 3: Football Gold (10pm) Spotted a television presenter who hasn't quite made it? A commentator who never gets called up to do Football Focus, not even when Sue Thearle's on holiday? Then email the.boss@theguardian.com and tell us about it. God, we love it when you to write to us.

fields.headline: The questions people ask
fields.standfirst: As well as publishing test reports, the Good Housekeeping Institute answers readers' queries. Here are the five questions most often asked about hairdryers.
fields.trailText: As well as publishing test reports, the Good Housekeeping Institute answers readers' queries. Here are the five questions most often asked about hairdryers.
fields.body:
1. What is most important - watts or weight?

Weight and balance matter more than wattage. So does your hair type: there's no point paying more for a dryer with a diffuser, for example, if you have short, straight hair. If your hair needs styling into position whenever you wash it, choose a dryer with a cool setting or a separate cool-shot button: damp, warm hair is still pliable and won't hold its shape without a concentrated burst of cool air to fix the style in place.

2. Do I need a diffuser or a volumiser?

Diffusers are a useful way of drying naturally wavy or permed hair without damage. Used on low speed and heat settings, the diffuser's perforations and hollow prongs help spread heat evenly and gently (the dome shape also helps to contain curls and stop them blowing about). Volumiser attachments have longer prongs to lift your hair, adding extra body or texture to finer hair. They can take practice, and you may find the prongs uncomfortable.

3. Are separate speed and temperature controls worth having?

Yes, because they give you greater control over the temperature, and more flexibility if you want to share your dryer with someone with a different type or length of hair. Short, layered hair needs a low speed with a higher temperature; someone with long, straight hair is likely to want it to dry quickly, using a fast speed and high temperature.

4. How can I get that "just out of the salon" look?

You'll need a narrow-outlet concentrator nozzle to direct the air along the length of your hair, and the patience to work in sections, starting from the nape of your neck. A 15-second stream of air on a cool setting or cool-shot button will help "set" each section, too. If you've used a good-quality conditioner after shampooing, and got rid of most of the excess moisture by towelling gently (rubbing too hard damages the cuticle and leaves hair looking dull), you'll be halfway there already.

5. Any advice for problem frizzy or fine hair?

Frizzy hair can be smoothed out by using a narrow nozzle with a large round brush (at least 5cm diameter), holding the hair taut and rolling the ends slightly under as you dry. Alternatively use a diffuser to tease the hair into waves or curls. To give fine flyaway hair more volume, dry it with your head upside down, using a volumiser attachment. Direct the airflow towards the roots for maximum lift. When your hair is dry, toss your head back and brush into place. For natural-look waves, try grasping your hair at the roots and scrunching it between your fingers while drying.

fields.headline: To dry for
fields.standfirst: There are dozens on the market, but which hairdryer should you choose for guaranteed good hair days? In the latest of our collaborations with the Good Housekeeping Institute, we put the leading brands through their paces
fields.trailText: There are dozens on the market, but which hairdryer should you choose for guaranteed good hair days? In the latest of our collaborations with the Good Housekeeping Institute, we put the leading brands through their paces.
fields.body:
A large "professional"-style hairdryer can achieve superb results in the hands of a good hairdresser; using your own, however, is just as likely to result in arm ache and disappointment. In fact, if you have an easy-care haircut and just want to rough-style your hair, a basic short-snout dryer will do a good job for £15 or less - at a third of the size and half the weight. At that price, you'll find simple combined heat and speed settings, rather than the greater range of temperature and air-flow options available on the dearer models.

For hair that needs coaxing into shape, smoothness, volume or crisper curls, you will need to spend at least £20 - for useful style-setting attachments like a concentrator nozzle with a narrow outlet, a diffuser, a cool-shot button, or even Velcro rollers (yes, honestly) or vibrating "fingers" - and be prepared for a little weightlifting.

In our latest collaboration with the Good Housekeeping Institute, we tell you which dryers are worth their weight.

The test

The GHI put 27 hairdryers currently on the market through a series of tests. Testers measured the air temperature produced at each heat setting; those that reached 80 C and higher were eliminated (80 C is the point at which hair starts to suffer heat damage). Noise, weight and balance were also assessed. Finally, a panel of volunteers with different hair types and styles tried out the dryers and the nozzles and attachments that came with them, rating them for comfort, ease of use, and the finished results.

The shortlist

The hairdryers tested were weighed without any attachments fitted. All the selected hairdryers come with a concentrator nozzle; other attachments and other extras included are listed. All come with a guarantee of at least 12 months.

More than £25

Braun Sensation

£2 9.99. Score: 8/10

1800 watts.

Two heat settings, three speed settings.

Weight: 352g.

Extras included: "power flower" nozzle, "Sensation" volumiser attachment with vibrating "fingers".

Pros

Rubberised soft-grip handle. The Sensation attachment adds loads of volume with little effort. Power flower mini-diffuser nozzle dries hair very quickly. Clear controls are colour-coded and well positioned. Filter is removable for cleaning. Quiet even on maximum speed.

Cons

Handle is a bit chunky. Poorly balanced and bulky when used with the Sensation attachment. Fiddly to set up initially. Short (1.7m) flex.

Verdict: Great for adding volume with little effort.

Stockists: 0800 783 7010 www.braun.com

Charles Worthington Results AC Salon Professional 1600W

£27.99 Score: 8/10

1600 watts.

Three heat settings, two speed settings.

Weight: 586g.

Extras included: diffuser.

Pros

Clear controls. Attachments are easy to fit and remove. Evenly balanced, even with the diffuser. Diffuser is good at adding volume to fine/straight hair, and the slim concentrator nozzle gives a very sleek finish. Filter is removable for cleaning. Three-year guarantee and long (3m) flex. Good instructions with a few styling tips.

Cons

Big and heavy to use - the long barrel makes it awkward to style your hair. Handle is bulky and uncomfortable to hold. Easy to accidentally change settings while drying your hair.

Verdict: Impressive, sleek results for that "just left the salon" look.

Stockists: 0800 212 438 www.cwlondon.com

Remington Big Shot Curl Up

£29.99. Score: 9/10

1800 watts.

Three heat settings, two speed settings; cool-shot button.

Weight: 420g.

Extras included: diffuser, thermal bristle brush, vent brush, four Velcro rollers, four sectioning clips.

Pros

Handle is very comfortable, with a textured grip. Lightweight and well-balanced, even when used with the diffuser. Dries hair fast, and the diffuser is great at creating curls and adding volume. Clear controls are at your fingertips. Filter is removable for cleaning. Good instructions with a few styling tips. Two-year guarantee. Long (2.9m) flex.

Cons

Diffuser and nozzle are fiddly to fit and remove. Concentrator nozzle has wide outlet.

Verdict: Everything a person needs for gorgeous curls.

fields.headline: Arafat allies stand by refugees
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Arab foreign ministers insisted today that Palestinian refugees' right of return to homes in Israel is "sacred", leaving Yasser Arafat little room to manoeuvre on a key concession demanded in the American peace plan.
fields.body:
Arab foreign ministers insisted today that Palestinian refugees' right of return to homes in Israel is "sacred", leaving Yasser Arafat little room to manoeuvre on a key concession demanded in the American peace plan.

The Palestinian leader had turned today to Arab League foreign ministers meeting in Cairo for support as he contemplated a US suggestion that he surrender the right of refugees now in Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and elsewhere to return to homes in Israel.

In exchange, the Palestinians would gain control of a key holy site in Jerusalem. Mr Arafat has reportedly accepted the formula as a basis for talks with Israel.

Israel made the same commitment earlier, though its prime minister, Ehud Barak, has said he would never sign an agreement giving the Palestinians sovereignty over the Jerusalem site, revered by Jews and Muslims.

Israel's cabinet indicated it might resume peace talks but with positions hardening on either side, it is unclear how much progress could be made at any talks.

The Egyptian foreign minister, Amr Moussa, speaking as the chairman of today's meeting, said after the talks: "I would like to point out that Lebanon has totally rejected the idea of resettling the Palestinian refugees [permanently] and insisted on the right of the Palestinians to return. We believe that this is a sacred right."

In Israel, foreign ministry spokesman Noam Katz said his government was engaged with the Palestinians, not the Arab League.

Israel, Mr Katz said, was trying to determine if Mr Arafat's reported conditional acceptance "falls within the parameters of the Clinton proposals. If it does, and if a drastic drop takes place in the level of violence, then we will consider in a positive spirit resumption of the negotiations."

Mr Arafat had been expected to announce his response to the US proposals after the meeting. However, he left without speaking to reporters.

Mr Moussa said he could not say whether the Palestinians would return to the negotiating table.

He said the foreign ministers also were concerned the Palestinians had not been assured full sovereignty over east Jerusalem and the city's Muslim holy sites. He added that Arabs wanted further clarifications from the Americans.

Before the Arab League meeting, Mr Arafat briefed the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, on his talks this week with Mr Clinton.

Moderate and radical Arabs have rejected the US formula.

The radical Palestinian Hamas movement said in a statement that with his formula, Mr Clinton had virtually adopted "Zionist proposals, conditions and visions."

The Syrian foreign minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, whose state media repeatedly denounced the US proposals in recent days, reportedly opened today's Arab League meeting by saying the plan should not even be discussed.

The meeting was closed, but a source speaking on condition of anonymity said al-Sharaa called on the Arab League to instead concentrate on supporting the Palestinian uprising.

Iran's English-language newspaper Iran Daily said that "for the Palestinians, the right of return is as clear as the sun. It can't be made foggy, hazy or nebulous".

Palestinian-Israeli clashes have killed more than 350 people - most of them Palestinian - in the last three months.

fields.headline: Labour donors give £4m to party
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour today announced that it was receiving £4m in new donations from two major backers.
fields.body:
Labour today announced that it was receiving £4m in new donations from two major backers.

Former Tory supporter Christopher Ondaatje, who is to join the Labour party, has already donated £2m.

And Science Minister Lord Sainsbury announced his intention to make a donation of the same size.

The news came just days after publisher Lord Hamlyn disclosed he was the mystery donor who gave the Labour party £2m to help it fight the next election.

That announcement came after days of damaging speculation about who had handed Labour a massive gift just weeks before new rules brought in by the government would have forced parties to say who was behind big donations.

fields.headline: Xmas sales boost Vodafone's global reach
fields.trailText: 4pm: Mobile phone giant Vodafone has tightened its grip on the global handset market with bumper Christmas sales, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Vodafone has tightened its grip on the global handset market with bumper Christmas sales.

The mobile phone giant gained a further 13.2m customers in the fourth quarter, taking its total number of users to 78.7m.

In the UK, Vodafone added 1.4m customers, bringing it above 11.6m users.

"These figures show strong underlying growth from virtually all of our networks," said Chris Gent, Vodafone chief executive.

Vodafone has underpinned its customer growth with a series of acquisitions over the past year, including the whole of Germany's Mannesmann and a 15% stake in Japan Telecom.

Europe remains Vodafone's strongest market, with 5m new customers added to its 46m total.

The company gained 749,000 people in the Americas and Asia region, where cracking the Japanese market is a high priority.

Vodafone's shares, the bellwether of the flagship FTSE 100 index, rose 7.8% to 242.75p by mid-afternoon trading.

webTitle: US rate cut may spark UK move

fields.headline: US rate cut may spark UK move
fields.trailText: The United States last night acted to boost a flagging American economy and head off the threat of a global recession by slashing interest rates for the first time in two years in a move which stunned financial markets.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson  and Jane Martinson  in Austin, Texas
fields.body:
The United States last night acted to boost a flagging American economy and head off the threat of a global recession by slashing interest rates for the first time in two years in a move which stunned financial markets.

With confidence collapsing in the wake of last year's surge in the oil price and falling hi-tech share prices, the US Federal Reserve, led by Alan Greenspan, grasped the initiative by cutting the cost of borrowing by half a percentage point to 6% to bolster consumer and business sentiment.

The move was welcomed by president-elect George W. Bush, although he said further action would be needed to stimulate the economy.

City analysts believe the decision could lead to the first UK interest rate cut since last February. The bank's monetary policy committee meets next week and has been facing calls from industry leaders to cut the current 6% level.

Neil Parker, market strategist for the Royal Bank of Scotland, said: "This is only going to heighten expectations of interest rate cuts in the UK. I am sure the Bank of England's monetary policy committee will be surprised by this."

Justin Urquhart-Stewart, of Barclays Stockbrokers in London, said the move could have a negative effect. He said: "This is not Greenspan this is Greenpanic." He said he feared a whiff of deflation in the Fed move - deep concern that the market might shrug off the rate cut and that the economy would still weaken.

The US rate cut triggered a rally of America's technology-heavy Nasdaq share price index which initially soared by 11%. The Dow Jones industrials index, which reflects the fortunes of so-called old economy stocks, rose 2% and the dollar pared losses against the resurgent euro.

The cut, announced after an emergency session in Washington, came as a big surprise in global financial markets, which had not been expecting a rate cut until the end of the month, at the Fed's next scheduled meeting.

The last time the Fed changed rates between timetabled meetings was in September 1998, when the global economy was in danger of being dragged into recession by the fall-out from the Asian financial crisis.

Analysts said the Fed's prompt action was an indication of the seriousness of the rapidly deteriorating situation in the US, which accounts for 25% of the world economy.

In the UK, two members of the bank's nine-person mone tary policy committee - Sushil Wadhwani and DeAnne Julius - have already begun voting for lower UK interest rates, arguing that the danger from the global slowdown in growth far outweighs domestic inflationary pressure.

Speaking before the US decision, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, Mervyn King, denied US rate cuts would automatically be followed by a similar UK move.

The Fed's announcement that it was lowering its key federal funds lending rate was issued halfway through an economic forum being held in Texas by the president-elect.

Mr Bush called it a bold action, as did the head of General Electric, Jack Welch, one of a number of prominent businessmen at the summit. Mr Bush said: "We have got to be mindful of the warning signs and today Alan Greenspan showed he was."

However, the president-elect continued to stress the need for his significant tax-cutting proposals and urged Congress to take a "bold step".

Mr Bush said his specially convened meeting had been dominated by talks of a slowing economy. "The warning signs are real, people's bottom lines are being affected. Talking to people here it is clear that a rate reduction of half a per cent is not enough."

Explaining its decision in a formal statement, the Fed noted that inflation was under control and said that it had decided to act "in the light of further weakening of sales and production, and in the context of lower consumer confidence, tight conditions in some segments of financial markets and high energy prices sapping household and business purchasing power."

Figures published on Tuesday showed US manufacturing suffering the worst conditions since April 1991 when the US economy was emerging from recession.

fields.headline: Recruitment without discrimination
fields.standfirst: The European directive prohibiting religious discrimination in employment has far-reaching implications for social care providers
fields.trailText: A new directive that prohibits religious and belief discrimination in employment and occupation could mean the often religious ethos surrounding recruitment in social care will have to be cautiously applied, Emma Burrows offers advice
fields.body:
Many social care providers are borne of philanthropy. Unsurprisingly, these providers often have a strong religious or belief-based ethos. In our new pluralist age should we encourage that to wither? European politicians think so. The ministers of the European council issued a directive on October 17 2000 prohibiting discrimination in employment and occupation on the grounds of religion and belief. This is the first time religious discrimination has been addressed in England and Wales. It is already unlawful in Northern Ireland.

The directive's purpose is to outlaw the different treatment of people in employment, unless objectively justified. This may appear to be an extension of the Christian belief of "love thy neighbour" but on a literal reading could result in say, a Jewish charity being accused of discrimination by failing to provide the same employment opportunities to non-Jews and Jews alike. An open recruitment policy will inevitably lead religious organisations to fear a dilution of their central ethos. It also raises interesting cultural questions in Great Britain where different religions can equate to different cultures.

The directive has an important exception. Member states can provide exceptions in their own law to allow "public or private organisations based on religion or belief" to employ staff of the same religion or belief. The limited circumstances in which this will apply are where the job is directly and essentially related to religion or belief; to maintain the ethos of the religious organisation, and where it is a genuine occupational requirement that the job is carried out by a person of that religion or belief. The way this derogation from the basic principle of anti-discrimination works is key.

The directive is unlikely to become law until 2003, so it is sensible to consider the position under current law. For instance, can a Muslim school advertise for a headteacher who is a practising Muslim?

The first consideration is whether such an advertisement discriminates on grounds of race. Indirect race discrimination occurs where a requirement is set out that cannot be complied with by a significantly larger proportion of one racial group and another. In this case, it is likely that significantly less Europeans would qualify than Asians. To ensure such an advert is not discriminatory, the school must ensure the requirement is justified. Case law has established that it may be where the belief is necessary for the performance of the job. In law, the court has established that it was necessary for the headteacher of a church-aided primary school to be a communicant Christian. The same argument would be unlikely to be deployed successfully in the case of the school secretary. It is also important for social care providers to consider their rights and remedies under the Human Rights Act 1998.

So how do social care providers deal with this difficult issue? At present, if a post becomes vacant a good employer should ensure:

 It follows a full and fair recruitment procedure
 Consider whether the employer has a stated religious belief or ethos
 If recruiting a candidate of a particular belief - consider whether the post justifies recruitment of a person with specific beliefs
 Be careful about the wording of the advertisement to ensure it is not discriminatory.

Social care organisations worried about the imposition of the directive in the UK should be taking steps to ensure they fall within the exemption as a religious organisation. They should use the delay in its introduction as an opportunity to lobby government on further guidance as to how it will be introduced by the UK. Nearer the time of its introduction, they will also have to consider which jobs justify requiring a postholder to share the organisation's beliefs and ethos. The world of discrimination law is a secular one; it is viewed from the side of the individual. Whether it is right or not, the new law challenges our perceptions of how religious organisations will operate in the future.

fields.headline: Recession
fields.standfirst: Fears are spreading of a worldwide economic slump. Simon Jeffery explains why
fields.trailText: Fears are spreading of a worldwide economic slump. We explain why.
fields.body:
What is a recession?
A recession is where an economy that had previously been growing slows down. The level of production declines, unemployment rises and consumer spending dries up - in the worst case scenarios, as happened in the depressions of the 1930s and the 1980s, so few people are spending money that businesses sack staff to cut costs.

And is that what is happening now?
No, but Alan Greenspan, who controls American monetary policy, is worried that it might. To this end he has cut US interest rates.

How will that help?
The cost of borrowing becomes cheaper, which means that people who owe a lot of money (for example in a mortgage) have more cash in their pockets. Those who don't are more likely to take out loans. Businesses are able to expand with cheap loans, too, and create more jobs. Cutting interest rates also gives a boost to share prices since the money (interest) that an investor can make in a fixed rate bank account becomes much, much less than on the stock market.

Sounds great. Who even thought of raising interest rates in the first place?
Mr Greenspan again. For the last two years he has been more concerned about inflation, which can spiral out of control when borrowing is cheap. Unable to predict the rate at which prices rise, wage demands go up beyond the rate of inflation and businesses, now incurring greater running costs, pass on their wage bill to the consumer by putting up the prices of their goods - raising inflation.

So what does he do?
The US federal reserve, of which Mr Greenspan is the chairman, adjusts its interest rate to maintain healthy economic growth. More importantly in the context of a potential recession it tries to put an end to the cycle of boom and bust, which Mr Greenspan has probably seen enough of for one lifetime. He a was child in the 30s, became a White House economic adviser during the economic troubles of the mid-70s, and took up his present job just months before the 1987 stock market crash.

Will it work?
It will be months before we know - during which time the US economy could become still weaker. On the other hand, there is no guarantee that there would have been a US recession, and then a global recession, without Mr Greenspan's cut. Share prices rose after the announcement but, as brokers warn potential investors, they can also fall.

What will the effect be in Britain?
Share prices have risen, which will stimulate the economy, but the big test will be if the Bank of England (our equivalent to the US federal reserve) decides to cut UK interest rates when its monetary policy committee meets later this month.

fields.trailText: Sir William Macpherson disclosed today that he had received death threats over his controversial report on the Stephen Lawrence case, in which he accused the Metropolitan Police of "institutional racism".
fields.body:
Sir William Macpherson disclosed today that he had received death threats over his controversial report on the Stephen Lawrence case, in which he accused the Metropolitan Police of "institutional racism".

He is quoted in an interview in The Spectator magazine as saying the phrase was not his, that he hesitated before using it, and that he had expressly denied that every Metropolitan Police officer was racist.

However, he insisted that it was the only way he could see to sum up what was clearly a systemic failure of policing in which unconsciously racist assumptions had played a part at several stages.

He said: "It was a collective failure, little groups of people. Not just one person, not the rotten apple in the barrel, but each infecting the other.

"If they, the police, are losing their morale still, if they are still being shot away by it, that's because they ought to be rightly ashamed of what happened during the case.

"It was primarily inefficiency and lack of proper control, but also infected by racism. That is what is at the root of it all. I could have bottled out. I could have decided not to mention racism at all and stuck to the policing questions.

"But as this procession of coppers came in, our mouths sort of fell open, and we thought we are bloody well going to have the courage to say it all publicly.

"I get awful letters from people who say they are going to come and murder me, and that Enoch Powell was right, and that I ought to have said they all ought to be sent back.

"But what saddens me is the newspapers, because I hoped and believed they would be on the same side in getting the police to get it right for the future."

Sir William said that unconscious racism was more dangerous in a way than out-and-out racism, "because it just sort of happens, and it fouls up the atmosphere between those who are misunderstood by the police when the police won't react properly to them and so on".

When asked: "Why are we racist?", Sir William replied: "How difficult to answer. I suppose in the end we started in this country by being a totally white insular population and there is a resistance to the gradual arrival, and the spread of immigration."

He went on: "Asylum seekers are one thing, but there are a tremendous number of people who come in legitimately, and so lots more places are going to become like Leicester because they tend to settle in the same area.

"It's something that's got to be not confronted, but accepted, because you can't do anything about it."

 The friend who saw Stephen Lawrence murdered today called on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to reverse his decision to reinstate a Metropolitan Police officer sacked for racism.

He described Mr Straw's decision to reinstate Pc Steve Hutt - sacked for calling a 14-year-old boy a "black bastard" - as a "concession to racism".

Duwayne Brooks, 25, was with 18-year-old Stephen when a white gang stabbed him to death in Eltham, south east London, in 1993.

In a letter to Mr Straw today, he said the Macpherson report into the killing had sparked a backlash in the police - and the campaign which led to the reinstatement of Mr Hutt was part of this.

Pc Hutt was sacked by the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, after he admitted shouting "sit down, you black bastard" during a struggle to arrest him. The decision was overturned by Mr Straw last month after thousands of police officers signed a petition demanding his reinstatement.

The mother of the child also condemned the decision to sack him. Pc Hutt admitted he had made the comment in a "moment of madness".

However, Mr Brooks said the campaign to reinstate the police officer was "coded racism".

A home office spokeswoman said Mr Brooks' letter had been received this morning. "We will be looking at it and responding in due course," she said.

webTitle: Patsy lands detective role in BBC series

fields.headline: Patsy lands detective role in BBC series
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Former EastEnders star Patsy Palmer is to make a TV comeback as a private eye, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Actress Patsy Palmer is set to make a return to primetime television less than a year after quitting EastEnders.

She will play a private investigator in a father and daughter team for a series originally written for her and the late actor, Ballykissangel star Tony Doyle.

BBC Northern Ireland has decided to push ahead with a full-blown series of McReady and Daughter following the success of the one-off pilot of the show last June.

Ms Palmer, who played Bianca Butcher in the BBC soap, will star alongside Lorcan Cranitch.

"I am delighted that the show has been commissioned and I am thrilled to be working with Lorcan again," she said.

Her co-star, who played Sean Dillon in the BBC's hugely popular Ballykissangel, added: "I am looking forward to taking on the challenging role of McCready again. Working with Patsy is so much fun."

Filming will begin in London this month and the series is expected to hit screens in the summer.

Kate Triggs, executive producer at BBC Northern Ireland, said: "Developing a new series for Patsy Palmer and Lorcan Cranitch has been a joy. As father and daughter in this series they light up the screen."
