Not only did he then shut down Athena Notes by returning the tiny bequest to the donorthe father-in-law of the editorbut, to encourage early retirement, he forced the deadest of the deadwood out of the courses they'd been delivering by rote for the last twenty or thirty years and into freshman English and the history survey and the new freshman orientation program held during the hot last days of the summer. He eliminated the ill-named Scholar of the Year Prize and assigned the thousand dollars elsewhere. For the first time in the college's history, he made people apply formally, with a detailed project description, for paid sabbatical leave, which was more often than not denied. He got rid of the clubby faculty lunchroom, which boasted the most exquisite of the paneled oak interiors on the campus, converted it back into the honors seminar room it was intended to be, and made the faculty eat in the cafeteria with the students. He insisted on faculty meetingsnever holding them had made the previous dean enormously popular. Coleman had attendance taken by the faculty secretary so that even the eminences with the three-hour-a-week schedules were forced onto the campus to show up. He found a provision in the college constitution that said there were to be no executive committees, and arguing that those stodgy impediments to serious change had grown up only by convention and tradition, he abolished them and ruled these faculty meetings by fiat, using each as an occasion to announce what he was going to do next that was sure to stir up even more resentment. Under his leadership, promotion became difficultand this, perhaps, was the greatest shock of all: people were no longer promoted through rank automatically on the basis of being popular teachers, and they didn't get salary increases that weren't tied to merit. In short, he brought in competition, he made the place competitive, which, as an early enemy noted, "is what Jews do." And whenever an angry ad hoc committee was formed to go and complain to Pierce Roberts, the president unfailingly backed Coleman. In the Roberts years all the bright younger people he recruited loved Coleman because of the room he was making for them and because of the good people he began hiring out of graduate programs at Johns Hopkins and Yale and Cornell"the revolution of quality," as they themselves liked to describe it. They prized him for taking the ruling elite out of their little club and threatening their self-presentation, which never fails to drive a pompous professor crazy. All the older guys who were the weakest part of the faculty had survived on the ways that they thought of themselvesthe greatest scholar of the year 100 b.c., and so forthand once those were challenged from above, their confidence eroded and, in a matter of a few years, they had nearly all disappeared. Heady times! But after Pierce Roberts moved on to the big job at Michigan, and Haines, the new president, came in with no particular loyalty to Colemanand, unlike his predecessor, exhibiting no special tolerance for the brand of bulldozing vanity and autocratic ego that had cleaned the place out in so brief a periodand as the young people Coleman had kept on as well as those he'd recruited began to become the veteran faculty, a reaction against Dean Silk started to set in. How strong it was he had never entirely realized until he counted all the people, department by department, who seemed to be not at all displeased that the word the old dean had chosen to characterize his two seemingly nonexistent students was definable not only by the primary dictionary meaning that he maintained was obviously the one he'd intended but by the pejorative racial meaning that had sent his two black students to lodge their complaint. I remember clearly that April day two years back when Iris Silk died and the insanity took hold of Coleman. Other than to offer a nod to one or the other of them whenever our paths crossed down at the general store or the post office, I had not really known the Silks or anything much about them before then. I hadn't even known that Coleman had grown up some four or five miles away from me in the tiny Essex County town of East Orange, New Jersey, and that, as a 1944 graduate of East Orange High, he had been some six years ahead of me in my neighboring Newark school. Coleman had made no effort to get to know me, nor had I left New York and moved into a two-room cabin set way back in a field on a rural road high in the Berkshires to meet new people or to join a new community. The invitations I received during my first months out here in 1993to come to a dinner, to tea, to a cocktail party, to trek to the college down in the valley to deliver a public lecture or, if I preferred, to talk informally to a literature classI politely declined, and after that both the neighbors and the college let me be to live and do my work on my own. But then, on that afternoon two years back, having driven directly from making arrangements for Iris's burial, Coleman was at the side of my house, banging on the door and asking to be let in. Though he had something urgent to ask, he couldn't stay seated for more than thirty seconds to clarify what it was. He got up, sat down, got up again, roamed round and round my workroom, speaking loudly and in a rush, even menacingly shaking a fist in the air whenerroneouslyhe believed emphasis was needed. I had to write something for himhe all but ordered me to. If he wrote the story in all of its absurdity, altering nothing, nobody would believe it, nobody would take it seriously, people would say it was a ludicrous lie, a self-serving exaggeration, they would say that more than his having uttered the word "spooks" in a classroom had to lie behind his downfall. But if I wrote it, if a professional writer wrote it . . . All the restraint had collapsed within him, and so watching him, listening to hima man I did not know, but clearly someone accomplished and of consequence now completely unhingedwas like being present at a bad highway accident or a fire or a frightening explosion, at a public disaster that mesmerizes as much by its improbability as by its grotesqueness. The way he careened around the room made me think of those familiar chickens that keep on going after having been beheaded. His head had been lopped off, the head encasing the educated brain of the once unassailable faculty dean and classics professor, and what I was witnessing was the amputated rest of him spinning out of control. Iwhose house he had never before entered, whose very voice he had barely heard beforehad to put aside whatever else I might be doing and write about how his enemies at Athena, in striking out at him, had instead felled her. Creating their false image of him, calling him everything that he wasn't and could never be, they had not merely misrepresented a professional career conducted with the utmost seriousness and dedicationthey had killed his wife of over forty years. Killed her as if they'd taken aim and fired a bullet into her heart. I had to write about this "absurdity," that "absurdity"I, who then knew nothing about his woes at the college and could not even begin to follow the chronology of the horror that, for five months now, had engulfed him and the late Iris Silk: the punishing immersion in meetings, hearings, and interviews, the documents and letters submitted to college officials, to faculty committees, to a pro bono black lawyer representing the two students . . . the charges, denials, and countercharges, the obtuseness, ignorance, and cynicism, the gross and deliberate misinterpretations, the laborious, repetitious explanations, the prosecutorial questionsand always, perpetually, the pervasive sense of unreality. "Her murder!" Coleman cried, leaning across my desk and hammering on it with his fist. "These people murdered Iris!" The face he showed me, the face he placed no more than a foot from my own, was by now dented and lopsided andfor the face of a well-groomed, youthfully handsome older manstrangely repellent, more than likely distorted from the toxic effect of all the emotion coursing through him. It was, up close, bruised and ruined like a piece of fruit that's been knocked from its stall in the marketplace and kicked to and fro along the ground by the passing shoppers. There is something fascinating about what moral suffering can do to someone who is in no obvious way a weak or feeble person. It's more insidious even than what physical illness can do, because there is no morphine drip or spinal block or radical surgery to alleviate it. Once you're in its grip, it's as though it will have to kill you for you to be free of it. Its raw realism is like nothing else. Murdered. For Coleman that alone explained how, out of nowhere, the end could have come to an energetic sixty-four-year-old woman of commanding presence and in perfect health, an abstract painter whose canvases dominated the local art shows and who herself autocratically administered the town artists' association, a poet published in the county newspaper, in her day the college's leading politically active opponent of bomb shelters, of strontium 90, eventually of the Vietnam War, opinionated, unyielding, impolitic, an imperious whirlwind of a woman recognizable a hundred yards away by her great tangled wreath of wiry white hair; so strong a person, apparently, that despite his own formidableness, the dean who reputedly could steamroll anybody, the dean who had done the academically impossible by bringing deliverance to Athena College, could best his own wife at nothing other than tennis. Once Coleman had come under attack, howeveronce the racist charge had been taken up for investigation, not only by the new dean of faculty but by the college's small black student organization and by a black activist group from Pittsfieldthe outright madness of it blotted out the million difficulties of the Silks' marriage, and that same imperiousness that had for four decades clashed with his own obstinate autonomy and resulted in the unending friction of their lives, Iris placed at the disposal of her husband's cause. Though for years they had not slept in the same bed or been able to endure very much of the other's conversationor of the other's friendsthe Silks were side by side again, waving their fists in the faces of people they hated more profoundly than, in their most insufferable moments, they could manage to hate each other. All they'd had in common as comradely lovers forty years earlier in Greenwich Villagewhen he was at NYU finishing up his Ph.D. and Iris was an escapee fresh from two nutty anarchist parents in Passaic and modeling for life drawing classes at the Art Students League, armed already with her thicket of important hair, big-featured and voluptuous, already then a theatrical-looking high priestess in folkloric jewelry, the biblical high priestess from before the time of the synagogueall they'd had in common in those Village days (except for the erotic passion) once again broke wildly out into the open . . . until the morning when she awakened with a ferocious headache and no feeling in one of her arms. Coleman rushed her to the hospital, but by the next day she was dead. "They meant to kill me and they got her instead." So Coleman told me more than once during that unannounced visit to my house, and then made sure to tell every single person at her funeral the following afternoon. And so he still believed. He was not susceptible to any other explanation. Ever since her deathand since he'd come to recognize that his ordeal wasn't a subject I wished to address in my fiction and he had accepted back from me all the documentation dumped on my desk that dayhe had been at work on a book of his own about why he had resigned from Athena, a nonfiction book he was calling Spooks. There's a small FM station over in Springfield that on Saturday nights, from six to midnight, takes a break from the regular classical programming and plays big-band music for the first few hours of the evening and then jazz later on. On my side of the mountain you get nothing but static tuning to that frequency, but on the slope where Coleman lives the reception's fine, and on the occasions when he'd invite me for a Saturday evening drink, all those sugary-sweet dance tunes that kids of our generation heard continuously over the radio and played on the jukeboxes back in the forties could be heard coming from Coleman's house as soon as I stepped out of my car in his driveway. Coleman had it going full blast not just on the living room stereo receiver but on the radio beside his bed, the radio beside the shower, and the radio beside the kitchen bread box. No matter what he might be doing around the house on a Saturday night, until the station signed off at midnightfollowing a ritual weekly half hour of Benny Goodmanhe wasn't out of earshot for a minute. Oddly, he said, none of the serious stuff he'd been listening to all his adult life put him into emotional motion the way that old swing music now did: "Everything stoical within me unclenches and the wish not to die, never to die, is almost too great to bear. And all this," he explained, "from listening to Vaughn Monroe." Some nights, every line of every song assumed a significance so bizarrely momentous that he'd wind up dancing by himself the shuffling, drifting, repetitious, uninspired, yet wonderfully serviceable, mood- making fox trot that he used to dance with the East Orange High girls on whom he pressed, through his trousers, his first meaningful erections; and while he danced, nothing he was feeling, he told me, was simulated, neither the terror (over extinction) nor the rapture (over "You sigh, the song begins. You speak, and I hear violins"). The teardrops were all spontaneously shed, however astonished he may have been by how little resistance he had to Helen O'Connell and Bob Eberly alternately delivering the verses of "Green Eyes," however much he might marvel at how Jimmy and Tommy Dorsey were able to transform him into the kind of assailable old man he could never have expected to be. "But let anyone born in 1926," he'd say, "try to stay alone at home on a Saturday night in 1998 and listen to Dick Haymes singing 'Those Little White Lies.' Just have them do that, and then let them tell me afterwards if they have not understood at last the celebrated doctrine of the catharsis effected by tragedy." Continue

fields.headline: Ebay technical hitch halts auctions
fields.trailText: 3.30pm:Online auctioneer eBay went offline for nearly 11 hours on Wednesday night, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Online auction powerhouse eBay went offline for nearly 11 hours on Wednesday night, disrupting trading and halting auctions.

According to the company, the problem was caused by a decision to delay the replacement of new computer equipment because of the Christmas rush.

Ebay said it did not expect any material loss from the outage, merely the irritation from customers unable to access their trading accounts.

Ebay is the busiest auction site in the world and recent company results showed it had hosted some 68.5m auctions in the previous quarter.

The outage isn't the first for eBay, nor the longest. The site was closed for 22 hours in June 1999, thanks to another problem with computing equipment.

While most websites wouldn't feel the ire of customers for such a relatively small technical problem, eBay users are often fanatics, and auctions taking place on the site have a time-sensitive element.

Bidders compete aggressively in some auctions, waiting until the sale is nearly closed before topping the final bid by pennies.

Ebay said that all auctions affected by the technical glitches would be extended by 24 hours, according to company policy.

The problems started sometime after 3pm, US eastern time, and continued until nearly 3am.

webTitle: Arafat, Barak and Clinton: the ABC of peace

fields.headline: Arafat, Barak and Clinton: the ABC of peace
fields.standfirst:
With little more than two weeks before Bill Clinton stands down as US president, crunch time for the Middle East peace negotiators is fast approaching. Derek Brown assesses the options open to the main players.
Special report: Israel &Middle East
fields.trailText: With little more than two weeks before Bill Clinton stands down as US president, crunch time for the Middle East peace negotiators is fast approaching. Derek Brown assesses the options open to the main players.
fields.body:
Now we really are down to the wire. With just 16 days to go before Bill Clinton leaves the White House, and 33 days before Israel makes a momentous choice of prime minister, Middle East peace prospects are trembling in the balance.

Both sides are poised to leap. One or both may yet pull back. It is the classic negotiating stage where neither policy nor events count. Only time matters.

Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak says that he will not start serious talks until there is a marked drop in Palestinian violence. That is pure bluster, as everyone knows.

Israeli negotiators are already at work in Washington, being chivvied along by a president who still lusts after a peace treaty. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat also plays a mean game of bluff. He has had his moment in the White House sun. Now he's off to Cairo to consult with Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak.

Much will be decided there. If Arafat appeals for Arab backing for compromise, then we will know the process is going ahead. If instead he calls for solidarity in resisting US/Israeli demands, then the game is up.

In one sense what is being played out in Washington is an elaborate charade. What is at stake is not a full-fledged final settlement, but an outline of one.

Filling in the details will take months of arduous and abrasive bargaining. And even if they get that far, there is the uncomfortable reality that peace is not so much about agreement, as about events on the ground.

The stones and the bullets are still flying. The zealots on both sides are still rousing their respective rabbles. They are more likely to be inflamed than appeased by the proposals on the table in Washington.

The latest scraps of detail to have filtered out indicate, tantalisingly, that Arafat may be prepared to budge on his main sticking-point: the right of return of Palestinian refugees. The US suggestion, which he has not rejected out of hand, is that the 4m or so refugees and their descendants will have an unqualified right of return to the new Palestinian state to be established on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip.

A token few - perhaps as many as 10,000 over several years - will also be allowed into Israel itself on "humanitarian" grounds.

A new refugee issue has emerged: Israel's longstanding but muted claim for compensation for the 800,000 or so Jews who fled their homes in the Middle East and elsewhere in the 1940s and 1950s. Successive governments have been reluctant to press the claim, for fear it would open up the bigger issue of Palestinian refugees.

Now it is out in the open, and Clinton is apparently suggesting the establishment of a compensation fund, with sizeable contributions from Europe and Japan. A much bigger issue for most Israelis is the future of Jerusalem. There is widespread shock that their government is prepared to concede even a token Palestinian presence in the Holy City, but the latest plan is even more dramatic:

Arafat will be offered all the Arab districts, including the Muslim and Christian quarters of the walled Old City, captured from Jordan in 1967. He would also have control of the religious complex known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as al-Haram al-Sharif.

Israel would, however, retain full sovereignty over the most sacred site in Judaism, the Western Wall, as well as the Jewish quarter of the Old City.

Such a deal would allow Arafat his cherished dream of establishing a Palestinian capital in Jerusalem. It would be a bitter pill for Israel to swallow, but Clinton is reportedly offering to sweeten it by leading the way for international recognition of the Jewish part of the city as Israel's capital.

He has even offered to pay a flying visit to lay the foundation stone of a US embassy in the city.

There remains one other outstanding issue: the exact boundaries of the new Palestine. Barak agreed in principle to hand over 95% of the West Bank - which will mean the forcible expulsion of tens of thousands of Jewish colonists - plus a chunk of Israel proper to be added on to the grossly overcrowded Gaza Strip.

The Palestinians, knowing Israel's propensity for slipping last-minute surprises into such arrangements, have a deep distrust of percentages. They want to see detailed maps showing precisely where their new state will be.

That will take longer than 16 days. But after more than half a century of conflict, peace is worth waiting for.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 5.
fields.trailText: January 5: Former BBC Radio and Music head Andria Vidler has been appointed as managing director of Capital Radio London.
fields.body:
Capital Radio has appointed former BBC Radio & Music division head of marketing and communications Andria Vidler as managing director for Capital Radio London.

Dennis Publishing has secured the licence to publish fitness magazines Shape and Men's Fitness in the UK.

Andersen Consulting will channel global business worth $175m into The Media Edge over the next three months, as the company is rebranded Accenture in the biggest ever business-to-business rebranding campaign.

Bailey's liqueur is to sponsor Channel 4's third series of Sex and the City in a deal said to be worth £1m.

JCDecaux has retained the £20m contract to sell London Transport Property's billboard portfolio.

Kingston Interactive Television has put its £25m media planning and buying account up for pitch as it embarks on a major marketing push throughout 2001.

The BBC is once again facing a combined attack from an alliance of commercial broadcasters who are against the BBC's proposals to significantly expand its digital television services.

The Post Office is to sponsor ITV's Wish You Were Here in a deal said to be worth in the region of £1.4m.

webTitle: Dot.coms fail to connect with customers

fields.headline: Dot.coms fail to connect with customers
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Despite spending millions on ad campaigns, dot.coms are failing to connect with customers claims a new report. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Despite burning millions of pounds on high-profile ad campaigns, dot.com brands are failing to connect with customers, according to a new report from consultant Interbrand.

Interbrand says that while online brands such as Amazon, Lastminute and Tesco Direct have succeeded in creating basic awareness, they are not striking the emotional bond with customers that is enjoyed by their offline counterparts.

The report comes at a time when there is intense shareholder scrutiny on dot.com marketing strategies due to plummeting share prices.

This week online auction brand QXL decided to scrap major ad campaigns in favour of a more sales-driven approach.

The report criticises online brands for continuing to focus on the "functional" aspects of their business such as price or speed of delivery, which offer only short-term competitive advantage, rather than building the essential element of brand "trust".

It says that even the best-known online brands lag a long way behind traditional brands in terms of the perceived authority and the relevance to consumers' lives that drive purchasing decisions.

Jez Frampton, managing director of Interbrand's interactive arm, said: "Creating pure brand awareness in the early stages is okay, but many dot.coms are now beyond that and need to make unique service promises."

Interbrand says Tesco's online delivery service, TescoDirect, had attained less than 50% of the customer commitment enjoyed by its supermarket brand.

"Traditional companies are not thinking hard enough about how to put their traditional businesses online," said Mr Frampton, "There needs to be greater understanding of the softer side of why customer might be buying from them."

fields.headline: Kufuor wins Ghana's run-off election
fields.trailText: Thousands of jubilant Ghanaians flooded into the streets last weekend to celebrate the election victory of the opposition presidential candidate, John Kufuor, and the exit of President Jerry John Rawlings after two decades in power.
fields.body:
Thousands of jubilant Ghanaians flooded into the streets last weekend to celebrate the election victory of the opposition presidential candidate, John Kufuor, and the exit of President Jerry John Rawlings after two decades in power.

There are widespread expectations of a political and economic upturn in the country, which was Africa's first to win independence in 1957. But Mr Kufuor and fellow leaders of the victorious New Patriotic party are calling for restraint - fearful of retaliation from hardliners and their military associates in the outgoing Rawlings regime.

"We must hold hands and tackle the challenges in a spirit of reconciliation," Mr Kufuor said. Three days earlier the military had parked an armoured car opposite Kufuor's house in a move condemned as intimidatory by his supporters.

Brandishing red, blue and white party flags, Mr Kufuor's supporters claimed a new era had begun for Ghana, whose economy remains weak and dependent after more than 15 years of Western-backed reform and authoritarian rule.

Mr Rawlings's nominated successor, John Atta Mills, conceded defeat to Mr Kufuor after the national Electoral Commission announced that he had won more than 56% of the vote in the second round of voting in Ghana's presidential elections last week.

The president wished his newly elected successor well. At a ceremony last Sunday marking the anniversary of the 1981 coup that brought him back to power, Mr Rawlings pledged to do everything possible to ensure a smooth transition.

"Let me seize this opportunity to congratulate Mr J Kufuor on his election," he said in an address broadcast to the nation. "I wish him well and hope he and his colleagues will be able to deliver their rapid promises. My government will do everything possible to make the transition smooth."

Mr Kufuor's victory marks the first real transfer of power through the ballot box in the West African nation.

Praising the elections, which had been marred by sporadic violence, the United Nations secretary-general Kofi Annan, a Ghanaian, said: "With these elections Ghana has demonstrated that democracy and its institutions are taking root in Africa."

Many of Ghana's West African neighbours such as Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea face a debilitating combination of armed rebellions and economic stagnation.

Mr Kufuor, a 62-year-old lawyer, will inherit a tough legacy after two months of bruising and divisive campaigning, and is expected to rely on advice from Ghana's business elite, who bankrolled his campaign. The value of the cedi currency has crashed from three cedis to $1 when Rawlings came to power in 1979 to its present level of 7,000 cedis to the dollar. Inflation and interest rates are running at more than 50%.

Despite successive World Bank reform programmes and some $6bn in foreign loans the economy is dependent on its main exports of cocoa and gold. The combination of low export prices and high oil import prices means Mr Kufuor's government will have little room to manoeuvre.

Mr Kufuor recognises that Mr Rawlings and his National Democratic Congress still have substantial support in the country, especially in the poorest regions in the east and north. Mr Rawlings's supporters say that he presided over a transition from military to constitutional rule that won much international backing and reformed the economy - even if most Ghanaians eking out a living of $2 a day have yet to see the benefits from this.

However, there are big questions about the future for Mr Rawlings, who has been accused by the opposition of gross human rights abuses, setting up his own militia and siphoning state funds to Europe.

"There will be no room for witch-hunts of individuals or groups," Mr Kufuor said at his victory press conference. "I will show President Rawlings the respect that is due him as former head of state."

Around 400 Ghanaians are thought to have been secretly killed during the Rawlings era: the most publicised case was the murder of three senior judges in the early 80s. The Observer

fields.headline: Francesco Rosi: Salvatore Giuliano
fields.standfirst: No 98
fields.trailText: It is almost certainly the best film about the social and political forces that have shaped [Sicily]... It looks almost like a documentary as it traces the career and downfall of a bandit who became a legend on the island after his violent death in 1950
fields.body:
Francesco Rosi, once called the heavy conscience of the Italian cinema, was born in Naples - a possible reason why most of his films are about corruption. His most famous film, though, was made in Sicily.

It is almost certainly the best film about the social and political forces that have shaped that benighted island. It looks almost like a documentary as it traces the career and downfall of Salvatore Giuliano, a bandit who became a legend on the island after his violent death in 1950. Yet the word Mafia is never once mentioned, and Giuliano himself is hardly seen. All the superficial cliches of a well-known genre are thus subverted.

Rosi performed the voiceover himself, at least in the Italian version, and structured the film round the bandit's death. Giuliano is seen as a corpse in the first sequence, with a city official reading a detailed description of his death. This gives us no clue to the questions we want answered - a deliberate ploy by Rosi, who is determined that we should think for ourselves as the film progresses. He merely provides evidence, often elliptical. But the result is a fascinating study not only of the tentacles of crime, but of a whole way of life.

We are not allowed to be passive spectators because we see Giuliano only briefly, with Rosi using flashbacks chronicling his story from the end of the second world war. We witness the growth of the Sicilian separatist movement, an attack on a communist peasant gathering, a kidnapping and the government, separatists, police and army linking up at various times with the criminal forces they are supposed to oppose.

Using local non-professionals as actors and with his camera sweeping over the mountainous terrain that concealed Giuliano from his enemies, Rosi builds up a formidable picture of a time and place. It is a style that has its roots in neo-realism, but Rosi is interested more in society than in the individual characters that other directors (such as Vittorio de Sica) examined so sympathetically. Giuliano remains a legend throughout; the nearest we get to a conventional figure is his murderer, who emerges from the background only as the film reaches its final stretch.

Everything in the film was based on extensive historical research, including official court records and journalistic accounts. But Rosi makes no attempt to make complete sense of them, since it is virtually impossible to do so. At the end of the film, what Rosi has carefully assembled is not so much the facts as a reading of what lies behind the confused story of Giuliano's life.

Possibly only Gillo Pontecorvo's The Battle of Algiers managed so brilliantly to summarise a slice of by now half-remembered history, and Rosi never quite achieved the same mastery of tone and atmosphere again. Later, he made Lucky Luciano, a more conventional Mafia story, and films such as The Mattei Case and Illustrious Corpses, dossiers on power and corruption that relied on a much more ornate style and the brilliance of actors such as the great Gian Maria Volonte to sustain their considerable eloquence.

But Salvatore Giuliano has never been bettered as an interpretation of history without resort to special pleading. It's as if the film-maker is standing back and providing clues that we have to interpret ourselves. This is something Hollywood would never do, and justifies European cinema as much as any other film of what now looks like a golden period.

fields.headline: Litmanen signs for Liverpool
fields.trailText: Liverpool have completed the signing of Jari Litmanen on a free transfer, according to the club's official website.
fields.body:
Liverpool have completed the signing of Jari Litmanen on a free transfer, according to the club's official website.

The Finnish international met his new Liverpool team-mates for the first time this morning, before putting pen to paper on a deal rumoured to be worth £55,000 a week.

A delighted Gerald Houllier was quick to insist that the 29-year-old Litmanen was one of the most exciting signings in Liverpool's history.

"We have signed a world-class player," he told the club's website (www.liverpoolfc.net). "He comes with a reputation which needs no improvement. He's one of the most exciting signings we have ever made.

"Jari knows all about Liverpool. He's a fan of the club and he wanted to play for us. He can play in a variety of positions in attack and will bring a different style of play than some of our other strikers.

"He is a player I'm aware this club has wanted for a long time and to get him on a free transfer is a snip. Another bonus for us is Jari is not European tied and so can play in the Uefa Cup," he added.

And the feeling seems mutual. Last night, Litmanen admitted he has always harboured ambitions of playing for Liverpool.

'It has always been my dream to play for Liverpool," he said. "I have supported them since I was a child and there has been talk about me joining them before.

"I seem to have been linked with every club in Europe but it's no secret that Liverpool have always been very special to me."

fields.headline: Could do better
fields.standfirst: They have no friends, they live alone, and they're usually bald, unstylish and have wrinkles in their foreheads from thinking so hard. Or that's what children said in a survey about maths teachers this week. John Dunford , who is one, balances the equation
fields.trailText: They have no friends, they live alone, and they're usually bald, unstylish and have wrinkles in their foreheads from thinking so hard. Or that's what children said in a survey about maths teachers this week. John Dunford , who is one, balances the equation.
fields.body:
Math teachers are nerds, we are told in a survey published this week. Researchers at Plymouth University asked 12 year olds in seven countries for their impressions of their maths teachers. The findings included expressions of the sort of kindness and generosity in which young teenagers specialise when talking about teachers or their parents.

Fat, bald nerds with glasses and beards apparently predominate at the front of maths classrooms. These sad figures are apparently seen as unmarried and unstylish, wrinkled from all the hard thinking that they have had to do in order to solve maths problems throughout their lives. At least the teachers in Britain are not seen as gun-toting terrorists, as their counterparts in Finland are.

As a maths teacher since 1970, I would like to put in a few good words for me and my colleagues. I cannot really recall anyone who might have been described as a nerd, even by 12 year olds with particularly fertile imaginations. I do recall one maths teacher in the 1970s who bred champion dogs. Both he and his dog were exceptionally hairy and could have fallen into the nerd category, but the dog was said to be the son of the animal in the Dulux advertisements and presumably would have qualified as a pedigree nerd.

Normality was the defining characteristic of my many other colleagues over the years - family people mostly, with a good range of interests from swimming and badminton to reading and cooking. They even went to the pub occasionally (when the everlasting marking was finished) and if they looked sad it was either the price of the drinks as a proportion of their teacher's salaries or the quality of the work they had just marked.

Why didn't Plymouth University do a survey about English or history teachers, I wonder? There must be something about maths teachers that invites sympathy or derision, or both. The trouble with maths from the pupils' viewpoint, of course, is that their answers are either right or wrong. In English, you can write a reasonably good essay; in history, you can get most of the required answer and feel pleased. Even when you do write a brilliant answer in these subjects, you never seem to get full marks. However, the teachers give you credit, even when you have only got part of the answer.

In maths, though, the pupil is often wrong and the teacher is always right. The marks range from zero to full marks and the difference between right and wrong is stark. That can be really irritating for pupils, in whose minds accusations of nerdishness must often surface in maths lessons.

There could be an age factor too. I may not find my colleagues nerdish, but I do recall my own maths teachers at school as coming into that category. One in particular, I recall, who wrote the textbook that we were using in some abstract part of A-level maths, was particularly unworldly. We didn't understand him, or his textbook, and the word nerd (had it been invented in the 60s) would have come to mind on days when we were feeling excessively polite.

There is, of course, a serious point in this research. We currently have a major crisis in the recruitment of specialist teachers to secondary schools and the most difficult subject in which to recruit is maths. For many years now, the government target for the recruitment of maths teachers has not been met. The country has reached the position where a very high proportion of each year's university maths graduates needs to be recruited into teaching in order to make up for the shortfall in previous years. Unfortunately, this crisis comes at a time when the economy is booming and there are many lucrative careers tempting potential maths teachers away from the classroom.

If maths teachers have an image of nerdishness, then lively 21 year olds, with clear memories of their own maths schoolteachers from three years earlier, are less likely to want to enter the teaching profession.

So, maths teachers, perhaps we had better smarten up our act after all. Straighten out the wrinkles that, the pupils in the survey believe, come from thinking too hard. Buy some stylish clothes. Shave off the beard. Take the pens out of your top pocket. And stop talking about quadratic equations.

On second thoughts, quadratic equations are fascinating and have many interesting applications in science and in the wider world. Let me tell you all about them.

Quod erat demonstrandum.

 John Dunford is general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association and was a maths teacher from 1970 until he retired as the head of Durham Johnston comprehensive school in Durham City in 1998.

webTitle: Egg ads prompt deluge of complaints

fields.headline: Egg ads prompt deluge of complaints
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Egg's latest TV ad campaign has prompted a flood of complaints from viewers, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Online bank Egg's latest TV advertising campaign has prompted a surge of complaints from the public alleging that they contain homosexual references and connotations of child abuse.

The Independent Television Commission said that it had received 81 complaints about the ad in November alone, but decided not to uphold any of them.

A series of four ads in Egg's "Love" campaign feature 'Rob', an over-familiar Egg representative who appears out of the blue in the daily routines of 'Stuart', an Egg customer.

Scenes include Rob washing Stuart's hair in the shower and cuddling up to him in bed saying how much Egg loved him. The ads end with children's voices singing "Egg and you, sitting in a tree, k-i-s-s-i-n-g".

The campaign was created by HHCL & Partners.

Complaints alleged that the ads were offensive because of their perceived homosexual references, that Rob was 'sinister', and that the use of the nursery rhyme was inappropriate because of a connection that could be made in people's minds between the behaviour of Rob and the issue of child abuse.

The ITC argued that all but one of the series of commercials had been cleared by the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre to be shown outside children's programmes.

It judged that although some viewers might have found the content distasteful, it did not consider the ads unsuitable for general viewing.

The commission said that it "did not consider that the ads either promoted or stereotyped any form of sexual preference but portrayed Rob as a farcically over-caring Egg rep in order to demonstrate how much Egg cared about its customers."

webTitle: London shares soar after US rates cut

fields.headline: London shares soar after US rates cut
fields.trailText: London shares rocketed in early trading today, in response to the US's surprise decision last night to slash interest rates.
fields.body:
London shares rocketed in early trading today, in response to the US's surprise decision last night to slash interest rates.

In the first few minutes of dealing, the FTSE-100 index of leading shares was up 144.8 points at 6184.7.

The TUC general secretary, John Monks, urged the Bank of England to follow the lead of the US Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, in cutting base interest rates, but some analysts said this was "premature talk".

US stock markets soared yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing nearly 300 points ahead and the Nasdaq up 324 points, following the Federal Reserve's decision.

The news came as a welcome relief for the FTSE-100, which has been on a downwards slide. Yesterday it dived 134 points, or 2.2%, falling perilously close to the psychologically important 6,000 mark.

Mr Monks said today: "We have got slowing growth in employment, our inflation is low and yet our interest rates are higher than in euroland and I think the time is right now for the governor of the Bank of England and his colleagues to be as bold as Mr Greenspan in the States."

"They are already below the chancellor's target and their job is to try to keep to that target of 2.5% inflation. They have got loads of scope."

The Federal Reserve's move was a sign that it was shifting its key target from that of avoiding inflation to one of avoiding recession, said Mr Monks.

He added: "Although we are not in recession in this country, as far as manufacturing is concerned things are grim and two out of three workers in manufacturing are working in factories where output is falling.

"That is what the bank needs to address. By cutting interest rates they will also have some effect on the exchange rate and move us closer to where the euro is."

However, analysts said it was too early to talk about a similar interest rate cut in the UK. Jeremy Batstone, head of research at Natwest Stockbrokers, said the situation in Britain was significantly different to that in the US, and while the UK economy was slowing it was "not in a tailspin".

He said: "UK rates are set with the UK economy in mind." He added that he expected rates to fall around Easter.

The American rate cut, Mr Batstone said, was "a very, very risky move... it's a gamble of epic proportions. The rationale is fair enough, but the extent of the cut is slightly surprising."

Top of the London share risers today were battered technology stocks, which put in across-the-board leaps. Colt Telecom leapt 16%, BT was 7% higher and Vodafone jumped 6%, while tech stocks including chip designer Arm, software group Sage and telecom equipment firm Energis all put in double-digit percentage hikes.

The shock rate cut came against a backdrop of data showing the US economy is slowing. It will be seen by many experts as an acknowledgement of the problems the US faces, and the concerns of a recession in the world's largest economy.

The Fed said the action had been taken in the light of further weakening in sales and production, lower consumer confidence and tight conditions in some sections of the financial markets.

Mr Greenspan's action will bring US rates down to 6%, the same level as UK interest rates.

Attention will now be focused on the US opening bell this afternoon, to see if the Dow Jones and technology-dominated Nasdaq will sustain further gains.

Economists called the initial reaction on the markets a knee-jerk response. Analysts in the UK thought the reaction had now been factored into the US markets and when they opened later today there would not be a dramatic movement.

Mr Monks said today: "We have got slowing growth in employment, our inflation is low and yet our interest rates are higher than in euroland and I think the time is right now for the governor of the Bank of England and his colleagues to be as bold as Mr Greenspan in the States." "They are already below the chancellor's target and their job is to try to keep to that target of 2.5% inflation. They have got loads of scope." The Federal Reserve's move was a sign that it was shifting its key target from that of avoiding inflation to one of avoiding recession, said Mr Monks. He added: "Although we are not in recession in this country, as far as manufacturing is concerned things are grim and two out of three workers in manufacturing are working in factories where output is falling. "That is what the bank needs to address. By cutting interest rates they will also have some effect on the exchange rate and move us closer to where the euro is." However, analysts said it was too early to talk about a similar interest rate cut in the UK. Jeremy Batstone, head of research at Natwest Stockbrokers, said the situation in Britain was significantly different to that in the US, and while the UK economy was slowing it was "not in a tailspin". He said: "UK rates are set with the UK economy in mind." He added that he expected rates to fall around Easter. The American rate cut, Mr Batstone said, was "a very, very risky move... it's a gamble of epic proportions. The rationale is fair enough, but the extent of the cut is slightly surprising." Top of the London share risers today were battered technology stocks, which put in across-the-board leaps. Colt Telecom leapt 16%, BT was 7% higher and Vodafone jumped 6%, while tech stocks including chip designer Arm, software group Sage and telecom equipment firm Energis all put in double-digit percentage hikes. The shock rate cut came against a backdrop of data showing the US economy is slowing. It will be seen by many experts as an acknowledgement of the problems the US faces, and the concerns of a recession in the world's largest economy. The Fed said the action had been taken in the light of further weakening in sales and production, lower consumer confidence and tight conditions in some sections of the financial markets. Mr Greenspan's action will bring US rates down to 6%, the same level as UK interest rates. Attention will now be focused on the US opening bell this afternoon, to see if the Dow Jones and technology-dominated Nasdaq will sustain further gains. Economists called the initial reaction on the markets a knee-jerk response. Analysts in the UK thought the reaction had now been factored into the US markets and when they opened later today there would not be a dramatic movement. webTitle: Orange rings up record Christmas sales

fields.headline: Orange rings up record Christmas sales
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Mobile phone operator Orange has announced record-breaking sales over Christmas, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange has announced record-breaking sales over Christmas, as the boom in handset sales shows no sign of ending.

Fourth-quarter figures showed the company added 1.56m UK mobile phone users, compared with 1.41m for last year, taking its number of customers to 9.83m.

It is timely boost for Orange ahead of its planned March flotation, when it faces the task of winning over a market sceptical of debt-laden telecoms operators.

"They were very good figures, but we are expecting rampant growth over the next few years anyway. The issue is not how many phones are out there, but how much is spent using them," said Mark James, telecoms analyst at Nomura.

The exorbitant cost of next-generation mobile phone licences and rolling out the new networks has saddled telecoms companies with massive debts.

Investors are beginning to question the wisdom of buying into companies that will not profit from their investments for years.

Nonetheless, today's figures could see the France Telecom-owned company overtake BT Cellnet as Britain's second largest mobile phone operator.

The BT subsidiary has 8.74m customers and will need bumper Christmas sales figures to retain its position.

BT Cellnet will reveal its sales figures next week, but admitted that hundreds of thousands of users could not activate their new phones over Christmas because its computer billings systems could not cope with the demand.

"Mobile phones were the most popular gift over Christmas, and we knew it would be a nightmare on Christmas day," said a BT Cellnet spokeswoman.

Market leader Vodafone will announce its figures later today, with analysts expecting total fourth-quarter mobile phone sales to clear 5m.

fields.headline: C4's Sword carves healthy niche
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: Channel 4's big winter drama, Sword of Honour, finished strongly last night picking up nearly 2.5m viewers, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's big winter drama, second world war saga Sword of Honour, grew stronger in its concluding instalment last night, finishing with nearly 2.5m viewers.

Sword of Honour, adapted by William Boyd from Evelyn Waugh's sprawling trilogy, pulled in 2.4m and an 11% share over two hours from 9pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Viewing figures were up 200,000 on Tuesday night, when the first part took 2.2m.

But in the first week of January last year, Longitude, another major Channel 4 drama adapted from a novel, notched up 2.9m.

Elsewhere last night the enduring appeal of David Jason's grumpy northern detective, DI Jack Frost, was again demonstrated on ITV.

A repeated Touch of Frost drew 9.1m and a 37% share to ITV from 8-10pm, comfortably seeing off all BBC1 opposition.

This included Escape to the Sun, a new docu-soap series following a year in the lives of ex-pats in Benidorm. It took 6.1m and a 25% share from 8.45pm.

Escape to the Sun was followed by Kevin and Perry's Girlfriends, a one-off special looking at the relationships between mothers and their teenage daughters, which averaged 5.8m from 9.15pm.

At 10pm last night ITV aired Ken and Me, a 60-minute profile of Coronation Street legend Bill Roache.

The documentary, award-winning film-maker Jane Treays' first since moving to Granada from United Productions, drew 5.8m and a 30% share.

Earlier in the evening, Channel 5 offered the first part of a documentary series designed to bring out the five-year-old boy in all grown men.

Big Stuff, featuring the world's most powerful tug and largest nuclear submarine, attracted 1.2m and a 5% share from 8-9pm.

fields.headline: Jazz enjoys fleeting revival
fields.standfirst: America's greatest art form is back in vogue thanks to a major documentary series. But not for long, fears Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: America's greatest art form is back in vogue thanks to a major documentary series. But not for long, fears Michael Ellison in New York.
fields.body:
Here it comes again: it, one more time, is the great jazz revival, the latest attempt to restore to its rightful place at the centre of American life arguably the only art form to which the nation has given birth.

The CDs are in the shops, as are the video and DVD collections, the sumptuous coffee-table book is there for the taking and the website is up and running. The main event, a 17.5-hour documentary series, starts next week.

Of course, the CDs have always been in the shops. It's just that no one has paid much attention for a long, long time. Once, during the swing era (no, not the novelty craze of a couple of years back), the genre accounted for 70% of record sales.

Now it is 3%, about the same as classical music. It doesn't take a genius - here, genius is a synonym for Louis Armstrong - to work out that if this cultural reconditioning doesn't work, nothing will prevent the music from returning permanently to its familiar redoubts: the dungeon, the supper club and the conservatory.

The project is in the hands of Ken Burns, once described by the New York Times as "the most accomplished documentary film-maker of his generation," who, quite apart from his other achievements, knows how to develop a taste for the recondite. Until he started work on the series, Burns had only two jazz albums in his collection: now he listens to little else.

The Burns track record is formidable: the last 20 of his 47 years have produced 18 films or series. Jazz, the latest, is the final part in what he has come to see as a trilogy, the other constituent parts being The Civil War (1990), and Baseball (1994).

The rationale for the set of three is fixed by something the essayist Gerald Early said to him: "When they come to study our American civilisation 2,000 years from now, we'll be known for three things: the constitution, baseball and jazz music."

His ouvre is taken to address the constitution through the civil war because this was its greatest challenge (please, let's not get into the recent "election").

At least 40m watched each of the first two series and were informed, entertained, possibly even irritated occasionally, by his wistful, elegiac and politically correct style, granted an additional layer of gravitas by sagacious talking heads.

But neither of these had the marketing clout of Jazz. There is a five-CD boxed set; a single CD compilation of 20 of the pieces contained therein; 22 CDs devoted to the works of individual musicians; the Burns hall of fame; the book; the DVDs; the videos; and music from the series is infiltrating pro-basketball games and Starbucks coffee shops.

A look at the branding for all of these, under the title Ken Burns Jazz, produces the unsettling feeling that someone might be led to believe that this music exists now only because of the film-maker's recent fascination with it.

It's a fair bet, though, that those with an interest in music and who would like to know more about jazz will be delighted, even if they do find it difficult to make time for each of 10 nearly-two-hour episodes broadcast over three weeks.

But Burns shares with Wynton Marsalis, the trumpeter and chief executive officer of Jazz at Lincoln Centre, the preservation hall precept that all the best jazz has been made already and that conservation is what the music requires. The last 25 years of jazz history is dispensed with in about 30 minutes.

And, understandably in view of the general nature of the target audience, the story is told through a few towering figures: Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Benny Goodman, Charlie Parker and Miles Davis.

A judicious article (even if it does include the word "seminal") in the New Yorker at the end of last year identifies without condemning Burns just a few of those who have been excluded or given scant attention.

Take Charles Mingus. His music has been celebrated by some of New York's finest jazz musicians every Thursday night for the past 10 years at the Fez in Manhattan, but he is a fleeting figure in the film. Incongruously, the bass player and composer is one of the 22 allowed a CD of his own in the Ken Burns series.

Burns says that he left more battles and generals out of The Civil War and more big moments out of Baseball, without attracting so many complaints as has his latest documentary. The series is expected to be shown in the United Kingdom before the end of the year. It would be a pity if by then jazz, whatever the quibbles about the Burns, had simply been returned, bearing a few lacerations, to the aficionado.

Heineken is emerging as the most likely bidder for Bass Brewers following the government ruling that Interbrew must sell the business to an officially approved buyer.

Nestle is considering rolling out a range of novel food products after signing a deal with UK company BioProgress Technology International, which has developed an alternative to gelatin.

News Group , which owns the Sun and News of the World, is reviewing the future of its online properties including Page3.com and Supergoals.com.

HSBC Holdings has appointed Canadian advertising guru Peter Stringham as its new marketing supremo.

Virgin Interactive , the games publishing arm of Virgin, has appointed Roy Campbell, managing director of rival Infogrames, to run its UK operation.

Diageo-owned Guinness has back-tracked on plans to appoint a single global agency, instead splitting its £50m advertising business between roster agencies Abbott Mead Vickers.BBDO and Saatchi & Saatchi.

webTitle: Integrated staff must have a fair hearing

fields.headline: Integrated staff must have a fair hearing
fields.standfirst: Without sufficient consultation and the opportunity to take full account of staff concerns service integration cannot succeed
fields.trailText: Comment: In the quest for full integration, service care staff are failing to be adequately consulted on the new roles they will be expected to undertake, writesGeoff Martin
fields.body:
"Integration" is one of those words you find liberally scattered around service planning documents in an effort to conjure up a warm and cosy feeling that everything is going to be just fine in the future, with the all the different bits and pieces pulling together for the common good.

There are some other classic examples from the report authors lexicon designed to convey the same rosy glow - partnership, harmonisation, seamless and Chelsea 5-Manchester United 0 - are all commonly used, the last one by me at least, to reinforce the impression that all will be well just as soon as the next strategic plan is bolted into place.

The sell-out show in town at the moment, as far as social care is concerned, is the integration of adult mental health services under a single umbrella. I've waded though a number of consultation documents on this subject covering various parts of London and, believe me, every cliche in the book has been dusted down, patted on the head and sent into action to convince the world that this really is the big one.

Call me cynical, but having talked all this through with several front line staff from both health and social services, I remain to be convinced. Don't get me wrong, the principal of service integration doesn't bother me too much and I can certainly see the merits, but the headlong rush to hit phase three - full integration - is hurtling along with only cursory consultation with the front-line staff and the service users.

This is a massive oversight. Apart from anything else, the logistics in terms of staffing arrangements are a minefield. I was recently talking to a manager from social services who had been seconded over to the NHS without being briefed on appropriate disciplinary procedures - would it be the local government procedure, Whitley Council or did the NHS trust have its own local arrangements? Make a mistake on something as fundamental as this and it's a short journey to the employment tribunal.

The point has also been made to me in no uncertain terms about the democratic deficit. At least local government services, despite all the fiddling around with cabinets and scrutiny committees, are theoretically controlled by elected councillors who you can vote out when they screw things up. The NHS is controlled from top to bottom by appointed quangos beholden to one form of patronage or another. Increasing the power of the quango can hardly be dressed up as a great leap forward.

But importantly for the workers who will be expected to deliver the brave new world of service integration is the question of terms and conditions. Most staff are being shovelled across from social services to health on secondment - I always thought secondments were voluntary but that no longer appears to be the case. In Manchester, where a full-scale adult mental health partnership has been established, social services staff have transferred to the new employer with TUPE protection of terms and conditions.

But the TUPE protection will not last indefinitely. The drive to harmonise terms and conditions will be unstoppable. Anyone familiar with local government and the NHS will know that the differences in pay scales, service conditions, pension arrangements and procedure are colossal.

The real danger in all of this is that the financial pressures in both sectors will be the dominant force and, rather than levelling up to best practice, the accountants will see the exercise as an opportunity to hack back costs. One thing's for sure, an integrated service that doesn't take full account of staff concerns is not going to stay integrated for long.

webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: What the Middle East papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Derek Brown reviews the press response to the latest twists and turns in the peace negotiations.
fields.body:
One of the more popular words being used to describe the tortuous peace negotiations in Washington is, for obvious reasons, 'rollercoaster'. Over the past 24 hours hopes have dimmed and brightened again with each scrap of information emerging from the talks.

The latest issue of the news magazine Jerusalem Report carries details of the draft settlement, featuring several sweeteners for Israeli public opinion.

They include compensation - funded in Europe and Japan - for the 800,000 Jewish refugees uprooted from their homes in the Middle East and elsewhere from the late1940s onward. Palestinian refugees, meanwhile, will have to give up their cherished 'right of return' to Israel but will be allowed to settle in the new Palestine.

The magazine predicts that prime minister Ehud Barak is about to embark on a pre-election PR blitz to win public support: "Barak's main argument in promoting the deal will be that, without it, the Middle East will slide toward even greater instability and possibly war, and that with the accord, there is at least a chance for stability and the creation of a system of mutually beneficial regional relations. It is this message that Barak hopes will win him re-election on February 6."

The liberal Tel Aviv daily Ha'aretz points out that even if outline agreement is reached, it will only be the prelude to long and arduous negotiation over the details.

The paper also highlights the wider Arab dimension: "Arafat is expected to report today to the Arab foreign ministers monitoring committee, which will meet in Cairo, on the result of his talks in Washington. At the end of the meeting, it will become clear whether the Palestinians are seeking the support of the Arab leadership in a compromise arrangement with Israel, or their support in blocking the Clinton initiative. If Arafat asks Clinton to immediately initiate rapid negotiations toward an agreement of principles, Israel will not be able to turn its back and chance a further deterioration in the territories and an escalation in regional tensions."

The rightwing Jerusalem Post, which strongly opposes the current proposals, weighs in with a leader questioning Barak's right to initial an agreement in the run-up to the February 6 prime ministerial election.

The paper backs the government's own attorney-general, Elyakim Rubinstein, who issued an open letter to the prime minister last week saying he had a legal, but not a moral, right to negotiate: "Rubinstein is right that Barak's claim that he currently has the right to take steps that will affect, not just the next government, but the future of Israel for generations to come, is breathtakingly undemocratic and stretches the test of 'reasonableness' far beyond the breaking point. It points out that the steadily mounting statistics of death and injury in the Palestinian territories mask the human dimension of the conflict.

Most contributors heartily favour the tactic. "The surgical removal of belligerents is far preferable to carpet-bombing. Tanks and artillery do collateral damage. Professional snipers rarely do," writes one.

fields.headline: Press Gazette round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 5.
fields.trailText: January 5: Express editor Rosie Boycott is in talks with Northern & Shell about her departure settlement.
fields.body:
Express editor Rosie Boycott is in talks with Northern & Shell about a settlement for her departure from the paper. Lawyers are discussing the terms of her package, as new names for the editorship are being lined up, with internal candidates Michael Pilgrim and Chris Williams now thought to be front-runners.

Former Maxim editor Chris Maillard is poised to launch a new free magazine to compete with Time Out, backed by £500,000 of investment, called London.co.uk.

A shake-up at BBC News is expected to follow the general election, with Tony Hall's departure thought to be imminent.

Premier Media Partners has beaten off competition from rivals to hold on to the contract for the British Airways magazine High Life.

The owners of the Newcastle Morning News , the rival to Associated Newspapers' Metro, have indicated that they will pull out of the morning commuter newspaper market and sell the title to Trinity Mirror.

Dennis Publishing has bought the licence to publish Men's Fitness and Shape from Mollin Publishing, after the company announced it was going into administration.

webTitle: BT sells properties to reduce debt

fields.headline: BT sells properties to reduce debt
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Telecoms giant BT may sell up to 7,500 properties to reduce its debt burden, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT is leaving no stone unturned in attempts to reduce its debt burden, after announcing a £2bn property sell-off.

The telecoms giant has compiled a shortlist of buyers for 30% of its 7,500 properties, which are mainly located in London, Glasgow, Birmingham and Manchester.

BT will sell the leasehold on the remaining 70%, which are operational buildings such as telephone exchanges. The company stressed that it will retain the freehold and exclusive control of those properties.

"This approach realises the value of these assets and increases shareholder value by enabling BT to focus on its core business rather than acting as owners and managers of an extensive property estate," said Geoffrey Almeida, chief executive of BT Business Services.

City analysts have been clamouring for BT to tackle its debt mountain, which is expected to reach £30bn by the middle of the year.

A partial break-up of the company was announced in November, including the proposed £10bn flotation of its mobile phone division.

Most of the debt has originated from shelling out billions of pounds for European mobile phone licences and overseas acquisitions.

However, BT is not alone in its predicament: the Financial Services Authority in the UK has warned banks about excessive lending to telecoms operators, who are fighting for a foothold in the next-generation mobile phone market.

BT shares rose 6% to 593p in early trading as technology, media and technology stocks surged on the back of yesterday's half-point cut in US interest rates.

fields.headline: Boycott poised to leave Express
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Express editor Rosie Boycott could leave the newspaper within 24 hours, according to sources, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Express editor Rosie Boycott could leave the newspaper within 24 hours, according to sources.

Lawyers for Ms Boycott are believed to be thrashing out details of a financial package with lawyers for Express owner Northern & Shell, which will pay her for the severance of her annual contract.

Her deputy, Chris Blackhurst, is also thought to be on the point of resigning.

Meanwhile, it is thought that Express owner Mr Desmond favours an internal candidate to replace Ms Boycott, with names in the frame including associate editor Chris Williams, Sunday Express executive editor Michael Pilgrim and assistant editor Robert Jobson.

Outside candidates whose names have been mentioned in connection with the job include Mirror editor Piers Morgan, former News of the World editor Phil Hall, former Daily Record editor Martin Clarke, OK! editor Martin Townsend and People editor Neil Wallis.

However, one source said: "Desmond does not want an outsider. He does not want someone who will come in with an entourage and big plans for the paper. What he wants is an insider, somebody who will not rock the boat."

Journalists are anticipating job cuts in editorial departments after the end of the compulsory three-month consultation period after any company takeover.

Speculation from within Express Newspapers that the company plans to rely more heavily on news from Press Association has been denied by the PA chief Paul Potts.

Neither Ms Boycott nor Northern & Shell were available for comment.

fields.headline: Britain 'developing new hi-tech bomb'
fields.trailText: Britain is developing its own version of a controversial hi-tech bomb, the use of which by the Russians in Chechnya has sparked  protests from human rights campaigners, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Britain is developing its own version of a controversial hi-tech bomb, the use of which by the Russians in Chechnya has sparked protests from human rights campaigners, it was reported today.

The thermobaric munition uses a massive wave of heat and blast pressure rather than high explosive to destroy buildings and kill humans over a large area.

BBC Radio 4's Today programme claimed that the weapon was already in development by the Defence Evaluation and Research Agency (DERA) in Kent and may be in service by 2005.

However, a statement given to the programme by the Ministry of Defence suggested that Britain's plans may be less well-advanced.

It read: "We are currently investigating the possibility. It is possible that this might involve a thermobaric solution. We would, of course, ensure that this is fully in accordance with international law."

But Today claimed that Major Ian Orr, commander of the Army Urban Warfare Training Team, had assured its reporter that development was already under way at DERA.

The weapon - the effect of which has been compared to that of a tactical nuclear bomb - has caused concern among the military because it renders conventional body armour useless.

And it has sparked protests from human rights campaigners, who claim that it is disproportionate and indiscriminate in its effects, as it causes massive internal injuries to anyone, including innocent civilians, within range of its blast.

According to Today, Britain's version of the weapon would be less devastating than the Russian devices used in the Chechen capital Grozny, and would be designed specifically to limit civilian casualties.

fields.headline: Redknapp makes £6m bid for Southgate
fields.trailText: West Ham are preparing a £6m bid for Aston Villa's transfer-listed defender Gareth Southgate.
fields.body:
West Ham are preparing a £6m bid for Aston Villa's transfer-listed defender Gareth Southgate.

"I rate Gareth highly, both as a player and a professional, and it's time we put in an offer," West Ham manager Harry Redknapp told today's London Evening Standard.

But Redknapp claimed he would not match Villa's asking price of £10m for 30-year-old Southgate, describing it as "way too high".

In recent months, Villa manager John Gregory has been adamant that he will not listen to offers of less than £10m for the English international defender. But according to the Standard, Southgate is unhappy about what he considers to be an unrealistic fee set by Villa - and has asked Gregory to lower it.

Redknapp is also still keen on Rangers defender Lorenzo Amoruso. "I wouldn't mind having both Southgate and Amoruso at Upton Park. Lorenzo has a presence about him. He's strong and powerful," the Hammers boss admitted today.

webTitle: Minister accused of 'rubber stamping' BBC digital plans

fields.headline: Minister accused of 'rubber stamping' BBC digital plans
fields.standfirst:
Letter to Chris Smith
Jan 3: Commercial TV giants challenge BBC
fields.trailText:
10.45am:Commercial TV companies have launched a furious attack on culture secretary Chris Smith over the BBC's new digital services, reports Jason Deans.
Letter to Chris Smith
Jan 3: Commercial TV giants challenge BBC
fields.body:
BSkyB, MTV and other commercial TV companies have launched a furious attack on culture secretary Chris Smith, accusing him of presiding over a "rubber stamping exercise" in relation to the BBC's new digital TV services.

In a strongly worded letter sent to Mr Smith, seven broadcasters said they were "writing to register our strongest concern" at the lack of any information about the criteria the government is using to approve the launch of five new BBC TV channels including BBC3, BBC4 and two new children's channels.

Pulling no punches, they said they had "a right to expect...our views to be taken properly into account".

The letter said: "We are extremely concerned that the BBC is behaving as if it had been given tacit consent to build their plans for new services, without the proper process being adhered to.

"We believe this is significant because it suggests to us that the new proposals process is perceived as simply a rubber stamping exercise by the BBC and Department of Culture, Media and Sport."

The broadcasters also ask Mr Smith to publish the approval guidelines as soon as possible, because "the BBC appears to be implementing its new service proposals prior to your official consent".

The letter, signed by senior TV figures including BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball and Telewest chief executive Adam Singer, also proposes some changes to the approval criteria for new BBC services.

The lobbying group believes the BBC should be required to demonstrate that each new service would be "distinctive from what already exists in the market", as well as market failure in that programming area.

The BBC's commercial rivals are also asking that the corporation be required to provide "much more detailed financial, marketing and programming information to enable the industry and relevant regulators to make an informed assessment" of the impact of any new licence-fee funded service on the market.

The letter was also signed by Turner Broadcasting Europe UK managing director Mick Buckley; MTV Networks Europe chief executive Brent Hansen; Artsworld chief executive John Hambley; Nickelodeon UK general manager Paul Lindley; and Discovery Networks Europe managing director Joyce Taylor.
