webTitle: Initial success in mobile numbers game

fields.headline: Initial success in mobile numbers game
fields.standfirst: Technological afterthought surprises phone companies to bring in £4bn of profits
fields.trailText: Technological afterthought surprises phone companies to bring in £4bn of profits.
fields.body:
RUF2T? AFAIK IL BL8, PCM. The language may look like gobbledegook but it is fuelling business worth nearly £4bn a year in profits to Europe's mobile phone operators.

The apparent nonsense is a series of terminologies developed by mobile users for text messaging. It reads: "Are you free tonight? As far as I know, I am going to be late. Please call me." It is one of dozens of shorthand ways that young people are using to stay in touch on their mobiles.

Figures over the next few days from the leading networks are expected to confirm that mobile phones were the most popular gift at Christmas and delivered a further boost to text messaging, the fastest growing mobile service in Europe.

The so-called short messaging service (SMS) allows the exchange of up to 160 characters between mobile phones. Last month an estimated 20bn text messages were sent worldwide, a seven-fold increase on December 1999.

The service is mostly used by tech-savvy types aged 24 or less who are attracted by the low cost and the fact that what they have to say doesn't necessarily require a full telephone conversation.

On Virgin Mobile, the average customer sends and receives 20 to 40 messages per month, according to spokesman Steven Day. Several heavy users send up to 3,000 a month - or 100 per day. "In the last two years mobile messaging has really taken off," said Mr Day.

"The youth market are the heaviest users. There have even been instances of kids taking their mobiles into school exams and text messaging each other the answers to test questions."

The popularity of text messaging has delivered an unlikely windfall for mobile phone network operators.

The technology was designed almost as an afterthought and it was initially targeted at the corporate market. Businesses were at first unimpressed but are now starting to use it to keep in touch with colleagues and transmit company announcements.

On the other hand consumers took to the medium immediately. Each message costs the user about 10p to send and nothing to receive. Margins can be as high as 90% for some operators. "European carriers make around €6bn (£3.8bn) from SMS each year but three years ago it was a zero euro industry," said Joe Cunningham, head of wireless strategy at software group Logica.

Popularity is likely to wane slightly from spring when networks are expected to introduce an estimated 3p charge to connect users' messages to operators other than their own.

The increase is unlikely to put off marketing companies who have started to understand the value of being able to message adverts and promotions direct to consumers' hands.

A mobile marketing firm recently caused mayhem in the Lakeside shopping centre, Thurrock, when it sent out a "location-sensitive" text message to shoppers offering a free pair of Reebok trainers to whoever turned up at a new shop with their phone. The store manager was inundated with visitors and most were turned away empty-handed.

Worldpop, the cross-media pop and dance music portal, piloted a successful text messaging marketing campaign on Ibiza this summer.

More than 3,000 holiday makers signed up to received messaged offers of reduced entry into nightclubs in return for also being sent a few adverts from firms like Durex, the Ministry of Sound and budget airline Go, a Worldpop spokesman said.

Amnesty International is harnessing text messages to apply speedy pressure on Governments to release political prisoners. Instead of physically signing a petition supporters can text-message their support as and when new instances of human rights violations and torture are highlighted by the pressure group.

Logica has been one of the biggest British beneficiaries as a result of providing the technology platforms that enable network operators like Orange and One2One to send and receive text messages.

The systems cost tens of millions of pounds to install but pay for themselves in about 12 weeks, said Logica's Mr Cunningham.

Today Logica carries more than 60% of global SMS traffic, accounting for £127m or 15% of total group annual revenues.

Technological advances will soon allow users in Britain to send colour pictures, music and even video clips instead of just plain text.

"Phones are already starting to come out with built-in cameras that allow you to push a button and send a picture as a message immediately," said Mr Cunningham. "The medium is becoming easier and more entertaining to use. We don't see growth slowing."

BTDT Been there, done that

c%d Could

CID Consider it done

CUL8r See you later

DXNRE Dictionary

GAL Get a life

HHOJ Ha ha only joking

IL BL8 I am going to be late

MbR$d Embarrassed

OMG Oh my god

PCM Please call me

RUF2T Are you free to talk?

w%d Would

It is one of dozens of shorthand ways that young people are using to stay in touch on their mobiles. Figures over the next few days from the leading networks are expected to confirm that mobile phones were the most popular gift at Christmas and delivered a further boost to text messaging, the fastest growing mobile service in Europe. The so-called short messaging service (SMS) allows the exchange of up to 160 characters between mobile phones. Last month an estimated 20bn text messages were sent worldwide, a seven-fold increase on December 1999. The service is mostly used by tech-savvy types aged 24 or less who are attracted by the low cost and the fact that what they have to say doesn't necessarily require a full telephone conversation. On Virgin Mobile, the average customer sends and receives 20 to 40 messages per month, according to spokesman Steven Day. Several heavy users send up to 3,000 a month - or 100 per day. "In the last two years mobile messaging has really taken off," said Mr Day. "The youth market are the heaviest users. There have even been instances of kids taking their mobiles into school exams and text messaging each other the answers to test questions." The popularity of text messaging has delivered an unlikely windfall for mobile phone network operators. The technology was designed almost as an afterthought and it was initially targeted at the corporate market. Businesses were at first unimpressed but are now starting to use it to keep in touch with colleagues and transmit company announcements. On the other hand consumers took to the medium immediately. Each message costs the user about 10p to send and nothing to receive. Margins can be as high as 90% for some operators. "European carriers make around €6bn (£3.8bn) from SMS each year but three years ago it was a zero euro industry," said Joe Cunningham, head of wireless strategy at software group Logica. Popularity is likely to wane slightly from spring when networks are expected to introduce an estimated 3p charge to connect users' messages to operators other than their own. The increase is unlikely to put off marketing companies who have started to understand the value of being able to message adverts and promotions direct to consumers' hands. A mobile marketing firm recently caused mayhem in the Lakeside shopping centre, Thurrock, when it sent out a "location-sensitive" text message to shoppers offering a free pair of Reebok trainers to whoever turned up at a new shop with their phone. The store manager was inundated with visitors and most were turned away empty-handed. Worldpop, the cross-media pop and dance music portal, piloted a successful text messaging marketing campaign on Ibiza this summer. More than 3,000 holiday makers signed up to received messaged offers of reduced entry into nightclubs in return for also being sent a few adverts from firms like Durex, the Ministry of Sound and budget airline Go, a Worldpop spokesman said. Instead of physically signing a petition supporters can text-message their support as and when new instances of human rights violations and torture are highlighted by the pressure group. Logica has been one of the biggest British beneficiaries as a result of providing the technology platforms that enable network operators like Orange and One2One to send and receive text messages. "The medium is becoming easier and more entertaining to use. We don't see growth slowing." fields.headline: 'Blinding neglect' of care
fields.trailText: Police and social services were incompetent and negligent when they allowed an eight-year-old girl to return home to her death, a jury at the Old Bailey in London was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Police and social services were incompetent and negligent when they allowed an eight-year-old girl to return home to her death, a jury at the Old Bailey in London was told yesterday.

The jury heard that three London boroughs knew of the plight of Anna Climbié, who died from hypothermia and neglect after allegedly being trussed up in a bath and made to eat like a dog - but they failed to act.

"Police and social services, those people exhibited a truly blinding degree of incompetence," said Nigel Rumfitt, QC, defending.

The court was hearing the summing up in the case of Marie Thérèse Kouao, 44, and her former boyfriend Carl Manning, 28, who are accused of murdering Anna in February of last year. Kouao denies all charges whilst Manning has admitted manslaughter and child cruelty.

Linda Stern, prosecuting, told the jury that a police officer and a social worker were responsible for Anna being returned to Manning's flat in Tottenham, north London, where she eventually died of neglect and hypothermia.

A Home Office pathologist had described Anna's case as the worst case of child abuse he had encountered and the jury was reminded that the child had suffered months of neglect, was critically undernourished, had been bound up, and had been exposed to wet as well as cold resulting in progressive hypothermia.

Mrs Stern told the jury that child protection officer Karen Jones had been "incompetent in her handling of the case" along with social worker Lisa Arthur-Worry, and both had been heavily criticised for their lack of care in the case.

Michael Gledhill, defending Kouao, criticised London councils for refusing to help a woman and small child because they were deemed to be intentionally homeless after moving to London from France.

The court was told Kouao brought Anna from the Ivory Coast to London via France for what the child believed was a better education and life.

"Anna left the sunshine of the Ivory Coast and went to France with Marie Therese Kouao. She left a loving family as a healthy, happy little girl... Just under a year later she was dead," said Mrs Stern, who added that Kouao was a cunning, manipulative liar.

Mr Rumfitt described Manning as "a bit of a nerd". He went on: "What transformed a harmless nerd like that into a man who causes Anna to die? We say that Marie Therese Koauo is a devious, dishonest, manipulative woman."

The case continues.

fields.headline: ANM launches femail.co.uk portal
fields.trailText: 10am: Associated New Media is to launch its revamped women's internet portal, femail.co.uk, on Saturday, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Associated New Media believes it can take the heartland of the tricky women's internet portal market with its reincarnated women's portal, femail.co.uk.

Launching on Saturday, femail.co.uk will be a more tightly focused product than its forerunner, Charlottestreet.com, aiming unashamedly for the more traditional Daily Mail readership of ABC1 women aged 30-50.

"We think we can get it right," said Ted Verity, editorial director of Associated New Media.

"Associated Newspapers knows how to talk to women. We've owned the market in the offline world for 20 years and we think we can do it online too."

The portal will be headed by Maria Trkjula, formerly deputy editor of Now Magazine and editor of Associated-owned Zoom.co.uk, with an editorial staff of 15.

Mr Verity said the site would be "anything but the Daily Mail online", with original content from columnists and celebrities including marriage counsellor Zelda West-Meads, TV chief Nigel Slater, Julia Carling and Princess Diana's astrologer Debbie Frank.

Some content will also be taken from the Femail section of the Daily Mail.

Charlottestreet.com, which launched more than a year ago amid a blaze of publicity, has been reduced to a strand within femail.co.uk.

"Femail is a much better brand partly because of the play on email and because it is an established women's brand, " said Mr Verity.

"Two years ago people were more keen on exotic names but now the internet is more grown up."

The company refused to disclose how much it is spending on the launch but in December it reported investments of £69m in its websites and Metro newspapers. And in 1999, it ploughed more than £20m into internet services.

The launch comes at the end of a turbulent year for internet services targeted at women, with sites including IPC's Beme.com, Charlottestreet, the National Magazine Company's ukwomen.com and icircle.com all competing for custom.

Even the market leader, ivillage, has recently seen its stock plunge with the loss of several senior executives.

Associated New Media's high-profile managing director, Martin Dunn, left the post last year, less than a year after the creation of Charlottestreet.com.

Mr Verity said femail.co.uk would initially rely on advertising for the bulk of its revenue, adding that the company was planning to offer bundled advertising sales packages with the Associated Newspapers titles.

He said that the market for e-commerce in the UK "hasn't taken off yet, and we will be relying on advertising for the forseeable future".

But he added that recent US figures suggest that the biggest e-commerce users there are women over 40.

webTitle: Sean Bean steps into the Tardis

fields.headline: Sean Bean steps into the Tardis
fields.standfirst: The 41-year-old actor is to play the latest incarnation of Doctor Who in a £250m film version of the classic time-travel TV series
fields.trailText: The 41-year-old actor is to play the latest incarnation of Doctor Who in a £250m film version of the classic time-travel TV series.
fields.body:
After months of fierce debate and rumour - putting the casting of Star Wars: Episode II to shame - the Daily Mirror reports today that Sean Bean is to play the latest incarnation of Doctor Who in a £250m film version of the classic time-travel TV series.

The 41-year-old actor becomes the 10th actor to play the title role in a deal said to be worth around £3m. British actress Tara Fitzgerald, last seen in 1999's Rancid Aluminium, will play the Time Lord's trusty assistant. Shooting is to begin at Pinewood Studios in the spring.

A source close to the project said: "The powers that be are delighted to have got Bean. They wanted a British actor and a big name and he's both. To have got Tara as well is the icing on the cake."

Best known for his role as Andy McNab in 1999's Bravo Two Zero, Bean was last seen in the British gangster film Essex Boys, released last July. He is currently filming the big screen adaptation of Lord of the Rings alongside Ian McKellen and Liv Tyler.

The Doctor Who TV series ran from 1963 to 1989 with film versions in 1965 and 1966. The last big screen outing for the doctor, starring Paul McGann, flopped in 1996. No doubt the producers hope that the current trend for sci-fi films, such as last year's X-Men and the forthcoming Steven Spielberg project A.I., will help the film's success.

Since the project was announced last year, everyone from Patrick Stewart to Denzel Washington has been rumoured to be stepping into the Doctor's scruffy brogues. One ex-doctor however is not so sure about the big screen version. Tom Baker, who played the doctor's fourth incarnation said: "I wish the BBC all the best - but will be praying to St Jude, the patron saint of lost causes."

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Out in the cold

It's now four months since David and Moira Emmett returned to their Leeds home to find their fridge wasn't working. "We threw away the contents and went to bed confident that we'd bought a first-class piece of equipment from Westinghouse and had insurance to cover breakdowns." An agent from the insurers, Smegserve, duly arrived, fiddled, and declared the appliance fully working. Only it wasn't. The next step was to order a new part and the Emmetts were warned to expect a three-week wait. Three weeks became three months and the couple were told variously that their insurance was no longer valid, that the part had never been ordered or that it would have to be shipped from the US. "It seems that while White-Westinghouse can make parts for rockets, satellites and nuclear power stations, an overload switch for a fridge is beyond them," says David Emmett, who has been living out of a camping coolbox in the interim.

* It takes Consumer three weeks to get through on Smegserve's helpline, a triumph only achievable if you have 20 spare minutes and a good book. "This is an unbelievable situation. It's such an exception!" cries a customer services manager. "Westinghouse keeps 99% of its parts in the UK, but this was an unusual one." The parts do eventually arrive, are fitted and . . . make not a whit of difference. It turns out that the problem was a gas leak which would be impossible to mend. The Emmetts have now accepted a £550 settlement.

Barred by BA

Having worked for an aid agency in Mozambique, Robert Cooke of Brighton recently funded a holiday in the UK for a Mozambican. The latter was due to catch a connecting to London from Johannesburg but was barred from boarding by British Airways officials who mistrusted his paperwork. "He could not explain the situation because his English was nonexistent and there was no interpreter," says Cooke. "He was put on the next flight back to Mozambique and his baggage travelled on to London." Cooke then had to buy a second ticket, this time from Air Portugal, and his guest arrived in England without incident on the same visa and passport. Despite this, BA is refusing to refund the cost of the original ticket. "On this logic they could refuse any traveller at any time and simply say their passport was false then resell the ticket," protests Cooke.

*BA points out that under its conditions of carriage it has the right to refuse passengers and that airlines are liable for fines of up to £2,000 if caught carrying a passenger with illegal paperwork.
Stray emails

Snooping at other people's intimacies is always entertaining but it's a privilege that Peter Lennard is keen to forgo. "I get half a dozen missent emails a week," he laments. "I've complained to my service provider, Onetel, but they do nothing."

*The difficulty lies in a comma, according to Onetel, and the singularity of Lennard's email address. If a sender substitutes a comma for a full stop, the email programme cuts off the rest of the email address at that point and divides it into two addresses. If the comma works its mischief between the co.uk part of the address, the email programme will assume that the uk bit is a separate address and that the service provider matches that of the sender. Thus, poor Mr Lennard, whose address begins with uk, receives mail from every butter-fingered Onetel subscriber. The only thing he can do, says a spokesman, is change his address.

Set-to over set-top box

When L Wilson and his wife moved to their new home in Paignton they cancelled their digital TV service with Telewest and arranged for the company to collect the set-top box from their old home. The new owner had agreed to hand it over on the afternoon in question. As it happened the only contact from Telewest was a bill for £242. Wilson's letter of inquiry was ignored; instead a reminder bill arrived, then another. Suspecting that the invoice was for the set-top box which should have been collected, Wilson wrote twice more, and the only response was a letter regretting that he'd cancelled his digital service. Next came the menace of a debt collection agency unless he paid within seven days. Meanwhile, the owner of his old home confirmed that Telewest had missed the appointment to collect the equipment, which was still waiting, and he had not heard from them since.

*After Consumer contacts Telewest it collects the box and withdraws its invoices. "Only if we are unable to retrieve a box after a number of attempts will a customer be asked to cover the cost," says a spokesman. "Mr Wilson will receive a conciliatory letter."

fields.headline: Fashion star Chalayan 'files for liquidation'
fields.standfirst: Troubled times for top British designer cast gloom over catwalks
fields.trailText: Troubled times for top British designer cast gloom over catwalks.
fields.body:
Hussein Chalayan, British designer of the year and one of the fashion world's brightest stars, has filed for voluntary liquidation, according to reports.

According to the US fashion newspaper Women's Wear Daily - an industry bible - Chalayan, 30, is said to owe approximately £250,000 to various stylists and manufacturers who worked on his last catwalk show, which was held at the Gainsborough studios in London in September.

Sources told the newspaper that his six staff, employed by his company Cartesia Ltd, have been laid off and outside contracts have been terminated.

The news puts into question whether Chalayan will take part in next month's London fashion week, casting a shadow over the industry's new year.

Alongside Alexander McQueen, Chalayan is the leading light of the reinvigorated London fashion industry.

An uncompromising conceptualist, Chalayan's shows have become a must-see for foreign press and buyers on the packed international schedule. Last year, the designer stunned audiences with tables that turned into skirts, chair covers that became dresses and frocks made from spun sugar which shattered.

Although highly lauded by insiders for their technical brilliance, the label had difficulties translating the critical success into sales, averaging at around £1m a year.

Chalayan, whose office in Covent Garden is now closed, is said to be in New York, where he works as a consulting designer for Tse.

Chalayan, a Turkish-Cypriot who has lived in London since he was 12, was first praised after his degree show from Central Saint Martins in 1994. His work, bought by fashion cognoscenti such as Bjork, has steadily built up a reputation for combining philosophical ideals with wearable clothes. But for the past year, Chalayan has been trying to find new investment for his label. In May, he was said to be in talks with Gucci, who decided instead to put their money behind McQueen.

He reportedly met with the French giant LVMH and the newly founded US conglomerate Pegasus Apparel Group. Meanwhile, his name was linked to the design post at Jil Sander, after the German designer quit her Prada-owned label last year. None of the negotiations came to fruition.

News of the liquidation comes at a time of unease in the fashion industry, with many high profile designers selling up to luxury goods groups rather than take the risk of going it alone.

The end of last year saw a flurry of acquisitions, with McQueen going to Gucci and Donna Karan signing up to LVMH. This week it was also reported that the famed British label Paul Smith has sold a 20% stake to Bernard Arnault's LVMH. Insiders believe Chalayan failed to find a deal because of his refusal to water down his vision.

In an interview last year, he said that "there are very few collaborations where the designer is right for the investor and the investor is right for the designer. Its finding someone who loves culture and loves ideas."

Sources claim Chalayan hopes to mount some form of "conceptual presentation" during fashion week, which starts in six weeks time. But the absence of his signature big budget show will puncture the optimism of an industry fighting to maintain its position in an increasingly crowded world stage.

Making of the man behind the label

Hussein Chalayan

 Born August 12, 1970 in Nicosia, Cyprus

 Education Came to England aged 12 and was a boarder at Highgate boys' school in north London. Switched from architecture to fashion after A-levels and trained at St Martins School of Art in London from 1989-93

 Career Briefly worked with tailor Timothy Everest, and launched his own label in 1994.

Has designed for US cashmere company Tse since 1998 and has been contracted to do so until 2001.

He has designed for Top Shop's TS collection and Marks & Spencer's Autograph collection and was asked to design outfits for the models in the Body Zone at the Millennium Dome.

Was shortlisted for the title of British designer of the year three times before winning it in 1999 and 2000.

 Creations He showed a collection of decomposed dresses which he had buried with iron filings to see how they would rust, he then sold the entire collection to the influential London store Browns.

His collections have included a paper dress, a wearable chair, an electronically powered dress and a wooden corset. In 1997 he sent his models on to the catwalk wearing yashmaks and very little else. His show at London fashion week last year featured exploding ballerina dresses made from sugar glass

 Fans The singer Bjork said of him: "He raises daily life to a level of something magical, he was born with these powers and it is a question of whether 50,000 business people are willing to go there with him."

"Absolutely fantastic," said Michael Roberts, fashion editor of the New Yorker magazine after one of his shows last year.

Sally James Gregory

Although highly lauded by insiders for their technical brilliance, the label had difficulties translating the critical success into sales, averaging at around £1m a year. Chalayan, whose office in Covent Garden is now closed, is said to be in New York, where he works as a consulting designer for Tse. Chalayan, a Turkish-Cypriot who has lived in London since he was 12, was first praised after his degree show from Central Saint Martins in 1994. His work, bought by fashion cognoscenti such as Bjork, has steadily built up a reputation for combining philosophical ideals with wearable clothes. But for the past year, Chalayan has been trying to find new investment for his label. In May, he was said to be in talks with Gucci, who decided instead to put their money behind McQueen. He reportedly met with the French giant LVMH and the newly founded US conglomerate Pegasus Apparel Group. Meanwhile, his name was linked to the design post at Jil Sander, after the German designer quit her Prada-owned label last year. None of the negotiations came to fruition. News of the liquidation comes at a time of unease in the fashion industry, with many high profile designers selling up to luxury goods groups rather than take the risk of going it alone. The end of last year saw a flurry of acquisitions, with McQueen going to Gucci and Donna Karan signing up to LVMH. This week it was also reported that the famed British label Paul Smith has sold a 20% stake to Bernard Arnault's LVMH. Insiders believe Chalayan failed to find a deal because of his refusal to water down his vision. In an interview last year, he said that "there are very few collaborations where the designer is right for the investor and the investor is right for the designer. Its finding someone who loves culture and loves ideas." Sources claim Chalayan hopes to mount some form of "conceptual presentation" during fashion week, which starts in six weeks time. But the absence of his signature big budget show will puncture the optimism of an industry fighting to maintain its position in an increasingly crowded world stage. Making of the man behind the label Hussein Chalayan  Born August 12, 1970 in Nicosia, Cyprus  Education Came to England aged 12 and was a boarder at Highgate boys' school in north London. Switched from architecture to fashion after A-levels and trained at St Martins School of Art in London from 1989-93  Career Briefly worked with tailor Timothy Everest, and launched his own label in 1994. Has designed for US cashmere company Tse since 1998 and has been contracted to do so until 2001. He has designed for Top Shop's TS collection and Marks & Spencer's Autograph collection and was asked to design outfits for the models in the Body Zone at the Millennium Dome. Was shortlisted for the title of British designer of the year three times before winning it in 1999 and 2000.  Creations He showed a collection of decomposed dresses which he had buried with iron filings to see how they would rust, he then sold the entire collection to the influential London store Browns. His collections have included a paper dress, a wearable chair, an electronically powered dress and a wooden corset. In 1997 he sent his models on to the catwalk wearing yashmaks and very little else. His show at London fashion week last year featured exploding ballerina dresses made from sugar glass  Fans The singer Bjork said of him: "He raises daily life to a level of something magical, he was born with these powers and it is a question of whether 50,000 business people are willing to go there with him." "Absolutely fantastic," said Michael Roberts, fashion editor of the New Yorker magazine after one of his shows last year. Sally James Gregory

fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are supporting the Sun's Boycott the Oil Barons campaign
fields.trailText: Chelsea are preparing a renewed bid for Robbie Fowler in the wake of Liverpool's move for Jari Litmanen, reports every tabloid this morning. As the Express's Rob Shepherd points out: "The lights of London are bright, but there are so many of them that it is much easier not to get spotted."
fields.body:
Chelsea are preparing a renewed bid for Robbie Fowler in the wake of Liverpool's move for Jari Litmanen, reports every tabloid this morning. As the Express's Rob Shepherd points out: "The lights of London are bright, but there are so many of them that it is much easier not to get spotted."

Gerald Houllier's tentative enquiry about the availability of Bayern Munich goalkeeper Oliver Kahn has been rebuffed by Franz Beckenbauer. "Liverpool, or anyone else for that matter, can forget about even trying to sign Oliver. He is not for sale at any price," he said.

Monaco are already holding talks with Frank Leboeuf about a possible move, reports the Star. The paper claims that Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri is anxious to "refresh" his squad and that Dennis Wise, Ed de Goey and Gianfranco Zola could also be on their way out in the next few months.

Arsenal have renewed their interest in £15m-rated Edgar Davids. The Mirror claims Davids has become "disillusioned with life at Juventus" and "has made it known he wants to be given the chance to prove himself in the Premiership". However, the paper admits that no deal will be done until the future of the transfer system is resolved.

Middlesbrough have denied any interest in Celtic striker Mark Burchill. "I am aware of the story, but there is no truth behind it," said Bryan Robson. "To be honest, we want to get it right with the lads we've got here. We are not specifically looking to spend any more money here at the moment."

Nottingham Forest have made a £2.5m offer for Ipswich striker David Johnson. Forest manager David Platt admitted: "We have made a firm enquiry for David Johnson but it has been difficult to sort things out because of the Christmas and New Year schedule. I hope to speak to George Burley again before the end of the week and, hopefully, we can sort something out."

Newcastle - and not Tottenham - could be the destination for Argentine playmaker Juan Fernandez di Alessio, reports Planet Football. The website claims that "sources in Argentina" say di Alessio could be heading to Tyneside in a £1.34m deal in the next week.

Crystal Palace have made a £1.3m bid for Tranmere midfielder Jason Koumas.

webTitle: Egan wins legal fight over ONdigital bonuses

fields.headline: Egan wins legal fight over ONdigital bonuses
fields.trailText: 11.15am: John Egan, former director of operations at ONdigital, has won a legal battle over unpaid bonuses, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
John Egan, the former ONdigital director of operations, has won his legal battle to secure £100,000 in unpaid bonuses from the terrestrial pay-TV operator.

An industrial tribunal found that Mr Egan, who left the broadcaster in September 1999 to launch interactive TV company Sit-up.com, had been unfairly dismissed and should have been paid two bonuses worth nearly £100,000.

Another former ONdigital executive now working with Mr Egan at Sit-up, ex-director of programmes Ashley Faull, is also suing the pay-TV company for non-payment of a performance-related bonus.

At a hearing in November, ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble argued that Mr Egan's bonus had not been paid because of problems with the management of the company's pay-TV service launch in late 1998.

fields.headline: Future Network shares plummet
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Shares in Future Network have crashed following the magazine publisher's second profits warning in two months, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in Future Network have crashed following the magazine publisher's second profits warning in two months.

The stock plummeted 48%, or 70p, to 76p after the company said an anticipated pre-Christmas sales rush for its computer magazines failed to materialise.

Hopes for the all-important fourth quarter have been damaged by low newsstand magazine sales and the delayed release of the PlayStation 2 console, causing games makers to pull advertising bookings.

Around 30% of the company's revenues come from games magazines.

Greg Ingham, Future Network chief executive, said: "As so much of our business is seasonally weighted to the fourth quarter, even relatively minor changes in newsstand sales can have a significant impact on the results of operations."

Future Network, which publishes e-commerce title Business 2.0 and has recruited Elisabeth Murdoch as a non-executive director, said sales for last year will be 3% lower than expected at £253m.

Damage limitation exercises have already begun, with this year's investment in the company to be cut from £30m to below £20m.

It has been a nightmare six months for a company that was worth £1bn in August last year but is now worth £92m after its stock tumbled from a 12-month high of 937p.

In November, it issued a profits warning after discovering a financial shortfall in its French business, causing its shares to tumble 45%.

fields.headline: Letter to Chris Smith
fields.trailText: 22nd December 2000
fields.body:
22nd December 2000

Rt Hon Chris Smith MP

Re: Approval and scrutiny of BBC New services

With the White Paper now published we - the major commercial broadcasters in UK cable, satellite and digital television - note the Government's clear intention to retain the existing approvals mechanism for new BBC public service channels. Given the imminent application by the BBC for your approval of its proposed new digital channels, we are writing to register our strongest concern at the lack of any finalised criteria on which these new services will be approved or rejected, and to restate some of the changes which we believe are necessary to the draft proposals for these criteria published in June this year.

As you are aware, the BBC's proposed new services will, if approved, have a wide reaching long term impact on commercial broadcasters and the creative industries as a whole. We therefore believe that we have a right to expect, at the very least, a means by which we can understand in detail the implications of any new BBC proposals on our businesses, and to be able to respond in full and with the confidence that our views will be taken properly into account before any final decision is taken. While the Government has already set out its draft proposals in this regard, we have yet to see any firm mechanism put in place. We therefore request that the Guidelines are published as soon as possible, before the BBC makes an application to the DCMS for the approval of its proposed new services, and well before the Government begins further consultation.

Early publication of the Guidelines is all the more important, we believe, given that the BBC appears to be implementing its new service proposals prior to your official consent. From our contacts within the industry, as well as the BBC itself, we know that plans for BBC 3, BBC 4 and the children's services are continuing apace. We are extremely concerned that the BBC is behaving as if it had been given tacit consent to build their plans for new services, without the proper process being adhered to. We believe that this is significant because it suggests to us that the new approvals process is perceived as simply a rubber stamping exercise by the BBC and DCMS.

As well as our concerns over the implementation of the Guidelines we have, as you may already be aware, also proposed to your officials a number of alterations which will ensure the creation of a truly valid and widely respected method of approving BBC services. In particular, the BBC should be required to demonstrate the value to licence fee payers of each new service by outlining how they would be distinctive from what already exists in the market, and by demonstrating that there is a failure of the market to provide such services. The BBC should be required to provide much more detailed financial, marketing and programming information to enable the industry and relevant regulators to make an informed assessment of what impact each service would have upon the market and the commerical broadcasting companies operating in that market. The industry consultation period should also be lengthened considerably from 15 working days to enable the industry to properly assess the BBC's proposals. In addition, there should be a firm undertaking by the DCMS that no new BBC services will be approved unless the requirements of the EC State aid rules have been satisfied. The approvals mechanism should, therefore, ensure that the BBC provides sufficient information in relation to new services to ensure that the EC Commission and market participants can ascertain whether the new services comply with EC State aid rules.

The underlying purpose of all these suggestion is to ensure that, when you come to make a decision about whether or not to approve a new service, you have as much detailed and well balanced evidence as possible to assist you in making that decision. It is, however, still unclear to us whether any of them have been taken onboard in the revised approvals process.

Given the strength of our concerns we would welcome a meeting to discuss the approvals process.

Yours sincerely

Tony Ball, Chief Executive & Managing Director, BSkyB
Mick Buckley, UK Managing Director, Turner Broadcasting System Europe Ltd
Brent Hansen, President & Chief Executive, MTV Networks Europe
John Hambley, Chief Executive, Artsworld
Paul Lindley, General Manager, Nickelodeon UK
Adam Singer, Chief Executive, Telewest
Joyce Taylor, Managing Director, Discovery Networks Europe

fields.headline: Ray Walston
fields.standfirst: Actor whose versatility ranged from Broadway musicals to Billy Wilder films to playing a Martian on TV
fields.trailText: Actor whose versatility ranged from Broadway musicals to Billy Wilder films to playing a Martian on TV has died aged 83
fields.body:
Ray Walston, who has died aged 83, was short, bald, had a clownish face and a penetrating, strangely articulated voice - ideal to play an extra-terrestrial, which he did from 1963 to 1966 on television in My Favourite Martian. The comic situations derived from Walston's deadpan humour as the character struggles to adapt to a more primitive civilisation, his ability to appear and disappear uncontrollably, read minds, speak to animals and levitate.

Walston was a down-to-earth character, who hated to be identified as the Martian for so long. He preferred to be remembered for two hit Broadway - and screen - musicals, South Pacific and Damn Yankees, his roles in Billy Wilder's The Apartment and Kiss Me, Stupid, and a string of character parts.

Walston was born in New Orleans, and made his professional debut for the Community Players in Houston, Texas, in 1938, playing Buddy in High Tor. It took him a few years, after working as a printer and reporter, before he returned to the profession. From playing an attendant in the Maurice Evans Hamlet in 1945 in New York, he went on to appear on Broadway in The Front Page, The Alchemist, and Tennessee Williams's Summer And Smoke, before landing the role of the conniving marine, Luther Billis, in the touring production of Rogers and Hammerstein's South Pacific in 1950. He repeated the role for two years at London's Drury Lane, staged by Joshua Logan, who also directed Walston in the 1958 film version. Walston survived Logan's stodgy direction, stealing every scene in which he appeared.

Before he made his film debut in 1957 as Cary Grant's naval sidekick in Stanley Donen's Kiss Them For Me, Walston sang in three more Broadway musicals, Rodgers and Hammerstein's Me And Juliet, Harold Arlen's House Of Flowers and George Abbott's Damn Yankees. In the last, for which he received a Tony, and in the 1958 movie, Walston played a deliciously wicked and frustrated Devil in the human form of an entrepreneur called Mr Applegate, stopping the show with Those Were The Good Old Days.

In 1960, Walston made The Apartment, in which he was one of the bosses using underling Jack Lemmon's pad for assignations; a shifty chauffeur bringing some reality into the risible soap opera Portrait in Black; a title character in Convicts 4, and a professor trying to help student Anthony Perkins pass an exam to permit him to play in a basketball game in Josh Logan's Tall Story.

In 1963 Walston appeared as Mr Quimby, the shop manager in the Frank Tashlin-Jerry Lewis comedy, Who's Minding The Store?, and returned to the big screen in Kiss Me, Stupid (1964). He got the part of Orville J Spooner when Peter Sellers suffered a heart attack. "Both my wife and I sat down and read the script," Walston recalled, "and I said when I finished it, 'It's not good, it's not good.' But one doesn't say that about a Billy Wilder- IAL Diamond script. The feeling was that they would repair it." They did, and Walston was amusing as a jealous piano teacher and would-be songwriter in Climax, Nevada, who sends his wife away while horny crooner Dean Martin is staying with him, hiring local hooker Kim Novak to play his wife.

"I had a line, when I first bring Kim Novak into the house: 'Well, it's not very big but it's clean.' And they wanted it done with a slight look from her as if it meant my cock. 'Hey, Ray,' Wilder said. 'Vat are the keedies gonna tink about you ven this film is released?'

"I replied, 'What are people gonna say about you? How do you think you're gonna get away with some of this stuff?' "

IAL Diamond's wife had her own thoughts: "They should have waited for Peter Sellers to recover, Ray Walston was too unattractive a personality." She was right in that Walston seldom heeded the exhortatory song You Gotta Have Heart from Damn Yankees, his performances tending towards caricature.

Walston worked on into the 1990s playing the race announcer in on a scam in The Sting (1973), one of the two killers pursuing Gene Wilder in Silver Streak (1976), Poopdeck Pappy in Robert Altman's Popeye (1981), and the quirky schoolteacher in Fast Times At Ridgemont High (1982), a part he repeated in the TV series Fast Times. Aged 75, Walston gave one of his best, and warmest, performances in Of Mice And Men (1992) as the veteran farmworker Candy, heartbroken at his old dog having to be put down.

Walston is survived by his wife, daughter and two grandchildren.

webTitle: Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger

fields.headline: Liberty Surf tight lipped on merger
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: French internet service provider Liberty Surf, which is part owned by the UK's Kingfisher group, confirmed yesterday that it is in talks with several potential partners. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
French internet service provider Liberty Surf, which is part owned by the UK's Kingfisher group, confirmed yesterday that it is in talks with several potential partners.

Speculation is centred on Belgium's state-controlled telecoms group, Belgacom, which is known to be keen to expand its internet operations in France, where it is already represented by Infosources.

Speculation about the possibility of a Belgacom bid allowed Liberty Surf shares to shrug off the general malaise affecting hi-tech stocks and close almost 9% higher on the day.

Liberty Surf yesterday refused to be drawn on the identities of the companies with which it was holding talks or the prospects of an alliance materialising.

"Following media reports referring to talks with a telecoms group, Liberty Surf would indicate that, while talks are going on with different partners, they could either reach or not reach a conclusion," the company said in a statement.

Belgacom - where the government has a 50% plus one share - is seen by industry analysts as a good partner for Liberty Surf at a time of consolidation among internet service providers.

Liberty Surf has said it would make sense for it to join forces with either a media or a telecoms company. A tie up with Infosources - which is 75% owned by Belgacom - would increase Infosources' presence in France, which accounts for a third of its active users.

Liberty Surf has some 730,000 users - including 600,000 in France.

One problem for Belgacom would be the way in which a deal would have to be financed. Liberty Surf has a market capitalisation of around €550m (£347m) and the Belgian telecoms group would almost certainly have to pay cash to fund a deal to combine the two sets of internet activities.

It would be difficult for it to use its own shares because it does not have a stock market quotation so valuation would be a problem. Even if that could be overcome, any new share issue would mean the Belgian government surrendering control - a position it is thought to have accepted in principle but where the practicalities have not been decided.

Belgacom could finance a deal by using shares in Infosources, which it bought back in December, but as Liberty Surf has a much larger market capitalisation than Info-sources that would mean it would have to surrender overall control. Yesterday Info-sources shares were down 18% on concerns about the extent of possible dilution for a deal with Liberty Surf.

"From an industrial point of view, such a deal [between Liberty Surf and Belgacom] would make sense but it does beg the questions about financing," David Cerdan, sector specialist at HSBC-CCF said.

Kingfisher, which has around 35% of Liberty Surf shares - the French group's other big shareholder is Bernard Arnault's Groupe Arnault - declined to comment on the day's developments.

Speculation is centred on Belgium's state-controlled telecoms group, Belgacom, which is known to be keen to expand its internet operations in France, where it is already represented by Infosources. Speculation about the possibility of a Belgacom bid allowed Liberty Surf shares to shrug off the general malaise affecting hi-tech stocks and close almost 9% higher on the day. Liberty Surf yesterday refused to be drawn on the identities of the companies with which it was holding talks or the prospects of an alliance materialising. "Following media reports referring to talks with a telecoms group, Liberty Surf would indicate that, while talks are going on with different partners, they could either reach or not reach a conclusion," the company said in a statement. Belgacom - where the government has a 50% plus one share - is seen by industry analysts as a good partner for Liberty Surf at a time of consolidation among internet service providers. Liberty Surf has said it would make sense for it to join forces with either a media or a telecoms company. A tie up with Infosources - which is 75% owned by Belgacom - would increase Infosources' presence in France, which accounts for a third of its active users. Liberty Surf has some 730,000 users - including 600,000 in France. One problem for Belgacom would be the way in which a deal would have to be financed. Liberty Surf has a market capitalisation of around €550m (£347m) and the Belgian telecoms group would almost certainly have to pay cash to fund a deal to combine the two sets of internet activities. It would be difficult for it to use its own shares because it does not have a stock market quotation so valuation would be a problem. Even if that could be overcome, any new share issue would mean the Belgian government surrendering control - a position it is thought to have accepted in principle but where the practicalities have not been decided. Belgacom could finance a deal by using shares in Infosources, which it bought back in December, but as Liberty Surf has a much larger market capitalisation than Info-sources that would mean it would have to surrender overall control. Yesterday Info-sources shares were down 18% on concerns about the extent of possible dilution for a deal with Liberty Surf. "From an industrial point of view, such a deal [between Liberty Surf and Belgacom] would make sense but it does beg the questions about financing," David Cerdan, sector specialist at HSBC-CCF said. Kingfisher, which has around 35% of Liberty Surf shares - the French group's other big shareholder is Bernard Arnault's Groupe Arnault - declined to comment on the day's developments.

webTitle: Txt, txt. Mobile phone book tops bestsellers

fields.headline: Txt, txt. Mobile phone book tops bestsellers
fields.trailText: A book only 96 pages long pipped Harry Potter, the Naked Chef and the Guinness book of records to emerge top of the bestsellers in the week before Christmas.
fields.body:
A book only 96 pages long pipped Harry Potter, the Naked Chef and the Guinness book of records to emerge top of the bestsellers in the week before Christmas.

The title is Wan2tlk?, a 99p guide to 1,000 abbreviations and "emoticons" in the burgeoning mobile phone short message craze.

Issued by the small pub lisher Michael O'Mara, it was lying third in the list, behind Guinness World Records: 2001 and Jamie Oliver's The Return of the Naked Chef, selling 36,000 copies a week until mid-December when its popularity as a stocking-filler pushed it up.

Its success, confirmed in figures in tomorrow's Bookseller magazine, reflects the electronics market's tendency to generate unpredicted enthusiasms.

The five highest selling books by December 23, according to research group Whitaker BookTrack, were Wan2tlk?, Jamie Oliver, Guinness 2001, then Who Wants to be a Millionaire? by Question Masters, and Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, by J K Rowling.

webTitle: TV Corp splashes out on power boat racing rights

fields.headline: TV Corp splashes out on power boat racing rights
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The Television Corporation wants to make power boat racing a must-see TV sport, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Television Corporation, owner of TV documentary specialist Mentorn Barraclough Carey and sports producer Sunset + Vine, is hoping to make offshore power boat racing a must-see television sport.

The company today announced that it is to buy Offshore Sport Promotions for up to £15m in shares, giving the TV Corporation rights to the Class 1 Worldwide Offshore Championships for the next 55 years.

Chris Rowlands, TV Corporation chief executive, said that power-boat racing "fulfils all the criteria of becoming a major global sport - it is fast, highly competitive, truly international and already has an enthusiastic worldwide fan base".

The company has appointed Nathan Knight as managing director of Offshore Sport Promotions. Mr Knight is the former vice-president of the Brussels office of the Motion Picture Association of America's anti-piracy unit.

fields.headline: Purporting to be beating cancer
fields.trailText: Comment:Few misconceptions are as widespread as the idea that the war against cancer is being won, writes George Monbiot
fields.body:
There is no notion so flawed that society will not, at some time, adopt it as a universal truth. Few misconceptions are as widespread as the idea that the war against cancer is being won. It's hardly surprising, for scarcely a week goes by without a promise that deliverance is just around the corner. Yesterday, for example, we learnt that a new injection might cure lymphomas. The day before, the government announced that a further £90m would help to eliminate intestinal tumours. Cancer, most commentators agree, is all but dead.

So it's perplexing to discover that cancer in industrialised countries is not falling, but rising. While lung, cervical, uterine and stomach cancers are declining, and treatments for testicular cancer and childhood leukaemia have greatly improved, cancer overall has increased by 60% in the past 50 years. Breast cancer has almost doubled. Prostate cancer has risen by 200%, testicular cancer in young men by 300%. In the US, childhood brain cancers and leukaemias have been advancing by 1.8% a year since 1973. In Britain, 40% of us are likely to contract cancer at some stage in our lives.

These increases are often ascribed to better detection and an ageing population. But the figures are age-adjusted: a 60-year-old today is 200% more likely to contract prostate cancer than a 60-year-old would have been in 1950. Reported cancers have continued to rise after the universal deployment of new screening techniques: this is not an artefact of diagnosis. Cancer is thriving.

According to Samuel Epstein, professor of environmental medicine at the University of Illinois, the reason is obvious. Since 1940, the world's production of synthetic organic chemicals has risen 600-fold, exposing our bodies to a massive toxic load. There is plenty of evidence to support his contention.

Last year, for example, a US study found that children living beside busy roads were six times as likely to suffer from cancer as children living in quiet areas. This is hardly surprising: the two most carcinogenic compounds ever detected are both produced by diesel engines. An English study published in 1997 showed that children living within five kilometres of oil refineries and chemical plants were more likely to contract cancer than those living further away.

Figures released by the US Environmental Protection Agency last year suggest that as many as 7% of all cancers are caused by dioxins, mostly from incinerators. A Danish study published in 1999 showed that women whose bodies contain high concentrations of the pesticide dieldrin are twice as likely to develop cancer. Other scientific papers have highlighted the dangers of herbicides, beef hormones, petrol additives, oral contraceptives, artificial sweeteners, PVC and scores of other chemicals.

So I commend to you a fascinating document, published by the Department of Health, called the NHS Cancer Plan, which tells us how the government intends to eliminate cancer in England. It contains plenty of helpful advice on giving up smoking. It outlines a scheme for increasing the amount of fruit and vegetables children eat. But only one pollutant is mentioned as a possible cause of cancer: radon gas, which happens to be naturally occurring.

It's not hard to see that both the major polluting industries and the pharmaceutical companies manufacturing cancer "cures" (they are often one and the same) have a certain interest in sustaining the status quo. But it strikes me that these might not be the only lobbyists the government is listening to. The big cancer charities also appear reluctant to take contamination seriously.

The Imperial Cancer Research Fund's website records no matches for the word "pollution". The researcher Martin Walker reports that of the 110 research units cited in its 1998 scientific report, not one deals with chemical or environmental carcinogens. Last year the Cancer Research Campaign predicted that cancer would be cured by 2050, as a result of new genetic technologies. Its website mentions pollution, but dismisses concerns with the claim that "experts think that only 5% of preventable cancer deaths may be linked to environmental factors".

The CRC's 10-page press release on poverty and cancer blames inequalities in treatment for differing rates of death, but says nothing about pollution, even though the poor are far more likely to live beside dirty factories and toxic dumps than the rich.

Give them more money, the cancer charities claim, and they will find the magic formula which will save us all from a hideous death. But could it be possible that we are dying so that they might live?

webTitle: Cardiff to host next three FA Cup finals

fields.headline: Cardiff to host next three FA Cup finals
fields.trailText: The FA Cup final is to be held outside England for the first time in its 129-year history following the finalisation of the agreement to stage it at Cardiff's Millennium stadium.
fields.body:
The FA Cup final is to be held outside England for the first time in its 129-year history following the finalisation of the agreement to stage it at Cardiff's Millennium stadium.

Today the Football Association will announce that it has concluded a deal to stage three FA Cup finals, starting with this year's, at the 72,000-capacity all-seat arena in the Welsh capital while redevelopment work takes place at Wembley.

The Football League has also reached agreement for the next four League Cup finals to be played at the Millennium stadium. The play-off finals and the Charity Shield will also take place there.

The deal between the FA and the Welsh Rugby Union, the venue's controller, was finalised after six months of negotiations which centred on the FA's demand for a "clean stadium" - that it, rather than the WRU, makes the money from internal advertising and catering - while the Football League was worried about the pitch.

Talks were stalling until the intervention of Cardiff county council, which has a stake in the stadium and was anxious lest the city's traders miss out on an anticipated bonanza. The sponsorship, catering and advertising contracts signed by the WRU will now be taken on by the football authorities but negotiations continue about the hospitality boxes.

The "palletised" pitch which caused problems in the early days is in the process of being enhanced with a state-of-the-art "roll-on" pitch, and the surface will not be used two weeks before a match is staged. Only five rugby matches are scheduled between now and May.

The Millennium stadium has a retractable roof, moreover, but while there are no plans to play the FA Cup final with it closed, the Football League will decide what to do about the League Cup final after consultation with the teams.

The WRU will earn between £100,000 and £250,000 a match, in effect around £1m a year, far less in percentage terms than it paid for Wembley in 1997-99 when the Millennium stadium was being built.

webTitle: Bowen raises laughing stock of Morecambe

fields.headline: Bowen raises laughing stock of Morecambe
fields.standfirst: The gags keep coming but old Bullseye host is dead serious about Ipswich
fields.trailText: The gags keep coming but old Bullseye host is dead serious about Ipswich.
fields.body:
Not many non-league clubs have put their presence in the FA Cup third round down to successfully bribing a referee and linesman, but then not many non-league clubs have Jim Bowen as their president. While Morecambe brims with excitement over the impending visit of Ipswich Town, Bowen claims to have already taken care of the brown envelopes - again.

There has always been a show business feel to this Lancashire seaside town. Eric Bartholomew was a previous president, long after changing his name to Morecambe, and a statue now stands in the town in his memory. For the past five years, Bowen, whose 14 years as a game-show host on Bullseye made him a national institution, has ensured that life in the Conference has never been short of fun.

"When we played Cambridge United in the second round, I joked that we'd left a brown envelope in the referee's room," said Bowen yesterday. "The ref, Mr Parkes, was petrified that he'd be summoned to Soho Square to answer for his career. The last 16 minutes, after we'd gone 2-1 up, were the most harrowing of my life."

Mark Quayle's goal had put Morecambe in round three for only the second time in their 80-year history. Looking ahead Jim Harvey, the Morecambe manager as well as being Sammy McIlroy's No2 at Northern Ireland, said: "Ipswich hold no fears for me. In the last few months I've had to help prepare for matches against Yugoslavia, Denmark and Hungary.

"If we can hang on until the last 10 minutes on Saturday, it could be very interesting."

Bowen takes another view and warns Ipswich that travellers' cheques are already on the way to the referee and that if the result goes the right way, the fourth official can anticipate a weekend in Llandudno. They have always gone about things strangely in Morecambe; the club existed for almost 30 years without a manager.

Bowen's love of football was first formed in Accrington - "If you're not sure where it is, it's where the M65 is cobbled" - and then as a supporter of Blackburn Rovers. "If you stood on concrete on the terraces in the 50s, you were a capitalist," he said. He remembered Jack Walker, who was later to commit his millions to buying Rovers a Premiership title, enjoying particular favour. "The rest of us were on mud, but Jack had his own rail and stood leeward of a concrete barrier. By the time that Jack got his pie at half-time, it was still hot."

Bowen's first job was as a dustman, until national service intervened. "I defended my country at Shrewsbury," he said. "Our task was to keep the Welsh out. The sheep up here in Lancashire are frightened enough as it is." He was made a physical-training instructor - "To keep me away from the live ammunition" - and qualified as a teacher in 1959.

"My role is to speak at a few sportsmen's dinners and raise a bit of money, but I understand the game reasonably well, and even took a brief coaching course at Lilleshall. I used to be a winger, because that was where they used to put the kid with glasses and skinny legs. I suffered from a lack of confidence. I played in the under-15s. I was 19 at the time," he said.

Around the time that Bowen took up teaching, Morecambe were enjoying a renaissance. Ray Charnley, later to play for England, was sold to Blackpool; Christie Park was treated to floodlights, a supporters' club plus a new stand, and in 1961-2, an FA Cup third round tie against Weymouth drew a record crowd of 9,234. Their finest hour was in 1974 when they beat Dartford at Wembley in the FA Trophy final.

The visit of Ipswich, fourth in the Premiership, is an opportunity to scale new heights. Bowen is relying on adrenalin to "get them the extra yard" and "a bottle of Scotch in the dressing room that we won't even charge them for".

At "63 going on 107" Morecambe's honorary president still leads a hectic life. His morning show with Sally Naden on BBC Radio Lancashire, The Happy Daft Farm, dominates ratings. Its avowed aim is to find the most miserable people in Lancashire and cheer them up. "The BBC," says Bowen, "have finally heightened my awareness that money isn't everything." Next summer, Bowen has been re-engaged on the QE2, where he will play trumpet with Colin Bryant's Hot Rhythm Orchestra.

But it is for his role on Bullseye, the darts quiz show, for which Bowen is remembered with affection. His Sunday afternoon slot peaked at 18.9m viewers and was revered by grannies and students alike. Here was the maths teacher who could not add up, and who once uttered "smashing" 43 times in one half-hour programme. "It was the happiest 14 years of my showbiz life."

Thoughts of an FA Cup win drew from Bowen the ultimate accolade. "Tell you what, if we beat Ipswich, it'll be even better than a speedboat."

webTitle: Czechs rally to save state TV

fields.headline: Czechs rally to save state TV
fields.standfirst: Thousands take to the streets to support striking journalists in station standoff
fields.trailText: Thousands take to the streets to support striking journalists in station standoff.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of Czechs streamed into Wenceslas Square in the capital, Prague, last night to show their support for the journalists involved in an increasingly bitter newsroom strike at the state-owned Czech Television (CT).

Holding banners and chanting, an estimated 100,000 people - the largest gathering in the square since the Velvet Revolution against communist rule in November 1989 - demanded that the country's political leaders end the standoff between the CT director, Jiri Hodac, and the journalists.

The journalists have been occupying the studios since Christmas Eve. With the open support of President Vaclav Havel, they are demanding the dismissal of Mr Hodac, who has close political links to the main opposition group, the Civic Democratic party.

The party's leader, former prime minister Vaclav Klaus, who is favourite to become president after the elections due next year, intends to privatise the television service, which is seen as a watchdog for democracy.

The journalists regard Mr Hodac's appointment as a threat to their livelihoods and the beginning of the end for the station's editorial independence. Some of their management colleagues have already been removed since his appointment.

"All of us face a danger that ... Czech TV will become an obedient instrument of the people who are in power," they said in a statement.

They accuse Mr Hodac of exercising political bias in his news reporting, purging the editorial department of "undesirables", and dismissing key managers.

In August Mr Hodac resigned as news editor after complaints about his slanted news judgment. Although he was given his new position by a committee appointed by parliament, he denies any political bias.

Politicians at both ends of the political spectrum agree that if the crisis is not ended soon it could increase to the point when early elections will benecessary. But talks between the four main political parties earlier this week ended in deadlock.

In a letter to the strikers, the secretary general of the International Federation of Journalists, Aidan White, called on member organisations in more than 100 countries "to show their support and to declare that they will assist you in your strike". T

"The fight for media freedom and democracy does not take place in one country," he said.

The mood in the newsroom remained defiant yesterday, as reporters insisted they would continue their sit-in until Mr Hodac resigned.

"We won't leave until they send in the tanks," said Adam Komers - alluding to the Spring of 1968, when Soviet tanks rolled into Prague, crushing a popular uprising against communist rule.

Mr Hodac, a former head of the BBC's Czech Service, has been deserted by most of his correspondents and is failing to fill even half of the news slots.

The journalists are backed by a petition signed by more than 150,000 people calling for "television for the people, not for the parties". Supporters are placing supplies of food, toiletries and clean clothes in a bucket which is pulled up to the studio on a rope by the journalists, who have been camping on the floor in sleeping bags. Mobile toilets have been set up in a sound studio.

Eva Kurnertova, 23, editor of the daily news briefs, said: "Everyone I speak to on my mobile tells me to stick it out here. If we give this room up, we can no longer broadcast the truth and then we will have lost."

In the past week 5,000 to 10,000 supporters - including famous actors, former dissidents and musicians - have rallied each night in freezing conditions outside the station.

"We're here because the public nature of Czech television as the watchdog of democracy is under threat," said Ludek Nesleha, an actor who was a member of the strike committee member in the runup to the Velvet Revolution.

"This isn't like 1989, but it's a warning to the politicians that they should finally start learning to behave themselves."

Holding banners and chanting, an estimated 100,000 people - the largest gathering in the square since the Velvet Revolution against communist rule in November 1989 - demanded that the country's political leaders end the standoff between the CT director, Jiri Hodac, and the journalists. The journalists have been occupying the studios since Christmas Eve. With the open support of President Vaclav Havel, they are demanding the dismissal of Mr Hodac, who has close political links to the main opposition group, the Civic Democratic party. The party's leader, former prime minister Vaclav Klaus, who is favourite to become president after the elections due next year, intends to privatise the television service, which is seen as a watchdog for democracy. The journalists regard Mr Hodac's appointment as a threat to their livelihoods and the beginning of the end for the station's editorial independence. Some of their management colleagues have already been removed since his appointment. "All of us face a danger that ... Czech TV will become an obedient instrument of the people who are in power," they said in a statement. They accuse Mr Hodac of exercising political bias in his news reporting, purging the editorial department of "undesirables", and dismissing key managers. In August Mr Hodac resigned as news editor after complaints about his slanted news judgment. Although he was given his new position by a committee appointed by parliament, he denies any political bias. Politicians at both ends of the political spectrum agree that if the crisis is not ended soon it could increase to the point when early elections will benecessary. But talks between the four main political parties earlier this week ended in deadlock. In a letter to the strikers, the secretary general of the International Federation of Journalists, Aidan White, called on member organisations in more than 100 countries "to show their support and to declare that they will assist you in your strike". T "The fight for media freedom and democracy does not take place in one country," he said. The mood in the newsroom remained defiant yesterday, as reporters insisted they would continue their sit-in until Mr Hodac resigned. "We won't leave until they send in the tanks," said Adam Komers - alluding to the Spring of 1968, when Soviet tanks rolled into Prague, crushing a popular uprising against communist rule. Mr Hodac, a former head of the BBC's Czech Service, has been deserted by most of his correspondents and is failing to fill even half of the news slots. The journalists are backed by a petition signed by more than 150,000 people calling for "television for the people, not for the parties". Supporters are placing supplies of food, toiletries and clean clothes in a bucket which is pulled up to the studio on a rope by the journalists, who have been camping on the floor in sleeping bags. Mobile toilets have been set up in a sound studio. Eva Kurnertova, 23, editor of the daily news briefs, said: "Everyone I speak to on my mobile tells me to stick it out here. If we give this room up, we can no longer broadcast the truth and then we will have lost." In the past week 5,000 to 10,000 supporters - including famous actors, former dissidents and musicians - have rallied each night in freezing conditions outside the station. "We're here because the public nature of Czech television as the watchdog of democracy is under threat," said Ludek Nesleha, an actor who was a member of the strike committee member in the runup to the Velvet Revolution. "This isn't like 1989, but it's a warning to the politicians that they should finally start learning to behave themselves."

webTitle: Leader: Yet again, vaccination proves its worth

fields.headline: In Jenner's footsteps
fields.standfirst: Yet again, vaccination proves its worth
fields.trailText: Yet again, vaccination proves its worth.
fields.body:
The truth that prevention is better than cure has been demonstrated down the years by a long list of public health initiatives. Immunisation is one - despite the opposition of the anti-vaccination lobby. Had that had been at work in 1796, when Edward Jenner inoculated a boy with cowpox to demonstrate it would make him immune from smallpox, we would still be suffering from the deadly disease. Instead, one of the world's biggest killers was eradicated in 1977 by a concerted 10-year campaign by the World Health Organisation.

There was good news yesterday of another new vaccine. Just over a year ago, the UK became the first country to develop and introduce a vaccine to combat meningitis C, the infection that accounts for 40% of the deadly disease. About 1,500 cases were contracted in the year before the immunisation programme began, when 150 children died. Now, following 18m vaccinations, cases have fallen by 75% and by up to 90% among the most vulnerable groups, teenagers and young babies. But do not expect the anti-vaccination lobby to quit.

All vaccinations have side effects. Indeed, 12 people who were vaccinated subsequently died, but in each case investigations by the committee on safety of medicines eliminated the vaccine as a cause. The fact that two events coincide does not mean there is a correlation. Remember, 18m people were vaccinated. Remember, too, an even starker statistic: one out of 10 people contracting the disease will die. We need to heed the professionals and protect our children.

fields.headline: Forest move for Ipswich's £2.5m Johnson
fields.trailText: Ipswich Town's swift and impressive acclimatisation to life back in the Premiership is likely to precipitate the £2.5m departure of David Johnson to Nottingham Forest.
fields.body:
Ipswich Town's swift and impressive acclimatisation to life back in the Premiership is likely to precipitate the £2.5m departure of David Johnson to Nottingham Forest.

The Forest manager David Platt yesterday tabled an official bid for the 24-year-old striker, who played a key role in Ipswich's promotion to the top flight but has been only a peripheral figure this season. "We've made a firm inquiry with Ipswich and I'm hoping to speak to George Burley again in the next 24 hours," said Platt.

Burley's £700,000 signing of Alun Armstrong from Middlesbrough last month has pushed Johnson further down the pecking order and Forest will be able to offer him first-team football again, albeit in the First Division. If everything goes according to plan, Platt hopes to conclude a deal in time for Johnson to make his debut against Wolves in the FA Cup on Sunday.

The struggling French champions Monaco are reportedly interested in signing the France defender Frank Leboeuf from Chelsea. Leboeuf is seen by Monaco as the man to plug a defence that has conceded 32 goals in 22 matches, the second worst record in the French league.

The defender has a contract with Chelsea until 2002 but Monaco believe the London club may be prepared to let him go if they receive the right offer as he will turn 32 later this month. Monaco are currently 15th in the 18-team French league, only four points above the relegation zone.

They are also reportedly interested in signing the Italian defender Christian Panucci, who is currently on loan to Chelsea from Internazionale.

Lazio are set to sign the Czech winger Karel Poborsky from Portugal's Benfica for around £3.5m, according to reports in Italian newspapers. The injury-hit Roman club have suffered a series of disappointing results since their manager Sven-Goran Eriksson was named as England's coach.

The Sunderland winger Nicky Summerbee has signed for the First Division promotion contenders Bolton in a £500,000 deal. The 29-year-old has not made a first-team appearance this season after negotiations over a new contract at the Stadium of Light stalled.

webTitle: Atkins future up in the air as Brown buys Carlisle

fields.headline: Atkins future up in the air as Brown buys Carlisle
fields.trailText: The Carlisle United manager Ian Atkins may find himself the first victim of the club's new era even if his side, six points adrift at the foot of the Third Division, beat Arsenal in the FA Cup third round on Saturday.
fields.body:
The Carlisle United manager Ian Atkins may find himself the first victim of the club's new era even if his side, six points adrift at the foot of the Third Division, beat Arsenal in the FA Cup third round on Saturday.

A consortium fronted by the property developer Stephen Brown and including a Gibraltarian investment company, Mamcarr Investments, completed its buy-out of Michael Knighton's 93% stake in the club yesterday and will meet with Atkins next week.

"If we beat Arsenal and get Manchester United in the next round, his position might be assured," said Brown. "This is a new chapter for Carlisle United. We have a good chance of avoiding relegation and, with the acquisition of a few players, I'm confident we'll start climbing the table."

Atkins, who recently made his first permanent signings since coming to the club when he bought Chesterfield's Michael Galloway and Dundee's Lee Maddison, said: "I've put a lot of hard work into this club. If I hadn't, we wouldn't be in with the fighting chance we have of avoiding relegation."
