webTitle: Fulham soccer captain breaks leg in car crash

fields.headline: Fulham soccer captain breaks leg in car crash
fields.trailText: The Fulham football captain, Chris Coleman, faces a fight to save his career after breaking his right leg in several places in a car crash on Tuesday night.
fields.body:
The Fulham football captain, Chris Coleman, faces a fight to save his career after breaking his right leg in several places in a car crash on Tuesday night.

The Wales international defender underwent emergency surgery at East Surrey hospital in Redhill where he was said to be comfortable yesterday after crashing his Jaguar through a metal fence and into a tree.

Firefighters spent around 45 minutes freeing him and a Surrey fire brigade spokeswoman said crews used cutting equipment to reach him.

Coleman was alone and there were no other vehicles involved. Police plan to inter view the former Blackburn player, who was not breathalised at the scene because he was in such pain.

An ambulance service spokesman, Russell Kempton, said Coleman had broken his leg in several places between ankle and knee and had an open wound. He had been conscious and in great pain.

Coleman's car destroyed 60ft of wrought iron fencing as it careered off the road and uprooted two trees before coming to rest in ditch.

Mr Kempton said. "The driver was trapped for the best part of an hour and it was necessary to give him pain relief."

 Liverpool and England striker Robbie Fowler was said to be "upset and shocked" yesterday after apparently being punched in the face in an early morning fracas.

He suffered slight face injuries in the attack at a Liverpoool bar which he had allegedly been asked to leave. A 39-year-old man was arrested and has been released on police bail.

fields.headline: Fowler injured in bar attack
fields.trailText: Liverpool and England footballer Robbie Fowler was today nursing his wounds after apparently being punched in the face in an early morning fracas outside a bar.
fields.body:
Liverpool and England footballer Robbie Fowler was today nursing his wounds after apparently being punched in the face in an early morning fracas outside a bar.

The striker was said to be upset and shocked after the alleged attack which was sparked by a fan taking a photograph as he enjoyed a drink with his fiancee, Kerry Hannon, and two friends.

The soccer star was understood to have been asked to leave the Wonder Bar in Liverpool after a row between him and another customer yesterday.

It is believed he was punched in the face as he was being escorted from the premises by door staff.

A 39-year-old man was arrested by police called by a friend of Mr Fowler's. The man was released on police bail until March 7.

A Liverpool FC spokesman said in a statement last night: "Robbie Fowler was the victim of a completely unprovoked assault in Liverpool. Although the player's injuries are not serious, Robbie is obviously upset and shocked."

Bar staff from a pub opposite the Wonder Bar said they saw Fowler stagger outside clutching his face while a small crowd of onlookers chanted his name. One barmaid said: "He seemed to have a big lump on his nose and loads of lads were chanting 'Fowler, Fowler'."

fields.headline: Letsbuyit.com bosses step down
fields.standfirst:
Jan 3: Letsbuyit.com on the brink
Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText:
9.45am: The management of Letsbuyit.com have paid the price for the online retailer's disastrous collapse, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 3: Letsbuyit.com on the brink
Special report: dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
The management of Letsbuyit.com have paid the price for the online retailer's disastrous collapse.

Chief executive Martin Coles last night resigned along with his management board, with supervisory board member John Palmer named as the new boss.

Administrators Paul Schaink and Maarten Drop will run the firm with Mr Palmer, and have set a deadline of four weeks to find the £50m needed to keep the company afloat.

Letsbuyit has just £11m left in the bank and has stopped taking orders on its website.

"The company is intending to continue talks with potential investors during this period and is aiming to reduce sales at the earliest possible date," said the company in a statement.

However, investors have lost all faith in Letsbuyit.com, which lost nearly 70% of its stock market value when its suspended shares resumed trading on Tuesday.

The overall plight of technology and internet stocks, which have been savaged by fears of a downturn in the US economy, has made the prospect of a rescue even more unlikely.

fields.headline: Toyota to boost British production
fields.trailText: Japanese car giant Toyota has announced it will step up car production in Britain by 30 percent, moving production of the three-door Corolla saloon from Japan to the company's existing Burnaston plant in Derbyshire.
fields.body:
Japanese car giant Toyota has announced it will step up car production in Britain by 30 percent, moving production of the three-door Corolla saloon from Japan to the company's existing Burnaston plant in Derbyshire.

However, the company is still concerned that the high level of sterling is hurting export competitiveness.

With an increase in production of engines for the car at Deeside, north Wales, approximately 300 jobs would be created.

Brian Jackson, a senior official of the company, told BBC radio that production at Burnaston would rise to 220,000 cars a year.

"We have the capacity and it is not really a new investment," he said. "We will fully utilise it."

Jackson, a director of Toyota UK, said the company was still concerned about the competitiveness of UK production given the high level of sterling.

"It will not fully remove the underlying problem, where it is difficult to be profitable with the present exchange rate," he said.

"We have a responsibility to make sure the plant survives and to supply customers with cars."

Toyota has long complained about the sterling exchange rate, which makes its UK-made cars more costly in Europe, and there have been concerns the company might rein back on investment in the UK while the government remained uncommitted on the euro.

Although Burnaston is Europe's second most productive car plant, it still made a £52m loss last year, largely because of sterling's relative strength against the euro.

On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, Toyota's shares ended the first session of the New Year modestly higher at 3,720 yen, up 1.92 percent.

Good news from Toyota follows year of motor industry misery

Vauxhall
 Workers suffered a huge shock last month when parent company General Motors announced it was closing the firm's Luton plant early next year with the loss of 2,000 jobs.

 Analysts say the American firm's move to end production of the Vectra at Luton could mean a total of more than 6,000 job losses because of its impact on the local economy and suppliers.

 Unions said British workers were suffering because the law made it easier for them to be laid off than their foreign counterparts.

Nissan
 The Government is believed to be offering the Japanese firm a £41 million aid package in an attempt to save production of the Micra at its Sunderland plant and secure 2,000 jobs, amid speculation that the plant might be under threat.

 Renault bought a 37 percent stake in the company in 1999 and is imposing economies of scale by merging production of models - the replacement for the Micra will be built alongside the Clio's successor.

 Insiders fear the next small hatchback will not be built in Sunderland but at a Renault plant in Flins, near Paris. Nissan is due to decide this month where the car will be built.

Ford
 The American giant announced last year that production of its Fiesta model at its Dagenham plant would end early next year - with the loss of 3,500 jobs.

 Last month 6,300 workers at the Essex plant voted almost two to one not to strike, and accepted a restructuring plan that will see £400m invested in a new diesel engine plant.

 Since May the company has reduced planned redundancies to 1,300.

Rover
 Rover's Longbridge plant was bought from German owners BMW by former chief executive John Towers for a nominal £10 last year after 1,000 jobs were lost.

 The deal saved thousands of jobs and since then the new company, MG Rover, has made significant progress in establishing itself in the marketplace - just before Christmas it reported buoyant sales.

 Chief executive Kevin Howe said UK dealerships had sold 35 percent more cars than in 1999 and the company had sold more than 200,000 vehicles worldwide.

 But Rover workers are unlikely to forget the weeks of uncertainty they faced as BMW negotiated with potential buyers such as venture capitalist Alchemy - its bid was eventually aborted.

Related special report
Rover in crisis

webTitle: Jones steps out of the darkness and into Molineux

fields.headline: Jones steps out of the darkness and into Molineux
fields.standfirst: Former Saints manager beats 50 applicants to take the helm at Wolves
fields.trailText: David Jones returned to football yesterday when he was appointed as manager of Wolverhampton Wanderers 29 days after leaving Chester crown court following the collapse of child-abuse charges and his exoneration by the judge.
fields.body:
David Jones returned to football yesterday when he was appointed as manager of Wolverhampton Wanderers 29 days after leaving Chester crown court following the collapse of child-abuse charges and his exoneration by the judge.

The 44-year-old Jones, who was also wanted by Barnsley, becomes the First Division club's fifth manager in seven years and has agreed a 3-year contract that ties him to Molineux until 2004.

His brief is straightforward but it is one that has proved beyond his immediate predecessors, namely Graham Turner, Graham Taylor, Mark McGhee and Colin Lee: to lead the club to the top flight after an absence of 17 years.

It is an objective Jones has not ruled out this season, even though Wolves are languishing in 12th place, 14 points shy of play-off places. "Why not?" he asked when he was introduced to the media and a welcoming posse of supporters.

"We have to have something to aim for. When I went to Southampton their priority was to finish fourth from bottom. But what if they failed and finished one place below that? They were out, so why not aim for the top?"

It was his positive style that enabled Jones to see off the claims of Dave Bassett and another 50 applicants to succeed Lee, who was sacked just before Christmas.

"The board's decision was unanimous and it was Jones's determination and desire to manage Wolves that tipped the scales in his favour," said the club's managing director Jez Moxey.

Wolves were also impressed by the way Jones dealt with his personal ordeal. "We have seen his resilience in a difficult time and we believe he can use this to make Wolverhampton Wanderers successful and get us promoted," Moxey added.

And after 17 years of waiting, Wolves will also be delighted to have come across a manager who has wasted little time in returning to work and is in even more of a hurry to get back to the Premiership.

"I had no control of what went on at Southampton," said Jones, who was paid off by them against his will so that he could concentrate on clearing his name.

"They made a decision I didn't agree with it but I understand why they had to do it. I felt I shouldn't have been out of the Premiership and I want to get back there."

Such undisguised ambition suggests Jones sees this job as a route to higher things but he rejects such suggestions. In fact, reading between the lines, Jones regards under-achieving Wolves as the biggest club he has managed.

"Someone said to me, you can use Wolves as a stepping stone to get to a bigger club. This is not a big club, it's a massive club. I compare it with the one I played at - Everton. And if it gets into the Premiership how many bigger clubs are there?"

Once that is achieved, Jones will still not be satisfied. "When, not if, this club gets in the Premiership that will still not be enough. I want to win cups and get into Europe."

For the time being Jones plans to put his ambitions on hold and assess what Lee has left behind. He has been promised money for new players but will give the current squad members every chance to prove themselves. That chance, however, is accompanied by a stark warning: "If any player here or any member of the coaching staff is not as ambitious as me they will be gone. It's as simple as that," he said.

It is a stance that will doubtless make Jones a few enemies. That will not worry him: his real enemies, those who falsely accused him, have been vanquished. "They didn't have a case," Jones said.

By contrast, the events of the past year have shown Jones just how many friends he has, evidence of which can be found on his kitchen walls. "At the last count they were covered by more than 2,000 cards and letters sent to me. All were supportive - I did not realise how many friends I have got, not just in this country but in the world.

"It was frightening because people weren't even putting my address on the envelopes. All that some said were 'Dave Jones, ex-Saints manager. Please forward'.

"Now I can do what I do best and that's managing a football club," he said. And with the Wolves motto reading Out of Darkness Comes Light, where better to do it?

webTitle: Liverpool poised to complete Litmanen signing

fields.headline: Liverpool poised to complete Litmanen signing
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier confidently expects to unveil Jari Litmanen as Liverpool's latest foreign recruit today in a whirlwind move that is likely to trigger Robbie Fowler's departure from Anfield this summer.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier confidently expects to unveil Jari Litmanen as Liverpool's latest foreign recruit today in a whirlwind move that is likely to trigger Robbie Fowler's departure from Anfield this summer.

Litmanen is scheduled to arrive on Merseyside this afternoon with his financial adviser Heikki Martinen to conclude a free transfer from Barcelona and become the highest paid player in English football on wages of £55,000 a week.

"The deal has been agreed and Jari is flying to England to talk about personal terms," his agent Harri Kampman confirmed last night.

"It has always been my dream to play for Liverpool," said Litmanen. "I have supported them since I was a child and there has been talk about me joining them before. I seem to have been linked with every club in Europe but it's no secret that Liverpool have always been very special to me."

Houllier had to act quickly after the Belgian champions Anderlecht and Fenerbahce of Turkey both instigated talks with the 29-year-old Finland captain. Litmanen has been the Finnish player of the year for nine consecutive seasons but his international pedigree has still not been enough to warrant a regular place at Barcelona.

Since Louis van Gaal quit as Barca's coach last May his successor Lorenzo Serra Ferrer has made it clear that Litmanen's services are no longer required at the Nou Camp, playing him in only one friendly match all season.

Nevertheless, Litmanen's form as a creative attacker in nine successful years under Van Gaal at Ajax was such that Houllier knows he has lured one of Europe's finest talents to help his team consolidate their challenge for a Champions League place.

Liverpool have closely monitored Litmanen's progress for several years but his arrival, perhaps initially on a loan agreement pending discussions over a 2-year contract, will almost certainly have career-changing repercussions for Fowler.

The England striker is giving renewed thought to breaking his ties with Anfield after a number of disagreements with Houllier and, after being the victim of street attacks twice in 18 months, the apparent change in attitude towards him in Liverpool.

Although neither party is willing to go on the record, both Fowler and Houllier have privately accepted that it may be time for him to make a clean break at the end of the season. Chelsea reiterated their long-standing interest yesterday, while Aston Villa are the latest to make discreet inquiries with the player's advisers.

webTitle: Angry Robson 'in the clear' as Spurs seek video review

fields.headline: Angry Robson 'in the clear' as Spurs seek video review
fields.trailText: Bobby Robson is unlikely to face disciplinary action from the Football Association for his criticism of the referee Steve Bennett during and after Newcastle's 4-2 defeat at Tottenham on Tuesday night.
fields.body:
Bobby Robson is unlikely to face disciplinary action from the Football Association for his criticism of the referee Steve Bennett during and after Newcastle's 4-2 defeat at Tottenham on Tuesday night.

The Newcastle manager was involved in an exchange with Bennett at half-time and also remonstrated with the fourth official, Andy d'Urso. Afterwards he criticised Bennett's performance, angry that the official had ignored United's claims for a penalty but had awarded Spurs two spot-kicks and sent off Nolberto Solano for handball.

Robson also expressed amazement that Kieron Dyer was not awarded a free-kick in the incident which precipitated his dismissal for foul and abusive language to an assistant referee. "I am as angry as I have been since I came back to manage in England," Robson said. The FA is awaiting Bennett's report but is thought unlikely to take the matter further.

Tottenham have asked Bennett to review his decision to send off Neil Sullivan, the Spurs goalkeeper, in the same match. Television replays indicated that the Scottish international made contact with the ball when he challenged Dyer in the penalty box early in the second half and Tottenham hope that he will escape a ban when the referee looks at the video of the match.

Tottenham's manager George Graham was in understanding mood afterwards but was convinced that his man should have avoided punishment. "The referee sees what he sees and he has to make a decision on that," said Graham. "I have seen a rerun of the incident and the goalkeeper actually touched the ball. It probably looked like a sending-off but he doesn't have a video to help him out."

Should Bennett stick to his guns, Graham will be encouraged that Ian Walker, who came on as a substitute after Sullivan's dismissal, has said he will now stay and try to force his way back into the first team rather than continue to seek a loan move.

"I will wait and see how the appeal goes but if I get a game or two, then I won't be asking to go anywhere at the moment," Walker said. "The plan was to go in and see the manager today but now I will wait and see what happens before doing that."

Darren Anderton has also said that he wants to stay at White Hart Lane. The midfielder's contract ends in the summer and he, along with the club captain Sol Campbell, are now free to speak to foreign clubs.

But Anderton, 28, said he had opened contract talks and was hopeful of a positive outcome. "I'm not just saying I want to stay, I really do want to. I feel I am part of the family here. I know that because my contract is up in the summer I could talk to foreign clubs now, but I would rather stay at Spurs.

"My agent had a meeting with David Pleat, the club's director of football, just before Christmas. Although no offer was made at the meeting, Spurs asked if I wanted to stay at the club and I made it clear to them through my agent that I did.

"I will wait and see what offer they come up with, and I imagine they will do that soon now that we have finished with the Christmas and new year fixture programme. If a European club came in for me tomorrow I would wait to see what Spurs had to offer me first before I made any decision."

Campbell said that his future would be determined by the intentions of the club's new owners, Enic. "I have put my cards on the table and it all depends on what the new owners want when they come in," he said. "They know where I am."

Portsmouth have cancelled the contract of their manager Tony Pulis for an alleged act of misconduct. Pulis was put on four months' leave and replaced by Steve Claridge in October to allow him to concentrate on fighting a high court case against his former club Gillingham and their chairman Paul Scally. The club refused to reveal what the alleged act of misconduct was, while Pulis himself was unavailable for comment.

West Bromwich Albion have completed the signing of the goalkeeper Russell Hoult from Portsmouth for £450,000.

fields.headline: Government warns of measles outbreak
fields.trailText: Children returning to school for the new term are at risk from a potentially fatal measles outbreak because of health fears over the controversial measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, government scientists warned today.
fields.body:
Children returning to school for the new term are at risk from a potentially fatal measles outbreak because of health fears over the controversial measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine, government scientists warned today.

Concern that the MMR jab could be linked to autism and other problems have led to immunisation levels falling to a dangerously low level, the Public Health Laboratory Service (PHLS) said.

Now the new intake of four-year-olds into Britain's primary schools contains high numbers who have not been vaccinated, which could trigger a major outbreak of the disease.

In Dublin - where there has been a similar drop in the take-up of MMR - two children have died and hundreds more have been ill.

For the MMR vaccine to be effective, 95% of the child population must have the jab to ensure so-called "herd immunity" for everyone.

But reports three years ago showing a possible link to autism and other problems have caused immunisation levels to fall to 88% and to as low as 75% in some parts of London.

That means as many as one in four children in some age groups may not be protected against measles, which can cause death or permanent brain damage. Professor Brian Duerden, medical director of the PHLS, said: "This is a serious situation. We have to do all we can to convince parents that the MMR jab is safe. We've a safe vaccine which we have looked at in great detail because of concerns that were raised and we've found it is not linked to these side effects people are worried about."

The Department of Health also defended the MMR jab. A spokeswoman said: "This is a safe vaccine and we would urge parents to have their children immunised."

fields.headline: Obituary: Betty Westgate
fields.trailText: Campaign founder who helped change attitudes to breast cancer.
fields.body:
The major change in attitudes to breast cancer can be credited to women such as Betty Westgate, founder and president of Breast Cancer Care, who has died aged 81. In 1968, this small, outgoing biology teacher had a biopsy for a lump in the breast. It was diagnosed as benign, but a week later she was told it was not, and that she would be having a mastectomy. She knew little about breast cancer, and when she asked a doctor about the operation, he reacted as though he could not understand her need to know.

Later, after five weeks of radiotherapy, another doctor told her how marvellous it was that women could survive five or even more years after a mastectomy. Resentment and anger at this casual death sentence fired Betty with the determination to live for another 30 years. The myths, inaccuracies and superstitions surrounding breast cancer led her into a major reading and learning programme.

In 1972 she founded Cancer Education Voluntary Service, offering a talk called "Lumps and Bumps" to groups. From the questions asked, she recognised the need for an organisation giving non-medical help and post-operative information. Since it did not exist, she set up one herself, and called it the Mastectomy Association.

Born in Wiltshire but educated in Croydon, Betty first ran the campaign from her Croydon home, helped by her husband Jim, a chief mechanical engineer at London Transport, whom she married in 1940. When finance became a problem she sought funding, and from 1977 received an annual grant from the Department of Health. In 1981, she found funding for an office and paid staff. In 1994 the name was changed to Breast Cancer Care (BCC).

What was extraordinary was the range of Betty's understanding of the many facets of breast cancer and her ability to understand women's needs. In the 70s, post-operative women were advised to stuff handkerchiefs, cotton wool which disintegrated, or even tights into their bras; breast forms were few in size and could be lumpy. In 1974 Betty designed the "Cumfie", which was washable, spin-dryable, supersoft; they were still being made in the 90s.

Today, BCC organises fashion parades, but early on Betty saw the need for purpose-designed swimwear and bras. She got VAT removed from them. She also got prostheses made in different sizes and lighter weights. She bared her own scar and prosthesis, and later the implant, to nurses. In the days when a woman needed her doctor to write a letter to approve a breast implant, Betty wrote to a doctor who had suggested that one of his patients did not need one and asked him whether if he lost a testicle he would want an implant.

Betty told the story of her campaign in a booklet, Life, Here I Come! It was published in 1998 to celebrate 25 years of the organisation she founded. The title of the book summed up Betty's philosophy. She travelled the world to talk and educate people about the charity. She had a great love of flying, and had trained as a pilot until forced to give it up when she was pregnant with her first child in 1942. When, aged 70, she was told she was too old to go hang-gliding, she was most indignant.

She is survived by Jim and her four sons.

webTitle: British 'bone factory' discovery offers new surgical hope for the elderly

fields.headline: British 'bone factory' discovery offers new surgical hope for the elderly
fields.trailText: Seven years of patent protected research have led to a world first for British medical scientists, who have reproduced the body's "bone factory" cell in a university laboratory. By Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
Seven years of patent protected research have led to a world first for British medical scientists, who have reproduced the body's "bone factory" cell in a university laboratory.

Bio-material taken from human skeletal cells has successfully triggered the natural process of endochronal ossification (EO) which creates cartilage and new bone round fractures and damaged bones.

Trials of injecting the new substance into hip and knee joints and dental repairs will start shortly at Sheffield University, after success in triggering bone-making in ordinary marrow cells.

Potentially the technique has important implications for surgery on older people, whose natural cartilage replacement has slowed down, and in reversing the bone damage caused by osteoporosis in older bones.

"We believe we have discovered the gold standard in this field," said Bradley Stringer, a tissue specialist at Sheffield, which took out protective patents in 1994 when doctors decided to investigate copying the natural EO process. "What we've created is the very stuff that nature produces herself to repair bones or make them grow."

The product, provisionally named Skeletex, is the result of painstaking work to copy the rich mixture of proteins and chemicals which trigger bone growth and repair. The Sheffield formula exactly mirrors the collection of active ingredients and others which remain inert until they meet bone marrow cells, which they then trigger into helping the ossification.

"You could call it a chemical soup, or perhaps a chemical symphony," said Dr Stringer. "The task has been to find all the orchestra's members and then to get them playing together."

Trials will start at Sheffield's school of clinical dentistry on volunteers with dental implants or gum disease which has worn away the bone which helps hold teeth in place.

Success will lead to commercial marketing.

"One of our problems in med icine today is a shortage in the bone bank for conventional grafts," said Dr Stringer.

"Skeletex also has the promise to be much more effective than grafts, especially those using bone material ... where sterilisation is essential and the result is not always as effective as the natural, bone growing process."

Hip and knee joints are another potential market be cause of the bio-material's strength which promises to remove the "joint wobble" problem which tends to affect people when cement used to fix artificial joint pins wears loose.

Commercial benefits will accrue to Sheffield through its tissue-engineering company CellFactors which has financed the research programme.

webTitle: Bullied train staff to receive counselling

fields.headline: Bullied train staff to receive counselling
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train staff are to receive help from a 24-hour counselling hotline set up to help them cope with the stress of dealing with "rail rage"  passengers.
fields.body:
Train staff are to receive help from a 24-hour counselling hotline set up to help them cope with the stress of dealing with "rail rage" passengers.

Virgin Trains and Silverlink are both set to provide a help-line for their workers.

Richard Branson's company has written to its 3,000 staff to tell them about the new service in the wake of months of rail disruption which has resulted in verbal abuse and threats of physical violence from passengers.

The hotline will be staffed by experts from PPP Healthcare every day of the year.

The south-London Connex service has reported four attacks on staff, while Great North Eastern Railways has stepped up counselling for workers and their families.

Partners of employees have been included in the counselling package and there have also been reports of the children of Railtrack workers being bullied at school.

Stress on workers, who are in the firing line of complaints, increased following the Hatfield crash which claimed four lives and sparked a series of delays as tracks were replaced around the country.

Flashpoints have been identified at major stations such as Watford Junction and Euston.

webTitle: BBC news chief's opera job talks stall

fields.headline: Hall waiting in the wings as opera talks stall
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Talks between BBC head of news Tony Hall and the Royal Opera House may have stalled over money, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Talks between the BBC's head of news, Tony Hall, and Royal Opera House management appear to have stalled over money.

Mr Hall was before Christmas reported to have been on the shortlist for the job of executive director. An opera lover, Mr Hall is understood to be keen to take on the high-profile role, but may be holding out for a better financial package, say sources.

His appointment was expected to be announced on December 22 but will not be made until at least next week when he returns from his Christmas holidays.

However, to maintain his current salary would pose a challenge for the board of the Opera House, whose pay scales, in line with other arts bodies, do not offer the lucrative packages accrued by senior BBC staff.

Mr Hall took home £250,000 last year in salary and other benefits while the last Royal Opera House head, Michael Kaiser, earned around £140,000 a year.

Public sector arts administration jobs pay significantly lower salaries than their private sector counterparts, with the highest-paid arts administrator, the South Bank Centre's Karsten Witt, believed to earn £213,000.

Mr Hall, who has been a director of BBC News since 1990, was close to the former director general John Birt, but is thought to have cooler relations with the present incumbent, Greg Dyke.

fields.headline: Elderly suicides: the religious divide
fields.trailText: Popular images of happy, long-lived Italians and isolated, lonely British pensioners have been overturned by new research which found elderly people in Catholic and Orthodox countries are more likely to commit suicide than those in secular and Protestant countries
fields.body:
Elderly people in Catholic and Orthodox countries are more likely to commit suicide than those in secular and Protestant countries, according to new research.

The findings completely overturn popular images of happy, long-lived Italians and isolated, lonely British pensioners.

The unexpected results are a tribute to UK health and social services, said Colin Pritchard, of Southampton University, who argues that suicide among the over-75s is a sign of neglect and isolation.

He suggested the extended family still does provide a support system in Latin countries. But if you dont have children or you are unmarried then you are worse off than in Britain, he added.

Despite a strong prohibition of suicide by the Catholic church, elderly suicide rates are higher in Italy, Spain and Portugal than in the UK or Scandinavia. An exception is Ireland, which has a very low rate but where researchers believe suicides are under-reported to spare relatives shame. But Orthodox Greece also has a lower rate than England and Wales.

The study by Professor Pritchard and Dr David Baldwin, published in the latest edition of the International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry, shows the five highest elderly male suicide rates per million were Hungary at 1785, Slovenia at 1225, Austria at 1168, Bulgaria at 1125 and the Russian Federation at 1093. The countries with the lowest elderly male rates were New Zealand at 250, England and Wales at 163, Greece at 143, Ireland at 139, and Scotland at 135.

Prof Pritchard said: "Our findings were completely unexpected. Suicide amongst elderly people is usually associated with ill health, social isolation and exclusion. With elderly people in Catholic and Orthodox countries tending to hold more traditional views on the family and religion, we might have assumed that this would be reflected in lower suicide rates, not higher.

"The 'extended family' is a feature in countries such as Italy, yet the Italian elderly suicide rate was far higher than in Britain. Additionally, suicide is still seen as a cardinal sin in many Catholic and Orthodox countries, yet some of the highest rates of elderly (over 75 years of age) male and female suicide were found in such countries as Spain, Portugal and Italy. The lowest rates were mainly in 'secular' countries such as Canada, New Zealand and Britain."

Scotland had the lowest rates of suicide amongst elderly men in the 35 countries investigated, with England and Wales coming 31st lowest out of 35, and 26th out of 35, in respect of suicide amongst elderly women. Professor Pritchard says the low Scottish figure may reflect a more rural population with a tradition of mutual support and self-reliance.

"This reflects well on British general practitioners, social services staff and geriatricians, but especially upon the much maligned British family carers, who bear the greatest load in support of their elderly relatives," said Prof Pritchard.

"However, these results show that we need to rethink views on suicide, and continue to improve provision of services for elderly people and rid ourselves of ageist stereotypes. The majority of elderly suicides die because they are inadequately supported and/or have poor medical care," he added.

webTitle: No 10 rebukes Hoey in gun row

fields.headline: No 10 rebukes Hoey in gun row
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Downing Street last night slapped down the outspoken sports minister Kate Hoey after she attacked the ban on handguns introduced after the Dunblane massacre.
fields.body:
Downing Street last night slapped down the outspoken sports minister Kate Hoey after she attacked the ban on handguns introduced after the Dunblane massacre.

A spokeswoman stressed Ms Hoey's views, which drew immediate condemnation from anti-gun campaigners, were not shared by the prime minister and were a clear breach of laws banning all handguns introduced in 1997.

The careful distancing from the junior minister's views came after the maverick MP for Vauxhall told a shooting magazine fellow Labour MPs had taken a "very unfair attitude" towards legitimate shooting. She claimed the ban had done nothing to prevent criminals getting their hands on weapons and suggested young children should be encouraged to learn shooting.

The minister appeared particularly provocative since her comments came barely a week after she contradicted the government line by calling for a return to terracing at Premiership football grounds, which have been all-seater since the Taylor Report into the Hillsborough tragedy.

Ms Hoey, an Arsenal fan who learned to shoot as a farmer's daughter in County Antrim, has been no stranger to controversy. She has consistently defended foxhunting, winning plaudits from the Countryside Alliance.

fields.headline: Starbucks seeks online loyalty
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
Starbucks
fields.trailText: Starbucks Coffee Company has teamed up with Microsoft in an online venture to make customers linger longer over their lattes, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Starbucks Coffee Company has teamed up with Microsoft to make customers linger longer over their lattes.

The Seattle coffee firm has linked with its cross-town neighbour to offer North American customers a range of broadband internet services designed to improve brand loyalty and revenues.

Frappuccino fans will be able to order their favourite drinks over their mobile phones or hook their laptop computers or handheld organisers to the web via a wireless connection when they visit the store for their morning croissant and cappuccino.

"These new relationships will provide us with a great opportunity to enhance our existing customers' in-store experience as well as attract new customers to our retail locations," said Howard Schultz, chairman of Starbucks. He said 90% of his customers were internet users.

Coffee drinkers will be able to log on to Microsoft's MSN network or access their corporate intranet and work remotely. The network infrastructure will be provided by MobileStar. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Starbucks operates about 150 outlets in Britain though there are no firm plans to export the scheme across the Atlantic at present.

Analysts predict that technology that enables devices to be connected to the internet without wires will be made widely available at buildings like airports, conference halls, shopping malls and coffee shops where there is a captive audience.

Locally provided networks can be much cheaper than national or international networks and businesses like coffee shops believe that if they can offer customers cheaper or free connections to the web, they will hang around their stores longer and buy more goods.

Starbucks is keen to project a progressive corporate image through new technology but in August it was forced to write off a £14m investment in online venture Living.com, a furniture retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection. Other investments have also struggled.

webTitle: Dismal December meant one dot.com closure a day

fields.headline: Dismal December meant one dot.com closure a day
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: At least 210 internet companies worldwide went out of business last year, according to a survey by webmergers.com, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
At least 210 internet companies worldwide went out of business last year, according to a survey by webmergers.com.

The San Francisco company estimated that as many as 15,000 people lost their jobs as a result of the closures.

That does not include all dot.com layoffs, however, because many companies still in business have reduced staff.

The rate of companies failing accelerated in the fourth quarter of 2000 with 60%, of closures - 121 - happening towards the end of the year. The closure rate in the last three months of the year was more than one company a day.

"Shutdowns accelerated in the fourth quarter as dot.coms began to run out of funding that began drying up after the stock market shakeup that began in late March," the report says.

About $1.5bn of investment money and 40 companies were lost in December, compared with 46 closures in November.

The business-to-consumer sector was hardest hit, with 75% of failures being in that area, according to the study.

Hi-tech regional centres bore the brunt of the fall-out with just above 30% of closures taking place in California. New York and Massachusetts each accounted for nearly 10%, while western Europe lost 23 companies, 11% of the total.

Most of the companies that failed, 109 out of 210, were e-commerce businesses. Online content sites made up another 30 of the total, with infrastructure and other online service companies accounting for the rest of the failures.

Some firms shut in December even before they ran out of money. DeskTop.com and BizBuyer.com, both closed before their funding ran out.

The study concluded that: "At least a quarter of December's shutdowns are seeking to sell their assets or to reorganise through bankruptcy filings or some other means."

The report was based on data from more than 50 news sources and concentrated on large companies.

webTitle: Sportinglife.com adds video and radio coverage

fields.headline: Sportinglife.com adds video and radio coverage
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Sportinglife.com, the PA/Trinity Mirror website joint venture, is to offer video and radio sports news coverage, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sportinglife.com, the PA/Trinity Mirror sports website joint venture, is to begin offering video and radio sports news coverage.

The new online services are expected to go live later this month, following deals with Sports Media Broadcasting and SNTVi.

Sports Media Broadcasting is to supply sportinglife.com with an eight-hour daily radio show, while SNTVi, which is owned by TV sports news agency SNTV, will provide video footage to the site.

Sportinglife.com users will be able to watch and listen to the latest news and interviews across a range of sports including football, rugby, golf, cricket, motor racing and horseracing.

David Annat, sportinglife.com managing director, said: "These deals will provide additional valuable streams of content, further complementing our position as the online authority for sports news and information."

fields.headline: 13,000 hopefuls queue up for Castaway 2001
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The producers of Castaway have revealed that 13,000 hopefuls have approached them for Castaway 2001, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
It might be thought that the goldfish-like existence of the participants of Castaway, Big Brother and countless other TV shows would be enough to deter most viewers from signing up for a reality-TV show.

But the producers of Castaway have revealed that a staggering 13,000 hopefuls have approached them wanting to join the next Castaway programme.

Jeremy Mills, joint managing director of Lion TV, who was behind the original programme, was keeping plans for the follow-up, Castaway 2001, close to his chest.

But he said the follow-up would definitely not be set on a tropical island.

"We're going to do the same thing, taking a group of people to a place where they will be forced to confront aspects of themselves they might not have dealt with before and address their preconceptions," he said.

fields.headline: Fiat unveils £4m Punto campaign
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Fiat has unveiled a £4m TV campaign for its Punto car taking a horror movie theme as its centrepiece, writes Caroline Furneaus.
fields.body:
Fiat's latest TV campaign takes a horror movie theme as its centrepiece.

The £4m campaign is the seventh in a series of adverts that play on the relationships between men and women, who are being exhorted to buy the latest in the car company's Punto range.

The ad opens with a car fleeing from the lava-path of a volcano, dodging deadly flows of volcanic ash. As the lava and smoke begin to envelop the car, it comes to an abrupt halt.

But, as it is adland, neither of the occupants perish. Instead a young woman furious with her back-seat driver boyfriend emerges, hair flying in gale force wind, demanding he take over the wheel.

The agency behind the campaign, D'Arcy, said the campaign was aimed to appeal equally to the feisty nature in both men and women

In a departure from previous Spirito di Punto commercials, the ad is shot to feel dark and threatening, part of a bid to break with the traditional beauty parade feel of car adverts.

webTitle: TV rivals accuse Smith of collusion with BBC

fields.headline: TV rivals accuse Smith of collusion with BBC
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Some of the best known names in commercial television have rounded on culture secretary Chris Smith for what they see as his failure to regulate the BBC's expansion plans.
fields.body:
Some of the best known names in commercial television have rounded on culture secretary Chris Smith for what they see as his failure to regulate the BBC's expansion plans.

A consortium of seven broadcasters including BSkyB, Turner Broadcasting and Telewest are pressing Mr Smith to formalise the criteria by which the corporation may launch new services.

In a strongly worded letter they also express their concern over the relationship between the BBC and the department for culture, media and sport. It suggests both sides regard consultation on the corporation's raft of new services as a mere "rubber stamping".

The letter, dated December 22 and leaked to The Guardian reads: "From our contacts within the industry, as well as the BBC itself, we know that plans for BBC3 and BBC4 and the childrens' services are continuing apace. We are extremely concerned that the BBC is behaving as if it had been given tacit consent."

One industry source said: "it looks like cosy collusion between the BBC and DCMS". The letter was also signed by the heads of MTV Networks Europe, Nickelodeon, Discovery and Artsworld, the recently launched arts channel led by Sir Jeremy Isaacs.

Greg Dyke, BBC director general, sparked fury in the commercial sector when he outlined plans last summer to launch BBC3 at the youth market and BBC4 which will be focused on arts and cultural programming. During the day, services for children will run on both channels. The commercial sector argues the BBC should be prevented from launching into already well served markets with licence fee funded services.

The BBC has already submitted draft proposals for its new services which are expected to go to public consultation in the next few weeks. The letter however urges the government to wait until the commercial sector has more clarity on the rules governing the BBC. "As you are aware, the BBC's proposed new services will, if approved, have a wide reaching and long term impact on commercial broadcasters...We request the guidelines (for approving new ser vices) are published as soon as possible"

The signatories, including Tony Ball, chief executive of BSkyB and Adam Singer of Telewest have requested an urgent meeting to discuss the approvals process with Mr Smith.

A DCMS spokeswoman said Mr Smith has yet to see the letter and returns from holiday next week.

Mr Smith announced in June that the BBC would face tougher tests before launching new publicly funded services against measures including the effect on the commercial sector. Formalised criteria have not been made public and it remains unclear whether there is an intention to do so.

A key plank of Mr Dyke's argument is that the childrens' services will commission new British-made programming. The Disney Channel, Nickelodeon and Cartoon Network largely rely on US imports.

fields.headline: Shell joins petrol price war
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Shell yesterday hit back at the supermarkets in the growing petrol price war, cutting pump prices by 1p a litre, with rivals expected to follow suit.
fields.body:
Shell yesterday hit back at the supermarkets in the growing petrol price war, cutting pump prices by 1p a litre, with rivals expected to follow suit.

But that did little to assuage anger among motorist groups which dismissed the cuts as too little, too late. They accused forecourt retailers of "ripping off" consumers.

Shell has reduced its cheapest unleaded petrol to 75.9p a litre, the lowest level for six months, following cuts by the Sainsbury, Tesco and Morrisons supermarket chains. Other oil groups such as BP, Esso and Texaco said they were always sensitive to competitive pressures and would keep prices in line with rivals'.

Campaigners point out that during September's fuel protests the monthly average crude price was $34 per barrel but in December it fell to under $24 a barrel.

Edmund King of the RAC said: "Oil companies are very quick to raise prices ... but very slow to actually reduce them when the world oil price falls. It's ripping off the consumer at the pumps."

Garry Russell, organiser of the Dump the Pump pressure group, accepted that retail margins were tight but said oil companies made billions in profit on oil extraction. "They are profiteering from that and I believe the chancellor should target them with a windfall tax."

But an oil industry spokesman said companies could make further cuts only if Gordon Brown eased the tax burden on petrol.

Ray Holloway of the Petrol Retailers Association said the percentage of tax in the retail price during the protests was 76% and that had risen to 79% "That figure is the very reason why prices cannot fall much further in the UK." A drop from 79.9p in September to 75.9p was a significant change.

Shadow transport minister Bernard Jenkin called on the government to reduce fuel duty, something Mr Brown refused to do in November during his pre-Budget Statement.

Analysts said oil companies were right to delay large price cuts, particularly with talk of Opec agreeing ouput reductions at its January 17 meeting.

fields.headline: European disunion
fields.standfirst:
A titanic struggle is looming after the next election, between the prime minister and his chancellor
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: A titanic struggle is looming after the next election, between the prime minister and his chancellor.
fields.body:
The epic struggle of 2001 will not be the general election. The election, in the eyes of most participants, is already decided. The details are awaited, including the incalculable size of the Labour majority. And the psyche of politicians requires them never to be certain of anything, so near-panic will always hover. But the struggle that is real and unpredictable will come after. It will be the great story of this year. Its potential for exposing ruinous division in a newly elected government - or else for driving that government to duck a decision history requires of it - is taking, I believe, a new turn.

There is no getting away from the euro. After a decent victory, especially if it's big, Tony Blair cannot avoid addressing his commitment to decide whether sterling ought to join. But first he will need to address and resolve the differences between himself and Gordon Brown, differences that show no sign of slackening. They are, if anything, deepening: not, perhaps, as a matter of substance, but as a matter of tactics, bringing into play new definitions of what this decision is all about, and new judgments on whether the British people can be persuaded to back the euro in a referendum.

The major assessment of the euro, Mr Blair and Mr Brown have always said, must be economic. Now the five tests that Brown laid down for the economic effects of entry are closer to being met, and arguably are already satisfied. Added to this is the recovery of the euro's market value, which makes it possible to envisage the exchange-rate issue becoming a lot more manageable in the months following the election.

But this, of course, is not the end of the story. The core question was, is and always will be political. Is entry, in the larger sense, a good thing? Is it essential to British power and influence, or destructive of same? Do the British want to change their national trajectory in this definitive way? Are we ready, after our dabbling baptism 30 years ago, for the existential plunge we have resisted since the war?

Blair's position is now that he has a strong bias for entry. His euro-glass is more than half-full. He needs to believe he can carry a referendum, but the main effect of the Nice summit was to replenish his confidence that he can win the national argument on Europe. He slaughtered William Hague then and, we're assuming, will have done so again at the election. Besides, another landslide victory cannot easily coexist, in his mind, with retreat from the contest he has been holding out as the reason for silencing the euro debate during the election campaign.

He also has a historic mission to fulfil. That's another swayer of subjective judgment. He will have secured his first historic goal, the second term, but has often cited the ending of British ambivalence on Europe as the other one. He wants a reformed Europe. He welcomes the retreat of power from Brussels. His Europeanism is pragmatic, realistic, British. He is certain that Britain cannot expect to influence the shape the new Europe takes unless London is a fully participating member of the single currency.

Brown's position is different, a bias, I would say, against entry. Not for ever, and not with any trace of the anti- Europeanism of the modern Tory party. Gordon Brown is a serious man. He is perfectly aware of the linkage between the island and continental economies. His scepticism about the euro is not that of the dissembler (David Owen), the nationalist (Michael Portillo) or the fanatic (Margaret Thatcher).

But he has developed Thatcher-like traits. The shortcomings of European economies irritate him as much as the brilliance of the American model entrances him. Europe, he believes, still has much to learn, and the lessons are one-way, from Anglo-Saxonry east, never vice versa. The road to a liberalised economy is long, and across the channel has barely begun to be traversed. He knows where it leads, and is magisterially impatient with EU colleagues who have not seen the light.

More crucially, the Treasury is developing a political and not just an economic position. This is the change I'm noticing. Maybe it has something to do with the discovery that, in statistical terms, the five economic tests, plus the exchange-rate, are looking positive. But Brown's anxiety about the EU now touches on such issues as its perceived legitimacy and democratic accountability. The European Commission has become a bugbear of, again, Thatcher-like resonance, getting in the way of his schemes for venture capital and regional aid, and even daring to challenge the personal triumph he secured last year against a unified withholding tax.

A sixth test, in short, begins to emerge: that the EU should be seen to be more democratically accountable, and not controlled by faceless bureaucrats, before a referendum can safely be held. For no country has won a referendum on the euro. It is a huge political risk, likely to awaken the deeper scepticism that people rightly have about the very legitimacy of the EU as presently run. These issues, the argument goes, are not just the creation of the Sun, the Times and the Mail. They have the capacity, unless we carefully respect them, to wreck what this government has achieved, just as the euro itself, entered at the wrong moment, will put in peril the hard-won prosperity of the Brown chancellorship, not to mention the future career of the man who has yet to be prime minister.

On this view, there is, to put it mildly, no urgency about a referendum. Trying to calculate its timing, as is commonly done, by reference to the following election is a tactic of almost contemptible triviality. These issues are much bigger than tactics. Europe needs time, to get both its economy and its politics right, before Labour could recommend Brits to vote for a new kind of future that, among other things, transfers monetary sovereignty to a European central bank that needs more political input. Not only must we be sure of winning, we need serious proof of a national consensus. Hair's-breadth majorities are not enough. I've heard 70% as the desirable minimum "yes" before the Treasury would happily plunge.

What will happen after the election? The economic assessment, as promised, will be made. The Treasury intends it to be extremely detailed. It passionately believes in its stated tests, and rejects the scorn often heaped on them. What's indisputable, though, is that the verdict can be heavily conditioned by the answer the government wants to hear. If Mr Brown does not revisit his scepticism, and if he wants to set the scene for a referendum that must be at best delayed, he has the means at his disposal.

The decisive argument with Mr Blair must therefore happen before the assessment is completed. While the economic benefits of entry can never be "proved" either way, the statement of probabilities will vitally affect the environment in which the political choice is made. The smallest hesitation by the Treasury will be seized on as a signal from Brown that Blair cannot ignore. Just as the faintest quiver of Brown's doubting eyelid, once the decision to go ahead is made, would be exploited by the other side, including the sceptic newspapers that have already made him their hero.

The broadening of the Brown agenda has not yet been conveyed to 10 Downing Street. Indeed, the post-election scenario has not been deeply thought about there at all, partly because ministers seldom have time to look more than a week ahead, but also because such planning cuts against the conceit on which Blair and Brown do strongly agree, that the euro has no place in the election campaign.

It's too early to call Brown's position destructive. For one thing, the referendum does not axiomatically have to happen very soon. Though that's the conventional calculation, it could wait until 2003 if currency-convergence required it, and also to allow more time for Brown's anxieties about the politics to be allayed. Most Labour MPs simply want to get shot of the issue, and would follow the Blair line rather than face another whole parliament of indecision. But there are enough indifferent semi-sceptics in the cabinet to whom delay might well appeal. Though Blair could carry his cabinet with a summons to arms, there's no critical mass there pushing him to issue one, beyond Messrs Cook, Mandelson, Byers and Hoon.

Succumbing to Brown's anxieties would, however, be full of hazard. Wait for the EU to secure democratic legitimacy and you could be dithering for a decade or two. Wait and see how the 2004 intergovernmental conference turns out, with its alternative plans for a constitution, and you've missed the boat this parliament. After that, who knows who will be in charge?

I don't believe Blair will be willing to wait that long, unless a real crisis hits the viability of the euro in the next year. His instinct will be to override the inveterate nay-sayers, from Sir Eddie George down, and calculate that business people who have gone quiet-to-sceptic will respond to a dramatic commitment by which, at last, he dispelled the endless years of indecision. The country, he thinks, will better listen to him than the mendacious minions of Murdoch and Rothermere.

But first he must win an argument, by main political force, closer to home. This looks like being more fundamental than many people, anticipating a post-election euphoria that makes everything easier, have thought of. The hare is getting ready to run. The tortoise prepares, perhaps, not to win the race but stop it taking place.

fields.headline: The President who bought power and sold the world
fields.standfirst:
George Bush's decision to ignore global warming and pull the plug on Kyoto is payback for the energy industries which backed him, reports Ed Vulliamy

Special report: George Bush's
America
Special report: global
warming
fields.trailText: George Bush's decision to ignore global warming and pull the plug on Kyoto is payback for the energy industries which backed him, reports Ed Vulliamy.
fields.body:
When George Bush was Governor of Texas, he called upon the big oil companies, such as Exxon-Mobil, to draw up a draft for the state's Clean Air Act. They came up with a Bill allowing them to regulate themselves. Just as Bush was signing it into law, in December 1988, the town of Odessa - a few miles from his birthplace - was engulfed by a black, toxic smoke so thick that drivers had to use their headlights during daytime.

The President they call 'the Toxic Texan' took office on a platform pledging to turn his gubernatorial principles into national policy - to make America a 'greater Texas'. And last week Bush began his attempt to make the world environment that of a 'greater America'. He 'declared war on the environment' - in the words of Democrat Senator Barbara Boxer, both at home and on the international stage.

Defying his European allies and many Third World countries, Bush in effect killed off the Kyoto Protocol of 1997 - by which more than 100 nations undertook to reduce emissions of 'greenhouse gases' that cause global warming - turning the US, for environmentalists, into a greedy, polluting pariah. On the domestic front, meanwhile, a series of brazen measures has provoked an outcry from even the most moderate and established of environmental groups.

Withdrawal by the US from Kyoto tolls a death knell for the treaty, because although it accounts for only 4 per cent of the world's population, it is responsible for 25 per cent of the emissions of gases that cause the greenhouse effect. Half of America's industrial might still burns fossil fuels and belches out fumes, while Americans themselves drive heavy trucks and cars further than any other people - to the mall and across the infinite landscape - and even the average household boasts 2.8 television sets and a wealth of electrical appliances.

The story behind the singular determination of Bush to fly in the face of world opinion, the sentiments of most Americans and even many in his own government reveals adherence to ideological rigour and a payment of debts to the business interests that helped him to the White House - above all, oil and coal. Oil runs through every sinew and vein of the Bush administration; rarely, if ever, has a Western government been so intimately entwined with a single industry. When Bush assumed office, however, oil and other energy industries were in the political cold after eight years of Bill Clinton's environmental record. Prompted by his keenly environmentalist deputy, Al Gore, Clinton had cautiously recommended ratification of Kyoto, but it was flatly rejected in the Senate.

Clinton nevertheless put more wilderness under federal protection than any President since Franklin Roosevelt and decreed a sweeping series of anti-pollution, clean air and clean water measures, facing down formidable constituencies such as the timber industry, sugar barons, big utility and automotive lobbies - and, above all, Big Oil and King Coal.

Determined backing for Bush was thereby assured from these quarters. According to the Centre for Responsive Politics, $10 million out of $14m in political contributions from oil and gas companies to the last election went to Republican candidates. The Bush family has roots in the oil business, and the President began his own career with a series of unsuccessful drilling ventures bailed out by bigger oil com panies. He was backed by most of the big names in oil, especially Texaco and Exxon-Mobil, in his campaigns for Governor and later President. Bush has now charged his Vice-President Dick Cheney - the pivotal power in the White House - to compile an overall energy policy document due for publication before the completion of his first 100 days in office. Cheney's connections to big oil have been close-knit and especially lucrative.

The Pentagon chief under Bush senior, Cheney used connections forged by the Gulf war to open up valuable business for the giant Halliburton Company, of which he was made chief executive in 1995, and which does 70 per cent of its $15 billion sales to Arab governments. Bush's Commerce Secretary, Don Evans, is a long-time personal friend from the President's home town of Midland, Texas, and a man raised in oil. His father was a manager for Shell and he is chairman and chief executive of the Midland-based Tom Brown oil company which, before the Eighties crash, was worth $2bn - equivalent to the Ford Corporation.

Among the less well known oil connections are those of America's ambassador to London, Doug Farish, who went into politics as an aide to Bush senior in 1964 and is described by former First Lady Barbara Bush as 'one of the family'.

Despite his reclusive image as a rancher who sold horses to the Queen, Farish is a Texas oil magnate from a Texas oil family. His grandfather founded the Humble Oil and Refining Company, part of what is now Exxon, and later became president of Standard Oil. Farish's own dealings in the oil state have not only been in liquid gold but also gas exploration and mining. Bush's break with world opinion on Kyoto was debated and contested within the administration, with Secretary of State Colin Powell and the Treasury reportedly eager to leave a door open to join Britain and other nations in a commitment to reduce 'greenhouse gas' emissions.

But even in the State Department, big oil has its man moulding policy: Middle East guru Richard Haas who, with Powell and Cheney, has an aversion to unilateral sanctions that hurt business.

Haas hails from the Brookings think-tank, and has propelled America's preparedness to consider easing sanctions on Iraq with a document entitled 'Iraq: A Modified Approach', written by Meghan O'Sullivan, a researcher who worked under Haas at Brookings. The paper argues that embargoes are 'bad for particular businesses' - principally oil - and it emerges that much of Haas's project was funded by Conoco and Arco, with whom he has worked as a consultant. He also has a seat on the board of oil firm, Santa Fe International. With these and other connections in place, big oil was quick to move once Bush was inaugurated. The National Petrochemical Refiners Association lobbied first, for a rollback of clean-air standards for buses and big trucks decreed by Clinton.

The association's counsel, Bob Slaughter, said he hoped 'the administration would be more interested in balancing the energy supply and environmental concerns' - and it was: Bush put a moratorium on this and all similar decrees, citing a fear of fuel price rises. Bush had promised to regulate the emissions of carbon dioxide, but two weeks ago he reversed this, citing a report commissioned last year by Republican Senator David McIntosh, saying that carbon dioxide restrictions could 'boost electricity prices and hurt coal-fired utilities'. Shortly before the announcement, Washington was blitzed by the 'Coal Based Generators' group to lobby for a reversal on emissions and tax breaks for 'clean coal' utilities.

Leading the group was Irl Engelhardt, chairman of Peabody, America's largest coal enterprise, who was also a major Republican contributor and energy adviser to the Bush-Cheney transition team. The same letter that disclosed the volte-face on carbon dioxide also announced the scrapping of new Clinton regulations reducing arsenic levels in drinking water by 80 per cent. The EPA's former administrator for water, Chuck Fox, who drafted the legislation, said: 'This action will jeopardise the health of millions of Americans.' And its backer in Congress, Henry Waxman, called the ruling 'another example of payback to industries that gave millions of dollars in campaign contributions'.

Fear of continuing fuel price rises and shrinking supply then dictated the White House's reaction to the energy crisis in California - ironically caused, said the Democrats, by the very deregulation policies favoured by the administration on a national scale. Bush's language - and his catchphrase that 'national security depends on energy security' - turned the crisis into a national emergency which dovetailed into the arguments that tranches of federal land protected by Clinton - including the vast and virgin Arctic wilderness in Alaska - should be opened up for prospecting and drilling.

These announcements - as well as Kyoto - have stirred even the most mainstream groups to exasperation, with the executive director of the Sierra Club - equivalent to the National Trust - predicting 'a very major fight'. Two entwined schools of thought form the core of the Bush administration: deregulation and decentralisation. The underpinning ideology is the injection of market forces into management of the public domain, and the belief that industry should police itself. Supporters of last week's decision include David Victor, fellow of science and technology at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. Victor argues that Kyoto cannot work, nor can unrealistic regulations on emissions reduction.

Instead he argues for 'economic incentives that, over time, will slow the build-up of carbon dioxide without the imposition of binding targets for a far-off future'. This ideology is embodied by John Graham, whom Bush picked last weekend to head his Office of Management and Budget - which oversees all regulatory agencies - an appointment which thrilled lobbyists. Graham, regarded as the guru of cost benefit analysis, has a history of eco-scepticism.

Last week's decision to kill Kyoto did not enjoy full backing of the administration - some quarters of which saw it as a fait accompli from the White House and the National Security Council. Successive opinion polls show that the environment is a major issue for voters, and Bush's enemies are lining up for a PR battle. Even Republican Representative Sherwood Boehlert believes Bush is 'taking a risk' by issuing 'so many controversial decisions so early'. Mark Mellman, a Democrat pollster, said: 'Bush is creating a political disaster for himself.'

fields.headline: The world in 2050
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: It is the year 2050, and April blizzards have gripped southern England for the third successive year while violent storms batter the North Sea coast.
fields.body:
It is the year 2050, and April blizzards have gripped southern England for the third successive year while violent storms batter the North Sea coast. The Gulf Stream, whose warming waters once heated our shores, has long since disappeared, destroyed by a deluge pouring south from the melting Arctic ice cap.

In the United States, much of Alaska has turned into a quagmire as permafrost and glaciers disintegrate. In Colorado, chair lift pylons stand rusting in the warm drizzle, reminders that the nation once supported a billion-dollar ski industry, while the remnants of Florida are declared America's second island state.

Africa is faring badly. Its coastline from Cairo to Lagos is completely flooded and many of the major cities have been abandoned. Tens of millions of people have been forced to flee and are struggling to survive in a parched, waterless interior.

In Asia there is a similar, terrifying picture. Bangladesh is almost totally inundated and the East Indies have been reduced to a few scrappy islands. Tens of millions stand on the brink of death.

It is a startling scenario worthy of a science fiction disaster film. And it would be easy to dismiss, were it not for the uncomfortable fact that these visions are the result of rigorous scientific analysis by some of the world's most distinguished climatologists.

As the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) points out in its recent Climate Change 2001 report, global warming is likely to trigger a cascade of unpleasant effects: elderly people will suffer and die in smoggy, polluted cities; crops will fail; and wildlife and livestock will perish on a scorched and miserable planet. That report was the combined work of several thousand of the world's leading meteorological experts, scientists whose views George Bush has now dismissed as 'questionable' and whose work in creating the Kyoto protocol has been utterly undone.

The US decision to pull out of the international accord on climate change has caused predictable international alarm, though it is important to note it will have no direct effect on levels of carbon dioxide now circulating in the atmosphere.

Kyoto merely pledged developed countries to restrict their industrial output. 'It was an excellent first step towards reversing climate change,' according to Southampton University's Professor Nigel Arnell. Kyoto was, in effect, a statement of intent. The industrial nations which had, after all, initiated the problem of global warming, would show their commitment by making the first crucial, self-sacrificing moves. Then the Third World could be drawn in, and the first decreases in carbon-dioxide emissions agreed over the next few years.

'Bush has now made the attainment of these next crucial steps much more difficult,' says Arnell. In fact, most experts believe he has made them impossible. If the West won't act, why should the rest of the world? If no action is taken, the consequences are likely to be calamitous. Before the industrial revolution, the atmosphere was made up of 250 parts per million of carbon dioxide. Now that figure has reached 366 and is already producing meteorological effects: a steady increase in devastating storms across Britain, rising sea levels, and dwindling glaciers and ice-caps. And that is just the start. Carbon dioxide levels will inevitably reach 450, even if governments closed every factory tomorrow.

'Plants absorb carbon dioxide and when they die they release that gas,' says Dr David Griggs of the IPCC's science working group. 'Similarly, the oceans absorb and release carbon dioxide.' These carbon dioxide stores mean that we could not stop atmospheric levels rising for future decades, no matter what we did. 'The climate is changing and will continue to change, regardless of what George Bush says,' comments Dr Mike Hulme of the Tyndall Centre for Climate Change in Norwich.

In any case, closing down factories is not on the cards. With the nation responsible for a quarter of all global carbon dioxide emissions refusing to limit its output by the merest fraction, levels will inevitably reach 550 parts per million - double their pre-industrial revolution figure - by about 2050. By then the world's temperature will have increased by 1.4 degrees Centigrade, triggering the mayhem outlined in the IPCC report.

'It is very difficult to make hard predictions,' adds Griggs. 'All we can say is that the future is going to be very uncertain, highly variable.' Britain provides an excellent example of the problem. We may swelter - or, if icy Arctic waters divert the Gulf Stream, we may shiver. Either way, the consequences will mean millions of homes will be refused insurance, native wildlife will perish and great chunks of coastline will be inundated.

And, say meteorologists, it now looks as if there is nothing we can do about it.

fields.headline: A taste of the winners
fields.standfirst: Double first for novel newcomer Zadie Smith
fields.trailText: Biography
fields.body:
Biography

When I was 12, my father stopped hitting me - not because I learned obedience, not even because I lied better, but for reasons of decency. My adolescent breasts and curves were beginning to give the whole performance a compromising, sexual savour. After all, spanking was a popular motif in 1950s films, a taming-of-the-shrew mating ritual. John Wayne spanked Maureen O'Hara particularly memorably in The Quiet Man ... No wonder Dad was embarrassed.

Poetry

All afternoon we picnicked on the lawn

then danced in awkward couples to the hiss

of gramophones as daylight turned to dusk;

a subtle exchange in the half-light; acts of grace:

townsfolk conferring the weight of a normal world,

homes in the suburbs, the brisk lives of men who can who sleep _

who wake and forget what they dreamed, and go off to work,

and wish for nothing.

Beside the patients, we were lithe and calm:

we doled out charity and easy praise

and waited for the dancing to erase

the pain in the knot of the throat, the birdlike

angle of defeat against the spine.

Novel

Potent evidence that separate races cannot and will not intermix. Discovery of fundamental importance. Increasingly convinced that types... the key to comprehending all human history + also future destiny of man. Patience of stolid Saxon will finally snap. Normans' weakness and parasitism will be exposed and sorely punished. Weaker nations... will be swept away. New era will begin.

First novel

They were of a breed: Raggastani. It was a new breed just recently joining the ranks of the other street crews ... Their ethos, their manifesto, if it could be called that, was equally a hybrid thing: Allah featured, but more as a collective big brother... But mainly their function was to put the Invincible back in Indian, the Bad-aaaass back in Bengali, the P-Funk back in Pakistan ... No one fucked with any of them any more because they looked like trouble.
