fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Chemicals clue to Parkinson's
fields.body:
Chemicals clue to Parkinson's

Parkinson's disease could be linked to a cocktail of two agricultural chemicals, US scientists believe. The combination of the herbicide paraquat, once used by gardeners everywhere, and the agricultural fungicide maneb, create a pattern of brain damage in mice like that seen in humans with Parkinsonism, according to a study at the University of Rochester published in the Journal of Neuroscience.

Sacked HIV man wins payout

A furniture company worker Michael Scott, 33, of Newcastle, who claimed that his employer forced him out of his job after he told managers he was HIV positive yesterday won an undisclosed pay-out from the company, Barker and Stonehouse, in a settlement ahead of a planned employment tribunal hearing.

Police sergeant found hanged

A sergeant was found by colleagues hanged in the outbuilding of a police station, it emerged today. Sgt Ian White, 44, had been reported missing by his wife after he failed to return to their home in Tarleton, near Preston, Lancashire, on New Year's Day following a night shift. A police spokesman said there were no suspicious circumstances.

Woman held captive

A 28-year-old woman was abducted and held prisoner for four days in a windowless room where she was indecently assaulted, police said yesterday. The victim was dragged into a car by a man and woman near her home in Whitechapel, east London, in the attack last month.

Grammy hope for Radiohead

Radiohead's experimental album Kid A - widely acclaimed by critics - has been shortlisted for album of the year in the US music awards the Grammys. The Oxford-based group's album was the first by a British act to top the US charts for three years. It faces competition from Eminem, Paul Simon, Beck and Steely Dan.

New floods warning

Heavy rainfall could cause further flood misery to many parts of Britain towards the end of the week, the environment agency warned last night. Heavy rain and melting snow could cause rivers already on flood alert to burst their banks.

Man beaten in pub fight dies

A man who lay in a coma for six months after being beaten severely in a pub brawl has died, police have confirmed. Brian Heslip was seriously injured after being attacked at the Sussex Arms in Haywards Heath, West Sussex, on June 4. A man was charged with assault at the time and is on police bail.

webTitle: Lib-Lab links in 'coma' over voting reform

fields.headline: Lib-Lab links in 'coma' over voting reform
fields.standfirst:
Kennedy abandons joint cabinet committee until after election as Lib Dem exasperation grows over Labour delay on electoral changes

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Kennedy abandons joint cabinet committee until after election as Lib Dem exasperation grows over Labour delay on electoral changes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's cherished project to realign the centre left has fallen into a coma, according to the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, who has abandoned a joint cabinet committee until after the general election.

Exasperated by the prime minister's failure to live up to his promises on electoral reform, Mr Kennedy has decided that there is little point in maintaining the Lib-Lab cabinet committee unless Labour shifts its stance on proportional representation. "The project is gently residing in a coma where it is ready for people to revive it if they wish," a Kennedy aide said yesterday. "We haven't held a meeting of the cabinet committee since the summer because we can't see the point of poncing up Downing Street if we aren't going to get something out of it."

Mr Kennedy's reluctance to sit on the historic cabinet committee will come as a severe disappointment to the champions of Lib-Lab cooperation, which was forged in the run-up to the last election by Tony Blair and Sir Paddy Ashdown. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and his Lib Dem counterpart Menzies Campbell, two of the original architects of the project, yesterday underlined their determination to press ahead with strengthening the links.

In an article in the Times to promote a forthcoming book on the centre left, Mr Cook and Mr Campbell said they hoped their "unique exercise in political cooperation" would help to create a new style of politics in Britain.

"Our existing political culture is not conducive to consensus building," they wrote. "The adversarial approach to debate promotes polarisation of opinion. Our cooperation should not be seen as an exercise in short term political management but as a continuing contribution towards a new style of politics." Although the article was approved by both the prime minister and the Lib Dem leader, its friendly language contrasted with the thinking of the Kennedy circle. The Kennedy aide insisted that there was no division between Mr Campbell and Mr Kennedy, but added: "You can be a bit more statesmanlike in foreign affairs."

Mr Kennedy will decide whether to shut down Lib-Lab cooperation altogether when Labour publishes its manifesto. If Labour commits itself to holding a referendum on electoral reform, he is likely to reopen talks. If there is no mention of a referendum, the project will be consigned to the history books.

Lib Dems have been disappointed with Labour for failing to live up to its 1997 manifesto commitment to hold a referendum on electoral reform. An independent commission was set up under the chairmanship of Lord Jenkins of Hillhead after the election, but its proposal for a new system known as AV plus has been quietly shelved.

It is understood that Mr Kennedy has still not given up hope of a referendum pledge in Labour's next maniesto. But there are reports that Labour may opt for an AV system of voting which falls well short of the Jenkins proposal. "Let us wait to see the colour of their money," the Kennedy aide said.

While the Lib Dems await Labour's manifesto, the party is scaling down its links with the government. There has been no meeting since July of the joint cabinet committee which has been mothballed until after the election. Talks between individual frontbench spokesman are continuing, but these are being wound down.

Likening the state of the project to a coma is the most dramatic illustration of the Lib Dem leader's wariness over co-operation with Labour. Although Mr Kennedy has long been sceptical of the links, he has been careful to use diplomatic language since his election as party leader in 1999 to keep faith with allies of Sir Paddy.

While the parties drift apart at a national level, there is continuing speculation that they may agree informal election pacts at a grassroots level to encourage anti-Tory tactical voting at the general election. This is strenuously denied by both parties.

However, the Lib Dems have failed to select candidates in some key Labour/Tory marginal seats.

fields.headline: At this price?  Rolls Royce
fields.trailText: Sir Ralph Robins, patrician chairman of Rolls Royce, may have regained some of the glow that drained from his face last August when he announced a dismal set of interim results and warned that earnings in 2001, far from maintaining double-digit growth, would be flat.
fields.body:
Sir Ralph Robins, patrician chairman of Rolls Royce, may have regained some of the glow that drained from his face last August when he announced a dismal set of interim results and warned that earnings in 2001, far from maintaining double-digit growth, would be flat.

Sure enough, investors took flight and the shares, 170p on re-privatisation in 1987, slumped to 153p in September and Rolls, world No 2 in aero engines, fell out of the FTSE 100. Last month it rejoined the premier league and the shares are hovering around the 200p mark as the market regains some assurance about group strategy.

Rolls has begun a further round of restructuring, with the loss of thousands of jobs, and sold some peripheral businesses, many of them acquired during the Vickers takeover.

More pertinently, it has emerged as supplier for some of the airlines planning to buy the Airbus 380 superjumbo and yesterday won a £600m contract from International Aero Engines to repair and overhaul V2500 engines for BA's new fleet of Airbus 319/320s - 59 firm orders with 129 options.

The 20-year contract helps guarantee the 1,100 jobs at its East Kilbride plant and could mean a few more recruits to Lanarkshire.

This is Rolls' biggest single maintenance contract and boosts its strategy of selling engines at a discount or even loss, relying on the lucrative aftermarket for earnings growth. A late entrant to this market, the group has doubled the share of maintenance work on its own engines to 50% in five years and the aftermarket now accounts for 40% of overall sales.

All that was clear when Sir Ralph issued his warning five months ago but it has needed some firm evidence to prod the market back on side.

With the delayed Trent industrial engine, which caused a £120m hit in the first half, due for lift-off next year, Rolls could be a good long-term bet.

fields.headline: AstraZeneca problems
fields.trailText: Fresh negative comments came yesterday regarding AstraZeneca, off 45p to £33.40, from analysts at Deutsche Bank.
fields.body:
Fresh negative comments came yesterday regarding AstraZeneca, off 45p to £33.40, from analysts at Deutsche Bank.

Analysts highlighted two recent developments the market seems to have overlooked. The first is the agreement between two US drug firms which had been disputing first filer status for a generic version of Losec, AstraZeneca's blockbuster ulcer drug.

The deal, Deutsche says, increases the chances that Losec will see generic competition in the US market before the end of the year.

Deutsche notes, meanwhile, that AstraZeneca has still not received US approval for Nexium, the successor to Losec, suggesting that discussions with American regulators are not proving straightforward. Deutsche claims every week of delay to the launch of Nexium reduces the chances of converting patients from Losec and losing them to generic competition.

fields.headline: Crystal ball game abandoned
fields.trailText: According to one seasoned market watcher - Stephen Lewis of Monument Derivatives - it is rare at the outset of a year's trading for a firm consensus to develop over how investors should be positioning their funds. City analysts gaze into their crystal balls and predict - in convenient list form - which stocks and sectors will fare best.
fields.body:
According to one seasoned market watcher - Stephen Lewis of Monument Derivatives - it is rare at the outset of a year's trading for a firm consensus to develop over how investors should be positioning their funds. City analysts gaze into their crystal balls and predict - in convenient list form - which stocks and sectors will fare best.

In the first two trading sessions of the new year investors have not been playing the game, though that may change today when they sit down to digest the implications of the Federal Reserve's rate cut.

The Fed's move came too late to save the market yesterday and investors, fearing a recession in the US and slower global growth, continued to flee from equities into the safe haven of government bonds.

Just about every class of share - blue chip, technology and mid-cap - headed south yesterday. The FTSE 100 ended 134.8 points weaker at 6,039.9 - its lowest closing level since May - while the TechMark 100 fell 143.05 to 2,344.61, ending below the level it was launched at in November 1999. The FTSE mid 250 sank 66.3 to 6,464.8 and the FTSE Small Cap lost 40.30 to 3,139.7.

As usual, London was following the Wall Street lead. When the Nasdaq falls 7% (as it did on Tuesday night) and fails to recover (as seemed to be the case during London trading hours yesterday) billions of pounds tend to get wiped off share prices. Add a truly awful performance from market heavyweight Vodafone and you have the recipe for some serious wealth destruction.

In the event, the Dow was showing a 300-point surge towards 11,000 after the Fed's move, while the Nasdaq rocketed 250 points, close to 2,550 by mid-afternoon in New York.

Earlier, in light of the Nasdaq's poor initial showing, British tech stocks were left nursing the biggest losses. Software developer Autonomy fell 294p to £14.06, extending its losses in the past two sessions to nearly 30% and leaving it £18.70 adrift of its flotation price. Elsewhere, IT services groups CMG and Logica dropped 98p to 737p and 167p to £15.04p respectively, while accountancy software group Sage slipped 26p to 267p.

Handheld computer maker Psion was again unwanted, falling 22p, or 8.30%, to 243p, as rumours of a profits warning were given a fresh airing.

Industry sources played down the speculation. They reckon Psion is happy with the guidance it gave when it warned on profits back in October and put the weakness down to poor performances from US peers Palm and Handspring.

Psion was not alone, as there were all sorts of bearish stories in the market place yesterday, few with any substance.

Chip designer ARC International fell 7.5p to 221p, rocked by a nasty little tale that its BlueARC product, being evaluated by potential clients, has a design fault. A spokeswoman for ARC emphatically denied the charge and said development remained on track. ARC plans a full product release early in the second quarter.

Vodafone tumbled 16.5p to 225p, amid the usual chatter of an imminent share placing from one of its large shareholders. But shrewder market players were telling clients that the decline was nothing more than a technical correction from the inflated levels the stock reached at the back end of last week.

Last Friday, Vodafone shot up 12.5p to 245.5p, as tracker funds were forced to chase the stock higher in anticipation of an index reweighting. After the close of play on Friday, FTSE increased Vodafone's weighting to take account of the 3.1bn shares it issued to take control of Spanish mobile operator Airtel.

There were some bright spots in the market. Dixons had another good session, advancing 15p to 250p, as Credit Lyonnais joined the list of brokers expecting an upbeat Christmas trading statement. Classic defensive issues like Imperial Tobacco, up 18.5p to 720p, and United Utilities, 8p higher at 653p, found favour.

fields.headline: Microsoft faces $5bn discrimination claim
fields.standfirst:
Software group back in court again as seven former employees allege racial bias

More net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Software group back in court again as seven former employees allege racial bias.
fields.body:
Any hopes within the Microsoft Corporation that the new year might prove less legally embroiled than the old one were rudely shattered yesterday when lawyers in Washington DC filed a $5bn class action racial discrimination claim against the huge American software company.

The suit, which is the fourth major anti-discrimination legal challenge to Microsoft in the past three months, alleges that seven past and present Microsoft employees suffered racial bias in company evaluations, compensation, promotions and retaliation.

The new cases come on top of the historic competition case against the company last year in which Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that Microsoft had exercised monopolistic powers to control the market in operating systems and internet browsers; he ordered that the company should be split into two.

Microsoft has also faced persistent legal complaints from temporary workers about lack of full-time rights.

But the latest suit appears to be much the most serious challenge that the embattled corporation has faced on the race discrimination front. Only 2.6% of Microsoft's 21,429 workforce are black, according to 1999 company figures, and black staff make up only 1.6% of the company's managers. Black Americans make up approximately 13% of the US population as a whole.

"Microsoft has discriminated against African-American employees who made valuable contributions to the company but were not treated with the same dignity, respect and compensation as their white counterparts," alleged the plaintiffs' lawyer, Willie Gary, at a press conference in Washington yesterday.

"There are glass ceilings and glass walls in place for African Americans at Microsoft.

"We are stunned and disappointed in their treatment of black employees."

The man at the centre of the new case is Rahn Johnson, a former account executive at Microsoft who worked for the company for four and a half years selling its products to the US Army.

Mr Jackson stopped working for Microsoft in October 2000. He alleges that he was repeatdely passed over for promotions despite 17 years of sales experience, and that he contacted several company executives - including the corporation's president, Steve Ballmer, with his complaints. "I was absolutely ignored," Mr Jackson said yesterday.

Microsoft spokesman Dean Katz said the company was wholly committed to ethnic diversity. "Microsoft does not tolerate discrimination in any of its employment practices, and we are committed to treating all of our employees fairly," Mr Katz said.

But a former Microsoft information technology director, Peter Browne - who at one time was the highest ranking black American in the company workforce - challenged the company position yesterday, saying he was often approached by fellow black workers who were worred about their treatment.

"I found soon enough I couldn't help them. I couldn't help myself," Mr Browne said.

Mr Browne, who is 58, has his own race and age discrimination claim against Microsoft scheduled for trial hearing later this year.

Mr Gary comes to the new case against Microsoft with a formidable and high profile record - which includes a successful $720m anti-discrimination damages suit last year against Disney World.

He is also acting- along with OJ Simpson's lawyer Johnnie Cochran - in a continuing $1.5bn suit against US drinks group Coca-Cola.

webTitle: Call for state cash for political parties

fields.headline: Call for state cash for political parties
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership made strenuous efforts to name Lord Hamlyn as its mystery benefactor within hours of the revelation of his £2m donation, disproving claims that the party deliberately delayed naming the peer.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership made strenuous efforts to name Lord Hamlyn as its mystery benefactor within hours of the revelation of his £2m donation, disproving claims that the party deliberately delayed naming the peer.

One of the peer's closest friends indicated yesterday that the party attempted to speak to Lord Hamlyn at his home in France on Saturday after Labour was contacted by the Sunday Telegraph which disclosed the donation.

Lord Hamlyn was so ill with pneumonia that he was unable to come to the telephone. The multi-millionaire eventually spoke to the chief Labour fundraiser, Lord Levy, on Monday, which led to his statement on Tuesday saying that he had proudly donated £2m.

Labour faced criticism this week for trying to hide Lord Hamlyn's identity. A spokesman had responded to the news of the £2m donation with a bland statement that the party never commented on individual donations.

Lord Gavron, one of Lord Hamlyn's friends, said yesterday on the Today programme: "On Saturday he was extremely ill with pneumonia, which is quite dangerous for someone in his fragile state ."

The disclosure that Labour attempted to kill speculation about the donation before the Sunday Telegraph hit the streets came as pressure mounted for Britain to follow the example of the United States and sanction state funding of political parties' election campaigns.

Clive Soley, the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party who led the calls for Lord Hamlyn to be named as the party's mystery donor, became the most senior party figure to throw his weight behind the idea. In an interview on the Today programme, Mr Soley said: "It certainly would resolve a lot of the problems that parties have in an age where people increasingly give less on a voluntary basis."

The home secretary, Jack Straw, is thought to be wary of following the example of the United States. But he is happy for the electoral commission, which comes into force next month, to examine the issue. State funding of parties has risen in recent years but it stops short of bankrolling election campaigns.

The calls for state funding came as the government confirmed it may impose a cap of £15m on party spending at the next election. This is surprising because new electoral laws will impose a £20m limit.

However, Mr Straw will use his powers under the new legislation to introduce the £15m cap if the election is held in the spring. Home Office sources said that the lower figure would have to be imposed, in the event of an early election, because the £20m cap was meant to cover spending in the year leading up to an election.

The calls for state funding came as the government confirmed it may impose a cap of £15m on party spending at the next election. This is surprising because new electoral laws will impose a £20m limit. However, Mr Straw will use his powers under the new legislation to introduce the £15m cap if the election is held in the spring. Home Office sources said that the lower figure would have to be imposed, in the event of an early election, because the £20m cap was meant to cover spending in the year leading up to an election. fields.headline: Ryanair buys peace for £80,000
fields.trailText: Ryanair, Europe's largest low-fare airline, yesterday bought industrial peace by offering its pilots IR£100,000 (£80,000) worth of share options.
fields.body:
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-fare airline, yesterday bought industrial peace by offering its pilots IR£100,000 (£80,000) worth of share options.

The deal is part of a five year pay and conditions package in which the pay of all pilots will rise 15% by 2005.

The pilots voted overwhelmingly for the package. It contains improved rosters and better working arrangements for all pilots. Under the share option deal options of more than £80,000-worth of Ryanair shares will be offered at a strike price of £10 per share to each pilot.

Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, said that the deal paved the way for further pilot recruitment and continued growth at the company.

Mr O'Leary said that the pay deal would see all pilots' earnings rising over the next few years to more than £100,000 per annum.

 Bosses at budget airline EasyJet are considering taking legal action against Liverpool and Luton airports after chaos over Christmas which led to 177 flights being cancelled due to bad weather.

fields.headline: Bass takeover is scuppered
fields.standfirst:
Interbrew faces £1bn loss as regulatory doubts force it to unravel deal

Mr Byers won't be the saviour of Fowler's Wee Heavy
fields.trailText: Britain's beer industry was plunged into turmoil yesterday, after trade secretary Stephen Byers ordered Belgian firm Interbrew to unravel its £2.3bn takeover of Bass's brewing operations.
fields.body:
Britain's beer industry was plunged into turmoil yesterday, after trade secretary Stephen Byers ordered Belgian firm Interbrew to unravel its £2.3bn takeover of Bass's brewing operations.

Mr Byers's surprise decision, which was in accordance with advice from the competition commission, followed an outcry about the deal from pub operators, supermarkets and regional beer producers.

The commission expressed fears that a duopoly could emerge with Interbrew and Scottish & Newcastle dominant. Mr Byers said this would "reduce competition in the market, lead to higher prices for end consumers and reduce consumer choice".

The order surprised many in the industry and provoked fury at Interbrew, which said it was considering seeking a judicial review. Chief executive Hugo Powell, said: "This recommendation defies logic and is clearly disproportionate to the competition issues at stake."

Mr Powell's future looked grim as analysts calculated that selling Bass Brewers could leave the firm nursing a loss of £500m to £1bn. Possible buyers of the business, which produces Carling, Tennent's and Worthington, include South African Breweries, Heineken and US firm Anheuser Busch, which owns Budweiser.

Among the biggest critics of the deal was Hugh Osmond, chairman of the country's biggest pub chain Punch Taverns, who said: "This is an absolute disaster for Interbrew. I don't want to gloat too much, but it is very amusing."

Mr Osmond predicted Interbrew would struggle to get more than £1.5bn for the business, which must be sold quickly to a buyer approved by the office of fair trading. The firm is likely to face anger from shareholders - the company pressed ahead with an £8.5bn flotation last month, saying it was "quietly confident" of escaping regulatory difficulties. Its shares fell by a quarter to €28 (£17.75) yesterday.

Interbrew bought the brewing operations of Bass and Whitbread last year giving it a market share of between 33% and 37%. The deals meant the firm overtook Scottish & Newcastle, controlling Britain's top selling lagers, Carling and Stella Artois.

One member of the competition commission, Timothy Richmond, dissented from the majority view, suggesting Interbrew sell the much smaller Whitbread operations. His colleagues expressed deeper concerns, accusing the Belgian firm of discriminating already against smaller pub companies and off-licences.

J Sainsbury and Somerfield submitted objections to the deal, as did Japanese bank Nomura, which owns more than 3,000 pubs. Nightclub firm First Leisure, JD Wetherspoon and Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries were opposed.

Unions supported the takeover, saying Interbrew had promised a long-term future for Bass Brewers' 7,000 employees. Brian Revel of the Transport & General Workers' Union said: "Our members were impressed by Interbrew, as a company devoted to beer."

Janet Dean, the Labour MP for Burton-on-Trent, said she was disappointed by the decision, which leaves thousands of people in her constituency uncertain about their jobs. She has written to Mr Byers, asking for assurances that any approved alternative buyer give a commitment to retain staff.

fields.headline: Investors tug pay reins
fields.trailText: Institutional investors are preparing to get tough on directors' pay amid concerns that top companies are planning to flout existing rules on boardroom rewards.
fields.body:
Institutional investors are preparing to get tough on directors' pay amid concerns that top companies are planning to flout existing rules on boardroom rewards.

A breakaway group of some of the most influential investment firms is understood to have presented proposals for tougher pay guidelines to the Association of British Insurers, whose members control as much as 25% of the stockmarket.

Members of the rebel group were reluctant to be identified yesterday but are understood to be led by Baillie Gifford, the Scottish fund manager, which was unavailable for comment last night.

One of the group's main concerns is thought to be the way directors receive incentives, usually in the form of stock options, particularly in the light of falling markets which have left many such awards "under water".

The investors are said to be aware of the pressure they are under to exercise control over directors' pay and want to clarify the procedures for criticising what they consider excessive reward schemes.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, had promised a tough approach on directors' pay but indicated later that increased activism by investors, particularly over pay deals at Vodafone, had allowed the government to back off from its plans.

The rebels are understood to want to present their proposals not only to the ABI, but also the National Association of Pension Funds.

Peter Montagnon, head of investment affairs at the ABI, said he was aware of the breakaway group.

"We do talk to these institutions and their concerns are an indication among institutional investors that there are strong feelings on pay issues which companies would have to take into account," he said.

"We don't see this being in conflict with our own work but they are only one group and are not representative of the industry as a whole."

The move comes as the ABI and NAPF are reviewing their rules on directors' pay.

webTitle: Wal-Mart spends big to win UK retail war

fields.headline: Wal-Mart spends big to win UK retail war
fields.trailText: Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, yesterday underlined its commitment to winning the supermarkets battle in the UK by promising to spend £450m and create 5,000 new jobs this year at its Asda stores.
fields.body:
Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, yesterday underlined its commitment to winning the supermarkets battle in the UK by promising to spend £450m and create 5,000 new jobs this year at its Asda stores.

Further major reductions in prices were also promised, and efforts to cut queues. A new survey from consumer magazine Which?, published today, shows Asda top in a value-for- money survey ahead of market leader Tesco.

Nine new Asda stores will be announced this year and a further four will be rebuilt or resited. A new distribution depot will create 600 jobs in Bedford, an area where employment levels will be hit by the end of car assembly at Vauxhall, although three quarters of all Asda jobs are part-time.

Paul Mason, Asda's chief operating officer, said: "This record level of investment by Wal-Mart in the UK is in line with our strategy of long-term market share growth."

Asda claims it cut prices by 10% last year, and a spokesman said there would be "more investment in price" to ensure large reductions in 2001.

Already the gap has widened with the competition, Asda says. Last year prices were on average 5% to 10% cheaper; the gap has since widened to between 10% and 15%.

A survey by Which?, in which more than 6,000 shoppers were questioned, placed Asda as best value for money in terms of fresh meat and fish, fruit and vegetables, bakery, dairy produce, chilled food, ready meals and delicatessen. Only Waitrose was chosen as the best in organic produce, although the store was top of the survey regarding quality and choice.

But in the value for money category, Asda beat off competition from Waitrose, Tesco, Somerfield, and Sainsbury. Safeway came last.

But Asda did stumble when it came to queuing, with 9% of customers spending more than five minutes waiting at Waitrose compared to 17% at Tesco and 33% at Asda. The Asda spokesman said £6m would be spent this year on service initiatives designed to reduce queues.

Wal-Mart sales for the period to January 31 2000 were $165bn. The US-based group bought Asda in August 1999.

webTitle: Parent pulls plug on eToys UK

fields.headline: Parent pulls plug on eToys UK
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: "Can we fix it?" children's favourite Bob the Builder asks himself on the home page of beleaguered online retailer eToys UK. "No we can't," he replies, and waves farewell to the company's 90,000 customers.
fields.body:
"Can we fix it?" children's favourite Bob the Builder asks himself on the home page of beleaguered online retailer eToys UK. "No we can't," he replies, and waves farewell to the company's 90,000 customers.

The high-profile online toy store, eToys Inc, yesterday announced it was pulling the plug on its British business in an effort to stay afloat in the US.

The company said the closure, which will bring 74 job losses, was due to difficulties raising cash and poor Christmas sales at home.

Last month, the Californian e-tailer announced that dire financial straits had forced it to cut sales forecasts for the quarter including Christmas by 50%. The company was likely to run out of money by March if it did not receive "additional, substantial capital infusion".

Ruben Rodriguez, a vice-president of eToys Inc, said yesterday that the British operation's performance over Christmas had been significantly ahead of plans and expectations.

"What makes this announcement particularly disappointing is that eToys.co.uk has had a fabulous Christmas - we roughly doubled the revenues we had last year," he said. "The UK team has done a fabulous job and built itself up as the market leader.

"Our customer base grew to over 90,000 in the UK. Order size, gross margin and customer acquisition costs were all performing very well, but we are still far from profitability. Current market conditions have left us no other options [but to close the UK site]."

The operation will close on January 19, with 66 staff in Britain and eight at a warehouse in Belgium being made redundant by the end of the month.

Mr Rodriguez said the move was the first in a series designed to cut eToys' operating costs. Further measures would be announced this month after the company received a report from Goldman Sachs on the strategic options open to it.

Mr Rodriguez would not be drawn on how much eToys.co.uk has cost its US parent in the 15 months since it opened but said it achieved turnover £1.6m in its first six months of trading.

At the height of eToys' fortunes, plans to expand across Europe meant the number of employees in Britain swelled to 100.

More recently, staff cuts and revenue growth had not been enough to offset the high cash burn rate.

Mike Honor, online retail analyst at Forrester Research, said that, as an exclusively internet-based company, eToys had to spend large amounts generating and maintaining brand identity.

Despite success in raising its profile, the company still faced tough competition from established toy retailers such as Toys'R'Us, Wal-Mart, Kmart and Target, he said. News last summer of a partnership between Toys'R'Us and onliner retailer Amazon.com hit eToys particularly hard.

The company is now considering a similar partnership as well as restructuring options.

Meanwhile, eToys.co.uk joins the line of dot.com casualties: the debt-laden British e-tailer LetsBuyIt.com filed for creditor protection last week while Boo.com, Clickmango and Boxman have already folded after investors pulled the plug.

"Thanks once again for shopping with us at eToys UK over the past year," read the screen message beneath Bob the Builder on the website last night. "And please enjoy the irresistible savings to be found in our final clearance sale."

Toys, games, and baby products will be on sale at half price for two weeks.

fields.headline: Betty Westgate
fields.standfirst: Campaign founder who helped change attitudes to breast cancer
fields.trailText: Campaign founder who helped change attitudes to breast cancer.
fields.body:
The major change in attitudes to breast cancer can be credited to women such as Betty Westgate, founder and president of Breast Cancer Care, who has died aged 81. In 1968, this small, outgoing biology teacher had a biopsy for a lump in the breast. It was diagnosed as benign, but a week later she was told it was not, and that she would be having a mastectomy. She knew little about breast cancer, and when she asked a doctor about the operation, he reacted as though he could not understand her need to know.

Later, after five weeks of radiotherapy, another doctor told her how marvellous it was that women could survive five or even more years after a mastectomy. Resentment and anger at this casual death sentence fired Betty with the determination to live for another 30 years. The myths, inaccuracies and superstitions surrounding breast cancer led her into a major reading and learning programme.

In 1972 she founded Cancer Education Voluntary Service, offering a talk called "Lumps and Bumps" to groups. From the questions asked, she recognised the need for an organisation giving non-medical help and post-operative information. Since it did not exist, she set up one herself, and called it the Mastectomy Association.

Born in Wiltshire but educated in Croydon, Betty first ran the campaign from her Croydon home, helped by her husband Jim, a chief mechanical engineer at London Transport, whom she married in 1940. When finance became a problem she sought funding, and from 1977 received an annual grant from the Department of Health. In 1981, she found funding for an office and paid staff. In 1994 the name was changed to Breast Cancer Care (BCC).

What was extraordinary was the range of Betty's understanding of the many facets of breast cancer and her ability to understand women's needs. In the 70s, post-operative women were advised to stuff handkerchiefs, cotton wool which disintegrated, or even tights into their bras; breast forms were few in size and could be lumpy. In 1974 Betty designed the "Cumfie", which was washable, spin-dryable, supersoft; they were still being made in the 90s.

Today, BCC organises fashion parades, but early on Betty saw the need for purpose-designed swimwear and bras. She got VAT removed from them. She also got prostheses made in different sizes and lighter weights. She bared her own scar and prosthesis, and later the implant, to nurses. In the days when a woman needed her doctor to write a letter to approve a breast implant, Betty wrote to a doctor who had suggested that one of his patients did not need one and asked him whether if he lost a testicle he would want an implant.

Betty told the story of her campaign in a booklet, Life, Here I Come! It was published in 1998 to celebrate 25 years of the organisation she founded. The title of the book summed up Betty's philosophy. She travelled the world to talk and educate people about the charity. She had a great love of flying, and had trained as a pilot until forced to give it up when she was pregnant with her first child in 1942. When, aged 70, she was told she was too old to go hang-gliding, she was most indignant.

She is survived by Jim and her four sons.

fields.headline: Tanaquil Le Clercq
fields.standfirst: Despite a career cut short by polio, she played a key role in the development of classic American ballet
fields.trailText: Despite a career cut short by polio, she played a key role in the development of classic American ballet.
fields.body:
The ballerina Tanaquil Le Clercq, who has died of pneumonia aged 71, was George Balanchine's muse at a crucial period in the development of American classic ballet. Her career lasted only from 1945 - when she first danced in works by Balanchine as a student at the School of American Ballet in New York - until it was tragically cut short when she contracted polio during the 1956 European tour of New York City Ballet.

By that time she had been married to Balanchine for four years. As with his previous wives (Tamara Geva, Vera Zorina and Maria Tallchief) and other ballerinas who served as his muse, the relationship was at least as much artistic as emotional, although he remained with Le Clercq in Copenhagen after she was first taken ill and did not choreograph for a year.

Tanaquil Le Clercq was born in Paris and moved to New York with her parents (her father was French, her mother American) at the age of three. As a child she studied with Mikhail Mordkin, then in 1941 she won a scholarship to the School of American Ballet, Balanchine's school.

Almost at once he singled her out as a potential ballerina, and in 1945 cast her in two ballets made for a student performance, the classical Symphonie Concertante and, more significantly, a duet for two women to Igor Stravinsky's Elegie, which looked forward to the more experimental style of which Le Clercq was to become a leading exponent.

In the following year he choreographed another short ballet, Resurgence, performed only once at a benefit for the March of Dimes, a charity devoted to ending the spread of polio. In this number, Le Clercq appeared as a young dancer menaced by the Threat of Polio, played by Balanchine himself, an irony that was not lost on him when Le Clercq actually succumbed to the disease 10 years later.

In that decade, he created many roles for her in which she epitomised the American classic style that he had envisioned when he first went to the US at Lincoln Kirstein's invitation in 1933 to found a school and an associated company. Le Clercq was his ideal ballerina, the exemplar of what came to be known as the Balanchine type - sleek, long-limbed, instinctively musical. Moreover, as early as 1946, in the first season of Ballet Society, precursor of New York City Ballet, she brought a personal dramatic intensity to the Choleric variation in the Four Temperaments. In a purely classical vein, she spun out the long seamless line of the slow movement of Bizet's Symphony in C.

Her long legs and delicate but strong technique, and her style, which had a subtlety more European than American, were unique. One of her most memorable roles was in La Valse, a neo-romantic work by Balanchine to music by Ravel. In Bourrée Fantasque (Chabrier) she brought down the house when she swung those legendary legs over her shorter partner Robbins's head.

Her brilliant career may have been cut short when she contracted polio in 1956, but after the initial shock of being confined to a wheelchair, she forged a new life with the wonderful support of her husband, George Balanchine. Their commodious apartment in the historic Apthorp building on Manhattan's Upper West Side provided the setting for delicious dinners cooked by George that were attended by devoted friends such as the duo pianists Bobby Fizdale and Arthur Gold, and Diana Adams, the ballerina.

By the time her marriage ended, several years later, she had regained her spirit and zest for life. She taught ballet at the Dance Theater of Harlem, using her slim hands to demonstrate the steps, and from her wheelchair she also taught the roles that had been created for her to the young dancers at the New York City Ballet. She was a talented portrait photographer, and an avid crossword puzzler from both sides of the grid; the New York Times published several of her invention.

Tanny and I were students together at the School of American Ballet, where she was already a star pupil: her style and exceptional promise were evident even then. I admired her dancing enormously, but I admired her courage in facing her illness even more. Her wit and strength never left her, nor did she indulge in self-pity. It was always a treat to be in her vivacious company, as I and her many other devoted friends will testify.

fields.headline: Letter: Professor Gerald Aylmer
fields.trailText: Professor Gerald Aylmer (obituary December 29 2000) had a great commitment to students of the 17th century from outside conventional academic institutions.
fields.body:
Dr Richard Allen and Dr Anne Laurence write: Professor Gerald Aylmer (obituary December 29 2000) had a great commitment to students of the 17th century from outside conventional academic institutions. He lectured for the Workers' Educational Association, for the Historical Association and for various extra-mural bodies, and he was always courteous and approachable to students from abroad and to amateur historians.

His dedication to such students was particularly evident in his connection with the Open University. Here his work touched the studies in the 1980s of some 18,000 students of the interdisciplinary course, Seventeenth-Century England: A Changing Culture? which was prepared by a team led by his former tutor at Oxford university, Christopher Hill. After eight years as external assessor and examiner, he retired with the words: "I think it is time I gave up, for I am beginning to feel that these are my own students."

webTitle: Embassy bombings trial begins in US

fields.headline: Embassy bombings trial begins in US
fields.trailText: Four men appeared in court yesterday in a trial which the prosecution wants to turn into an in absentia case against the fugitive Saudi Arabian millionaire Osama bin Laden, more than two years after the bombings of two US embassies in which 224 people died.
fields.body:
Four men appeared in court yesterday in a trial which the prosecution wants to turn into an in absentia case against the fugitive Saudi Arabian millionaire Osama bin Laden, more than two years after the bombings of two US embassies in which 224 people died.

The four, charged with conspiring with Mr Bin Laden to bomb the embassies, were led into the federal court in Manhattan wearing white Islamic clothing.

The location is resonant with meaning: it is the court in which six men were found guilty of bombing the World Trade Centre in 1993.

Concrete and metal barriers were in place outside the courthouse, but with only six cameras present the media circus was more of a sideshow.

Families of victims of the bombs in Nairobi, Kenya, and in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, in August 1998 were there to take the gloss off the attempt inside to unfold an image of a global international terror plot.

Edith Bartley, whose father and brother died in the Nairobi attack, said: "They [the US government] were playing Russian roulette with Americans lives and they continuing to do so.

"The government was negligent. Our American government chose not to look at warnings.

"The position of Madeleine Albright and our government is one of arrogance."

Stuart Newberger, a lawyer representing most of the 12 Americans killed, said: "All the families of the victims of this gross act of terrorism have been anxiously awaiting what the US government can accomplish in processing justice against these people."

The prosecutors expect to call 100 witnesses from six countries and to use confessions, computer and telephone records, and other evidence.

The trial is expected to take at least nine months. Jury selection alone, from a pool of 1,500 people, is likely to stretch beyond three weeks, during which the public and press are excluded.

One man has already pleaded guilty to conspiring with Osama bin Laden and is expected to be the star witness for the prosecution, acting as a window on the world of the west's most reliable bogeyman.

Ali Mohamed's evidence linking Mr bin Laden to the bombings is the bridge on which the prosecution hopes to extend the trial into an examination of an organisation accused of killing westerners all over the world.

"We will pursue this goal for however long it takes and wherever in the world the evidence leads us," said Barry Mawn, assistant director of the FBI's New York office.

Ali Mohamed, 48, a former US army sergeant who has not been sentenced yet, told an earlier hearing that Mr bin Laden asked him seven years ago to carry out surveillance on British, American, French and Israeli targets in Nairobi.

"I took pictures, drew diagrams and wrote a report," he said.

Mr Mohamed's plea-bargain terms have not yet been made public.

"Bin Laden looked at the picture of the American embassy and pointed to where a truck could go as a suicide bomber. The objective of all this was just to attack any western target in the Middle East, to force the governments of western countries just to pull out of the Middle East, not to interfere."

In all, 22 people have been charged with the bombing: the four who went on trial yesterday, who have all denied the charges; another who will face the New York court later; three awaiting extradition from Britain; and 13, including Osama bin Laden, who remain at large.

Two of those on trial are liable to the death penalty if they are found guilty.

They Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, 23, a Saudi national accused of being a would-be suicide bomber in the Nairobi explosion; and Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, an Tanzanian, who is charged with helping to carry out the attack in Dar es Salaam.

Wadih el Hage, 40, a Lebanese-born US citizen, is charged with serving as a leading aide to Mr bin Laden.

The prosecutors say that the fourth defendant, Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, 35, a Jordanian, has already admitted that he was a member of al-Qaeda, Mr bin Laden's organisation.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Suicide bomber kills 2 in Turkey
fields.body:
Suicide bomber kills 2 in Turkey

A suicide bomber walked into a central Istanbul police station and detonated explosives strapped to his body, killing himself, a policeman, and a civilian, and injuring seven others.

The police said that leftwing militants avenging last month's violent prison raids were behind the attack.
AP, Istanbul

Spanish crash leaves 12 dead

A dozen migrant workers from Ecuador died in Spain yesterday when a train crushed their van at a level-crossing without barriers.

Two others in the van were hurt. None of the 30 people on the derailed train was seriously injured in the accident near Lorca, south-eastern Spain.
Reuters, Madrid

Taiwan diners lose dog dinner

The Taiwanese have been deprived of a winter treat: dog meat. Under a new law, which also covers cats and other pets, anyone caught butchering or selling dog meat can be fined up to £200.

Stalls serving dog stews and stir-fries have become less common thanks to increasing affluence and western values.
AP, Taipei

webTitle: Open letter on Iraq to Peter Hain

fields.headline: 'It is an outrage that you repeat fabricated disinformation'
fields.standfirst:
As the Bush administration prepares for power, the UN policy of sanctions against Baghdad, introduced 10 years ago, must be one of the first areas to claim its attention. A former senior UN official writes an open letter to Britain's minister with responsibility for Iraq, Peter Hain, a leading voice in defence of a policy now widely seen as ineffective and immoral

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A former senior UN official writes an open letter to Britain's minister with responsibility for sanctions against Iraq.
fields.body:
Dear Minister Hain,

17 December 2000 was the first anniversary of UN Resolution 1284. This resolution was offered by the UN security council last year as a step forward in resolving outstanding disarmament, and arms monitoring issues as a precondition for the suspension of comprehensive economic sanctions against Iraq.

As many feared, including myself, this resolution was a still-born creation. For this neither the British nor the Iraqi governments but rather the people of Iraq continue to pay dearly and daily. The European public is increasingly unwilling to accept such a policy. There is deep concern because of the suffering of innocent civilians and the irrefutable evidence of violations of international law by the UN security council.

Without a transparent political agenda and a determined end to contaminating information, I do not see an end to this costly human tragedy in Iraq. Your speech of 7 November at Chatham House has not helped in this regard. Let me single out nine specific points of what you have said:

 "Our air crews risk their lives patrolling the skies above southern Iraq."

The public does not know that you do this without a mandate by the UN security council. It is in your hands to stop endangering your pilots by withdrawing them from Iraqi skies. It angered your office that I introduced air-strike reporting for 1999 while serving in Iraq. I did so as the UN secretary general's designated official for security because of the dangers for the security of a highly mobile team of UN observers travelling daily on the roads of Iraq. The report showed that out of 132 incidents, UN staff was witness to such air strikes on 28 occasions.

The public does not know that in the very areas you established as 'no-fly zones' to protect (7) the population living there, 144 civilians died and 446 were wounded by UK/US airforces. The FCO classified these reports as Iraqi propaganda with a UN imprimatur" even though much of it was collected and verified by UN staff travelling in the areas at the time of the strikes.

 "Our sailors are involved in activities to curb the illegal export of Iraqi oil."

This is known. You are silent, as you have been in all your statements, about the UK condoned export of illegal oil from Iraq into Turkey. Your silence is understandable albeit not acceptable if you want the full story to be known. US/UK concurrence to this illegal export of oil is in exchange for Turkish government agreement to the use of Incirlik airbase in south-eastern Anatolia for allied sorties into the northern no-fly zone of Iraq.

 "I firmly believe that he (President of Iraq) remains determined to develop his nuclear, chemical and biological weapons capacity."

You offer no evidence. What I in turn 'firmly believe' is that you want to keep a picture of Iraq alive even though it no longer reflects the realities on the ground. This is not surprising. Without it the case for sanctions would be over. I remind here of what former Unscom chief weapons inspector Scott Ritter recently said: "There is absolutely no reason to believe that Iraq could have meaningfully reconstituted any element of its WMB capabilities in the past 18 months." Around the same time, Dr Blix, executive chairman of Unmovic, answered the question whether there was any indication that Iraq was trying to rearm. "No, I do not think you can say this. We have nothing to substantiate this."

 Iraq resolution 1284 "represents the collective will of the Security Council and has the full force of International Law."

You know how deceptive this assertion is. Three out of five permanent members and Malaysia did not support this resolution. Yes, security council decisions constitute international law. This puts a formidable responsibility on the shoulders of the UN security council. You are aware, no doubt, of the increasing numbers of serious objections by international legal experts to the continued application of these laws. The evidence is overwhelming that after ten years of sanctions these 'acts' have become illegal.

 (UN) "resolution 1284 removed the ceiling on the amount of oil Iraq is allowed to export."

This is a political ploy. Your government knows well from annual UN reports on the state of the Iraqi oil industry that Iraq cannot pump more oil unless the UN security council allows a complete overhaul of the oil industry. You mention "recent increases' in (oil) production." Why do you do this when you know that the Iraqi oil output has not increased at all but exports have fluctuated around 2.2m barrels per day?

 "With this large amount of revenue available, one cannot help but ask why we still see pictures of malnourished and sick children?"

My first reaction to this tendentious statement is to ask whether your officials ever show you UN documents? Unicef has repeatedly pointed out that this reality is only going to change when the sanctions regime is once again replaced by a normally functioning economy. Let me add that more often than not, it is the blocking of contracts by the US/UK which has created immense problems in implementing the oil-for-food programme. The present volume of blocked items amounts to $2.3bn the highest ever.

 "It is an outrage that the Iraqi government wilfully denies food and medicine...".

Please forgive me if I say that it is an outrage that against your better knowledge you repeat again and again truly fabricated and self-serving disinformation. Why do you ignore UN stock reports which give you the monthly distribution situation and which, verified by UN observers, show for food, medicines and other humanitarian supplies an average of over 90% distributed per month?

 "Contrast the situation with northern Iraq where the same sanctions apply but Saddam's writ does not run."

This statement is correct. The Kurdish areas are indeed doing better. I am distressed, however, about the false impression you create with the simplistic causality you offer. A fair comparison would mention that i) the Kurdish population received 19.4% of the oil revenue, i.e. a disproportionately higher amount than the population in central/southern Iraq; ii) sanctions are regularly broken in northern Iraq; iii) there is extensive cross-border trade with Turkey and therefore good income earning opportunities; iv) the UN security council does not block many contracts benefiting the Kurdish areas; v) the climatic conditions in the hilly areas of the north are more favourable. Why are you, Minister, not mentioning these factors?

 "... there are those who are undermining sanctions and challenging the authority of the UN."

Yes, this is true, and it includes me. Do accept, Minister Hain, that I do so with the utmost discomfort. I am fully aware that this weakens the very machinery which has been set up to deal with conflicts like this one. However, I see no other alternative when the fundamentals of human rights and international law are applied in a biased and lopsided manner. The human rights coin has two sides, Minister. Lawlessness of one kind does not justify lawlessness of another kind! This has grave consequences not only for the suffering of the Iraqi people but also for the importance we should ascribe in Europe to the laws earlier governments have helped to create. The FCO should carefully study the deposition of Professor Bossuyt to the Human Rights Commission in June 2000. It provides comprehensive legal arguments by a large group of jurists of the serious violation of international law by the UN security council in which the UK has always played such an important role.

Let me end by saying, the Iraq file cannot be handled objectively and in the interest of the people of Iraq unless the hidden agenda disappears. When this happens then but only then does this sentence in the closing paragraph of your Chatham House speech get the value it deserves. " We support human rights, transparency and accountability for other people because the values we demand for ourselves!" Yes, this is how it should be, Minister!

Yours Sincerely
H.C. Graf Sponeck
Former Humanitarian Coordinator for Iraq

Geneva, December 2000

Around the same time, Dr Blix, executive chairman of Unmovic, answered the question whether there was any indication that Iraq was trying to rearm. "No, I do not think you can say this. We have nothing to substantiate this."  Iraq resolution 1284 "represents the collective will of the Security Council and has the full force of International Law." You know how deceptive this assertion is. Three out of five permanent members and Malaysia did not support this resolution. Yes, security council decisions constitute international law. This puts a formidable responsibility on the shoulders of the UN security council. You are aware, no doubt, of the increasing numbers of serious objections by international legal experts to the continued application of these laws. The evidence is overwhelming that after ten years of sanctions these 'acts' have become illegal.  (UN) "resolution 1284 removed the ceiling on the amount of oil Iraq is allowed to export." This is a political ploy. Your government knows well from annual UN reports on the state of the Iraqi oil industry that Iraq cannot pump more oil unless the UN security council allows a complete overhaul of the oil industry. You mention "recent increases' in (oil) production." Why do you do this when you know that the Iraqi oil output has not increased at all but exports have fluctuated around 2.2m barrels per day?  "With this large amount of revenue available, one cannot help but ask why we still see pictures of malnourished and sick children?" My first reaction to this tendentious statement is to ask whether your officials ever show you UN documents? Unicef has repeatedly pointed out that this reality is only going to change when the sanctions regime is once again replaced by a normally functioning economy. Let me add that more often than not, it is the blocking of contracts by the US/UK which has created immense problems in implementing the oil-for-food programme. The present volume of blocked items amounts to $2.3bn the highest ever.  "It is an outrage that the Iraqi government wilfully denies food and medicine...". Please forgive me if I say that it is an outrage that against your better knowledge you repeat again and again truly fabricated and self-serving disinformation. Why do you ignore UN stock reports which give you the monthly distribution situation and which, verified by UN observers, show for food, medicines and other humanitarian supplies an average of over 90% distributed per month?  "Contrast the situation with northern Iraq where the same sanctions apply but Saddam's writ does not run." This statement is correct. The Kurdish areas are indeed doing better. I am distressed, however, about the false impression you create with the simplistic causality you offer. A fair comparison would mention that i) the Kurdish population received 19.4% of the oil revenue, i.e. a disproportionately higher amount than the population in central/southern Iraq; ii) sanctions are regularly broken in northern Iraq; iii) there is extensive cross-border trade with Turkey and therefore good income earning opportunities; iv) the UN security council does not block many contracts benefiting the Kurdish areas; v) the climatic conditions in the hilly areas of the north are more favourable. Why are you, Minister, not mentioning these factors?  "... there are those who are undermining sanctions and challenging the authority of the UN." Yes, this is true, and it includes me. Do accept, Minister Hain, that I do so with the utmost discomfort. I am fully aware that this weakens the very machinery which has been set up to deal with conflicts like this one. However, I see no other alternative when the fundamentals of human rights and international law are applied in a biased and lopsided manner. The human rights coin has two sides, Minister. Lawlessness of one kind does not justify lawlessness of another kind! This has grave consequences not only for the suffering of the Iraqi people but also for the importance we should ascribe in Europe to the laws earlier governments have helped to create. The FCO should carefully study the deposition of Professor Bossuyt to the Human Rights Commission in June 2000. It provides comprehensive legal arguments by a large group of jurists of the serious violation of international law by the UN security council in which the UK has always played such an important role. Let me end by saying, the Iraq file cannot be handled objectively and in the interest of the people of Iraq unless the hidden agenda disappears. When this happens then but only then does this sentence in the closing paragraph of your Chatham House speech get the value it deserves. " We support human rights, transparency and accountability for other people because the values we demand for ourselves!" Yes, this is how it should be, Minister! Yours Sincerely H.C. Graf Sponeck Former Humanitarian Coordinator for Iraq Geneva, December 2000

webTitle: Palestinians say proposed land split opens a Pandora's box

fields.headline: Devil in the detail threatens peace plan
fields.standfirst:
Palestinians say proposed land split with Jews opens a Pandora's box

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The seven-year effort by President Bill Clinton to secure a Middle East peace settlement depended last night on whether he could overcome Palestinian objections. The main sticking points for the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and his delegation are: the division of Jerusalem's Old City between Israel and the proposed Palestine state; the tortuous border between Israel and the West Bank and the future of Jewish settlers on the West Bank; and, the biggest problem of all, the right of the 3.7m Palestinian refugees to return to their homes in Israel.
fields.body:
The seven-year effort by President Bill Clinton to secure a Middle East peace settlement depended last night on whether he could overcome Palestinian objections. The main sticking points for the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and his delegation are: the division of Jerusalem's Old City between Israel and the proposed Palestine state; the tortuous border between Israel and the West Bank and the future of Jewish settlers on the West Bank; and, the biggest problem of all, the right of the 3.7m Palestinian refugees to return to their homes in Israel.

The Palestinian negotiator Yasser Abed Rabbo published maps yesterday of the proposed US division of the Old City, Jerusalem as a whole, and the West Bank.

In a four-page summary of its objections, published to coincide with Mr Arafat's visit to Washington, the Palestinian negotiating team praised Mr Clinton's efforts down the years, but concluded: "We cannot accept a proposal that secures neither the establishment of a viable Palestinian state nor the right of Palestinian refugees to return to their homes."

Jerusalem

The US plan proposes that "what is Arab should go to the Arabs and what is Jewish should go to the Jews".

That seems simple. The division between West Jerusalem, which is predominantly Jewish, and East Jerusalem, which is predominantly Palestinian, is stark. There is no wall between the two, but there is an invisible line running down the length of the Number One Highway, which cuts the city in two.

Since the intifada began again last September, it has been increasingly rare for people from one community to visit the other side. Israeli taxi drivers will not take fares to the Arab side. Theoretically, the divide is already there.

The problem is the Old City, which calls into four parts: the Jewish quarter, where 3,500 people live; the Armenian quarter, where there are 2,000; the Arab quarter, which has 25,000: and the Christian quarter, which has about 500. All are pushed together in the tightly-packed streets.

The US proposal is that Israel should have the Jewish quarter, plus part of the Armenian quarter, to provide a corridor from West Jerusalem to the Jewish quarter and the all-important Wailing Wall. The Palestinians would get the Arab and Christian quarters and the remainder of the Armenian quarter.

Dividing an area of less than one square kilometre thus will not work unless both sides are willing to live peacefully together.

But peaceful coexistence is made even more difficult by the religious divide. The Muslims want all of their holy site, the Haram al-Sharif. The Jews also want it, for the Wailing Wall. Mr Clinton suggested that the Muslims should have the upper half of the site and the Jews the lower.

Madhi Abul Hadhi, head of the Palestinian Academic Society for the Study of International Affairs, in Jerusalem, insists that sharing the site in this way will only create more problems.

"You have a bedroom and you are sleeping with your wife. You do not allow anyone to sleep under your bed, but there they are. And then they start complaining they can't sleep."

Territorial divide

Mr Clinton has proposed that Israel should cede 95% of the West Bank and all of the Gaza Strip. In return for taking some West Bank land containing Jewish settlers, Israel has offered the Palestinians more land in either Gaza or the Negev desert.

The Palestinians say this is less generous than it sounds. First, the West Bank land ceded to them will be closer to 90%, because Jerusalem and the Dead Sea are included in the calculation. Second, the Israelis want to keep three big isolated Jewish settlements on the West Bank: the Ariel block near Nablus in the north, the Ma'ale Adumim corridor between Jerusalem and Jericho in the centre, and Etzion, near Hebron, in the south. These settlements, the Palestinians argue, make it hard for Palestine to be viable as an independent state.

But the big problem is again Jerusalem. Under the US plan, Israel would keep many of its settlements east of the city, which would leave Arab East Jerusalem almost cut off from the West Bank. If the proposal went ahead, the Palestinians say, it would chop the Palestinian area immediately east of Jerusalem into 10 islands.

Refugees

The most awkward problem of all is that presented by the 3.7m Palestinian refugees in Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, the West Bank and Gaza. Except in Jordan, no attempt has been made to assimilate them.

The US proposal is that they should give up their claim to a right of return to Israel and accept a right of return only to the new state of Palestine. Israel would allow up to 100,000 refugees to return to the Jewish state, others would be resettled elsewhere with compensation. There would be further compensation for losses. Finally, land ceded by Israel in the Negev or Gaza could be used to resettle the bulk of the refugees. Although the US plan is not specific, the latter proposal is aimed mainly at Palestinians now in Lebanon.

Potential compromises could result in Tel Aviv increasing the number of refugees allowed to return to Israel and a US-EU-Japanese reconstruction programme to create new cities in Gaza for refugees from Lebanon. Other refugees could be absorbed in the countries where they live at present.

The Palestinian negotiators insist that the right of return to Israel has to remain, even if the people concerned are not planning to exercise it. The team's statement said: "There is no historical precedent for a people abandoning their fundamental right to return to their homes, whether they were forced to leave or fled in fear." But the negotiators added: "The Palestinians are prepared to think flexibly and creatively about the mechanisms for implementing the right of return."

Israeli security

Under the US plan, an international force will supervise the implementation of the final agreement and Israel will be given three years to withdraw from Palestinian territory. But Israel will be allowed to keep a force at specific locations in the Jordan Valley for another three years, and maintain three early warning stations for 10 years.

The Palestinians want details of where these Israeli units will be positioned and the size of the force. The negotiating team said: "Israel has yet to make a persuasive case regarding why it would require either a standing force in the Jordan Valley or emergency deployment rights, much less both. This is especially the case given that international forces will be present in these areas."

A Palestinian close to developments spoke of the negotiations as "an evolution of the maps". He said that maps were crucial to understanding why the Palestinians had needed to see the details of Mr Clinton's proposals.

He pulled out maps dating back to the British mandate in the early years of the last century, showing how at the end of each decade the Jews had spread further and further eastwards from the coast. That continued expansion, as seen in the Jewish settlements on the West Bank, had to be stopped, he said, if Palestine was to become a reality.

He was pessimistic about the chances of peace. "The struggle is endless," he said.

webTitle: Sweden 'declined Russian offer to swap Wallenberg'

fields.headline: Sweden 'declined Russian offer to swap Wallenberg'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Sweden refused a Russian offer to exchange the captured diplomat Raoul Wallenberg for Soviet citizens being held in the west after the second world war, a Swedish newspaper reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Sweden refused a Russian offer to exchange the captured diplomat Raoul Wallenberg for Soviet citizens being held in the west after the second world war, a Swedish newspaper reported yesterday.

Wallenberg, credited with saving thousands of Jews from Nazi death camps, was last seen in 1945 being arrested by Soviet troops in Budapest.

Moscow maintained for years that he died of a heart attack in 1947 in its Lubyanka jail.

But last month the Russian authorities said he had been "unjustifiably arrested by non-judicial bodies" and died in jail, a victim of Stalin's purges.

A Swedish-Russian investigation into Wallenberg's fate, which began in 1991 and will present its findings on January 12, will show evidence that Sweden turned down the chance to negotiate his return, the tabloid daily Svenska Dagbladet said yesterday.

The then Swedish foreign minister, Osten Unden, opposed an exchange because he did not want to carry out "human trade" or sour relations with the USSR, it said.

webTitle: Senator Hillary steals the show on the Hill

fields.headline: Senator Hillary steals the show on the Hill
fields.trailText: Hillary came to the Hill yesterday, and although more than 530 other newly elected members of the US Senate and House of Representatives were sworn in, all eyes were trained on the blonde in the blue trouser suit.
fields.body:
Hillary came to the Hill yesterday, and although more than 530 other newly elected members of the US Senate and House of Representatives were sworn in, all eyes were trained on the blonde in the blue trouser suit.

Mrs Clinton arrived on Capitol Hill in mid-morning in an official motorcade, accompanied by President Bill Clinton. He and their daughter Chelsea sat in the visitors' gallery to applaud the family's new principal political breadwinner as she swore the oath of loyalty.

Officially she is 97th in seniority in the 100-member Senate. But this was one of those days when her husband and congressional veterans were compelled to accept second billing to the first First Lady to win a senate seat.

The swearing-in ceremony normally passes without interest, but yesterday it was transformed into one of the last great pieces of political choreography of the Clinton years.

Even the administration of the oath was rich in poignant political irony. For who should be on hand to do it but Al Gore, who as vice-president presides over the Senate for another 17 days, until he is replaced by Dick Cheney.

"Congratulations, I'm so proud of you," he said as he shook hands with the woman who probably represents the most potent threat to his hopes of a second run at the presidency in 2004.

Afterwards he kissed her, a chaste peck on the cheek which, quite properly, bore no resemblance to the lascivious job with his wife Tipper last summer which proved to be the high-point of his political career.

Later Mrs Clinton took the oath again in the Old Senate Chamber for the benefit of the cameras and her friends and admirers. This is a tradition followed by all new senators - except that never before has a president held the bible on which the phoney oath was sworn by his wife.

All yesterday's pomp and ceremony may have temporarily succeeded in masking the bigger political significance, at least for Americans, of the arrival in Washington of perhaps the most intriguingly divided Congress in years.

Mrs Clinton takes her place in a Senate which is equally split between Democrats and Republicans.

She and the rest of the Democrats insist that this parity should be reflected in equal representation on committees and in agenda setting. But the Republicans, who will have control when Mr Cheney has the casting vote, will have none of it. There will be con cessions on speaking rights in the chamber - a matter of intense concern to senators, though not to many other Americans - but the Senate leader, Trent Lott, fully intends to remain in charge of patronage and the timetable.

On the other side of Capitol Hill, the 435 members of the House of Representatives were also being worn in. The Republicans control the House by 221 to 211. There are two independents, and a vacant seat after the death of the Democrat Julian Dixon last month.

A Republican from Illinois, Dennis Hastert, was re-elected House Speaker and begins a second two-year stint in the legislature's most important job. He succeeded the confrontational Newt Gingrich in 1998 and has the job of piloting George W Bush's legislation through the House.

The Congress will meet in joint session on Saturday, when members will receive and officially count the electoral college votes which made Mr Bush president.

At one point in the battle for the presidency it appeared that Saturday's session might produce an unprecedented constitutional showdown between rival electors from Florida. Now it will be the usual ceremonial occasion and nothing more.

webTitle: Payments for moving in Tory benefit plan

fields.headline: Payments for moving in Tory benefit plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: People on housing benefit will be offered cash incentives to move into smaller homes under Tory plans to slash £425m from the social security budget, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
People on housing benefit will be offered cash incentives to move into smaller homes under Tory plans to slash £425m from the social security budget, it was announced yesterday.

Those living in "inappropriately" large homes will be persuaded to move to smaller accommodation, but will be given the difference in benefit for two years with the option of receiving this as a lump sum.

The move would mean that someone moving from a three-bedroom £500 a month flat, to a one bedroom, £200 one, would receive a total of £7,200.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said the £425m would account for part of the £8bn the Tories claim they could slash from the government's overall spending plans. A total of £5.3bn has already been accounted for, but there has been fierce criticism of the opposition over where they would find the extra £2.7m saving. Also, £2.3m still remains to be accounted for, but yesterday the Tories insisted that, over the next few weeks, there would be further announcements.

Mr Willetts said £50m could also be saved by forcing local authorities to meet minimum standards in administration of housing benefit and handing over responsibility for those who fail to meet these to the benefits agency. And £300m a year could be saved by cracking down on fraud, error and overpayment - which the Labour election manifesto said cost £2bn a year.

Mr Willetts also accused Labour of causing a rise in the number of homeless families since coming to power - from 102,650 in 1997-98 to 105,520 two years later, by swamping local authorities in red tape and ensuring the whole housing benefit system, was "close to collapse".

But the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, said: "The Tories are claiming to be able to save £425m on housing benefit, but their figures are simply invented and based on the most bogus assumptions.

"This is further evidence that the Tories will say anything, do anything and repeat anything in their desperate attempt to hide the £16bn hole at the heart of their tax and spending plans."
