fields.headline: Tarantula venom may save lives
fields.trailText: It may have frightened the life out of Miss Muffet, but one also has something that could save a heart attack victim.
fields.body:
It may have frightened the life out of Miss Muffet, but one also has something that could save a heart attack victim.

US and German scientists report in Nature magazine today that a protein in tarantula venom could halt atrial fibrillation, the chaotic pounding of the heart that leads to heart disease or strokes.

Frederich Sachs at the State University of New York, Buffalo, and colleagues, used an electrical jolt to set rabbit hearts beating arrhythmically and then calmed them with a fragment of protein called a peptide, lifted from the poison of the Chilean tarantula Grammostola spatulata.

The peptide, known as GsMtx-4, suppressed both the incidence and the duration of the artificial fibrillation. This is not the first case of a near-lethal toxin being harnessed to save lives. Venom from the funnel-web spider could be developed to halt brain damage in stroke victims.

Professor Sachs predicted last year that his tarantula venom would have medical possibilities. This is because cells swell during congestive heart failure, and the peptide from the venom blocked the swelling process.

Frederich Sachs at the State University of New York, Buffalo, and colleagues, used an electrical jolt to set rabbit hearts beating arrhythmically and then calmed them with a fragment of protein called a peptide, lifted from the poison of the Chilean tarantula Grammostola spatulata. The peptide, known as GsMtx-4, suppressed both the incidence and the duration of the artificial fibrillation. This is not the first case of a near-lethal toxin being harnessed to save lives. Venom from the funnel-web spider could be developed to halt brain damage in stroke victims. Professor Sachs predicted last year that his tarantula venom would have medical possibilities. This is because cells swell during congestive heart failure, and the peptide from the venom blocked the swelling process.

webTitle: Girl dies in cable car accident

fields.headline: Girl dies in cable car accident
fields.trailText: A 14-year-old British girl died yesterday after being crushed in a cable car mechanism in front of her family at the top of Table Mountain in South Africa.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd and David Beresford in Cape Town
fields.body:
A 14-year-old British girl died yesterday after being crushed in a cable car mechanism in front of her family at the top of Table Mountain in South Africa.

Cara Weaver was with her parents, Robert and Gillian, and brother at the 3,500ft world-famous beauty spot when her head became ensnared in the cable car machinery, and her neck was broken.

It is believed that the teenager, who went to school in Dorset, had gone into a restricted area after climbing out of the window of a cable car station.

South African police believe Cara had wanted to abseil down the mountain.

John Harrison, managing director of the Table Mountain Aerial Cableway Company, which operates the cable car, said he had held Cara in his arms for 40 minutes after the accident.

He said: "She had severe neck injuries. Obviously none of us was a trained doctor but we tried our best. We applied mouth to mouth. At times she did not have a pulse.

"I was there within four minutes of it happening. It looked like she was trying to go down the mountain in an extremely dangerous area. They just should not have been there. It was ridiculous. The incident happened at the side of a building and some people looking down would have seen it."

Cara was spotted by cable car staff in an exclusion zone on the north-western corner of Table Mountain, some 30-50 metres west from the point tourists are allowed to abseil from.

Mr Harrison added: "Her mother and father were with her and would have seen it. The mother was very distressed. They were in a restricted no-go area, a part of the mountain that is very dangerous. It is clearly marked.

"Our staff saw them there and warned them it was a no-go area."

Mr Harrison said that Cara had suffered severe neck injuries after she was caught in the moving steel structure supporting the steel and rubber arms which guide the cable car into the top station.

She also suffered head injuries and was taken by air ambulance to hospital where she was pronounced dead on arrival.

Captain Andre Traut, of the Cape Town police, said it was believed to be the first accident involving the cable car since it opened in 1929. "If one abides by the rules and the warning signs an accident of this nature should not occur."

In London the Foreign Office said it believed Cara and her family had been holidaying in Namibia and South Africa since December 17. Arrangements were being made to inform relatives in Britain and return the body home. A date for an inquest has yet to be organised.

Abseiling off Table Mountain, which attracts nearly 500,000 visitors a year, has become very popular in recent years.

Vaughn Maree, operations manager of Abseil Africa, an adventure sports firm unconnected with the incident, said: "It is the exposure of it. You are stepping off 1,000 metres.

"From the top of Table Mountain you have an incredible view of the 12 Apostles mountain range and Camps Bay which is a very popular beach."

The descent takes an average of two to five minutes and anyone aged from 12 years, as long as they weigh over 40kg, up to 90 years old is allowed to participate, Mr Maree said.

He said the cable care area was "clearly signed as dangerous and the people there are very strict about not going there.

"The cable cars are coming up there and they weigh a couple of tonnes. You would not want to be there."

webTitle: Trains 'within seconds' of collision outside station

fields.headline: Trains 'within seconds' of collision outside station
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack yesterday ordered an immediate investigation into how two commuter trains came within seconds of colliding outside Victoria station in central London.
fields.body:
Railtrack yesterday ordered an immediate investigation into how two commuter trains came within seconds of colliding outside Victoria station in central London.

The near-miss, which left the trains just 10ft apart, happened when rail managers suspended normal operating regulations during a signal failure which affected all services out of the station.

With all signals at red, a Connex South Central train travelling from Victoria to Horsham, Sussex, was allowed to pass through a red light at 11.30pm on Tuesday night.

At the same time, another Connex train from Victoria to East Grinstead, Surrey, is thought to have gone through a red signal without permission.

A signalman in a box outside Victoria saw that the two trains were converging and cut the power to both trains. The Horsham train's driver reacted promptly by applying his brakes and the two trains halted "within feet" of each other.

Connex, which has also launched an inquiry into the incident, said that the signal failure affected seven of Victoria's 19 platforms. In such circumstances, it is normal for signallers to "talk through" trains, which are given permission to pass red signals one at a time.

Both trains involved in the incident were running late. Railtrack said that the trains were travelling very slowly, probably at about 10 mph. Early indications were that one of the trains set off without permission.

Railtrack said: "The signaller saw what was happening, and through his quick thinking was able to send out an emergency stop message to the trains and turn off the power to bring the trains automatically to a halt."

The spokesman added: "Despite the low speeds, any collision would have been very serious and a full and thorough investigation has started. We will be interviewing all those involved, including the drivers and signallers."

Railtrack said the signalling failure meant that all the lights would have been at red automatically. A set of points was damaged, indicating that one of the trains should not have moved at that spot.

The signaller was working in the Clapham box and continued working another six hours to the end of his shift after the incident.

The near-miss was an example of what is known on the railways as a "ding dong and away" incident where a driver sets off without checking the signal.

webTitle: Plan to keep dome open 'too costly'

fields.headline: Plan to keep dome open 'too costly'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Proposals by Michael Heseltine and the former millennium commissioner Simon Jenkins to re-open the dome would have landed the national lottery with a new £85m bill, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Proposals by Michael Heseltine and the former millennium commissioner Simon Jenkins to re-open the dome would have landed the national lottery with a new £85m bill, it was revealed yesterday.

The New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, disclosed yesterday that it had costed the option after a big rise in the number of visitors in the dome's closing weeks.

But because contracts for staff would have had to be renewed and contracts renegotiated with the sponsors, it would have meant an immediate request for more lottery cash from the millennium commission which had already objected to £76m being used to bail it out last year.

The public will, however, get two more days to view the dome before most of its contents are auctioned on March 1 and 2. On February 27 and 28, for the price of a catalogue, any member of the public will be able to view the remaining exhibits.

This will include the heart and brain of the body zone and all the contents of the faith zone which will remain in place until March before they are transfered to Council for the Promotion of Religious Education. The costumes and props used by performers for the show will also be on display before being sold.

It was claimed yesterday that the dome's chief, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, overruled some board members to allow the group Ministry of Sound free access to the grounds for the New Year's Eve rave.

A company spokesman said it had been public knowledge that the group was not being charged for use of the facilities. "If we had charged they would not have been able to put on the event and charge a reasonable ticket price."

Mr Gerbeau said: "I had the full support of the board for going ahead with the event and, in any case, Ministry of Sound paid up £50,000 rental money and £10,000 for retail and catering."

The Tories continued to attack Lord Falconer, the dome minister, for his handling of the project. The shadow Cabinet Office minister, Andrew Lansley, said "ministerial interference and mishandling" over the dome was continuing to cost taxpayers' money.

"Everyone knows P-Y Gerbeau and the dome staff have made the best of a bad job over recent months but have been handed a hopeless mess by the way ministers set up the project," he said. "Lord Falconer should now resign, or will no-one take responsibility for the waste and incompetence."

fields.headline: Health fear over farmed salmon
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Scientists yesterday revived concerns about the safety of fish farming by suggesting that farmed salmon contained high levels of potentially dangerous pollutants.
fields.body:
Scientists yesterday revived concerns about the safety of fish farming by suggesting that farmed salmon contained high levels of potentially dangerous pollutants.

They called for urgent research into the problems posed by the rapid growth of aquaculture which means that about a third of the fish now caught commercially on oceans and rivers worldwide goes to feed farmed fish or livestock.

Oily fish have long been know to be big carriers of pollutants but they have also been heavily promoted as healthy ingredients in people's diets, reducing the chances of heart disease and arthritis, among other benefits.

The man-made chemicals are found in a range of foods and result from waste from industrial processes, but in heavy doses are thought to pose a risk to the human nervous and immune systems, particularly in children, and to fertility.

The World Health Organisation and scientists advising the European commission have already recommended reducing tolerable daily intakes of the pollutants by up to a 10th of present levels allowed in Britain, which could pose severe tests for the Scottish farmed salmon industry. It employs about 6,500 people, two-thirds in the Highlands and Islands. The industry is already blamed for other forms of environmental damage and pollution.

In Britain the food standards agency says it has asked independent experts to review the maximum "doses" of pollutants people should consume through their food.

The latest concerns arose out of investigations for Warnings from the Wild, a BBC2 television programme to be screened on Sunday night. One scientist for the programme suggested that the concentration of trawled fish into a high protein diet for farmed fish was concentrating the pollutants too.

Michael Easton, who conducted an unpublished study for Canada's David Suzuki Foundation, told programme makers that farmed fish had much higher levels of PCBs, organochlorine pesticides and flame retardants. Miriam Jacobs, a nutritionist and toxicologist at Surrey University, who has been involved in research, said recent work suggested feed for farmed fish was a significant source of contamination.

The agency is furious at the way the research has been presented by the BBC, especially since Dr Jacobs's published work states that there is no significant difference between contaminant levels in farmed fish and those in wild or escaped fish.

webTitle: Fayed lawyers to get list of Hamilton court backers

fields.headline: Fayed lawyers to get list of Hamilton court backers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Hamilton v Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: A list naming those who bankrolled Neil Hamilton's ill-fated libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed is understood to have been sent to lawyers acting for the Harrods boss.
fields.body:
A list naming those who bankrolled Neil Hamilton's ill-fated libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed is understood to have been sent to lawyers acting for the Harrods boss.

The disgraced Tory MP lost a six-year battle to clear his name in an English court on December 22 when three appeal court judges refused to overturn a libel jury's verdict against him.

The court also lifted "stays" which had been put on costs orders and the naming of Mr Hamilton's backers. They could now be pursued for defence costs which are estimated to be £2m. Mr Hamilton said he could not afford to pay the costs.

Lord Harris of High Cross, who co-ordinated the £400,000 fighting fund, was directed to provide Mr Fayed's lawyers DJ Freeman with names of contributors who had donated more than £5,000.

Laurence Harris of DJ Freeman declined to confirm whether the list had been received, adding: "I cannot confirm or deny the identities or the number of names because that would be in breach of the court order of confidentiality."

webTitle: British 'bone factory' discovery offers new surgical hope for the elderly

fields.headline: British 'bone factory' discovery offers new surgical hope for the elderly
fields.trailText: Seven years of patent protected research have led to a world first for British medical scientists, who have reproduced the body's "bone factory" cell in a university laboratory.
fields.body:
Seven years of patent protected research have led to a world first for British medical scientists, who have reproduced the body's "bone factory" cell in a university laboratory.

Bio-material taken from human skeletal cells has successfully triggered the natural process of endochronal ossification (EO) which creates cartilage and new bone round fractures and damaged bones.

Trials of injecting the new substance into hip and knee joints and dental repairs will start shortly at Sheffield University, after success in triggering bone-making in ordinary marrow cells.

Potentially the technique has important implications for surgery on older people, whose natural cartilage replacement has slowed down, and in reversing the bone damage caused by osteoporosis in older bones.

"We believe we have discovered the gold standard in this field," said Bradley Stringer, a tissue specialist at Sheffield, which took out protective patents in 1994 when doctors decided to investigate copying the natural EO process. "What we've created is the very stuff that nature produces herself to repair bones or make them grow."

The product, provisionally named Skeletex, is the result of painstaking work to copy the rich mixture of proteins and chemicals which trigger bone growth and repair. The Sheffield formula exactly mirrors the collection of active ingredients and others which remain inert until they meet bone marrow cells, which they then trigger into helping the ossification.

"You could call it a chemical soup, or perhaps a chemical symphony," said Dr Stringer. "The task has been to find all the orchestra's members and then to get them playing together."

Trials will start at Sheffield's school of clinical dentistry on volunteers with dental implants or gum disease which has worn away the bone which helps hold teeth in place.

Success will lead to commercial marketing.

"One of our problems in med icine today is a shortage in the bone bank for conventional grafts," said Dr Stringer.

"Skeletex also has the promise to be much more effective than grafts, especially those using bone material ... where sterilisation is essential and the result is not always as effective as the natural, bone growing process."

Hip and knee joints are another potential market be cause of the bio-material's strength which promises to remove the "joint wobble" problem which tends to affect people when cement used to fix artificial joint pins wears loose.

Commercial benefits will accrue to Sheffield through its tissue-engineering company CellFactors which has financed the research programme.

webTitle: Barak agrees to talks with Palestinians

fields.headline: Barak agrees to talks with Palestinians
fields.standfirst:
Israeli leader plans to send team to discuss US peace deal

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli leader plans to send team to discuss US peace deal.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  in Jerusalem and Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak was last night preparing to send a team of negotiators led by Shlomo Ben Ami to Washington to meet a Palestinian delegation, leaving the door open for a last-minute Middle East peace deal.

Mr Arafat earlier gave his heavily-qualified acceptance to more negotiations during a meeting with Bill Clinton, in Washington, according to Palestinian and White House sources yesterday.

The Palestinian leader left Washington yesterday for Egypt after two sessions on Tuesday with Mr Clinton. He is to meet Arab leaders at a summit in Cairo today to discuss the latest US proposals.

"It is important to move the peace process forward," Mr Arafat called out to a CNN reporter as he got into his car to drive to Andrews air force base.

A state department official said they were cautiously optimistic, "but with the emphasis on the caution".

Mr Barak, after speaking with Mr Clinton, last night called a meeting of his cabinet ministers directly involved in the peace negotiations.

But a source inside the prime minister's office said that Mr Barak's assessment was unchanged: that there was almost no chance of agreement before Mr Clinton left office on January 20 or before the Israeli election on February 6.

Mr Barak, who was planning to speak to Mr Clinton again after the cabinet meeting, had no plans to go to Washington himself, the source said, adding that the Israeli government did not know whether Mr Arafat's acceptance was tactical or substantive but suspected the former.

A more upbeat assessment came from the Israeli justice minister, Yossi Beilin, who said: "I think there will be a possibility of resuming talks between us and the Palestinians."

However, he rejected outright a concession on one of the Palestinians' main areas of concern, the right of Palestinian refugees to return to Israel

The chief negotiator, Mr Ben Ami, said that it was above human power to achieve a deal before Mr Clinton leaves office, "but we have a moral duty to make the effort".

Mr Arafat, who is under immense pressure from all shades of Palestinian opinion to turn down the US plan, told Mr Clinton he would give a conditional acceptance even though he had reservations about the proposals, in particular over the future of Jerusalem and of the 3.7m Palestinian refugees. "We can't live with these [US] ideas. They have to be changed," a senior Palestinian official said.

Both the Islamic militant group, Hamas, and Mr Arafat's own grouping, Fatah, have warned him in recent days not to accept the US plans.

In spite of his response to Mr Clinton, Mr Arafat has already opened channels with George W Bush, through the Saudi embassy in Washington. The Saudi staff have strong personal links with Mr Bush's team which were forged during the Gulf war, and in par ticular with the next secretary of state, Colin Powell.

Mr Barak, who is trailing in the opinion polls to Ariel Sharon, had hoped to have a peace agreement to put before the Israeli electorate. On Tuesday, he switched tack, expressing pessimism about a peace deal.

The deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, said yesterday that Israel will continue its policy of assassinations of Palestinians suspected of involve ment in attacks on Israelis. Mr Barak blamed members of the Palestinian Authority for being behind the attacks. "If anyone has committed or is planning to carry out terrorist acts, he has to be hit," Mr Sneh told Israel army radio, adding that no one was immune.

While Mr Barak has adopted hawkish rhetoric, Mr Sharon, a hardliner, has been trying to soften his image to woo votes from the centre. But he said yesterday that if elected, he would keep Israeli forces in the Jordan valley, even though the US proposal is for a staged withdrawal.

There were violent incidents along the Israeli-Lebanon border yesterday. Israeli police also revealed that two weeks ago, they uncovered a cell of the militant Islamic Jihad group which was planning car bombings inside Israel.

Mr Arafat earlier gave his heavily-qualified acceptance to more negotiations during a meeting with Bill Clinton, in Washington, according to Palestinian and White House sources yesterday. The Palestinian leader left Washington yesterday for Egypt after two sessions on Tuesday with Mr Clinton. He is to meet Arab leaders at a summit in Cairo today to discuss the latest US proposals. "It is important to move the peace process forward," Mr Arafat called out to a CNN reporter as he got into his car to drive to Andrews air force base. A state department official said they were cautiously optimistic, "but with the emphasis on the caution". Mr Barak, after speaking with Mr Clinton, last night called a meeting of his cabinet ministers directly involved in the peace negotiations. But a source inside the prime minister's office said that Mr Barak's assessment was unchanged: that there was almost no chance of agreement before Mr Clinton left office on January 20 or before the Israeli election on February 6. Mr Barak, who was planning to speak to Mr Clinton again after the cabinet meeting, had no plans to go to Washington himself, the source said, adding that the Israeli government did not know whether Mr Arafat's acceptance was tactical or substantive but suspected the former. A more upbeat assessment came from the Israeli justice minister, Yossi Beilin, who said: "I think there will be a possibility of resuming talks between us and the Palestinians." However, he rejected outright a concession on one of the Palestinians' main areas of concern, the right of Palestinian refugees to return to Israel The chief negotiator, Mr Ben Ami, said that it was above human power to achieve a deal before Mr Clinton leaves office, "but we have a moral duty to make the effort". Mr Arafat, who is under immense pressure from all shades of Palestinian opinion to turn down the US plan, told Mr Clinton he would give a conditional acceptance even though he had reservations about the proposals, in particular over the future of Jerusalem and of the 3.7m Palestinian refugees. "We can't live with these [US] ideas. They have to be changed," a senior Palestinian official said. Both the Islamic militant group, Hamas, and Mr Arafat's own grouping, Fatah, have warned him in recent days not to accept the US plans. In spite of his response to Mr Clinton, Mr Arafat has already opened channels with George W Bush, through the Saudi embassy in Washington. The Saudi staff have strong personal links with Mr Bush's team which were forged during the Gulf war, and in par ticular with the next secretary of state, Colin Powell. Mr Barak, who is trailing in the opinion polls to Ariel Sharon, had hoped to have a peace agreement to put before the Israeli electorate. On Tuesday, he switched tack, expressing pessimism about a peace deal. The deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, said yesterday that Israel will continue its policy of assassinations of Palestinians suspected of involve ment in attacks on Israelis. Mr Barak blamed members of the Palestinian Authority for being behind the attacks. "If anyone has committed or is planning to carry out terrorist acts, he has to be hit," Mr Sneh told Israel army radio, adding that no one was immune. While Mr Barak has adopted hawkish rhetoric, Mr Sharon, a hardliner, has been trying to soften his image to woo votes from the centre. But he said yesterday that if elected, he would keep Israeli forces in the Jordan valley, even though the US proposal is for a staged withdrawal. There were violent incidents along the Israeli-Lebanon border yesterday. Israeli police also revealed that two weeks ago, they uncovered a cell of the militant Islamic Jihad group which was planning car bombings inside Israel. fields.headline: Melting permafrost threatens Alps
fields.standfirst:
Communities face devastating landslides from unstable mountain ranges

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Communities face devastating landslides from unstable mountain ranges.
fields.body:
Permafrost holding together the highest peaks in the Alps and other European mountain ranges is melting and threatening alpine villages and ski resorts with devastating rockfalls and landslides. Some villages may have to be evacuated and there are also fears that rivers may be blocked by debris, causing potential flash floods when the unstable dams created subsequently collapse.

A Europe-wide monitoring of permafrost in mountain peaks has been launched by the EU to predict when disasters may occur and so isolate unstable areas. Scientists are blaming the changes on global warming.

Dr Charles Harris, from the earth sciences department at Cardiff University, who coordinates the research for the EU, said the main area at risk was the Alps in Switzerland, Austria, France, Germany and Italy, where the mountains were more densely populated and the slopes very steep. Among the places being monitored is the Murtel-Corvatsch mountain above fashionable St Moritz, and the Schilthorn, which towers above the Muran and Gandeg resorts, near Zermatt.

"A borehole sunk above St Moritz 15 years ago shows the temperature of the ground has risen half a degree to one degree in that time. If the temperature inside the mountain is only -2C at the moment then it will not take long to defrost," Dr Harris said.

He said that in Switzerland there were already rockfalls, landslides, mudflows, debris and slushflows as the ice melted and weakened the mountains. These were certain to increase. "What we do not understand is how big these falls might get. Whole mountainsides could go at once, potentially crushing settlements, cutting railway lines and roads. We need to try to understand and predict this process."

Dr Harris added that the Swiss government was seriously concerned about the problem. "They are very worried about the future of their mountain communities and where they can continue to live with this increasing level of risk."

Vulnerable

A new organisation called Permafrost and Climate in Europe (Pace) has been set up to monitor the creeping effects of climate change on the stability of mountains. The surface soil and rock temperature rises above zero in the summer and refreezes again each winter, while a few inches inside the mountains the ice is permanent, or has been for thousands of years. Pace literature says: "The combination of ground temperatures only slightly below zero, high ice contents and steep slopes, makes mountain permafrost particularly vulnerable to even small climate changes."

To their surprise, researchers have shown that in high mountains permafrost exists as far south as the Sierra Nevada in Spain on the edge of the Mediterranean. Dr Harris said he would have expected the ice to have disappeared long ago because of the warmth of the climate. Although ice was only in the tops of the mountains in Spain it started at around 2,500 metres (7,750ft) in the Alps and 1,500m (4,600ft) in Sweden. In Svalbard in the high Arctic it was at sea level. Britain's highest mountains are too low and too close to the warm westerly winds to have permafrost.

A series of boreholes have been made across Europe to monitor how deep the permafrost goes and how cold the rocks in mountains are. The colder the temperature, the stronger the ice, so as it warms the mountains may collapse before the permafrost completely melts. Most falls were expected in the summer and autumn but that may not always be the case, Dr Harris said.

Resorts

Other mountain ranges with permafrost being monitored are the Pyrenees, which form the French-Spanish border, the Jotunheimen range in Norway and Abisko range in Sweden. Boreholes have also been dug in Svalbard, the islands north of Norway, where coal is mined in the permafrost and the buildings have their foundations on frozen soil as hard as rock. There are fears that the buildings will settle and fall over if the frost melts.

This could be a serious problem in the higher ski resorts where foundations of ski lifts and other buildings assume the ground will remain stable.

Dr Harris said the boreholes recently sunk were too new to assess long-term trends. That would come over the next 10, 20 and even 50 years. But the temperature gradients in the first 100 metres of rock had revealed new information.

"We know that the rock is coldest in the middle. It is heated from below by the earth's core, and from above by the warmer temperatures. We would expect in stable conditions for the temperature gradient to be in a straight line, but it is not," he said. "From our calculations we already know that the tops of the mountains have warmed one or two degrees in the last 100 to 150 years. That is at a far quicker rate than the speed of global warming generally."

Among the factors accelerating the warming of mountain tops was the melting of glaciers. These had retreated in the past 100 years and half were expected to disappear this century. "Once the surface ice goes, the rocks warm much quicker in the summer sun," Dr Harris said.

fields.headline: Spies trailed with radioactive spray
fields.trailText: East German communist security police - the notorious Stasi, the local equivalent of the KGB - had a way of getting glowing reports of suspected dissidents and spies.
fields.body:
East German communist security police - the notorious Stasi, the local equivalent of the KGB - had a way of getting glowing reports of suspected dissidents and spies.

They clandestinely labelled their victims with a radioactive marker, and tracked them by geiger counter, according to officials of the Berlin-based Gauck commission, a government agency investigating the archives of former secret police.

According to today's New Scientist, while the plotters mingled with the crowds, secret policemen followed them with vibrating radiation detectors concealed in their armpits.

"It's a remarkable story. It's the first well-documented case of such a thing," said Klaus Becker, a radiation protection expert. According to the Stasi files, during the 1970s and 1980s, the security police would spray people, their documents or their money with a solution of radioactive scandium-46. They could also spray whole meeting rooms, thus identifying any conspirators or dissidents who turned up. They also developed an airgun that could fire radio-labelled silver wire into a car tyre from 25 yards. There was care not to expose the police themselves to much danger - but dissidents could be exposed to quite high doses every time they were labelled.

Geiger counters clicked intensely as they got nearer to any radiation source. So 30 years ago the secret police developed the "silent ringers" now used in today's cell phones and pagers, in order not to alarm the suspects they were trailing. They may also have created problems for thousands of unsuspecting - and unsuspected - citizens.

"The Stasi marked West German deutschmarks with large amounts to see how they circulated, to whom and for what purpose," said Dr Becker. "While they expected to retrieve them, they didn't, and the notes disappeared without trace."

The security police later calculated that while a single note was probably harmless, two or more together were not. The effect of more than one on male fertility could have had the same effect as castration

"It really is the stuff of James Bond movies," one London radiologist told New Scientist. "It's an unpleasant thing to do. The risk is not limited to the person being tagged. You'd be exposing other people, such as a spouse."

webTitle: Government could take stake in Railtrack

fields.headline: Government could take stake in Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack will be given until Easter to restore the railway to normality or face the threat of the government taking a stake in the company to have more control over decisions, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack will be given until Easter to restore the railway to normality or face the threat of the government taking a stake in the company to have more control over decisions, industry sources said last night.

This message has been picked up in the industry as one of the options being examined by Labour in the run-up to the election. Railtrack confirmed yesterday that the issue had been discussed with ministers but was "not a burning issue".

As the election approaches, John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is concerned that the government should escape criticism from a disillusioned public for its handling of the rail crisis.

Ministers hope Railtrack can complete its recovery programme before the election, although Steve Marshall, chief executive, warned yesterday that normality may not be restored until May.

This would be too close for the government's comfort. It is being advised that it may have to take positive steps by buying into Railtrack. It would go part of the way towards meeting the widespread public support which exists for the renationalisation of Railtrack.

Mr Prescott has displayed considerable hostility towards Railtrack recently, pointedly refusing to back its former chief executive, Gerald Corbett, when he originally offered to resign. Mr Corbett was one of Railtrack's senior executives who was not opposed to the government taking a stake in the business.

The hostility is mutual. Sir Philip Beck, Railtrack's chairman, has told the government that it will not tolerate interference from ministers or regulators in the appointment of a new chairman this summer.

A government move to buy into Railtrack would be unprecedented, but could be achieved in various ways.

Railtrack could, for example, issue new shares which would be bought by the government. On Railtrack's current stock market value of just under £5bn, a 5% stake would mean investing around £250m.

With such a holding, the government could then request a place on Railtrack's board, installing its own non-executive director.

A second option would be for Railtrack to go for a fully fledged rights issue, with the government underwriting an offer of new shares to all City investors. This would allow the company to raise more money from the private sector, with the government mopping up any unwanted shares.

The government could justify its decision because it has just committed £15bn of taxpayers' money to Railtrack over the next five years, a move which is being supervised by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor. Ministers do not like standing by helplessly while Railtrack spends the government's money without being able to control where it is going.

The argument against government interference is that it would frighten off the private sector. Under the government's transport plans, £60bn is to be invested in the railways over the next 10 years, but £40bn of that is earmarked to come from the private sector.

By becoming more directly involved with the running of Railtrack, the government could also quickly find itself under attack in the event of another rail disaster or industry crisis. But this was hardly an issue under nationalisation when British Rail ran the industry on behalf of the government.

The Department of Transport said last night that the government had no plans at present to take a stake in Railtrack, although the idea had been considered.

Another problem for Railtrack emerged yesterday when it admitted that large sections of the west coast main line would have to be re-railed again because the track was not capable of taking high-speed tilting trains. If the work was not done, the tilting trains, due to be introduced next year, would be subject to speed restrictions lasting three years. Mr Marshall said the company was working closely with the government and the industry to ensure that arecovery plan for the railway was in place by January 18.

The rail regulator is threatening to take legal action against Railtrack if this is not done. Mr Marshall agreed that it was important for passengers "to know precisely how their services will be affected."

webTitle: Vous n'avez pas priorité - French ministers ahead

fields.headline: Vous n'avez pas priorité - French ministers ahead
fields.trailText: It was never going to be an easy promise to keep. "Sirens and flashing blue lights will disappear from official cars," said Jacques Chirac, newly elected president of the republic, in 1995. "In future, they will respect red lights and all other traffic regulations."
fields.body:
It was never going to be an easy promise to keep. "Sirens and flashing blue lights will disappear from official cars," said Jacques Chirac, newly elected president of the republic, in 1995. "In future, they will respect red lights and all other traffic regulations."

Five years on, the car enthusiasts' magazine Auto Plus decided to tail seven members of the cabinet to check the state of ministerial driving habits. The result? By rights, it said yesterday, five of them should have lost their licences.

"Fair enough," the magazine said, "sirens and flashing lights are used very rarely. But ministers jump red lights with impunity and, as for speed, they adapt their driving to the traffic conditions. Like most of us, that means 80kph instead of 50kph. But we, unlike them, will never be invisible to speed traps."

In a pleasing irony, the worst offenders were Marylise Lebranchu, the justice minister, and Jean-Claude Gayssot, the transport minister. Ms Lebranchu, guilty of jumping three red lights, illegally crossing a white line and driving the wrong way down a one-way street, should in theory have had 19 points deducted from her licence, an automatic suspension and a £2,100 fine.

In his recent legislation aimed at cutting in half France's staggering road death toll, Mr Gayssot said the "simple respect of speed limits" would save 3,000 lives a year. Unfortunately, in the five days he spent with Auto Plus on his tail, he jumped five sets of traffic lights and on four occasions exceeded the speed limit by more than 20kph.

Amid a sorry list of serial Gallic traffic offenders that included the finance minister, Laurent Fabius (licence suspended, £1,800 fine), the interior minister, Daniel Vaillant (ditto, £560 fine) and the environment minister Dominique Voynet (ditto, £1,500 fine), the president was the only one to heed his own instructions.

Caught in traffic jams on the Champs Elysées and the avenue de la Grande-Armée, Jacques Chirac simply sat in his Renault and waited.

fields.headline: Labour 'breaks roads pledge'
fields.standfirst:
Geographers conference: Prescott beats Tories on completing road schemes

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Geographers conference: Prescott beats Tories on completing road schemes
fields.body:
The Labour government has ditched its promises to reduce traffic growth and is going to complete more road schemes a year than the Conservatives, according to researchers at Aberdeen University.

Not since Margaret Thatcher launched the "great car economy" in the 1989 white paper, Roads for Prosperity, has there been such an ambitious road building programme, say Jon Shaw and William Walton.

"Faced with the highly sensitive needs of motorists and the political ramifications of curbing their freedom, the pledge of John Prescott to cut the number of car journeys in the first five years of Labour rule has been abandoned," Mr Walton said.

"There has in fact been a remorseless increase in traffic growth."

Another factor had been the damage to Britain's car factories if people were discouraged from driving.

"It is fundamentally inconsistent for the government to encourage more and more cars to be built in Britain and try to save factories due to be closed, and then ask people to buy cars but leave them in the garage," he said. "If people buy cars they want to use them more often."

Instead of curbing the motorist the government was spending more on public transport but at the same time attempting to revive the policy the Tories had abandoned of predicting traffic growth and providing the roads.

The Department of the Environment had said specifically in 1998 that this did not work, but the recent 10 year transport plan had outlined 41 new trunk road schemes, probable funding for another 31, and more than 100 motorway and major road widening schemes - more than the average the Tories maintained over their 18 years in office.

Instead of imposing restrictions on the motorist as Mr Prescott claimed he would in 1997, the powers to do this had been devolved to local authorities.

National government therefore escapes the blame for unpopular local road pricing and tax on workplace parking schemes.

Other research shows that death and serious injury rates vary dramatically in different parts of the country. The government had set local authority targets of reducing road casualties by 40% but it was clear that this was not likely to produce the best results, said Steven Toole of the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety.

Two adjoining councils, Redcar and Cleveland, and North Yorkshire, had the lowest and highest road casualty figures in the country: 36 per 100,000 population in Redcar and Cleveland and 165 in North Yorkshire - more than four times as much.

Greater London had around the average of 96 deaths and serious injury per 100,000 population.

The precise reasons for the differences had not been established. It was likely that the traffic differences between rural and urban areas was a factor. Through routes and motorways also would have an influence.

Research showed that speed cameras and cameras to catch people jumping red lights had a significant effect on reducing casualties.

In urban areas 20 mph speed limits were particularly effective.

It was clear that some measures, such as better car design and national drink driving campaigns, were outside the control of local authorities but also cut the casualty rate.

More research was needed to find out how such big discrepancies occurred to assist local authorities to meet government imposed targets.

fields.bodyText: The Labour government has ditched its promises to reduce traffic growth and is going to complete more road schemes a year than the Conservatives, according to researchers at Aberdeen University. Not since Margaret Thatcher launched the "great car economy" in the 1989 white paper, Roads for Prosperity, has there been such an ambitious road building programme, say Jon Shaw and William Walton. "Faced with the highly sensitive needs of motorists and the political ramifications of curbing their freedom, the pledge of John Prescott to cut the number of car journeys in the first five years of Labour rule has been abandoned," Mr Walton said. "There has in fact been a remorseless increase in traffic growth." Another factor had been the damage to Britain's car factories if people were discouraged from driving. "It is fundamentally inconsistent for the government to encourage more and more cars to be built in Britain and try to save factories due to be closed, and then ask people to buy cars but leave them in the garage," he said. "If people buy cars they want to use them more often." Instead of curbing the motorist the government was spending more on public transport but at the same time attempting to revive the policy the Tories had abandoned of predicting traffic growth and providing the roads. The Department of the Environment had said specifically in 1998 that this did not work, but the recent 10 year transport plan had outlined 41 new trunk road schemes, probable funding for another 31, and more than 100 motorway and major road widening schemes - more than the average the Tories maintained over their 18 years in office. Instead of imposing restrictions on the motorist as Mr Prescott claimed he would in 1997, the powers to do this had been devolved to local authorities. National government therefore escapes the blame for unpopular local road pricing and tax on workplace parking schemes. Other research shows that death and serious injury rates vary dramatically in different parts of the country. The government had set local authority targets of reducing road casualties by 40% but it was clear that this was not likely to produce the best results, said Steven Toole of the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety. Two adjoining councils, Redcar and Cleveland, and North Yorkshire, had the lowest and highest road casualty figures in the country: 36 per 100,000 population in Redcar and Cleveland and 165 in North Yorkshire - more than four times as much. Greater London had around the average of 96 deaths and serious injury per 100,000 population. The precise reasons for the differences had not been established. It was likely that the traffic differences between rural and urban areas was a factor. Through routes and motorways also would have an influence. Research showed that speed cameras and cameras to catch people jumping red lights had a significant effect on reducing casualties. In urban areas 20 mph speed limits were particularly effective. It was clear that some measures, such as better car design and national drink driving campaigns, were outside the control of local authorities but also cut the casualty rate. More research was needed to find out how such big discrepancies occurred to assist local authorities to meet government imposed targets. webTitle: RUC chief testifies in bid to keep Adair in jail

fields.headline: RUC chief testifies in bid to keep Adair in jail
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: RUC chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan was called as a witness yesterday in the government's legal bid to keep Belfast loyalist paramilitary leader Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair in prison.
fields.body:
RUC chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan was called as a witness yesterday in the government's legal bid to keep Belfast loyalist paramilitary leader Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair in prison.

Peter Mandelson had Adair, 37, jailed in August after police intelligence reports blamed him for orchestrating the feud between his Shankill Road Ulster Freedom Fighters and the Ulster Volunteer Force.

The Northern Ireland secretary was furious at last month's preliminary finding by the sentence review commission that Adair should be let out . He is challenging this at a private hearing, attended by the UFF leader, which continues today at Maghaberry prison, Co Antrim, where Adair is held.

Both the government and Adair's allies predict victory but a sentence review commission spokesman cautioned against taking the preliminary finding as any indication of the final ruling. Whatever happened, the loser would almost certainly appeal, and the final decision would go to judicial review. Mr Mandelson is determined to keep Adair in jail, fearing his release could reignite the inter-loyalist battle which claimed the lives of seven Belfast men before a truce was declared less than three weeks ago.

Many moderates voted for the Good Friday peace accord swayed by Tony Blair's pledge that paramilitary prisoners such as Adair who were freed early would be put back in jail if they reoffended.

Adair was imprisoned for 16 years on terrorism charges but freed in September 1999 after serving five years and now claims to be an advocate for peace.

"If it wasn't for people like Johnny Adair we mightn't have made the progress we have in the past six years," said John White, one of Adair's friends and chairman of the UFF's political wing, the Ulster Democratic Party.

"The seven men killed in the feud died after Johnny was back in jail which just goes to show he had nothing whatsoever to do with it."

However, the chief constable publicly warned Adair that his behaviour was under scrutiny after he made several appearances at Drumcree, Co Armagh, during the stand-off between loyalists and security forces when the the Orange march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown was banned last July.

On one occasion, Adair was captured on film, applauding masked members of the renegade Loyalist Volunteer Force, which fired a volley of shots in the air as a show of strength.

Ulster Defence Association leader, Andy Tyrie, and Mr White were among those lined up to speak on Adair's behalf but Mr White said lawyers had decided their testimony was no longer necessary because the preliminary finding meant the onus was now on the government to prove its case.

Much of yesterday's hearing was taken up with legal arguments about whether a member of Northern Ireland's new human rights commission could be present while police officers gave confidential information. Adair will not be present during these sessions.

Adair's counsel dropped this request when the government threatened to take the issue to judicial review, which could have delayed the hearing for months.

fields.headline: Drugs tsar hails new detector
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: New equipment which can spot drugs hidden inside a car by detecting particles in the air could soon be used to help stem the illicit trade into Britain, the government's drugs tsar said yesterday.
fields.body:
New equipment which can spot drugs hidden inside a car by detecting particles in the air could soon be used to help stem the illicit trade into Britain, the government's drugs tsar said yesterday.

In an upbeat speech to science academics and teachers, Keith Hellawell said the government's anti-drugs campaign was showing signs of success, with the growth in experimentation among schoolchildren levelling off.

But he stirred controversy when he singled out some families in Britain's Turkish community as being key links in the heroin trade.

Mr Hellawell, speaking at the International Conference for the Association for Science Education, at Surrey University, said new drug detection equipment being developed by Middlesex University would begin trials next month.

"Just before Christmas I saw a demonstration. Equipment such as this could be an invaluable aid in detecting smuggled drugs in the way carbon dioxide detection is used to examine vehicles suspected of having illegal immigrants concealed in them."

Mr Hellawell said he was confident that the new technology would be used to intensify Britain's attempts to disrupt the trade in drugs. Other measures already being taken included seconding British experts to Turkey and eastern European countries applying to enter the EU, to target the smugglers.

But his remarks, regarding the heroin trade, that some Turkish families living in Britain were key links in the supply route from the poppy fields of the far east, as importers and money launderers, sparked protests.

He said: "If you have Turkish families, and families of people with those linkages on the supply chain with legitimate bases in this country, then clearly that's the way this system works.

"We have got money laundering taking place in London, very often by legitimate businesses. But we don't want to tarnish all Turkish people or people from eastern Europe as potential criminals. They are not, but these linkages are something that we look at."

Fulden Cetin, a London based Turkish radio journalist, said yesterday that Mr Hellawell was wrong to single out the Turkish community.

Demand in Europe for heroin from the east caused the smugglers to seek a way through. "Turkey is the easiest route because of its geographical situation. We don't like it either," he said, urging Britain to step up its help in breaking up drugs mafias.

On a more positive note, Mr Hellawell pointed to a rise in the quantity of drugs detected, a fall in reoffending by addicts who had completed rehabilitation programmes, and more drugs education lessons in schools, as evidence that the government's policy was having an impact.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Creditors force Tuskar closure
fields.body:
Creditors force Tuskar closure

Tuskar Resources, the Irish oil company, announced plans to wind itself up following threats of legal action for non-payment of revenues by a Norwegian service company.

Shares in Tuskar fell 90% on the London stock market after it decided to invite another of its creditors, Allied Energy, to apply to the high court in Dublin for the company to be run down.

Shares in Tuskar traded as high as 3.75p last year but yesterday closed at 0.03p. Tuskar stocks attracted significant interest among a small band of speculative investors.

The firm claimed it had been forced to cease production at the Obe field in Nigeria because of rows with its local partner.

Norway's Brovig Offshore provided a tanker to carry crude from Nigeria but payments were not made because no oil was loaded. Brovig Offshore started legal action against Tuskar in London.

WH Smith ends magazine row

WH Smith has settled a row over its magazine distribution which will see an end to its own, two-month-old supply system.

Britain's largest wholesale and retail newsagent said it had also reached agreement with Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday, which backed the proposed industry solution for magazine distribution.

As a result Associated had withdrawn its threat to end its multi-million pound distribution deal with WH Smith News. The company said it would suspend its national distribution operation by January 27.

ShareLink founder returns

Entrepreneur David Jones is returning to the City five years after selling his share trading group ShareLink to Charles Schwab for £39.5m.

Mr Jones, 47, has become a non-executive director of Patsystems, a listed developer of derivatives trading software that targets private investors.

Patsystems said it approached Mr Jones, who has also served on the boards of the London Stock Exchange and Crestco, the securities clearing and settlement organisation, for his industry experience.

Patsystems floated last March and through offices in London, Chicago, Singapore, Sydney and Frankfurt enables access to a variety of exchanges around the world.

Bioglan buys into Germany

Bioglan Pharma yesterday bought a portfolio of 12 dermatology drugs for £16.4m from a German firm, Hexal, making it a leader in the German skin care market, the second biggest in the world.

Terry Sadler, Bioglan's chief executive, said: "Historically, the Germans have always used a lot of dermatology products. Once we start to build our sales force over there we hope to be the leading player in that country."

Mr Sadler said the company expected to make further acquisitions this year, particularly in continental countries such as Italy and Spain. Bioglan shares rose 9p to 476.5p.

Fidelity tops mutuals table

Fidelity Investments boosted assets under management in Britain by £3bn last year, making it the country's biggest mutual fund firm.

US-based Fidelity leapfrogged the British firm Schroders to take the number one spot, increasing funds under management from £13.1bn to £16.4bn in the year to November 30, according to industry body the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds.

fields.headline: Call to keep playschools non-academic
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Children who go to less academic playgroups are more likely to perform better at school, stay married, vote in elections, and read a newspaper, according to an academic.
fields.body:
Children who go to less academic playgroups are more likely to perform better at school, stay married, vote in elections, and read a newspaper, according to an academic.

Kathy Sylva, of Oxford University, will today tell the North of England education conference in Bridlington, East Yorkshire, that play schools are becoming too formal and academic.

The best nurseries allowed children to learn by singing songs, reciting nursery rhymes and engaging in "child-to-child chitchat", she will say. Children put through a "formal skills" programme showed "more anxiety and had lower self-esteem when they were primary pupils", she says.

Youngsters who had attended nurseries following a less academic formula were given more freedom and, later on, did better at school.

"Is there a take-home message? Yes, there is. In 25 years we have moved from no curriculum to an overly academic curriculum," Prof Sylva will tell delegates.

"In this new century we should move to the balanced cognitive and social curriculum."

The government said it realised the best nurseries and playschools allowed a mixture of play and lessons.

An education department spokesman said: "Songs and rhymes can be used to assist learning - we don't see any hard and fast division or separation between learning and play.

"Early Years centres which have demonstrated good practice have shown the ability seamlessly to deliver learning alongside play."

fields.headline: 'Blinding neglect' of care
fields.trailText: Police and social services were incompetent and negligent when they allowed an eight-year-old girl to return home to her death, a jury at the Old Bailey in London was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Police and social services were incompetent and negligent when they allowed an eight-year-old girl to return home to her death, a jury at the Old Bailey in London was told yesterday.

The jury heard that three London boroughs knew of the plight of Anna Climbie, who died from hypothermia and neglect after allegedly being trussed up in a bath and made to eat like a dog - but they failed to act.

"Police and social services, those people exhibited a truly blinding degree of incompetence," said Nigel Rumfitt, QC, defending.

The court was hearing the summing up in the case of Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and her former boyfriend Carl Manning, 28, who are accused of murdering Anna in February of last year. Kouao denies all charges whilst Manning has admitted manslaughter and child cruelty.

Linda Stern, prosecuting, told the jury that a police officer and a social worker were responsible for Anna being returned to Manning's flat in Tottenham, north London, where she eventually died of neglect and hypothermia.

A Home Office pathologist had described Anna's case as the worst case of child abuse he had encountered and the jury was reminded that the child had suffered months of neglect, was critically undernourished, had been bound up, and had been exposed to wet as well as cold resulting in progressive hypothermia.

Mrs Stern told the jury that child protection officer Karen Jones had been "incompetent in her handling of the case" along with social worker Lisa Arthur-Worry, and both had been heavily criticised for their lack of care in the case.

Michael Gledhill, defending Kouao, criticised London councils for refusing to help a woman and small child because they were deemed to be intentionally homeless after moving to London from France.

The court was told Kouao brought Anna from the Ivory Coast to London via France for what the child believed was a better education and life.

"Anna left the sunshine of the Ivory Coast and went to France with Marie Therese Kouao. She left a loving family as a healthy, happy little girl... Just under a year later she was dead," said Mrs Stern, who added that Kouao was a cunning, manipulative liar.

Mr Rumfitt described Manning as "a bit of a nerd". He went on: "What transformed a harmless nerd like that into a man who causes Anna to die? We say that Marie Therese Koauo is a devious, dishonest, manipulative woman."

The case continues.

fields.headline: Costly drugs case collapses
fields.standfirst: Taxpayer faces £1.5m bill as retrial is ordered
fields.trailText: Taxpayer faces £1.5m bill as retrial is ordered.
fields.body:
The taxpayer faces a bill of up to £1.5m over the collapse of a complex and costly high court case brought by the Office of Fair Trading to open up over-the-counter medicines to price competition.

The debacle is reminiscent of the Pinochet case, which had to be expensively reheard by the House of Lords after it emerged that one of the original panel of law lords, Lord Hoffmann, had close links with Amnesty International, a party to the case.

The medicines case was halted in November, six weeks into a trial in the restrictive practices court, after one of two lay members hearing the case with a high court judge disclosed that a month after the trial started she had applied for a job with one of two rival economic consultancies whose evidence on behalf of the two opposing sides will be crucial to the outcome.

Penelope Rowlatt, an economist hearing the case with Mr Justice Lightman and an accountant, James Scott, sounded out Frontier Economics about a job. A Frontier director is an important witness for the OFT on the key issue in the case - the effect on small pharmacies of abolishing the exemption for over the counter (OTC) medicines from the ban on resale price maintenance.

The OFT wants to lift a 30-year-old court ruling which allows suppliers of non-prescription medicines to set a minimum price for 2000 branded drugs, including such household names as Nurofen and Lemsip.

The OFT's opponents, the Proprietary Association of Great Britain and the Proprietary Articles Trade Association, representing independent pharmacists and makers of OTC medicines, asked Dr Rowlatt to stand down. She refused, but offered not to take up a job with Frontier for at least two years after the case finished.

The trade associations argued that the whole panel should stand down, because the other members would have discussed the case with Dr Rowlatt. But after she produced a letter from Frontier saying it had no vacancies, Mr Justice Lightman ruledthe case could continue before the existing panel.

The manufacturers and pharmacists went to the court of appeal, which held in November that the whole panel must stand down and the case must start again.

The appeal court gave the reasons for its decision just before the courts adjourned for Christmas. They concluded that the parties would not have had a fair trial, as guaranteed by the Human Rights Act, had the case continued with the existing panel. The Master of the Rolls, Lord Phillips, said: "We reached our decision with great regret. Its consequence is that an immense amount of industry will have gone for nothing."

But a fair-minded observer "would have concluded that there was a real danger that Dr Rowlatt would be unable to make an objective and impartial appraisal of the expert evidence placed before the court by Frontier". She would have discussed the economic issues with the other two panel members. Therefore, all three had to stand down.

Lord Phillips said the documentation was "quite enormous". There were nearly 170 bundles of documents and 70 witnesses.

The OFT, which had four barristers, two solicitors and three paralegals working on the case, said its costs to date totalled £2m, and the extra costs of a rehearing were estimated at £600,000. Its leading QC has other commitments and a new QC will have to be found.

Costs for the pharmacists' and manufacturers' associations, represented by five barristers and a team of solicitors, are certain to be higher. They are applying for their wasted costs to be paid by the Lord Chancellor's department, which sometimes makes ex gratia payments in cases where a judge's error incurs extra costs.

There were nearly 170 bundles of documents and 70 witnesses. The OFT, which had four barristers, two solicitors and three paralegals working on the case, said its costs to date totalled £2m, and the extra costs of a rehearing were estimated at £600,000. Its leading QC has other commitments and a new QC will have to be found. Costs for the pharmacists' and manufacturers' associations, represented by five barristers and a team of solicitors, are certain to be higher. They are applying for their wasted costs to be paid by the Lord Chancellor's department, which sometimes makes ex gratia payments in cases where a judge's error incurs extra costs.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
A photograph accompanying an article on John Cooper, the recently deceased British racing car designer, page 12, Sport, January 1, was not of Cooper, as was stated in the caption, but of another designer, Ron Tauranac. The error came with the picture, from a photographic agency.

In a report, 1,000 homes plan for dome site, page 4, December 29, we said that Greenwich council was thought to have been offered £125m for the site. In fact, Greenwich council does not own the site, and has not therefore been offered anything for it.

There was an apparent discrepancy in our reports about one of the cases of George Carman QC. On page 7, yesterday, we said that a video of a party at which Gillian Taylforth proclaimed, "I give good head", showed her wielding a bottle. In Mr Carman's obituary notice, page 20 of the same issue, we said she was brandishing a sausage. In fact, both figured in the video produced in court by Mr Carman.

The recipes for a long, lazy lunch to revive the spirits after the holiday festivities, pages 32 and 33, Weekend, December 30, were all for 20 people rather than the six we said they served. Apologies to readers who already have an excess of lamb korma on their hands.

In a column discussing the National Secular Society's view of the Christmas story, page 15, Comment, December 22, we gave an address from which the society's booklet, Our Pagan Christmas, could be obtained. We might have given the address of the NSS web site: www.secularism.org.uk where the booklet may be read without payment.

Apologies to readers perplexed by incompatible solutions to two clues in our quick crossword yesterday. 3 Down was Extreme. This required the solution of 13 across (an anagram of Hire IRA band) to be, impossibly, hare-brained, not hair-brained.

fields.headline: Gallery launching on favourable tide
fields.standfirst: Lonely hearts woman conned me out of £260,000
fields.trailText: Lonely hearts woman conned me out of £260,000.
fields.body:
Arts marketers planning the reopening of a regional gallery are considering revising upwards estimates of visitor numbers following the British public's new passion for gallery-going.

Manchester City Art Gallery, a neo-classical culture palace famous for its collection of pre-Raphaelite paintings, closed in 1998 and will reopen next year after a £25m extension and refurbishment scheme.

Its marketing team has carried out research into how to offer a welcome to new audiences, especially families, and had planned to attract between 300,000 and 500,000 visitors by 2005.

"But we have watched the huge interest in Tate Modern, the new gallery in Walsall and the Lowry in Salford, and decided we may have to rethink our projections," said Kate Farmery, head of marketing and business development.

"It could be that instead of a steady growth of visitors over three years we will be inundated from day one. We are watching the other galleries to see how they retain in years two and three the numbers they have had in year one."

Almost 4m people have visited Tate Modern since it opened in May, though the gallery expected a maximum of 3.5m visitors in its first year.

First year attendance figures at the £21m Walsall gallery are likely to top 250,000, way above expectations; the Lowry, with two theatres as well as galleries dedicated to the artist after whom it is named, was almost swamped by 70,000 visitors in its first week. In eight months, it is close to the 770,000 target set for its first year.

"It is fantastic that people now seem to want to rush off to galleries," added Ms Farmery. "There is a huge surge of interest, particularly in contemporary art. There has not been a better time to work in galleries since the mid-nineteenth century, when galleries such as ours were established."

But Manchester knows it cannot rely only on perceptions of the national mood. A survey taken in the year leading up to the gallery's closure showed the annual visitor to tal was 250,000. But closer inspection showed that the figure was dominated by a loyal core of 30,000 art lovers who came several times a year.

"We have found that there are 450,000 people within half an hour's travelling time of here who say they go to galleries," said Ms Farmery. "But a hell of a lot of them were not coming to our gallery.

"We were held in some degree of affection but people would not get round to visiting us, although they found time to go shopping. The research also showed some negative opinions. The building was designed to be impressive, to show that art could flourish in a Victorian city known for cloth caps, whippets and industry.

"But many people found the building daunting and some who walked past did not even realise it was a gallery.

"We now have to convince them that we are a viable visitor attraction that can rival the Trafford Centre [the shopping mall on the banks of the Manchester ship canal]."

One draw will be curiosity about a new project in the heart of the city. The original 1828 building will be linked to the later Athenaeum next door, with the two joined by a new stone extension housing an education suite and galleries suitable for blockbuster exhibitions.

As well as wooing families, the marketing team will seek to attract the over-50s and tourists.

"Until now, only a few of our visitors were tourists," said Ms Farmery.

"Manchester is renowned for its shopping, nightlife and sport. But we have not been able to reinvent the city as a cultural centre as Glasgow and Barcelona have done.

"Now we are working on cultural breaks here - and a world-class gallery will be a big attraction."

Manchester has poached an audience development officer from Walsall. Staff have also been converted by the commitment to inclusiveness of Walsall's director, Peter Jenkinson.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText:
•As Mr Tony Blair would agree, we live in a cynical age characterised by those he and I call "the sneerers". Ask them what is fresh and delightful about our political scene and they will moan about the tired posturing of two power-hungry but ideologically vacuous dinosaurs scrapping over the decomposing bones of Thatcherism.

Well, let them sneer. We believe there is something novel and delicious about politics, and it is this: the dramatic re- inventions to be found among the ruling elite. Politicians always reposition themselves for reasons pure and impure, but never has such a chunk of the government and its apparat performed so many spectacular volte-face for no other discernible reason than the acquisition and retention of power.

It is out of awe for this elasticity, and the genuine desire to honour our flexible friends, that we are holding the Turncoat of Turncoats contest. Today, we introduce the first five contestants, with odds supplied by Diary pundit Steptoe.

As Mr Tony Blair would agree, we live in a cynical age characterised by those he and I call "the sneerers". Ask them what is fresh and delightful about our political scene and they will moan about the tired posturing of two power-hungry but ideologically vacuous dinosaurs scrapping over the decomposing bones of Thatcherism.

Well, let them sneer. We believe there is something novel and delicious about politics, and it is this: the dramatic re- inventions to be found among the ruling elite. Politicians always reposition themselves for reasons pure and impure, but never has such a chunk of the government and its apparat performed so many spectacular volte-face for no other discernible reason than the acquisition and retention of power.

It is out of awe for this elasticity, and the genuine desire to honour our flexible friends, that we are holding the Turncoat of Turncoats contest. Today, we introduce the first five contestants, with odds supplied by Diary pundit Steptoe.

Clare Short: the about-turn of this 100-30 co-favourite has been one of bewildering elegance. A leading leftwing firebrand in the 80s, in 1990 Bomber quit the frontbench over Neil Kinnock's supportive Gulf war stand. A decade later, she was attacking opponents of bombing Belgrade as Milosevic apologists. Her slavish rhetoric in favour of policies indis- tinguishable from those which once had her quitting in disgust has secured her Mr Tony's admiration (in leaked cabinet minutes she was even shown backing the freeze on spending!), but will it secure her a Diary Turncoat? We shall see.

Alan Milburn: this 18-1 chance would be shorter priced were he less dull. Once, when a CND supporting Trot in Newcastle, Alan was an official of the Trade Union Information Studies Unit advocating militant workers' opposition to shipyard closures. In 1999, he went to Congress House to tell the TUC about "modernising the public services" in a speech promising "zero tolerance of failure with sanctions for the worst performers but rewards for the best". Tremendous. And let's not forget his compelling analysis of the NHS as a glass that is "half full, not half empty". Will his ballot box be half full of Turncoat votes?

Chris Mullin: the likable 66-1 long shot, onetime editor of Tribune, is included more out of sorrow than anger. Simply put, this once-committed socialist and keen supporter of Tony Benn for deputy leader has allowed himself to be put in charge of privatising the airways, presumably on the principle that if you want to pull off an act of demented rightwing thuggery, get an old leftie to front it up. Chris, Chris, what are you thinking of?

Paul Boateng: at 14-1, Paul represents useful each-way value. A leftwing lawyer and radical rebel in his GLC days, and a fervent Livingstone loyalist, last year Paul attacked his former hero with that special viciousness born of cabinet fever. How long ago it seems that the man who now calls himself "deputy home secretary" enlivened his acceptance speech on becoming MP for Brent South with the words: "Brent today, Soweto tomorrow." In fact, it's only 13 years. Paul's a bit of a dandy, of course, and he'd look swell in a Diary turncoat. But will you give him one?

Margaret Hodge: the Barking MP may be a 25-1 shot, but let's not rule out "Enver" Hodge just yet. This erstwhile rabid Bennite's innovations while chairing Islington council from 1982-92 included providing self-defence courses for lesbians and setting a leaf-fall allowance for street sweepers in autumn. By 1994 she was sending her child to school outside her local authority area, and a year later supported scrapping of clause 4. Suddenly 25-1 looks tempting, does it not? More tomorrow, including the other 100-30 co-favourites, Peter Hain and Gus Macdonald.
