fields.headline: Hanging on to nanny
fields.trailText: Why were nannies left out of the registration requirements of the 1989 Children Act (Mary Poppins - or the minder from hell? Parents, January 3)?
fields.body:
Why were nannies left out of the registration requirements of the 1989 Children Act (Mary Poppins - or the minder from hell? Parents, January 3)? Those of us from childcare organisations involved in consultations on the drafting of the white paper tried to raise this. We were told firmly that such discussion was inappropriate. Some of the civil servants and ministers involved employed nannies. Funny, that.
Jean Brown
Huddersfield

Mr Heseltine wants to know why British citizens should go without houses to make way for illegal immigrants (New asylum row erupts, January 1). Good question if he can answer why native north Americans should have had their lands stolen by violence and force by his land-hungry forbears from these islands.
L Arthur Myers
Braintree, Essex

If Fidel Castro is a despot (The despots who won't day die, G2 January 3), all we can say is that his victims are in perfect health. Perhaps that is what explains his continuing popularity.
Rob Miller
Cuba Solidarity Campaign

Your leader does not include science as a vital part of the "decent" British infrastructure. Is this an accidental omission, or a sign that the great and the good who should inform the country are victims of an outdated education system?
Dr Walter Kellermann

webTitle: Letter: Conflict over Israel's right to exist

fields.headline: Conflict over Israel's right to exist
fields.trailText: As if bringing Israelis and Palestinians together in some appreciation of each other's needs wasn't difficult enough, Faisal Bodi comes along to declare that Israel simply has no right to exist (Comment, January 3).
fields.body:
As if bringing Israelis and Palestinians together in some appreciation of each other's needs wasn't difficult enough, Faisal Bodi comes along to declare that Israel simply has no right to exist (Comment, January 3). Israel has as much right to exist as do other nations and Jews have as much right to self-determination as do other peoples. Mankind has always formed itself into nations. Another way of organising ourselves might have developed, but for the time being that's the way it is.

Since September 29 Israel has acted abominably: starting with killing stone-throwers (a disastrous method of controlling protests, leading to the continuing cycle of violence); going on to blockading Palestinian towns and villages, demolishing homes and destroying agriculture; and now political assassination. Israel's actions are astoundingly short-sighted for a country that wants to live in peace with its neighbours.

Just as a viable Palestinian state will be on the map, Israel will not disappear. A one-state solution is a non-starter in current global conditions. Who knows what the future holds vis-à-vis nation states?
Vivien Lichtenstein
British Friends of Peace Now

I commend your courage in publishing Faisal Bodi's excellent piece. As head of the Community Association of Britain, I can affirm that he eloquently articulates what all Palestinians feel: that Israel was iniquitously established in our land and at our expense to assuage a history of Jewish persecution not of our making. It is Israel's denial of that central fact and its evasion of moral responsibility that will make any durable peace impossible.

A study on reconciliation I undertook last year in Israel confirmed the depth of this denial, except amongst a few. Those who want to help resolve this conflict would do well to encourage the growth of this community of Israelis and others with the moral courage to acknowledge Israel's primary guilt towards the Palestinians.
Dr Ghada Karmi
London ghada_karmi@hotmail.com

Mr Bodi's article breaks a taboo which has existed unfairly for far too long. I have relatives in South Africa who suffered under apartheid. They also oppose apartheid in Israel against Palestinians and would argue that Israel has no right to exist as it does, in the same way that apartheid South Africa did not deserve to exist. Like apartheid, Israel has no rights morally or legally to force other people to recognise a state based on the dispossession of the Palestinian people, whose land it occupies.

I share their views. But whereas I'm applauded if I speak out against apartheid, I'm labelled a racist and anti-semitic if I speak out against Israel, like Mr Bodi. This is unacceptable in a free society. It is high time that we had a debate about Zionism and questioned the reality of Israel. I'm glad that the Guardian has taken the first step towards this.
Bilal Patel
London bilal_uk@hotmail.com

Faisal Bodi makes a retrograde case that precludes the possibility of political negotiations without which the Palestinians and Israel almost certainly face a future of perpetual war. Bodi claims that the existence of Israel "stands as the realisation of a biblical statement" resting upon a proclamation by God. This, he claims, is no moral basis upon which to found a state. States, however, have neither moral nor even divine foundations, but violent ones. They draw upon myths and narratives of nationhood, both religious and secular, in order to legitimise the acts of violence inherent in the establishment of territorial borders, and the inclusions and exclusions from hegemonic political communities that such acts incur.

The PLO finally gave up on the fantasy that Israel did not have a right to exist by recognising the state for a good pragmatic reason. Regardless of whether or not subsequent opportunities were fully exploited by the PLO leadership, the Palestinians could not have established the foundations for negotiation without such an act of recognition.

In citing South Africa as a model, Bodi forgets that in the absence of such negotiations the Truth and Reconciliation Commission would never have materialised in the wake of formal recognition of past injustices. The opportunity for the inclusion of forgiveness rather than retribution and revenge was made possible by the long and arduous process of negotiation.

Without Palestinian recognition of the existence of the state, it is difficult to see how any "genuine peace formula" which includes Israeli "self-reproach" might be possible.
Claire Moon
University of Bristol claire.moon@bristol.ac.uk

What right has any country to exist? I was born in Wallsend which is now part of the UK. Before that it was part of England, before that Northumbria. Most African countries' borders were decided by European colonisers in the last two centuries. Does that mean these have no right to exist?
Michael Kenyon
Nottingham

No state has such a right, otherwise the USSR, East Germany and Czechoslovakia would still be with us. The Israeli people do have a right to exist, which they should guarantee by recognising the equal right of the Palestinians. As for me, I look forward to the end of the existence of the British state.
Gerard Killoran
London gkilloran@yahoo.com

fields.headline: Reform bill
fields.trailText: All the proposals Robert Hazell makes for reform at Westminster in response to the imbalances of devolution are sensible and practical (Shrinking Westminster, January 3).
fields.body:
All the proposals Robert Hazell makes for reform at Westminster in response to the imbalances of devolution are sensible and practical (Shrinking Westminster, January 3). But the ultimate test of whether the new arrangements are acceptable to English voters is to be found in the chamber itself. Should a government be returned that is dependent on non-English MPs for its majority, then the pace of reform at Westminster will need to be much more fundamental than has been the case to date.

A less dramatic scenario could occur in this parliament. Of the 16 Bills announced in the Queen's Speech, only five were related to all of the UK. Yet all MPs are entitled to vote on all 16 bills.
Frank Field MP

webTitle: How to get under the skin

fields.headline: How to get under the skin
fields.standfirst: Jim Giles on the see-through approach to medical imaging
fields.trailText: Jim Giles on the see-through approach to medical imaging
fields.body:
Imagine being able to see through your skin into the wet and messy complexity of your body. Most people prefer to keep their insides nicely hidden away, but Ashley Welch wants to do just the opposite. The professor of biomedical engineering from the University of Texas is developing a way which could turn our skin into a window into our bodies. And yes, the treatment is reversible.

Welch says that our skin stops us from seeing into our bodies in just the same way that fog can obscure objects. Shine a torch into fog and the light is scattered by the fog, creating a halo of light around the beam rather than illuminating the object. Skin does much the same thing. Strong light can pass through skin - try shining a torch on your hand - but the light is scattered, destroying the image of structures beneath the skin.

If the light wasn't scattered, a whole range of conditions could become easier to diagnose and treat. Tumours below the skin are one example. These can be attacked using pulses of laser light, but skin obscures the tumour and absorbs some of the light, limiting the effectiveness of the treatment. Make the skin see-through and better treatments could follow.

The technique could also help those foolish enough to get a tattoo they might later regret - like a girlfriend's name misspelt in Hindi, for example. The tattoo would still remain visible as the skin became transparent, making it easier to target a laser onto a tattoo and destroy it.

Welch started working with samples of skin from rodents. Injecting the samples with glycerol, a substance usually used in cosmetics, changed the skin so much that a black and white pattern placed behind it was clearly visible. And when the researchers injected glycerol into living skin, they could see blood vessels beneath the skin that were normally hidden. Twenty minutes later the skin returned to normal.

Glycerol works in two different ways. Firstly, it brings the different components of skin tissue closer together.

As glycerol enters skin cells, some of the water that is normally found in the cells is forced out. But because the glycerol enters the cells slower than the water leaves them, the cells shrink. If lots of cells shrink, the tissue itself will do too. This shrinking reduces the amount of light scattering, making it more transparent.

One reason why skin is not normally transparent is that the different substances that make up skin interact with light in different ways. Different parts of the tissue bend the light by different amounts. When light travels through transparent substances like glass it still gets bent, but all part of the glass bend the light by the same amount.

Glycerol makes skin more like glass. Because glycerol interacts with light in a similar way to some of the components of skin like collagen, it reduces the amount by which the skin scatters the light. Put these two effects together and skin can become a window onto our bodies.

The University of Texas team is pressing ahead with further research. The next challenge is to find a substance that can be used safely in human trials, which they hope to begin in the next two years. If all goes well, skin tumours and other problems could one day be treated via a specially built window in our skin.

fields.headline: How the Grinch stole America
fields.standfirst:
(A verse for the inauguration, with apologies to Dr Seuss)

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: (A verse for the inauguration, with apologies to Dr Seuss)
fields.body:
Every Vote down in Voteville liked Voting a Lot,
But the GRINCH, who lived West of Voteville,
     did Not.

For Voting was Counting - not just Adding and such
But finding out if you Amounted to Much.
In this case, the question was, who, in a pinch,
Amounted to More? Did the Veep? Or the Grinch?

The Veep! What a creep!
What a CREEP! CREEP! CREEP! CREEP!
He simply could NOT be outdone by the Veep.

But the Veep was Experienced.
He'd done the big jobs,
He was smart. (He was smart-ass.)
He knew all the knobs
And the levers and buttons
that worked the State's Ship
And the Grinch?
Well, re: knowledge he was not too hip.
The President of India? The economy? Pass.
He'd never been close to the head of the class.

So far the poor Grinch hadn't Amounted to zip,
He just hadn't Counted. It gave him the pip.
     (His father! His eminent Dad! His own blood!
Compared to him, Grinchy had proved quite a dud.)

And now that he'd actually reached his Big Day
Argh! Counting the Ballots could steal it away!

And what was a Ballot? Was it silver or gold?
Were they counting up treasure? A fortune untold?
No! Just some dumb punch-card!
     They were counting up holes!
Oh, the holes! Yes, the holes!
Oh, the HOLES! HOLES! HOLES! HOLES!
The whole thing depended on Circles of Air -
Not to mention the half-holes,
     and holes that weren't there,
          But that wanted to be there,
               and thought that was fair.

All they would do was to add up! To Count!
And they'd count! And they'd count!
And they'd COUNT! COUNT! COUNT! COUNT!
And they'd probably end up with a Quite Wrong Amount!
"If they go on counting,"
          the Grinch shuddered, "Eep!"
"They may just wind up electing the Veep!"

"How to stop it?" the Grinch exclaimed with a moan
And then he remembered he wasn't alone.
There were Grinches all over,
big Grinches and small,
There were Grinches in Voteville
and in City Hall,
He knew some news-Grinches,
and he could depend
On these inky fellows to shape and to bend
Their stories to help him win through in the end.

But the Grinches who'd give him
the edge and the win
Were the great Legal Grinches,
and Grinches of Spin.

So he called on his cohorts.
"My friends, we must Grinch
This election! 'Nuff Counting!
Get to work! Do not flinch!
We must Grinch! We must Grinch!
We must GRINCH! GRINCH! GRINCH! GRINCH!
We cannot be beaten by circles of air
Or circles that only imagine they're there.
Every day that they Count them, the total will creep
Up and up, until it elects that old Veep!"

So they Grinched the election.
They Grinched, day by day,
Until all the options were whittled away.
They Grinched it with lawyers,
they Grinched it with writs,
They split all the hairs
and they picked all the nits,
And when it came up to the Ultimate Bench
They Grinched it away with one final Wrench.
They ordered all Voteville to give up its Count,
Before it came up with that Quite Wrong Amount.

And the Votes down in Voteville?
They've run out of steam.
'Tis the season to party, to heal and to dream.
Why worry? The Constitution is strong,
The judges who judge it can never be wrong,
The Veep may have won, but he's lost.
And that's that.
Voteville accepts the high judges' fiat.
There isn't a holler, there isn't a scream,
Think of the dollar! Let's play for the team!
So everyone okays the Grinch's régime,
And things are probably
     probably
          probably
               probably
                    probably
Not as bad as they seem.

"Four whole years of Grinchdom!"
     the Grinch cries with glee
"There's Only One Person who Counts now
     ...That's
          ME."

 Salman Rushdie writes monthly in the Guardian

fields.headline: Syrian president's British bride
fields.standfirst: All for love
fields.trailText: A British-born computer science graduate has married the president of Syria in a secret New Year's Day ceremony in Damascus.
fields.body:
A British-born computer science graduate has married the president of Syria in a secret New Year's Day ceremony in Damascus.

Asma Akhras, 25, who is from a wealthy and prominent London Syrian family, has left her job as an economist with the City bank JP Morgan and her family home in Acton, west London, to link her fortunes with Syria's youthful leader, Bashar al-Assad.

Al-Assad, 35, who succeeded to the presidency on his father's death last June, trained as an eye specialist in London and is thought to have met his bride at a party hosted by the British Syrian community.

Miss Akhras, whose father Fawaz is a heart specialist with a Harley Street practice, is from the Sunni Muslim tradition while the president is a member of the minority Alawite tradition.

Abdel Bari-Atwan, editor of London-based Arab newspa per Al-Quds, said: "It is a sort of reconciliation between the two traditions. He is presenting himself not as a sectarian leader but a leader for the whole of Syria.

"If they have a son, he will be from both sects, so this is highly significant."

Al-Assad, who is reputed to be mild-mannered and bookish, was thrust into the political limelight six years ago when his older and more charismatic brother, Basil, who was being readied for the succession, was killed in a car crash.

He was recalled from his studies in London and sent to a military academy, rising to become a colonel.

He is said to have met the bride's father while he was studying at the Western Eye hospital in London.

Miss Akhras's mother Sahar worked for the Syrian embassy, and she has two younger brothers.

Al-Assad's only official title before the presidency was head of Syria's computer society, a position he used to promote nationwide computer literacy.

He pushed for the introduction of the internet, which the regime had strenuously resisted as a "threat to security".

Al-Assad is of a generation of western-educated new leaders, and has befriended Jordan's Sandhurst-educated King Abdullah, who succeeded King Hussein in 1999.

Ranjeev Raman, a former lecturer of Miss Akhras at King's College, London, described her as outgoing.

"She was certainly very bright and very outgoing. She certainly seemed very Westernised and not in the least bit traditional."

Miss Akhras' family is understood to have flown out to Syria on Christmas Eve. But even members of the British Syrian community who were in Syria for the holiday period had no idea the wedding was going on.

Miss Akhras' father has been a prominent member of the Kensington-based Syrian Arab Association since it was founded in 1984.

One member said: "Most of the Syrian community know Dr Akhras well. He and his family are well respected."

The wedding was attended only by family and marked with the briefest of notices in the government newspaper.

This was accompanied by a large photograph of the president, but none of the bride, and the Syrian government has refused to release a picture of her.

One reason for this was that the president was concerned about public reaction to a lavish and high-profile ceremony, observers said.

Mr al-Atwan said: "The main reason is that his father has just died and there is still a state of mourning. Also, his mother has never been in the public eye. They have been a secluded family.

"They don't want to behave like a monarchy because they have been accused of turning a republic into a monarchy, and a big marriage would seem like a royal wedding."

The Syrian government said that Miss Akhras held citizenship in their country.

He was recalled from his studies in London and sent to a military academy, rising to become a colonel. He is said to have met the bride's father while he was studying at the Western Eye hospital in London. Miss Akhras's mother Sahar worked for the Syrian embassy, and she has two younger brothers. Al-Assad's only official title before the presidency was head of Syria's computer society, a position he used to promote nationwide computer literacy. He pushed for the introduction of the internet, which the regime had strenuously resisted as a "threat to security". Al-Assad is of a generation of western-educated new leaders, and has befriended Jordan's Sandhurst-educated King Abdullah, who succeeded King Hussein in 1999. Ranjeev Raman, a former lecturer of Miss Akhras at King's College, London, described her as outgoing. "She was certainly very bright and very outgoing. She certainly seemed very Westernised and not in the least bit traditional." Miss Akhras' family is understood to have flown out to Syria on Christmas Eve. But even members of the British Syrian community who were in Syria for the holiday period had no idea the wedding was going on. Miss Akhras' father has been a prominent member of the Kensington-based Syrian Arab Association since it was founded in 1984. One member said: "Most of the Syrian community know Dr Akhras well. He and his family are well respected." The wedding was attended only by family and marked with the briefest of notices in the government newspaper. This was accompanied by a large photograph of the president, but none of the bride, and the Syrian government has refused to release a picture of her. One reason for this was that the president was concerned about public reaction to a lavish and high-profile ceremony, observers said. Mr al-Atwan said: "The main reason is that his father has just died and there is still a state of mourning. Also, his mother has never been in the public eye. They have been a secluded family. "They don't want to behave like a monarchy because they have been accused of turning a republic into a monarchy, and a big marriage would seem like a royal wedding." The Syrian government said that Miss Akhras held citizenship in their country.

fields.headline: Greenspan rallies markets
fields.standfirst: Federal Reserve's move could reverse fall of pound against euro, say analysts
fields.trailText: US financial markets surged ahead last night after the Federal Reserve came to their rescue by announcing a surprise interest rate cut to boost flagging confidence in the world's biggest economy.
fields.body:
US financial markets surged ahead last night after the Federal Reserve came to their rescue by announcing a surprise interest rate cut to boost flagging confidence in the world's biggest economy.

With share dealers calculating that cheaper borrowing costs would improve the outlook for company profitability, the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average closed up 299 points at 10,945 - a gain of almost 3% - and the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index jumped 14%, or 324 points, to 2616.

The Fed's move also arrested the dollar's sharp slide against the euro, which fell back below 93 cents after climbing to a six-month high of more than 95 cents earlier in the day.

News of the move came too late to affect the British markets, but analysts expect it to prompt a sharp rally when London opens for business this morning.

Despite a denial earlier in the day by Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the Bank of England, that UK rates would automatically follow US rates downwards, economists predicted that British business and consumers would soon be enjoying cheaper credit.

Economists have warned that Britain is likely to suffer more from a US slowdown than other European economies because of closer investment and trade links.

Traders had dumped sterling yesterday, betting that the euro was a safer haven in the event of a US slowdown, and sending the pound to a six-month low against the euro.

Wariness about the impact of the American slowdown on corporate profitability did take its toll on the stock market, however, with the FTSE 100 closing down 134.8 points at 6039.9 before news of the Fed's shock action emerged.

Sterling's value at yesterday's low point of 63.57p to the euro translates to less than 3.10 German marks, compared to last year's peak of DM3.45, providing a welcome boost for exporters to the euro zone. However analysts said the US rate cut could reverse the fall.

Earlier in the day Kate Barker, of the Confederation of British Industry, welcomed sterling's fall against the euro, but she said: "I still think it's going to be difficult for exporters, but for different reasons."

While a stronger euro would boost profitability among exporters, sterling's rise against the dollar and US-led slowdown would hamper export growth elsewhere. "The case for an interest rate cut is growing," said Ms Barker.

In a hawkish interview with Reuters, Mr King warned there were still inflationary risks in the economy.

"Clearly a marked slowdown in the US would affect world activity, it would reduce UK exports, it would in turn lead to lower activity here and lower inflationary pressure. But there are risks on the other side too." He added: "We don't see many signs yet of a slowdown in consumer demand which would be necessary to meet the inflation target."

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee meets next week and although a UK rate cut is not expected, the US move is likely to strengthen the hand of those advocating a rate cut at the end of last year.

In the wake of the US cut Roger Bootle, of Capital Economics, predicted the cost of UK borrowing would be down to 5% by the end of 2001.

webTitle: Notebook: Greenspan sticks his neck out

fields.headline: Greenspan sticks his neck out
fields.standfirst: Fed's cut is a stunner
fields.trailText: One thing the Federal Reserve can congratulate itself on. Yesterday's 50 basis point cut in rates certainly took the markets by surprise. But while Wall Street's pundits were scratching their heads at the timing of the move equity markets were euphoric.
fields.body:
One thing the Federal Reserve can congratulate itself on. Yesterday's 50 basis point cut in rates certainly took the markets by surprise. But while Wall Street's pundits were scratching their heads at the timing of the move equity markets were euphoric.

That said, however, the suddenness and aggressiveness with which the Fed has acted poses the question as to whether the US central bank is trying to get ahead of the game or whether it has hit the panic button.

The temptation is to give the Fed the benefit of the doubt. After all it is the decision to cut rates now rather than wait until the end of the month that is the shock. Most analysts had expected a rate cut at the next scheduled open market committee. Some had even anticipated a cut ahead of the meeting, but on the back of tomorrow's unemployment numbers, not ahead of them.

The Fed's explanation was standard stuff. Inflation "remains contained" while falling consumer confidence is being reflected in weakening sales and production numbers. In other words the economic balance of risk is tipped more towards economic weakness rather than pressure on the prices front.

Behind such bland conventionalities, however, are some grim realities. Tuesday's report from the National Association of Purchasing Managers showed how difficult life is becoming for US manufacturers. That was underpinned by yesterday's figures from Ford and General Motors which showed their US vehicle sales had fallen sharply last month. For Fed chairman Alan Greenspan, always inclined to look towards the real economy, the figures will have made uncomfortable reading.

And although the Fed, rather glibly, argues that long-term advances in technology and productivity gains show no signs of abating, investors were taking a rather different view. Nasdaq, the bellwether of sentiment towards America's hi-tech sector, was not simply looking shell shocked ahead of yesterday's rate cut, it was looking bombed out.

The key point, however, is that nothing the Fed said adequately explains the timing of the rate cut. The "why" yes; but not the "when". There are plenty of analysts who believe the Fed should have acted in December. So why, if there was no reason to cut last month and with an open market committee meeting schedule for the end of this month, should the Fed choose to act between meetings in a manner that can only weaken its own policy making framework? What value in a set calender of meetings when interest rates can be changed any time?

It is possible that the Fed believes the impact of tomorrow's employment numbers on the financial markets - recent gloom about the US economic outlook has hit the dollar as well as equities - could be destabilising. Or even that the figures themselves are so bad that pre-emptive action was required. The latter is hard to accept. Until very recently jobless data was being scanned for signs of overtightness. A nasty surprise from the markets rather than the economy looks favourite.

Either way there are bound to be questions about the sureness of the Fed's touch. Mr Greenspan's credibility should head off accusations of panic. For now.

Wrong track

The cry has gone out. Something must be done about Railtrack. The government is coming under pressure to take a more active role in ending the chaos that has made rail travel a matter of desperation rather than expectation.

The latest idea doing the rounds is that the government should take an equity stake in Railtrack. There are superficial attractions. Given the extent to which Railtrack's investment programme is being supported from the public purse, there is a case for the tax payer getting something tangible in return. John Prescott might be tempted, too, by the idea of more direct leverage.

The practicalities however look less attractive. There are mechanisms through which the government could acquire a stake - a Treasury underwritten rights issue, for example, or a straight issue of new railtrack shares to the government. The former, however, is less than precise and the second might have City lawyers muttering about pre-emption rights.

An equity stake would also put the government even more firmly in the firing line, yet would leave it short of overall control. Power without responsibility is one thing. Responsibility without power quite another.

If the rail chaos continues; if deadlines for recovery and improvements are missed the pressure for action is bound to increase. The onset of an election campaign will scarcely cool matters. Such pressures should be resisted, however. If Railtrack cannot function effectively in the private sector it should be taken back into public ownership. It should not be left stuck between the two.

webTitle: Fed prompts calls for UK cut

fields.headline: Fed prompts calls for UK cut
fields.standfirst: Industry demands help to avoid slide into recession, Mervyn King plays the hawk
fields.trailText: Industry demands help to avoid slide into recession, Mervyn King plays the hawk.
fields.body:
Pressure for Britain to follow the US lead and cut interest rates was mounting last night amid growing fears that the recessionary slide could spread across the Atlantic.

Industry leaders and trade unions were already calling for the Bank of England to cut rates from 6% before the US Federal Reserve's shock decision last night to cut American borrowing costs by half a percentage point.

Neil Parker, market strategist for the Royal Bank of Scot land, said: "This is only going to heighten expectations of interest rate cuts in the UK. I am sure the Bank of England's monetary policy committee will be surprised by this."

Yesterday, before the Fed's move, Mervyn King, the Bank's deputy governor, appeared to rule out following the US example when the Bank's key rate-setting committee meets next week.

Asked whether the MPC would feel under pressure to act in the wake of any rate cuts by the Fed, he said: "As such, no. What matters to us is the outlook for the British economy. We set interest rates for the UK, not the US."

Economists have warned that Britain is likely to suffer more from a US slowdown than other European economies because of closer investment and trade links.

Traders dumped sterling yesterday, betting that the euro was a safer haven in the event of a US slowdown, and sending the pound to a six-month low against the euro.

Wariness about the impact of the US slowdown on corporate profitability also took its toll on the stock market, with the FTSE 100 closing down 134.8 points at 6039.9 before news of the Fed's shock action emerged. The London stock market is likely to surge upwards this morning, taking its cue from Wall Street. There, the Dow Jones index jumped more than 300 points last night to trade close to the 11,000 level and the technology-laden Nasdaq composite rocketed more than 13%.

Sterling's value at yesterday's low point of 63.57p to the euro translates to less than 3.10 German marks, compared to last year's peak of DM3.45, providing a welcome boost for exporters to the euro zone.

Kate Barker, chief economic adviser at the Confederation of British Industry, said: "I still think it's going to be difficult for exporters, but for different reasons." Sterling's rise against the dollar and US-led slowdown in global growth would hamper export growth elsewhere. "The case for an interest rate cut is growing," said Ms Barker.

But in a hawkish interview with Reuters, Mr King warned there were still inflationary risks in the economy, particularly from consumer spending.

"Clearly a marked slowdown in the US would affect world activity, it would reduce UK exports, it would in turn lead to lower activity here and lower inflationary pressure.

"But there are risks on the other side too," he said. "We don't see many signs yet of a slowdown in consumer demand which would be necessary to meet the inflation target."

City analysts said the American move had been sparked by the rapid collapse in confidence about the economy and the markets' nervous start to the new year. Signs that the panic was spreading to Britain could force the UK authorities to follow suit.

webTitle: Mr Byers won't be the saviour of Fowler's Wee Heavy

fields.headline: Mr Byers won't be the saviour of Fowler's Wee Heavy
fields.standfirst: Bass takeover is scuppered
fields.trailText: Trade secretary Stephen Byers would like to cast himself as the saviour of the British pint, following his decision to prevent Belgium's Interbrew from snapping up a third of the country's beer industry.
fields.body:
Trade secretary Stephen Byers would like to cast himself as the saviour of the British pint, following his decision to prevent Belgium's Interbrew from snapping up a third of the country's beer industry.

Bodies such as the Independent Family Brewers of Britain feared Interbrew's purchase of Bass Brewers would lead to a day when "you could go into a pub and the only beer on tap would be Stella Artois".

Sadly it is doubtful whether Mr Byers' intervention will save Bass's traditional beers, such as Sweetheart Stout and Fowler's Wee Heavy.

Interbrew makes much of its aim to be "the world's local brewer". It is unlikely that rival buyers such as Anheuser Busch or South African Breweries would give a stuff about nurturing niche products.

They are devoted to the concept of global brands, showing little interest in anything smaller than a Budweiser or Carling.

An even worse outcome would be a purchase by a financial buyer such as Hicks, Muse or Alchemy Partners. Such venture capitalists will be tempted to buy the business at a knock-down price and strip out the assets.

To an impartial observer, the competition commission was right to quash the deal. The commission would be a waste of space if it turned a blind eye to two companies controlling more than 60% of Britain's beer.

But the decision leaves the country's brewers in a mess, because of the damage done earlier by a decade of misguided government action.

The beer orders in 1989 began the fiasco by limiting the number of pubs owned by each brewer. This was intended to break up the industry but merely led to the creation of huge, specialised pub retailers, such as Punch Taverns and Nomura, which prefer to buy in bulk from a handful of global brewers.

Since then, more than 40 British breweries have closed, costing 5,000 jobs, as drinkers have switched from ale to wines and spirits. Faced with this falling consumption, the big players tried to expand overseas. But Margaret Beckett prevented that by blocking Bass's attempt to buy Carlsberg-Tetley in 1997.

With little prospect of growth - and faced with some of the highest alcohol taxes in Europe - the likes of Whitbread and Bass have been scrambling to sell their breweries to the nearest foreign buyer. Interbrew should not be allowed to buy the lot, but the alternatives will scarcely be more palatable.

fields.headline: The yellow brick road leads to Leicester
fields.standfirst:
The Wizard of Oz
Haymarket Theatre, Leicester
****
fields.trailText:
The Wizard of Oz
Haymarket Theatre, Leicester
****
fields.body:
Little girls never change, they just have different dreams. Which modern pre-teen midwestern belle would not imagine that somewhere over the rainbow there must be a drive-in McDonald's, Campbell's soup cans and other branded detritus of the consumerist age?

Perhaps this is the final masterstroke of the marketeers in the never-ending quest for unbranded space: take out advertising in Oz and insert commercial breaks into people's dreams.

Director Paul Kerryson and set designer Patrick Connellan offer a new visualisation of Oz as a post-pop panoply of corporate Americana, which makes MGM's 1939 film seem sweetly uncorrupted.

The Cowardly Lion lives in a beat-up Pontiac in a forgotten parking lot. Tin Man is a soldered advertisement for various soft-drinks companies, rusted solid beside a vast, Warholian soup can. Even Scarecrow shares his field with a Jolly Green Giant. Perhaps the commercial department should have instigated an adopt-a-Munchkin scheme - certainly this winning little crowd would attract plenty of takers.

Munchkins are a problem on the modern stage. Do you enlist the services of a specialist agency at this most over-subscribed time of year? Or rope in a gaggle of starry eyed tots and risk crucial parts of a well-drilled production degenerating into a stage-school revue? Kerryson has opted for the latter but let it be said that Leicester's Munchkins are magnificent. Refusing to let the little people succeed on cuteness value alone, choreographer David Needham gives the miniature denizens of Munchkinland musical routines of wit and complexity to match any of the grown-up ensemble work.

These terrific tots are responsible for some of the slickest pieces of staging and among a remarkable troupe of diminutive dancers, Dharmesh Patel's winking and beaming confidence makes it quite clear why the rest of the Munchkins should have elected him their leader.

Few adult actors would fail to respond to the risk of being upstaged by the Mayor of Munchkinland and Kerryson has assembled a West End-quality cast with no weak link among them. Annalene Beechey is ideally sweet without becoming overly calorific as Dorothy. Simon Greiff, Tom Kanavan and Jon Clairmonte expertly steer the roles of Scarecrow, Tin Man and Lion away from their MGM stereotypes, while showcasing the imaginative twist common to all of Emma Donovan's fabulous costumes. Further proof from the Haymarket that this level of musical theatre can be sustained outside London.

Munchkin road maintenance teams have been spotted laying yellow bricks all the way along the M1.

* Until February 3. Box office: 0116-253 9797.

webTitle: It's time to clear those Christmas debts

fields.headline: It's time to clear those Christmas debts
fields.trailText: The festive season may be over, but January sales are in full swing and many people will be starting 2001 with big debts to sort out.
fields.body:
The festive season may be over, but January sales are in full swing and many people will be starting 2001 with big debts to sort out.

If you are guilty of over-spending, you wonÕt be alone. Many of us are tempted to buy those bargains, with plenty taking advantage of tempting storecard offers.

Christmas and the sales are not the only problems. Shopaholics who canÕt stop spending the whole year round now have a recognised problem and can count among their numbers Sir Elton John. He recently admitted heÕd spent over £40m in two years, with £293,000 on flowers alone.

The government is well aware of the UKÕs consumer debt problems. Last year, consumer affairs minister Kim Howells set up a taskforce to tackle the crisis and brought in a team of experts from banks, building societies and consumer associations. The taskforce is expected to report back in the spring. It will be looking at improving transparency and access to debt counselling.

Dr Howells has said he is concerned about the UKÕs increasingly easygoing attitude to debt. For example, consumer debt has grown by 60% over the past four years and is now running at around £159bn a year. There has also been a 37% increase in queries about debt at Citizens Advice Bureaux in the last two years.

Most students leave university owing thousands of pounds. Banks try and tempt their customers to take out loans they donÕt need and credit card companies are desperate for new high spending customers to sign up.

Dr Howells says: "Many consumers will be tempted to take out credit deals to buy expensive goods such as computers and furniture. But, often they donÕt fully understand the deals they sign up to. Some have an expensive sting in the tail. For instance, some consumers end up paying interest at 30% APR when they can't afford to make the final large payment on an interest free option deal."

If you have gone into the red, now is the time to draw up an action plan to get back into the black. These are the key areas to look at:

 Cut up storecards. Most charge far higher rates than credit cards.

 Switch the balance of your credit card to one that has a 0% transfer fee, such as Egg, or Cahoot, which offers a 5% cashback on a transferred balance.

 DonÕt ignore bills if you canÕt pay them. Putting in a call can often stall creditors until you have access to funds. Similarly, some credit cards have fines for late payments.

 If you have run up an unauthorised overdraft, contact your bank immediately. Such overdrafts can be prohibitively expensive and may be avoided if you speak to your branch.

 Think carefully before taking out a loan. If this is the only way to clear debts, then you are often better arranging this through your bank than a loan company.

 Beware of companies that promise to "restructure" your debts. You can end up paying off far more over a much longer period of time.

 Despite all the press surrounding ISAs and other investments, it is best to settle debts before putting money aside. Interest rates on debts are almost always far higher than anything you can make on savings.

But remember, even if the worst does happen, it is not the end of the world. A growing number of mortgage companies are looking to lend to those with credit problems, albeit at a higher cost. And, once you have sorted out past debts, it is possible to wipe the slate clean.

Sensible advice is supplied by the Office of Fair Trading where it is running a campaign, DonÕt let credit turn into debt. You can also call National Debtline on 0645 5005111.

webTitle: BT adds financial research to website armoury

fields.headline: BT adds financial research to website armoury
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: BT yesterday attempted to boost its standing as an internet service provider with a deal that will allow customers to research and buy financial products online.
fields.body:
BT yesterday attempted to boost its standing as an internet service provider with a deal that will allow customers to research and buy financial products online.

Independent financial adviser Inter-Alliance will offer its online services on BT's consumer websites.

From today the 800,000 customers of BTinternet will be able to research and buy from more than 3,000 funds from around 400 providers on the company's portal, though customers can only purchase 200 funds online; the remainder must be bought using downloaded forms.

Users of BT's broadband ser vices will also be able to access the new features on the btopenworld site.

Stuart McGreevy, chief executive of Inter-Alliance Group, said most investment companies were still unable to offer customers the facility to buy funds online.

"BT is well positioned, despite its difficulties at the moment, because it wants to change and is changing. It has the presence to reach out to customers. Our strategy is to work with established brands we believe will be winners in the online war."

BT has been under pressure to upgrade its services to online users in the face of competition from rivals such as Freeserve and AOL. Free serve offers British customers research facilities on a wide range of financial products, including a centre dedicated to individual savings accounts (Isas) run by Inter-Alliance.

Mr McGreevy said the BT site would offer a broader range of facilities than other ISP sites and even specialist financial intermediary sites such as iii.co.uk and Moneyextra because customers seeking personal advice would have access to Inter-Alliance's 1,350 advisers in 70 practices.

Next month an integrated wealth management tool, Mynetworth, and an offline centre will be built into the BT site. The companies said revenues from transactions would be shared.

webTitle: Abbey and Halifax set sights on turncoats

fields.headline: Abbey and Halifax set sights on turncoats
fields.standfirst:
Banking newcomers hope new ads and better rates will entice customers from the big four

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Banking newcomers hope new ads and better rates will entice customers from the big four.
fields.body:
It is banking folklore: Britons are more likely to divorce than move their bank account. It is also one tradition Halifax and Abbey National hope to consign to history through a dogged attempt to woo new customers.

The two banks have started 2001 with a bang. Their sights are set on the big four - NatWest, now part of Royal Bank of Scotland; Barclays; HSBC; and Lloyds TSB - which between them have a strangle hold over three-quarters of the country's current accounts.

Through massive advertising campaigns launched in recent days, Abbey and Halifax aim to prove that calling in the divorce lawyers is far more hassle than moving a current account.

They are even promising to save consumers money. Abbey, for instance, reckons it could save overdrawn customers £100 a year. David Fisher, general manager of banking and consumer finance at the Halifax, talks about eroding £1bn of profits made by the big four on their less competitive overdraft and interest rates.

While both Abbey and Halifax have set their sights on the big boys before, this year they mean business. They claim the timing of their campaigns is coincidence. Abbey says the move was planned long before its merger talks with Bank of Scotland were made public and the threat of a hostile bid by Lloyds TSB loomed. They agree that together they can have a greater impact.

Both Abbey and Halifax have promised potential customers they will be responsible for the burden of transferring direct debits and standing orders, traditionally regarded as one of the main deterrents to potential bank account moves. They promise to pick up the cost of any transfers. By this time next year, an industry-wide initiative will be in force, requiring all the financial institutions to agree to exchange information freely.

Andrew Pople, managing director of retail banking at Abbey National, said the bank's hotline has received a huge increase in inquiries about switching accounts, even though the campaign ran over the Christmas period. Mr Pople needs to open just over 300,000 new current accounts a year if he is to meet the bank's target for 4m current account customers by 2003. He says he is on track.

Halifax needs to achieve something similar. Mr Fisher said that applications for current accounts had risen by as much as 40% a month since the drive was announced in October, and before the recent advertising campaign began.

Halifax's campaign makes direct comparisons with the big four. Its television ads feature a singing bank manager who promises to make it easy to switch bank accounts and save money. Abbey National's promise of an interest-free overdraft for a year is plastered over poster boards across the country and boosted by comedian Alan Davies on television.

But despite their claims of savings for customers, some industry sources believe the odds are stacked against the two. Mr Pople of Abbey National admitted yesterday that just 2% of current account hold ers change banks each year, a minute proportion in comparison with the 30% of aspiring home owners who remortgage each year. This highly fluid mortgage market is where Halifax and Abbey have traditionally derived most of their business.

"It will grow," Mr Pople predicted. "But there is a long way to go before we even reach the divorce statistics."

Some industry sources are sceptical that Halifax's pledge to pay 4% interest on current accounts will be attractive, as customers with surplus cash are more likely to put it in a savings account.

Mr Pople believes that one gauge of Abbey's success will be any attempts by the big four to match its lower overdraft fees. Barclays said last night it had no immediate plans to change its tariffs and said it was continuing to attract new current account openings at the same rate as in past. Industry sources believe other major targets such as NatWest and HSBC are yet to feel the impact of the push by the two upstarts.

One leading analyst calculated that if the big four were to match the more attractive rates they could knock 5% off their combined profits of £7bn. He was cautious, however, about the impact of the Halifax and Abbey moves. "We're talking about a couple of pounds a year. Is it really going to be worth the hassle?" the analyst said.

And is the cost of advertising and lower rates worth it for Halifax and Abbey? They clearly think so, and hope that current account holders can be sold more bank products to generate more profit.

While this might be a cynical interpretation of the fight for current account business, the battle means customers can start to expect fewer charges, cheaper overdrafts and better interest rates. By showing customers that they can be better off financially and by doing the difficult part for them, Halifax and Abbey are hoping the big four's customers will start to file for divorce.

How the banks compare

Halifax

Interest: 4% Overdraft: 10%

Abbey National

Dropping charges for services such as banker's drafts.

Overdraft: interest free for one year, moving to 9.9%

Lloyds TSB

Interest: 0.1%

Overdraft: 18.8%

Barclays

Interest: 0.1%

Overdraft: 18.8%

NatWest

Interest: 0.1%

Overdraft: 18.38%

HSBC

Interest: 0.1%

Overdraft: 16.9%

Sources: Halifax, Abbey National

fields.headline: Job share executives 'outperform' full-timers
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Managers who cut down their hours or work from home are out-performing those who put in a traditional nine to five day, according to research.
fields.body:
Managers who cut down their hours or work from home are out-performing those who put in a traditional nine to five day, according to research.

A survey of almost 200 people in senior jobs with flexible working arrangements such as job-shares or reduced hours, found that 70% had a 30% higher level of output and scored higher on resilience, leadership and commitment than their traditional full time colleagues.

The study was presented at the British Psychological Society's occupational psychology conference in Winchester yesterday.

John Knell of the Industrial Society, which helped compile the research, said: "Employers find it hard to believe that flexible working among executives can work. And managers often regard mak ing such a request as career death. This research knocks both these misconceptions on the head."

The researchers said their findings "demolished" the view that job-sharing was inappropriate for senior and managerial jobs.

fields.headline: Zoot Women
fields.standfirst:
The End, London
****
fields.trailText:
The End, London
****
fields.body:
Whatever kind of act the name conjures up (some baggy- suited jazz homage?), Zoot Woman strike an instantly memorable pose. Three boys with blusher, smart casual white jackets and snazzy matching shoes, they're the latest signings to Wall Of Sound, indicative of club labels' growing fascination with 1980s stylings (Skint releasing Annie's Madonna-sampling single Greatest Hit being another recent instance).

Zoot Woman's bass player, Stuart Price, is actually a familiar Wall Of Sound star; even without the shocking pink locks, he's clearly recognisable as Jacques Lu Cont of 1980s evangelists Les Rhythmes Digitales. With extensive live experience under his belt, Price is the most confident onstage, delivering bass hooks with a devilish grin. Beside him, singer/guitarist Johnny Blake gradually relaxes into vocals laced with soul and, on numbers such as Holiday Home, reminiscent of Neil Tennant's clean, plaintive miserabilism. Johnny's brother Adam plays frosty keyboard riffs with a deadpan demeanour and boasts hair straight from a Studioline commercial, which is most pleasing to behold.

"They're calling us the new Hall and Oates," claims Johnny. It's certainly the kind of accolade that the band would cherish, but while their choruses contemplate cars, girls and consumerism, with an upcoming album entitled Living in a Magazine, these early twentysomethings are barely old enough to remember the era they fetishise.

A mainstream 1980s revival bodes well for Zoot Woman's crossover success but, crucially, they're not peddling an ironic nostalgia trip. Like Les Rhythmes Digitales, they combine snappy original compositions and studied retro influences with an ear for contemporary detail; their dreamy lyrics insist "It's a physical thing/I'm gonna change this city" but the pumped-up, perfectly danceable beats owe much to disco and house.

Unsurprisingly, they purvey a less polished sound than on record, and at points their drummer threatens to drown out the rest of the music, but any rough edges should quickly dissipate - in any case, a funky rawness is part of their appeal. Within a few songs, the trio progress from tentative debutantes to appearing coolly in their element as part of The End's alternative indie club night Trash.

While Trash tends to pack in devoted clubbers, they're by no means a complacent audience, but Zoot Woman deftly sway an assortment of glam cowboys, mods and 1980s flick chicks. And if a few spectators are initially ambivalent, no one seems able to resist the concluding number: a classy, guitar-heavy cover of Kraftwerk's The Model.

Zoot Woman are basically a figment of their own imagination; luckily, it's addictive make-believe, with songs that linger. This is pop with old-fashioned charisma and an effervescent 21st-century kick.

* Zoot Woman play the Monarch, London NW1 (020-7916 1049) on January 10.

fields.headline: Credit card fraud up by 60%
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Credit card fraud has jumped by almost 60% in the past year and annual losses are now around £300m, according to new figures which will increase pressure on the government to find a way to crack down the problem.
fields.body:
Credit card fraud has jumped by almost 60% in the past year and annual losses are now around £300m, according to new figures which will increase pressure on the government to find a way to crack down the problem.

Cloning - a scam involving the copying of card data which has stung thousands of people, including the shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe - accounted for a third of the total, said the Association for Payment Clearing Services (Apacs) yesterday. "That is pretty frightening considering it is a new type of crime that didn't exist until five years ago," said the group's spokesman, Richard Tyson-Davies.

He added that initial figures indicate total losses from credit and debit card fraud in 2000 are "somewhere approaching £300m" - more than double the 1998 figure of £135m. Within the new total, counterfeit fraud has jumped to around £90m.

Cloning, also known as "skimming", involves copying genuine data from the black magnetic strip on one card on to a blank card without the owner's knowledge. An unscrupulous shop assistant or restaurant waiter processing a transaction can quickly and easily record a card's data using a magnetic strip reader as small as a pager.

The sharp rise in card fraud prompted the Home Office to summon key figures from the industry to meetings last year to discuss ways of tackling the problem.

Proposals were put forward for the UK to adopt a system -already used in France - where people paying for goods with plastic simply type their four-digit Pin number into keypads at tills.

Consumers would no longer have to sign receipts under this new regime, which industry insiders expect to be given the official go-ahead within the next two or three months.

The final decision will have to be made by the banks and retailers, with input from the government. The new figures will strengthen the argument for them to move over quickly to the new system. One senior industry figure present at the last Home Office meeting in November said: "It is about how it is going to happen, not if."

In France, which abandoned signatures in favour of punching in Pin numbers a decade ago, the level of card fraud is less than 20% of that experienced in Britain.

The new system would coincide with the launch of a new generation of "smart" credit and debit cards containing computer chips. These new cards are more difficult to clone than traditional cards with a strip on the back.

Mr Tyson-Davies said the current cards were being exploited too easily by fraudsters, who recruit shop assistants, waiters and cashiers who regularly handle cards to copy people's plastic.

Card copying is often done using a hand-held device kept under the counter, out of sight of unsuspecting customers. Mr Tyson-Davies said the resulting counterfeit card can turn up anywhere else in the world at any time.

The National Criminal Intelligence Service has said that organised criminals may be using card crime as a compar atively low-risk way of raising revenue that later funds more violent crime.

It was revealed last month that Miss Widdecombe had fallen victim to card fraud. Barclaycard staff became suspicious about £2,500 spent in a single day at a pub in Shepherd's Bush, west London. It is thought her card was cloned and used for 42 false transactions over a 10-day period.

Credit card users are now being urged to keep a closer eye on their cards, and read their statements carefully, although banks are still liable for all losses from cloned cards.

Switching over to the French system and replacing all the plastic in circulation with the new chipped cards would cost a n estimated £1bn and would involve what one expert said was "a massive education and PR exercise".

Even if it is approved, the new system will probably not be in place until late 2003.

Proposals were put forward for the UK to adopt a system -already used in France - where people paying for goods with plastic simply type their four-digit Pin number into keypads at tills. Consumers would no longer have to sign receipts under this new regime, which industry insiders expect to be given the official go-ahead within the next two or three months. The final decision will have to be made by the banks and retailers, with input from the government. The new figures will strengthen the argument for them to move over quickly to the new system. One senior industry figure present at the last Home Office meeting in November said: "It is about how it is going to happen, not if." In France, which abandoned signatures in favour of punching in Pin numbers a decade ago, the level of card fraud is less than 20% of that experienced in Britain. The new system would coincide with the launch of a new generation of "smart" credit and debit cards containing computer chips. These new cards are more difficult to clone than traditional cards with a strip on the back. Mr Tyson-Davies said the current cards were being exploited too easily by fraudsters, who recruit shop assistants, waiters and cashiers who regularly handle cards to copy people's plastic. Card copying is often done using a hand-held device kept under the counter, out of sight of unsuspecting customers. Mr Tyson-Davies said the resulting counterfeit card can turn up anywhere else in the world at any time. The National Criminal Intelligence Service has said that organised criminals may be using card crime as a compar atively low-risk way of raising revenue that later funds more violent crime. It was revealed last month that Miss Widdecombe had fallen victim to card fraud. Barclaycard staff became suspicious about £2,500 spent in a single day at a pub in Shepherd's Bush, west London. It is thought her card was cloned and used for 42 false transactions over a 10-day period. Credit card users are now being urged to keep a closer eye on their cards, and read their statements carefully, although banks are still liable for all losses from cloned cards. Switching over to the French system and replacing all the plastic in circulation with the new chipped cards would cost a n estimated £1bn and would involve what one expert said was "a massive education and PR exercise". Even if it is approved, the new system will probably not be in place until late 2003.

fields.headline: Cross-dressing at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
As You Like It
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
As You Like It
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
If theatre is about suspending disbelief, then As You Like It is the art form at its purest. Shakespeare asks us to accept that after his noble lovers Orlando and Rosalind are separated by cruel relatives, then reunited in the Forest of Arden, Orlando would not recognise his sweetheart, now dressed as a man. And that a local woman would then fall for cross-dressing Rosalind.

One can only marvel at the goodwill demanded of the play's early audiences, for whom Rosalind was a boy playing a woman in turn passing herself off as a man. Add in the sudden conversion to righteousness of the work's villains, which brings to an end the lovers' rustication and enables them and a surrounding pack of fiances to finally marry, and this romantic comedy easily turns to farce.

So there is a heavy burden on the central character of Rosalind and her satellites Orlando and Celia (her cousin and companion). Director Gregory Doran adds to this at the Barbican by removing some of the frippery that irritated critics when this production opened in Stratford. The Pit's treeless forest - grey stage bordered by white walls, a few scattered cushions - now contains few distractions other than the opulent costumes. The play will work only if the upper-class trannie and her retinue can fill this bare space, if we find her both charming in her own self and amusing as an impostor.

Doran is blessed in Alexandra Gilbreath, his husky-voiced Rosalind, never afraid of going over the top as first a smitten ninny, then a teasing minx. The whole psychology of the part is suspect - would a lovestruck woman really wait so long before revealing her identity? But Gilbreath's performance sweeps all objections before it. She gets fine support from Nancy Carroll as Celia, although Anthony Howell brings little colour to the insipid role of Orlando.

The rest of the production is less satisfying, as Shakespeare's gentle critique of the pastoral myth loses direction in a fog of Merry Men-style scenes and a number of flashy-trashy gimmicks, such as a dodgy priest's collapsible altar. More You'll Like Bits than As You Like It.

•Until February 7. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Help me with my boss from hell

fields.headline: Help me with my boss from hell
fields.trailText: 4 January: I'm currently going through lots of problems at work regarding my manager. She is a serial bully - she drove a previous victim out of the company.
fields.body:
The problem

I'm currently going through lots of problems at work regarding my manager. She is a serial bully - she drove a previous victim out of the company.

My solicitor knows about the problem. The company I work for said they needed to know his name so I told them and on that very day I received a threatening phone call. He explained that he was a friend of my 'manager' and that if I use a solicitor he would personally break my life up.

At the moment I just want everything to go away. I am suffering from a lack of sleep and constantly worry about my job.

The solution

What an absolute nightmare. You really do have the boss from hell and are doing everything possible to stand up to her. Other than encouraging you to be strong enough to continue your fight, I have a couple more suggestions:


 First of all, do tell your solicitor about the threats you received. Keep detailed notes of them, including any distinguishing features of the voice and what was said. You should also tell your company about the threats.


 Start taking action to tape any such future calls. Hopefully, you will not receive any more, but if you can borrow a Dictaphone (or persuade your company to purchase phone-recording equipment) then you can record any future threats. You should inform the caller that their call is being recorded.


 I wonder if you can trace the person that left before you because of this bully in the company? This person could be very useful if they are prepared to stand up now to the bully. See what your solicitor says.


 Get support from the UK National Workplace Bullying Advice Line (01235 212286) or visit their Internet site Bully Online at: www.successunlimited.co.uk


 The Institute of Management have a guide, Dealing with Bullying at Work In a Week (Hodder & Stoughton, £6.99) which is also well worth a look.

Remember that (a) there is support out there and that (b) this nightmare will pass. It might be worth reading a self-help book or two on coping with worrying - this is a very difficult time for you, but you can find the strength to cope and get through it. Self-help books won't make the problem go away, but they can help you stop losing sleep over it. Good luck.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: Davy Graham
fields.body:
When Davy Graham first emerged on the London club circuit in the late 1950s, he was regarded as an eclectic guitar genius with one major problem: he baffled his audiences. Here was a man who didn't just play blues and jazz, traditional folk songs and classical styles, but was also fascinated by the music of north Africa, India and all points between.

Every guitar picker in town learned to play his song Anji (recorded by Simon and Garfunkel and still part of the Bert Jansch repertoire) but no one could follow his wild musical excursions around the globe.

In retrospect, he can be seen not just as one of the key figures in the British folk-blues movement, but as one of the earliest exponents of world music. He loved travelling and studying different styles and simply ignored musical boundaries.

With acoustic music back in fashion, the time is surely right for the rediscovery of Graham. He may have celebrated his 60th birthday last year, but with this appearance in that cramped but suitably intimate West End folk cellar, the 12 Bar Club, he proved that he's still in remarkably good form, in excellent humour and as unpredictable as ever.

Backed by bass guitarist Roger Bunn (who played with him on his 1976 album All That Moody) he came on wearing a purple tie, a hat, glasses and layers of sweaters. It was not the standard guitar hero image, but then this was not a standard guitar hero show.

He began in jovial, technically low-key fashion, strumming first through the slinky 1930s jazz drug tune If You're a Viper, and then Randy Newman's Yellow Man, before branching out for some blues and jazz solos. Then he swung off into a cheerful country hoe-down to end his first set, before re-emerging with a delicate, finely performed treatment of the Billie Holiday ballad God Bless the Child.

He followed this with a lengthy solo instrumental section in which he veered from Balkan dance tunes to echoes of Arabic styles, followed by "one from Armenia". Some of the crowd looked as baffled as Graham's audiences had back in the 1960s. He ended, to his bass player's obvious surprise, with a spirited version of Down and Out. "I haven't heard you play that since 1958," said Bunn.

So is Graham about to be discovered by a wider audience, as he most certainly deserves? Well, many of his classic, long-deleted old albums have been reissued at last and, like Jansch, he has acquired a new, far younger musical following. The opening set at the 12 Bar was provided by Matt Deighton, known to pop audiences for his guitar work with Paul Weller and on occasions Oasis, but acquiring a growing reputation for his solo acoustic guitar work and cool, gently introspective folk-soul songs such as Isolation.

Once he came off stage he was down at the front, watching and recording Graham's every move.

fields.headline: Carpetbaggers target Chelsea
fields.trailText: Carpetbaggers chasing windfalls will find out in mid-January if they have won the right for a vote over whether the Chelsea building society should convert to a bank.
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers chasing windfalls will find out in mid-January if they have won the right for a vote over whether the Chelsea building society should convert to a bank.

A spokesman for the Gloucestershire-based building society confirmed that one of its savers, Andy Naughton-Doe, had delivered a petition bearing 1,000 names in favour of demutualisation.

"We need to check that at least 500 of these have held £100 or more in an account for over two years and that this document falls within our rules for a vote," said the spokesman.

He added the society remained staunchly pro-mutual: "The fact we donÕt have to pay dividends means we can pay better rates. We believe we offer better deals in many cases than the banks."

But, it looks at though the vote will go ahead and that Chelsea will be under pressure to demutualise. If more than 50% of members vote in favour of windfalls, the conversion will be guaranteed.

Chelsea is the UKÕs seventh largest building society and has 450,000 members and assets of £5bn. While some carpetbaggers are anticipating windfalls of £1,000 each if they win the vote, the society has said these would only be about £500.

In March, Chelsea changed its rules stating that 10% of conversion assets would be given to charity and it has also raised the minimum amount needed to open an account to £2,500.

Naughton-Doe has denied he is a carpetbagger and says he is acting on the interests of others. He has said he will give any payout he receives to charity. He has also launched a website, where he thanks fellow savers for their support and promises regular updates.

Nationwide is facing similar pressures to Chelsea and could also face a conversion vote in July this year when it holds its annual general meeting.

This is being forced by Stephen Major, a plumber from Northern Ireland, who was responsible for prompting the Bradford & Bingley bank conversion. But, when this did convert, many carpetbaggers were disappointed to receive shares worth only around £600.

Major has said if he is successful he will challenge NationwideÕs policy of insisting new members had to sign away rights to any future windfalls.

He is understood to be trying to be elected to the Nationwide board, although a spokesman for the society said this was by no means definite.

A spokesman for Nationwide said that no application had been received from Mr Major. "The vote for new members to the board takes place in July and we have not heard from this person other than reading his comment about his intention. We remain committed to mutuality

Other likely conversions tipped by the carpetbaggers are Skipton and Dunfermline building societies. They have both changed their rules requiring new customers to donate any windfalls to charity.

In the wake of carpetbagging, many societies have closed their doors to savers who are not local and often insist that rights to any future windfalls, often for at least five years, be signed away.

 The carpetbaggers' website, lists all the UKÕs building societies and their current status for accepting new savers.

fields.headline: All hail the new Hall and Oates
fields.standfirst:
In the Public Eye
Burrell Collection, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
In the Public Eye
Burrell Collection, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
With tax bills looming for the self-employed, this may not be the best time of year for an exhibition brought to us, even indirectly, by the Inland Revenue. The tax exemption scheme for art, which has been in place since 1896, was set up to discourage the sale of important works to overseas buyers. Under certain conditions, such as an undertaking to allow the public some access, inheritance tax relating to the work will be waived.

There are now 58,000 works under the scheme; this exhibition is a selection made by Sotheby's of those in Scotland, Northumbria and Cumbria.

Though the quality of work is much more even here, there is a touch of the Antiques Roadshow or an auction preview to the proceedings. Paintings dominate, but there are also cases full of ceramics and jewellery, plus some rather grand furniture.

Gaudy peacock ornaments jostle with a pair of spectacles worn by Sir Walter Scott; an Italian carriage seat competes for our attention with a travelling backgammon set used by Mary Queen of Scots. With nothing linking them together except their tax status, these various objects may have historical importance but they muddle and clutter the exhibition.

The paintings are of a different calibre, and the chance to see works by Henry Raeburn, John Lavery and Allan Ramsay not normally on public view does give the exhibition a compelling core. The show is organised chronologically, and there is the now familiar shock in any survey of Scottish art when you turn into the 20th-century room and the work of the Colourists jumps out.

Highlights in this show include two paintings by Caddell - Nude Reflected in a Mirror, a languidly lovely soft smudge of composition, and, in sharp contrast, the almost brash intensity of The Rose.

But it's hard to switch off from the fiscal raison d'etre to this impressively swanky selection. In a city struggling to maintain its public galleries, including the rather dog-eared Burrell and sadly dwindling exhibition programme after giddy, misguided spending a decade ago, it's tough to marvel at these privately owned treasures.

Art and money: they are friends of long standing, of course. But rarely has an exhibition made that point so emphatically.

* Until February 4. Details: 0141-287 2550.
